formed_review_text: Pinstripes catered our engagement party this past weekend and did a great job.we commented on how this would be an ideal date spot.shoes and bowling balls were conveniently located right by our lanes.i opted for the stuffed mushrooms and the tenderloin sliders.i don't think it was worth the price we paid for.both were very delicious, especially the short ribs.i was lucky enough to attend the grand opening, and folks, you're in for a treat!! even with masses of people, the site was ready to serve! all the food was phenomenal- my favorites were the italian jambalaya, chicken parmesan slider and all of their amazing desserts! (ok, the wine wasn't bad either)this pinstripes has two huge levels- the top is darker and more sexy, while the lower level had white lights and felt more romantic..i made a reservation for a group of 15 a few weeks beforehand over the phone although their online reservation system said it was unavailable.really enjoyed it here! came to dinner with a large group of kids and adults all part of my family in chicago for a wedding.

I'm truly glad the majority of chicagoans don't know about it, because it's easy to get in! and in close proximity to lagunitas, so if they have a giant line, the trip south is not a total loss.how did i get pony?now, i know this has nothing to do with food which wasn't all that great either!!! i didn't leave this place thinking oh yeah i can't wait to go back!!!i had fun as always with my friends but i trully don't see why some people think the food is so great at this place.came here to celebrate a friend's birthday and i was surprised how jam packed it was.its not over priced, its consistent, and best of all it's just sooooooooooooo yummy! don't miss pasta vino italia festa in the summer with bacchanalia makes their famous sangria!..i had not tried bacchanalia yet and since it had been on my list for awhile to try- it popped into my head when i had a craving for some good italian food.this kind of carelessness and disrespect toward customers drives me bonkers.well i was definitely disappointed after reading the rave reviews.they serve up some exceptional pasta here.this place has been zagat rated as fuck for years, so there's a touch of resting on laurels here, but if you've got 50 or 75 bucks to blow for a date, i'd recommend this place for sure.

We could have cooked at home instead.i can't believe i waited so long to eat here.a the greatest mouth orgasm that i've had in a while.my sister and i came here one evening to try out their famous belly dog.pretty good..my fries came out white hot, very very good.the belly dog was topped with a slaw with korean flavors and a spicy mayo with a pita like bread instead of a bun.the beer menu is good the toppings were good and the lemonade was great.i got the pork meatball sandwich, which ended up feeling like a bit of a carb overload, because it's a big fluffy bun, with pork meatballs, and then a lot of noodles.

Beer selection was solid.definitely worth a try if you're in the area!.the guacamole was delicious and the marg was good.gave us a breakdown of what's what from wines, beers, and food.however, you can't really complain about getting a creative burger, a beer, a shot of bourbon and fries for 15 bucks.i would pass on coming here a second time though.i'll definitely be back to pl-zen when i'm in the area (which, sadly, isn't frequently..everyone's always really nice, but man, this place is slow.

Cheese, cheese.the mushrooms are arranged around a soft egg and i swear it was like the king of all mushrooms-- that good!service here is fantastic! it certainly helped that there weren't too many people here but our server was super knowledgeable and even helped prepare a dessert chocolate mousse on bread with a candle on top.yumyes to every food item thank you.been wanting to go to this place for a while.i know a bit about wine, but certainly not enough, and now i know more.i will enjoy it, but i will order 'smarter' next time.i should have known-- the evidence is everywhere-- thoughtful, warm, perfect.it was fairly empty at 9pm on a thursday.psshhhh.but honestly,  the food was really good.

My friends got a coffee to go from here and said it was decent..the coffee is very good.the borscht was phenomenal and full of flavor which comes with a few tasty rolls on the side..great little ukranian diner..it can get pretty busy for them, worth the wait.served with delicious brioche rolls.not as much of a fan of the omelet, which as someone else mentioned was more greasy than fluffy (maybe cooked a bit too much?).

In an indian style).the sweet potato fries were redeeming but really, how do you screw those up?the workers also somehow managed to make me feel rushed for my order even though the restaurant was empty.got takeaway about 20 minutes before close - their rice supply had been exhausted for the day, so i opted to order just the chicken tikka and sauce sans the wrap or salad.stop by for lunch before my trip back  to boston..the ordering and prep works pretty similar to a chipotle line, where you can choose between a wrap or salad bowl and then pick from a variety of traditional indian fillings.i don't think i would go back.won't come again unless the salt issue is solved.i also got to try their samosas which are perfectly sized and tasty.i had (1) paneer wrap accompanied by a mango lassi so that filled me up.

We ordered the guac which came with just the right amount of chips.we got seated at a prime booth area with a picture of us in front of the yes sign picture, and our waitress was just as sweet as can be.walking into summer house feels like you're leaving chicago and entering california.we were so pleased with the food.on a recommendation from a friend who lives in the city, my wife and i ate lunch here a few weeks ago, and we were absolutely pleased.perfect brunch spot in the city!we went for lunch and it was the cutest little place ever! luckily, there was no blizzard out but if there was one, i would appreciate this establishment even more so due to its beach-y interior.the service - the servers have always been really professional and i've honestly never had any issues.my friends love this place so needless to say i'll be back!  hoping for better service from restaurant and cooking staff.in particular because you can get it on an english muffin (if that is your thing).when you walk in the door it's slightly confusing, there's a bakery counter in front between the restaurant and the stella bar, and two host stands for each.

There's something about korean tacos that are so satisfying.i came here around lunchtime on a saturday and there was plenty of space to sit.got the bibimbap and it was delicious! the service could be a little friendlier, but overall i'd recommend this spot to others!.great for lunch and dinner.the tortilla was so soft!.food was amazing..absolutely the best tasting korean fried chicken drumlet in the city.the bibimbap in a hot stone bowl is always good.but really, when i think of this spot, i think of a quick, delicious bite.

For our visit- my friend was in heaven as they had old fashioneds in the cask.i have to admit that when i went, it was after a volleyball game and i was all gross so walking into this place was a little embarrassing.i like to fancy myself a bloody mary connoisseur and the mp bloody rates pretty high on my list.we were immediately greeted by a really nice hostess (who i am pretty sure was the owner).if you're unsure about what to get though, there are a number of themed flights as well as ones for bourbons and single malt scotches(!).we arrived just before the kitchen closed and didn't want to feel rushed into ordering a dessert or any other food, so we stuck with drinks only.every creamy bite of polenta was complimented by a tangy bite of salad and tomato reduction.from craft brews to whiskey flights to cask-aged cocktails, you can tell by the presentation that they pay very close attention to detail here at the monkey's paw.my friend i came with was pleased with the options of flights of scotch to try!.this was fine, as we got great service.

Very fresh.wanted something to eat on my way to work.you are in for a treat!.50 and comes packed with said fruit and other goodness.i am sure if it was hot, it will be a whole different story.la bomba really is.it's all fried.

The good: lots of interesting drinks and the food is great.the goat cheese counteracted any spiciness from the peppers and the bacon gave it a smoky flavor...love this place.it's basically a large bar space without a 'restaurant' area, per se.my boyfriend and i grabbed a table and immediately started paging through the menu.in my opinion however the pizza isn't fantastic..just an ok experience, the service was not that great, several people who had arrived after us got served before us, there was a pretty good beer selection, we ordered fries as an appetizer but it didn't get there until after the pizza had come.

That's for fast food establishments.count on staple diner food, that quintessential '50s aesthetic, and quick service.the food is what you'd expect from a 24hr place and so are the shenanigans.you nod at the sober ones as you sip your hot coffee and they drink their orange juice while watching their friends race yours to the bathroom.decor - i really liked the decor inside the restaurant, pretty neat! :)parking - plenty of parking if you park near the whole foods and just walk down to the restaurant..as for the food it was ok not great.this place gets a three stars just by being open all night.food is still great, service is great, but the late night crowd has shifted from a quiet, potentially romantic setting to a loud, ghetto environment requiring security.the place was dirty but the food was fine for the price!.

Would love to be back to try some of the other stuff on the menu!.the pork cutlet was thin, but well flavored.my cemita was really great! the chicken was flavorful and i really liked the concept but the bread was just a bit dry.i am pretty sure i will be back to try the cemitas.this is not your mama's torta, these are huge with a lot of meat and cheese.definitely enjoyed this high-end little fast food establishment.i don't think there is any going wrong with anything you order at this place.i feel that they are putting less meat and less ingredients in the cemitas at this new location.it was the perfect fast casual lunch we were looking for..

The food at this chinatown restaurant, & selection on menu is really worth 5 stars..the beef pancake seemed like a larger fried spring-roll, was okay but didn't rock my world like the rest of the food.one of my favorite go-to restaurants in chinatown.when you place orders online it costs less!!.but hey that's the only reason i knocked them down 1 star.another favorite is the pork flapjack rolls.i was not into it at all.people definitely come here just for the xiao long baos.i actually went past the restaurant three times.

Come here if you like lingering at the table and don't like being rushed..if i lived nearby and wanted a cheap quick date spot, i might use this, but i honestly doubt i'll ever be back.so when i crave pizza, but don't want deep dish or even thin crust from other pizza places and want a "healthier" if not "guilt free" option, pizzeria del mercato is my absolute favorite..our table was ready when we got there.i didn't think it was domed long enough though.i was here with one other person.the crust is nice and toothsome and the ingredients are super fresh.so, the pizza is good.

My bowl of ramen was good but wasn't anything special in my books.overall a great ramen spot in river north.things that i thought could be better - the chashu pork slices, they were sliced a little too thick for my liking.it didn't do it for me :(if i had just stop at the duck fat fried chicken, this would be a 4 star review.we ordered a wide variety of options and my favorite is the green tea cream puff! like a pillow of taste bud delight.the tunes are top 40s (though not the super obnoxious tracks).for the noodles, i tried the tan tan ramen.definitely recommend! if i were to go back, i would order the duck fat fried chicken.good ramen! not sure about other dishes though.not the best ramen, and because of the location, not the best prices either.

Located in the busy division and clark, this place gets a lot of traffic as it is also nestled with local shops and bars.not.both are a large portion for one person.late night + dranks = extra yummy eats..and don't let that quantity sales food you..i just stopped in for a late night fix and was met with exceptional customer service.+ good quality meats.parking isn't too bad around this area but if you go at night, there are always lots of drunk people walking around since there are lots of bars around this area.

I personally love the heat so it was no issue.i always stop by here when i'm in town for a couple vegetarian chicago dogs.i paid the extra dollar to get the polish sausage and picked my own toppings! they also have the classic chicago dog as well.it was perfect eating it on the steps of the field museum while admiring the skyline and the lake.they come stacked with mustard, relish, onions and a pickle spear.i think it's cash only, so make sure you have cash!.the first time it was perfect, but the second time the bun got soggy.i absolutely love this family and their food..i'm literally salivating as i write this thinking about how delicious this hotdog was.

Also, they sometimes tend to forget my sauce, napkins and fork even though they're not busy.i quickly learned i have to ask for my tacos with onions and cilantro, which annoys my snobby tendencies, but i gotta pick my battles you know?on the days i'm feeling uber lazy and not wanting to cook, chavas is a good option for food delivery.i also asked to be called on my cell so i could come down and my landlord was awoken to pounding at the front door from the driver.this was a gem as my friends and i rented an airbnb across the street.ran across this place off yelp and it was a hit.so if the weather's nice just take it to go, grab a 6 pack of coronas at the corner liqour store on western and picnic your culo in the park on grand avenue 2 blocks west past western ave.and every time i'm here, their horchata is my drink of choice.ps- the place isn't pretty but boy, is it good.too hung over to move? broke from a long weekend? need mexican food to make a quick recovery? this is your spot..

I ordered the venison, which turned out to be delicious.we all stared at this dish wondering how to share it since there were only 3 brussel sprouts cut up.the alligator legs seemed to be more of a novelty than a real dish, and although we enjoyed the brisket (+those sweetbreads!) it was just such a small dish.our second course included pulled boar and rueben sandwiches..it was a very uncomfortable situation and i don't recommend using the bathroom.the frontier did an outstanding job! everything we had discussed was followed to a t! working with jen was great! they did everything they could to make all of the guests happy, and checked in with me often to make sure everything was going as planned! the food was great! - we did the large format menu (whole pigs) with all the sides - which were delicious.any bartender that can whip me up a special lions tail is a winner in my book! the fire up front really adds to the cozy ambiance and makes you want to stay a while.- duck tacos:  comes in 3.great space and awesome patio.

Where has this place been my whole life!!! omg! this place is amazing! the service is great! the food is even better!!!! this is a must for those that love modern mexican cuisine!!! delicious!!!! we will be back!!!..com/biz_photos/el-m…).stopped in for an early dinner and margaritas on monday and had a good experience.was old.ok.so the salsa we started with was amazing.we opted to stick with the chips and salsa till our dinner hit the table.the restaurant was very empty on a saturday night, and the bad part is should not be.i highly recommend the carne asada.

Once again, delicate and flavorful with each bite and may i add a generous portion for restaurant week and in general.fantastic cocktails, need to come back for wine to truly taste the region!.the octopus did not have a rubbery texture to it.well since they open 12 days ago.they are dry and not very appealing.street parking has always been easy to find in this area (but then again we tend to eat early, like senior-discount early)..plus steering us away from the carne crude was also a ding.yes the concept is just your basic noodles with meat sauce, but it is done so well! the pasta is so fresh and the ragu is fantastic.

All the tacos here are under $3 and they are some of the meatiest and most packed i've ever had.although they were not big, they were full of nice chunks of quality meat with red cabbage, avocado, cilantro, sour cream, and beans..i finally got in the store this saturday and had the carne burrito.i love this place! i'm not in the area but would gladly drive out here for their steak breakfast breakfast tacos any day.i love that.decent tacos and clean establishment.they offer several aguas frescas, as well as fresh tortilla chips with some killer good salsas.byob..

My favorite parts were that they provided props and even taught you a few dance moves.great concept!  staff was extremely friendly and food was pretty good..it was a really great show and the performers/waiters are so nice.the staff wear prohibition era duds which adds to the ambiance of the place.so i'm a sucker for dinner shows and this one has been by far my favorite one, partly because i was so involved in the fun there were moments during dinner i was legitimately afraid i was going to be arrested for having hooch!it's pretty obvious the staff here loves what they do and are quite good at it.3.also had a huge dessert table too.the staff was fun and friendly.

99) and these were beyond good.i really respect the guys who work here because they work quickly and treat their customers well.friends, this might be the best cubano in the city.when did it switch..everything was delicious to the last bite.i always like it when the guy making everything comes out to ask how everything is, adds a nice personal touch and shows that a place like torta haus really cares what their customers think!the food itself is also very good, great spot for a relaxed dinner or lunch.i wanted to love this place like the other yelpers did, but i just didn't.free parking across the street, otherwise paybox on the street of the place.the only downside is service is slow -- we waited ~20 minutes for our food, which is somewhat long for an order-at-the-counter place.

Great ride..green and yellow zucchini thinly sliced submerged in olive oil, herbs and cheese.the mushroom omelette was delicious, just a little too salty.the texture was a bit grainier than the best pot de cremes, but i assume that is an occupational hazard of coffee grounds.very tasty.the big-league brunch items that we ordered and shared were smoked pecan french toast and a fish plate.when the server returned and was like "i ran these two cards i found on the table" without even asking.i saw the veggie dagwood on the lunch menu.get baked goods, great expresso coffee, and excellent brunch.

The in house pancetta was very smoky..the pancakes were a good sized portion, but a wee bit dry.the food is very good, but it can be a bit on the pricey side..food was okay, nothing amazing.definitely worth giving a try!.there are sunny areas (when the weather cooperates) and shady areas and the whole space is quite large.ordering at the counter was easy, menu sounded appetizing, staff was pleasant, and the patio was huge and inviting.this sure is a cute place to come with my girlfriend ;).

I order a taco that says it comes with sour creamno sour cream and no tomatostaff seemed annoyed when i walked in at 8:30 to order to-goi've lived here for four years and i believe this is the fourth place in this space..just tried salsa picante for the first time this week..one bite, and i was convinced i'd be back.lol, an odd request for a mexican establishment (i know), but she was ever-so pleased to meet my requests.

And ended up cancelling a second reservation of each because i wasn't very into the food.as this restaurant is part of a larger group with much experience, i expected that reservations would have been honored in a timely manner.it has influences of chinese cuisine with a modern twist.so many umami flavors going on here.i know i've mentioned flavor 100 time already, but flavor.rest assured that this won't affect you at all if you are not very chinese.while i would say i probably prefer the food at little goat and girl and the goat, i would still absolutely come back here for a special occasion or nice dinner.flavored weren't as robust as everything else but it was crispy & good portion.e.the inside was velvety while the outside was crunchy.
The omelette was massive and tasted super fresh.

The chips were thick and different and i liked it.the tortillas are green which i'm assuming have spinach in them.the servers are really superb."  the service was pleasant and relatively quick, and the dining area is decorated by a colorful mural of the "bean" - the landmark cloud gate sculpture of millennium park.my favorite burger was the t&b burger with grilled onions, guac, and shrimp.inside sits a piece of shrimp and guac, this tiny burger is incredibly quite filling.i got the t&b burger with a beef rather than bison patty and substituted sweet potato fries for the side.our waitress, monica, was so sweet, personable and friendly and really made our dinner a wonderful experience..the bathrooms were super clean as well which was an awesome surprise.

And the food proved law #346 overwhelmingly.only points i would knock off is that a lot of the stuff didn't set well with my palate (lot of fried greasy mystery meat) but thats just a personal preference.it still has the grandma's home feeling, but now it feels more like grandma is on her deathbed trying to cook and run a business.they serve an outstanding ukrainian borscht here, pre-mixed with sour cream and full of tender sliced cabbage and chunks of potato.second time, it's also 11.i brought this up to the waiter, and after talking to the manager, he apologized for their mistake and allowed us to stay.having a ukrainian friend with us to point us in the right direction was definitely helpful.i loaded my plate with a ton of blood sausage and other questional meats.the cold/salad area had pickled cabbage with caraway seeds (this was not kraut), puréed beets with horseradish, creamy tomato and cucumber salad, an amazingly delicious potato salad with cubed ham and peas, chopped oranges and watermelon, and assorted cake slices..

It was just what i expected: cheap, tasty, and fast.working in the neighborhood that i do has put me in close proximity to so many places to have a good lunch.we live close to this place and thought we would try it out vs our go to place.it gets real low with a large menu full of super cheap food and backs it up with everything from gyros to vegetarian fare to even some fairly healthy items..the outdoor patio was jam packed full of people.a weekday at 1030 am, the place wasn't busy, why cheap out on one of your signature dishes?.we order from koko's quite often and haven't been disappointed! we use grubhub and delivery is super fast and the food is hot and fresh out the kitchen.the falafel i ordered yesterday was straight from the freezer and i saw them dump it into the deep fryer..
So good.

Prices are reasonable but, sigh, it's cash only.i wasn't sure what to expect when we walked into grandma j's, but i was pleasantly surprised by the eclectic nature of the place.it still wasn't great tea, but a for effort.grandma j is clearly trying to fatten us (and the rest of chicago up) because there's not many healthy options on the menu.the good- the bacon was absolutely fantastic.i am dreaming about it.also it's not cheap.this is somewhat of a mixed review.there are just six small tables that would each hold either two or four people, two tables for up to six people, and a small bar-like counter that holds a total four people.i had the poached hamboldt.

But frankly, you should just bump whatever you need to do because that jerk chicken wrap deserves priority.great food, great staff.there were pieces of bones and gristle and fat??(where the hell did the fat comefrom on that turkey?) and i actually wound up throwing most of it away.

Their ice teas are so amazing, when i was done, i wanted more!  they are darker than most so it's not overly sweet and diluted with milk.but it's going to happen regardless because the food is so damned good here.so good!! stopped by for lunch this afternoon after rave reviews from a coworker and i was not disappointed.if you've decided that you're not a fan of thai food, you should seriously consider giving jj thai a shot.for our entree, we both had some variation of noodles and bbq pork with a side of soup.)i would definitely go rice dish over noodle dish next time i'm here.but if you're open to an adventure (particularly if you're open to spicy food), this is your place!it's pretty small so you may have a bit of a wait, but it's well worth it! or you can call ahead to make reservations.byob! we ordered the chicken balls as an appetizer and i ordered the papaya salad (crispy, fresh and not overly spicy) while the boy ordered stir fry seafood with egg.this place is also super close to home!  my memory is failing me on the other items we've tried, but one that i do remember is the fried chicken wings!  delicious.the sweet/sour sauce that comes with it is so good.

I like both exterior and interior.located between cc ferns and the clipper, spinning j provides an all ages appropriate spot for pie, coffee, and soda jerk creations (malts and egg creams).staff was friendly and helpful and clearly don't mind if you camp out for several hours to work using the free wifi.all of that said, i need to come back and try the high-end sodas to pass final-final judgment.i was going to go by cc ferns (5 stars too) but wanted a breakfast sandwich.glad this place is in my hood!.and, of course, all with a crunchy crust.happy one year anniversary spinning j bakery and soda fountain! i love ordering the fresh baked pies at spinning j with the blueberry being my favorite.everything was fantastic! took home some biscuits, which were delicious.the whole menu is so appealing:  sodas, milkshakes, gelato, pie, and more.

When we asked her to repeat it (she rushed through and it was loud), she caught an attitude and rushed through it again.i will most likely return and when that time comes, i will order two sides as opposed to one.can't wait to go back! i would say to try other items but i know i'll be getting the chicken and waffles again.there are a bunch of small tables, two counters you can post up to, and lots and lots of chickens haha.highly recommend and i'd actually like to go to the restaurant one day and have some lunch..i have visited the london location and you would never find a place like this at their location.the waffle was a little on the tough side but nothing a little of that egg gravy couldn't take care of.most of the entrees had good flavor, but it was nothing too great or special.i ran 5k the next day at the gym to shed off some guilt.

They don't take credit cards, which is a pain, and the staff isn't overly friendly (but it's okay - they are quite busy during the lunch rush).maybe a nice movie after that.enough for a monster sandwich and then leftovers for dinner.i will be back!.nothing here is gourmet or exotic but sometimes all you want to do is fill up your belly.service: don't care.usually, there's a special or two that will be tasty and fairly cheap (e.the new one is the chopped chicken on a bun and just plain different set of  toppings and flavor profile.definitely worth another visit, maybe the sandwiches next time.i like it better than chipotle because they don't lather on sour cream - also ask for jalapenos in your burrito.

The lentils and sauce really added a great variety of textures and flavors.a little pricey, since we dropped $60 for (very high-end) fast food, but we enjoyed the experience.get the plin.plin--we got the smaller sized order, which is more than enough to share among 2 people or feed one person if you're having something else too.not sure i'll hurry back, but i wouldn't rule it out.tip: you can get animale food via caviar delivery.came with thin slices of carrots that were kind of dry and green onions.they have replaced the old baccos and instead came in heavy handed in the fast casual atmosphere.they also do a great job with the accompanying mushrooms, onions, shallots.i was lured in by their truffle burger special.
Best quesadillas that i have ever eaten..i came in for the lunch period and ordered a taco salad, which was quite cheap and filling.gotta love it!.they are back and stronger than ever.

The chicken parmesan was very good, but the highlight was their tomato sauce..called 'rocket' in germany, it just brings back so many happy memories of my travels.great neighborhood italian.it's a nice interior, classy but not overly dressy.we each started with a glass of red wine while we looked over the menu; a napa cabernet for her, and a lodi zinfandel for me.we arrived late on a sunday, table for 5, all of us showing up at different times.i found the restaurant to be overcrowded and too loud.cheap in a relationship management sort of way.they're also unbelievably accommodating with minor changes, like switching out the spicy marinara for something mild or adding sausage to a pasta dish.

Yup, i'll do it.i also loved the al pastor taco; the meat was beautifully seasoned without being overly salty.a gem in the city that only few venture to.we ordered the horchata to drink and oh my goodness was that amazing!! probably some of the best horchata i have ever had, and they make it right there! we ordered 4 types of tacos: el pastor, carne asada, chorizo and the flank steak.

We put it on everything...mind you, all of my friends are korean and they have never tried puerto rican food before..and at least for your first time there, the steak jibaritos is a must eat.we also got the goat stew mixtas with yellow rice and pigeon peas.their beef stew, served with potatoes and rice was filling and was better than i expected.looking for cuban food but this came up in the list.ohh man.

I hope three stars doesn't come across as a harsh or negative review.i do know that they were very tasty and very generous in proportion (almost a dish that could be shared if you weren't super hungry--sharing might be the way to go on this menu anyways).that was a dish i did not care for it was pretty tasteless.that braised pork shoulder in that chile broth and avocado and radishes and cilantro--the flavors were all so crisp and fresh and they all melted together in your mouth.again - all the ingredients together were good, but some of the execution was off.i really like tje savory broth that the meal was in along with veggies but there was way too many mushrooms.my first..adds the perfect kick.i don't know, i don't think this place is really for group dinners but if you want to impress your date with potent drinks and horchata pie.

Fat johnnie's attains low-end, eat-on-the-sidewalk perfection..drove to the location with the help of the directions feature inside of yelp.what the place lacks in aesthetics, it makes up for in the dog.neighborhood seemed fine with the popeye's next door..go fat at johnnie's!cash only.hot dogs and tamales and chips and soda, all of which is pretty cheap and pretty damn tasty, especially the chili dog i took down a few days ago with a bag of jay's bbq chips and a root beer..i had a couple of dogs, both the mighty dog (minus the chilli) and a regular dog with everything (including the tasty cucumber spiced with celery salt).

The go to place for drunk food in bridgeport, it's super cheap and you get a lot for your money, ive had the cheeseburger, hot dog, fries, chicken nuggets and the mother in law (chili on a tamale) all were great and hit the spot, always look forward to going..we even gave it a try another time and our second experience is not good either.highly recommended for hotdogs!..breaded steak - i thought this was more tender than rico's, but think it needed some sweet pepper or something to give it that extra kick...

For some, the burger experience at this fine establishment may be overwhelming.the bun was perfectly baked and the steak fries were amazing.t and ending up in "butcher & the burger" in lincoln park, less than one (1)-block west from cta armitage brown/purple line station.this is crazy!!!!!the burgers weren't even that big.no one will go hungry here..interesting that you have the option to choose buns (croissant, split top, or pretzel), there are different seasoning options (i went with the chicago blend), and grass-fed is an option.i think that speaks wonders about how tasty this food is.overall, a fantastic vibe with solid food, but prices were a little too steep for me to see myself coming again and again.my classic response to enormous choice is to be paralyzed with fear of screwing it up and then i end up with something pretty straightforward as a result.

Excellent cuban coffee!..yes i have had the cubano sandwich (mostly because it is one of my favorite sammiches) and yes obviously it is amazing..yum..i waited for 20+ minutes for two coffees and my shake.before you go: i recommend the masitas de puerco appetizer..yes, get them.only about 10 seats inside.

I was also told that there is a sunday brunch from 2-6 which is open to the public but that reservations are necessary.in the future, i would especially like to try the brunch, which is available on weekends with two seatings at both 2 and 4 pm.oh and it's byob!!the chef/owner was a sweetheart.definitely come with someone you know pretty well.brazilian top sirloin, thin strips of beef grilled with onions.but that's okay, the usher took us up the stairs where we we smack dab in the middle of georgina's (owner and cook) living room..everything was cooked to perfection.need to go back soon!!!..

The tako salad was mediocre at best.i thought the bowl was tasty and just enough food for me.so delicious and i feel good after eating it.really cute place with fast service.this time, i got the big.the first time it was packed, and the line was out the door as i was the unfortunate one waiting outside on a very hot and humid day.went in and laughed my way in ordering since i was a newbie making my own poke bowl.i've been to the original location inside the west loop french market.i ordered the marinated tuna with crunch.i also added edamame and ginger for good measure!  the mini container itself is pretty small but they packed on all of the ingredient for a voluminous volcano of toppings!  the fresh and light ingredients truly hit the spot on a steamy chicago afternoon.

Now lead by the award winning mixologist julia momose, expect even more in the coming months with the opening of the annex bar.i was there for their grand opening night and keep going back there and i always enjoyed the beauty of the place and the deliciousness of the food & drinks.i had the peach salad with the fish it was fabulous.they're known for their cocktails and that showed as well.all the drinks were tasty including the one that had garam masala in it.definitely check this place out.first of all, the atmosphere is quite breathtaking, as we sat on the 18th floor and had a beautiful view of the city..the inside is still hip and clean and has a neat vibe.it's kind of confusing since it's nestled in a medical building on the 18th floor.

Very nice meal!.by far my favorite was the beef over potato pancakes.we enjoyed are dinner here but there are better polish restaurants in chicago.chicken breast stuffed with parsley, cheese and butter.get some perogies.ended up doing the family style dinner which included alot of items from the menu as well as dessert and coffee!the service was excellent here too.as far as polish food goes, i am a fan of the homemade goodies from babcia, but other than that i have not been to many polish restaurants.the inside was very compressed mashed potato.i had a serious pierogi craving and happened to be in the neighborhood.my husband had a pork cutlet.

We went on a friday morning and there was a ten minute wait.next up was the pretzel with welsh rarebit, a staple.next up was the artisanal cheese board which featured three kinds of cheeses-one was a parmesan, another was a french camembert, and the third was a brie type cheese.if you come to longman and eagle and don't order fried chicken you are a fool.i remembered a cold winter night three or four years ago and scrumming my way through a packed crowd to vie for the bartender's attention.the sweet potato and pork belly hash that came with them was also delicious, and even the syrup seemed special.this place has carved out a permanent place among chicago's elite culinary institutions, and i don't see it being dethroned any time soon..my friend ordered a standard breakfast of sausage and eggs and was thoroughly satisfied.oh man sooo good.

I hope it was just that i ordered breakfast at the wrong time of the day!.seating is a hit or miss..as i said, it was typical diner food with typical bad diner coffee.the waiter was friendly and he continued to check on us.i love this place.eggs were cooked well as were as the potatoes and i ended up constructing two mini breakfast burritos with the tortillas.byob.tons of thick juicy meat and loved they put the dressing on the side.there are way too many great brunch options in chicago to settle!.

Which is a problem for a bacon eater like me!overall, i wish the place took a chance to be really and wildly different than protein bar (based on the menus alone).great opportunity to try this place we are so glad we did.i can already tell.overall, it was great.will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu!.the look inside felt very chic and comfortable.they also have a good selection of protein desserts.so nice that they now have these side options since every time i eat at protein bar i crave something slightly more.i liked the self-check out ipads option too.

It smelled so good in there.the wait time is long though.the guy was pleasant enough when i walked in and took care of me right away..i sprinkled some of my parmesan cheese on my jerk q and i was in heaven the cheese cooled down some of the heat from jerk and also gave it a bit of a pop in flavor on my dancing taste buds.the variety of sauces is amazing.service is great here so this wasn't really a problem for us, but i can imagine that during busier hours it would be useful to have a napkin dispenser on each table since the wings are so messy.you can't go wrong with this wing joint! will be back to try more flavors.

Fist bump, chest bump, high five, and an ass slap to yelp on this one! you'd never know that bdp existed if it weren't for the internet.so yeah, love the premise..was scooting around mad house on madison and hit my bookmarks.

Sad to say because i've had some very great breakfasts here but it will be a long time before i come back if ever.we all enjoyed our food.we then ordered the combo breakfasts of longanesa (sausage) and tocino (wine pork), and my buddy got longanesa and bangus (fried fish) and it comes with garlic fried rice, 2 eggs anyways, and a chocolate rice.all in all, i was very disappointed with uncle mike's and definitely won't be back.a few times i ended up just sitting there for a n extra 10-15 minutes just waiting for a waiter to come back..95..luckily we knew better.i ordered the "famous" marinated skirt steak which appears in approximately 40% of the pictures posted for this restaurant!  (do we need another pic of the same steak & hash browns?) the server did inform me that the price had gone up a few dollars from that which was listed on the menu.

The burger was huge, cooked perfectly, and sooo good!the next time i was there i had breakfast and had the eggs benedict.and for some reason people seem to not know about it, so you don't need a reservation.great place, with large choice of drinks and very nice decor.red flag right there, i was expecting fresh watermelon in my drink not "syrup", so instead they offered me strawberry syrup.overall, i would return just to get hammered.thanks erica!troquet immediately won me over with one simple change from the lm bistro days.we went to have drinks and get a snack to eat.they had a unisex bathroom that was really clean and cute.the food, atmosphere, service.my friend scoped it out only half hour before we headed over.

We did not have a reservation but it wasn't a problem.for a friday night it wasn't too terribly busy; we were able to get a booth for two right away and as the night progressed it became a nice quiet setting.the  new potatoes were good  freshi finished the meal off with lemon sorbet all in all a great performance for this place.also ordered the antipasto dish.:d  we were given a basket of crusty bread, which came with a spicy oil (infused with chili peppers and such) - this was quite delicious!  definitely different than just dipping the bread in olive oil and/or spreading it with butter...initially we chose this spot because we saw there was outdoor seating, but sadly the rain has been pounding the city as of late so we ate inside.i'm rating this restaurant based on the cooking classes they have.the service was nice.

We wandered over here for breakfast a few saturday's ago and both enjoyed our sandwiches and coffee.cute cafe, outdoor seating, great place to grab a drink with friends and catch up.the anti-mega coffee chain if you're not looking for starbucks.this is a wonderful hipster-y cafe in west loop that serves simple but terrific sandwiches (both lunch and breakfast sandwiches), as well as bakery items and coffee.nice local sandwhich shop.the people who work here are really friendly and although you won't get your sandwich immediately, you can be assured that it will be delicious.i tried the vegan chocolate chip and it was great!  swing in for a quick sandwich or stay for longer and fuel up while getting some work done.coffee is the dark matter brandgood variety of pastries, begals and fresh sandwiches.free wifi is nice for doing work or studying, and it's small enough that you can quietly get your stuff done if you are looking for a change of scenery.blech.

So many soup options! the lobster bisque is my personal favorite and you can get your soup in a bread bowl if you choose.let's see about how this broccoli and white cheddar soup stacks up.i had the creamy chicken and wild rice and it was delicious.the place is small, but with a good number of tables.99 for grilled sandwich.it was very smooth, creamy and flavorful.it was particularly difficult to pick.i grabbed a sourdough breadbowl (i can't remember if there's any other type) and it was fine-crumbed, for a sourdough, and very flavorful.i love the idea of a soup shop with twelve varieties at the ready--but i'm disappointed by soupbox's execution.chili was thick and tasty.

Me n the ladies went there sunday and we all liked our meals.it was the only non-chinese place my family patronized besides the golden arches.grab your silverware and water too!i liked the options for sides, coleslaw and macho peas were great! the chicken, not a huge fan of, but i'll eat it.i ordered it hot with a side cesar salad - my go to flavoring and go to side dish.i've been wanting to try nando's for the past year and finally got my chance! loved the ambiance and vibe once i walked in.i always get the chicken skewers, portuguese rice and pineapple lemonade.this south african/portuguese restaurant is based around grilled chicken.the ambiance is great for outings, dates, or just binge eating the wings yourself.the mango lime wings had nice flavor with a hint of heat, but i sopped up an entire puddle of the lemon herb sauce with my chicken breast.how these guys took a simple concept with chicken, and elevated it to this level is amazing.

The pho is tasty but instead of a mint veggie plate, which is the norm, it comes with a cilantro veggie plate.the proprietor even brought me a "real" bowl when he found i was going to eat at the little table on the mall side, instead of carry out.will definitely come back when i crave pho!.i love korean food and if i'm not making it myself, the only times i could have it are the weekends (i rarely go get it on the weeknights since i don't want to battle traffic going to the north side of chicago where the majority of korean restaurants are).i particularly enjoyed the brown sauce that it came with (similar to teriyaki) for mixing in.it had many pieces of tofu, zucchini, mushrooms, radishes/white carrots and pork."i would recommend this place to anyone who likes pho/basic korean food, especially if they work around the area.in hawaii, it wasn't very difficult to just drive to the nearest yummy's or so gong dong, but in chicago, korean restaurants are pretty limited.we tried outt the beef pho and bibimbap.the soul of pho is the broth and you want to have the subtle hints of cinnamon, cloves, fennel, and star anise in the broth.

Delicious! the sandwich also comes with fries and chimichurri dipping sauce, which was tasty, but i couldn't eat many of the fries without being too full.ah, the memories!to say the least, the ropa vieja is simply wonderful! every bite of shredded flank steak has just the right amount of garlic, peppers, tomato deliciousness.i will definitely go back!!!.i finished 1.the restaurant was packed all night.the seafood paella was frankly kinda bad.wow.solid.that's my cue to leave.great cuban place! i went with my cousins and ordered the empanadas and ceviche for starters.

I did the damn thang on 5 gin & tonic drinks (word to the awesome bartender)the spot is pretty cool as it looks to be one half bar the other half restaurant.i ordered the the three piggy and was in awe.you know how hot doug's motto is "there are no two finer words in the english language than encased meats, my friend"? that's how i feel, but replace "encased meats" with fried chicken..com/watch?v=kl-1…)yes.the menu has incredible food, and their three little piggies is incredible..we were only able to conquer 2/3 of the sandwich..and i had the duck club sandwich.

I would go back to star kitchen, we would because the people work there are nice.i got late-night delivery from there, after seeing the plethora of positive reviews, which are certainly misplaced.but i wouldn't come here on a regular basis for chinese food since there are much better options in chinatown which is only about 5 mins away.the building is kind of sketchy.the serve gave me the food and it didn't have any soup..

Highly recommend the food herealways fresh, reasonably priced and friendly service on top of this the place is super clean.the sandwich definitely had roasted pork (this was probably the best pork and i could eat that roasted pork all day long), ham, cheese, mustard (i think), but i didn't have any pickles and that's one of my favorite parts of a cuban.

Giving this four stars seems like a tiny bit of benefit of the doubt, but i'm just going to reward them for having decent beef after a lot of lackluster burgers recently.get it all gooey.i look forward to going back to the paramount room to try more good food, drinks, and company.firstly, it's a la carte.still worth trying.however, it was not cooked medium rare but more medium well.good oyster happy hour but $1 bacon was kind of embarrassing - literally 1 strip of bacon is served, nothing special about it.pretty average place..relatively deserted location aside, this is a great spot!  it's an old speakeasy and you can definitely tell this in the basement where we were seated.

The service was excellent and the food and drinks were ok.i asked her what the issue was with her rolling her eyes when i can clearly see that there are more than enough tables empty! this was our first time there and i already was mad that this "hostess" was giving us this nasty ass attitude.after happy hour at the virgin we were pumped up to try these.it gets pretty busy and when we were there, lots of empty "reserved" tables..you enter via the alley and it's underground.if you are looking for a chill place with a good atmosphere, drinks, and tasty food come check this place out.i would say this is the top bar that we end up taking friends or family visiting from out of town as it is a really well done tiki bar with a cool vibe and ambiance.the entrance is super sketchy and my friend was like where are you taking us?! but it was worth it.some of the drinks are meant to be shared.

I used to frequent this place when i was a kid; still decent; still the after bar hangout..there was a guy playing guitar and singing for tips when we were there, which was nice too.it was the best beverage i had ever put into my body.i was able to get various items without cheese, egg, or mayonnaise [thereby making it vegan], but it would have been nice if they did have substitutes.pineapple drink - this was okay, but think i'll try the milkshake next time..5.el faro is a gem..but our waiter was awesome and brought us samples of horchata,  jamaica (hibiscus), and tamarindo drinks.

My friend and i split the chai hot chocolate, which is actually a mixture of 1/3 hot chocolate, 1/3 chai, and 1/3 mexican hot chocolate.then dessert, determined not to be overshadowed by the main course, came along and killed it.amazing pumpernickel bread, umami blast from the bacon, and great (vegan) tomato soup for dipping and enjoying.we easily could've just split one rather than both ordering our own.the waffles were delicate and the chicken was buttery and crisped to perfection.the burger had a good flavor, the quiche was good, and i liked the tomato soup.we just got one order and they split it in half for us (they put one order into two smaller mugs with two homemade marshmallows on each saucer..what could be better than hot chocolate.overall, i would not be desperate to come back as the drinks are pricey and the service wasn't great.

I ordered gyoza and duck curry.will def get this again!.i had the sushi and my husband had the red curry in the lunch special.the service was excellent and the food really good.the "restaurant" is basically a glorified cafateria where you need a key for the bathroom and have to walk through a super dated hallway in the basement to get there.service was quick and efficient, but it somehow felt they were rushing us even though there were only 4 of the approximately 30 tables seated.

She was attentive, split our checks and our food came out really quickly! our bartender, however, was not.great place to day drink and snack.the craziest bread appetizer is bomb dot com.i didn't try the pizza, but i did try the calamari and this dish was amazing i liked the textured, taste , flavor, everything, it was really good.they have a decent beer list, and simple menu.place is surprisingly huge.excellent wings! buffalo (maple sub-flavored) and the habanero-pineapple are great.we had ordered plenty of veggie options - some of them were ok and some were decent.it felt like a college bar that allows 20 yr old kids one.the place is not impressive in its appearance, comfort, or menu.

It wasn't particularly tasty either.the meat on the italian beef was tough and the juice had no flavor.total win.pizza looks to die for and with a $10 pie deal what's not to like.definitely worth the drive you can't lose here everything on the menu was good especially the infused italian ice.i got their donuts today.and the glass for water that they gave me was full-size, not one of those "penalty cups" some places stick you with for not buying into the high-fructose corn syrup industrial complex..in any case, we enjoyed our food and had a good time; will definitely be trekking back to this side of town when the breaded steak sandwich urges return.my co-workers got their meatball sandwiches and they said it was really good.

The flavor of the chicken without any sauce is already great, but add the garlic herb sauce and you're in business..the last time i went i had a quarter chicken with the chili sweet potato side and my friend got the chicken wrap with chips.(nando's is also nicer, so it becomes a place where you could plausibly go on a casual date."portuguese rice" - sigh i've had much better from a zatarain's box.the family meal was enough for 3 people.service is good, setup is good, i'll definitely be returning.i love the hammock chairs.service was great- pretty quick and definitely friendly.had the signature chicken and it was really good.

The oysters were decent but definitely not the best i've had.the only time we saw him was at the very beginning of the meal when we ordered our food and maybe when the bill was brought.the room is comfortable, modern and city chic.i would have expected more oohs and aahs over our food and drinks; more declarations of, "you have got to try this! it will change your life!" we could have had more sublime meals with flawless service at naha, cafe des archictectes or travelle..interior: chic and attractive.we started with the bruschetta which were 3 tiny pieces and so overpriced.all were good and the bartenders were really nice.good experience overall.

' there are certainly enough components for this restaurant to be excellent, but on the night i went, those components did not shine.the service was impeccable and the food was delicious.we asked for an outdoor table but were told there were none available.okay the pork was for two but both the ricotta toast and the dessert we shared and could not finish.beer list was diverse and appropriate for the menu..good cocktails.they were fantastic, as were the scrambled eggs and bacon i ordered as side dishes.service was solid, nothing special.i love food and flavors however, this was completely unusual.

Most notably, they have really refreshing flavored waters that they freshly prepare from fruit.as i'm writing this review i'm thinking what was  about it that didn't blow me away.i look forward to frequenting this spot!.

It was early morning and i had not had breakfast yet.looking forward to trying the lunch items.ordered the turkey avocado wrap which was actually more of a hoagie and the avocado is more like guacamole you would get at a subway.50 you get the sandwich and one side.however these guys give you a heap of food and it's damn good.

Anything.not outrageously priced, and lovely enough for a celebration or date night.not only is the ambience unparalleled, the food is phenomenal and packed with flavor..my bf and i went there last saturday for our first anniversary, it was a really good experience! we tried their tasting menu with wine pairing.if you are in the neighborhood you should check it out.but this a great place to splurge and do the 7 course tasting that was more like 9 courses, each one amazing, but we had a scallop and chorizo dish that really stood out as our favorite, but the smoked pork neck and monkfish and cheese course were all beyond amazing!.kudos to boka for that.the menu is reminiscent of blackbird's, sparse and simplistic, with just enough of a twist to make things interesting.it certainly is fine dining but it isn't over-the-top.
Service was excellent most of the food was good highly recommend egg waffle and french chocolate mousse cake..

Cool old pinball machines as lighting/decorations.all he did in response was shrug and tell me he didn't know much about wine..you can find craft brews right alongside your pbrs here as well.can't wait to try it!.the crowd has gotten a little on the young side.people seem to like the food, it may be worth popping in to sample that.just a nice atmosphere and nice people.that is why there is always next time.if i had known it was trivia night, i would have suggested some other place.

It was extremely filling, ended up paying around $12 i believe with tax.95 lunch special..on the positive side, service is very friendly and everything on the menu seems to be a healthier version of what i'm used to finding in a mediterranean restaurant.and they are so friendly!  there are often samples of falafel and pita chips on the counter..they're friendly, funny, and help you figure out exactly what you're craving that day.nice folks who work here but food was very average.i got a chicken shawarma plate.because that would have been some epic shit.
The sundaes are fantastic and very reasonable.

What really blows me away about four moon is the food.we're so glad to be back in the neighborhood, because this place is still pretty awesome!.on that score, four moon was pretty damn disappointing.i agree, they have a nice beer list and a great comfort food menu too.scrumpy hard cider beer that she claims was really good.and, surprisingly, the gyro.it's only a few blocks away, though! great bar food, delicious fries & great service.pool table- checkcheap drinks- checkstrangers who talk to one another- checkeverything about this place is great.you had me at southern tier pumking!.my boyfriend had the mushroom and meat pierogi, which were no different then buying from the store, but really enjoyed their sunday special- pot roast.
Def hope they get their service and menu ironed out that way they can stay around for a while.

So i'm guess it was a thumbs up, too.carlos is a great professional who always makes sure you get the donuts you want.in the mood for some wedding cake, but haven't been invited to an actual wedding? head on over to donut vault for their wedding cake donuts, you will definitely get your fill.i would've given this spot 5 stars but my hesitations are in the price and donut taste.all 3 flavors contained the same donut, but the toppings was where it differed.5 stars.just amazingly scrumptious!.they have an amazing texture, crisp exteriors, and the flavors are a mix of classic and more unusual combinations- there is something for everyone! the meyer lemon and pistachio is my favorite, but my husband is more of a classic guy, and he loves the glazed old fashioned.i got there a couple of hours after they had open for the day and several of their signature donuts were all gone..

So far - not so good.i usually stick to what i know (like pad thai or bamee soup), but with recommendations from our awesome waiter, trying new dishes, like the spicy tom tom papaya salad and the kinnaree noodles did not disappoint! i was even impressed by the flavors and tenderness of the meats in the dishes, like the pork in the kow moo dang and the moo ping (also pork).the promise of noodles led me here twice, but only a coupon would lead me back.i've had it a few times and it has been great every time.whether you're getting a safe pad thai with quality, chewy noodles, or you're trying their house kinnaree noodles (my personal favorite), you're in for some food made with passion, twists of bold flavor, and thai pride at this new neighborhood, family-run spot.i thought my boat noodles were tasty and would get this again.i was really excited about trying kinnaree.

Thanks moon for filling my tummy and starting my day off right!.anyway, i truly loved what i got from moon's today which was good  service,great food and an introduction to henry.it was delicious thin sliced corned beef with lettuce, pickle, tomato, and mustard.stick to the breakfast classics and make sure to get the sausage, which one server claimed is made specially for moon's (or in-house), and was the best thing we tried.moon's, where have you been all my life?  i hardly even know what to say, as my moon's experience was so whirlwind, but woah.old school.i was raised on the stuff.think manny's for half price.the customer service was great and i found the employees and even customers around me to be very friendly.
Always fast, fresh & friendly! it is one of my family's favorite pit stops...the shrimp was good as well.i only wish they offered  a lemon wedge for the calamari.
Awesome dinner!..as for the meal, it was very good and we were allowed to take our time without feeling rushed on a saturday night.the soup was probably the best soup i've had.

When i first hear about this i was so excited i put it down in my calendar.if you only get one thing here, it *~has~* to be a chocolate fernet milkshake..the burgers are almost as good as the ones at au cheval and that is good enough for me.overall, pretty good.casual quint space, positive/welcoming vibes, small menu (not a bad thing!), $10 per person average but good quality items.i loved everything about small cheval!it's such a quaint and small burger joint.and the smoothie was pretty good - i got the vanilla one..this is a good burger, but this is not the au cheval burger.

Unique burgers due to their signature sauce,theyre similar to culver's..i suggest you go with the chicago style hot dog, as that's what made them pseudo famous in the hood.but wait,there is more--parking and outdoor seating.you can tell it is real meat and not warm up in a microwave.small quiet burger joint.inexpensive mediocre fast food open late.so good!! whether you're drunk or sober, must try!!.woooweee, we were in for a treat!!food:- polish dogs with fries - simple, topped with onion, mustard, and relish.

Korean fried chicken is much crisper.).hands down one of the best dollar per taste bud value to be had.the chicken was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside.we will definitely return for the phenomenal korean spicy wings, the great price, and the friendly service!.this restaurant is very cute.a little pricy for just kfc wings, but worth it..it was a decent amount of squid, but it wasn't anything too special so we probably wouldn't get it again.

^_^i also put in an order for the family size honey garlic chicken.then i think she remembered he was standing there and said oh, glasses are over there *points to them*.ps the staff is so friendly and cute!.i had the chicken bop bowl - flavors and textures were good, but the chicken was overcooked and it wasn't served hot.i love that they serve it in the clay pot just be careful you don't accidentally burn yo'self.you get the eggs and fish cake, but you also get onion straws and other filler ingredients that make this place a pass.there is nothing like that crunchy rice at the bottom.what an interesting concept--get a meal that's half ramen, and half bibimbap.if you're looking for a good lunch spot, cupbop + ramen is a cool place to check out.order at to counter, get a number and grab a seat.

But i thought the food, while different, would be just as good as those two and i just did not feel that it was.we tried:smoked oysterscheddar rilletteshush puppieslasagnashrimp and gritsbutter pipe pasta with clamschickenbest bites were definitely the rillettes and chicken.amazing and definitely a must try! i loved every minute of my dining experience at roister.the friend that requested this to me doesn't even like salmon and the fact that i do- i had to get this.yeah, it's pricy for lunch, but you definitely get what you pay for.felt light and fresh.3 stars - inventive food which didn't quite hit the mark; drinks were not as good as aviary's.dinner as theatre - ya, you 'betcha.i'm not a fan of serving drinks in inappropriate glassware.the wives took a tour of the prep kitchen and a live tutorial on the foie gras snickers bar dipped in liquid nitrogen.
What a special place.

I do it all the time.i was in desperate need of some veggies and healthy eats - lo and behold, lyfe was just a block away from the hotel.food:roasted brussels and squash is my favorite item on the menu.who can beat that?  and i'm so excited my office will be moving nearer to this lunch spot so i can maintain my healthy diet.love love love! an amazing environment with great selection.i had a phenomenal experience earlier today at lyfe kitchen.stopped by lyfe for a quick lunch during work, and was really impressed by the variety of foods and how quick everything was prepared! do try to get here as early as possible though, to beat the lunch rush.excellent lunch and dinner choice.the food is so so so good..
A world-class burger for under $10 and without a line.this place has such a cool concept.

This dish was so tasty!!  the shrimp and the fish taste fresh, not at all rubbery..we decided to go safe and try a "traditional" burrito, which was nothing but "traditional".a fun, lively atmosphere with outdoor seating available and byob.you have to have their ceviche on a tostada with a drop of valentina hot sauce..all very rich in flavor with tomatoes, cilanto and onion, mouth watering...5 hours in we got a little worried and called the restaurant .

It was a well run operation from the cashier to the guy grilling the meat in the back.the homemade corn tortillas are delicious, and everything is made there in house and the portions are nice.i didn't enjoy how wet the taco/quesadilla was as it was sitting on our plate.talked to a couple of customers and everybody there seemed to be in a good mood.they produce, pound, and bake their own tortilla here, and watching them make it is also a spectacle.rubi's is only open on sundays.this makes the taco/quesadilla experience all the better.yes yes yes yesssssssss!i've finally found tacos similar to what i ate in puerto vallarta! shout out to my man at the spit and his knives! best cheerleader i've ever seen.finally madeit..

The cornbread cupcake was a very unique side but didn't help cut the sweetness since the maple cream was sweet itself as well.good food, but nothing too special.i ordered some sort of mac & cheese dish that had to be sent back as it was basically cold.nice touch! everyone enjoyed themselves and we will definitely be back!.for stars we shared the shishito peppers.these aren't your normal bite sized tater tots..5 stars.the food here is unique and delicious! for example, in something as simple as their free bread, they give you urchin mixed butter instead of ordinary plain butter.i had a reservation for a thursday night at 8 and it was still decently busy for a weeknight.

Having flown into town earlier in the day i was a little tired, but excited to have a beer, some cocktails, some decent food and watch snf.pros: beautiful patio by the river, ok pricing for the view and amount of food given, nice waitstaff but slow on the water bottle refillcons: sometimes the river smells like sewage, some brunch items were mediocre - like the beignets (although the housemade whipped cream and cinnamon glaze were on point), and the wicked tots were rather salty.shorter waits always make me giddy : ) our server was great! even with the busy crowd, she was just attentive enough and kept our drinks full.gross and might as well not have any.everyone from the hostess to the servers were super nice.our server was great and you can tell that the owners genuinely care about their customers..this place is pretty cool..this place has an amazing deck right along the river that makes you feel like you're eating at an exclusive yacht club.

White mousse n fruit sauces.this place was mindblowingly (is that a word?) amazing.incorporating not only taste but smell and sight into the equation..the signature dessert at the end is also amazing with chef achatz himself laying out the dessert!overall a wonderful experience..didn't love the hike in the pricedidn't love single stall bathroom on the first floor that was out of hand towels half way through the mealdid love the fooddid love meeting grantdid love the overall aestheticsi can't say anything bad about grant.there were diners at two other tables when we arrived in the dining room we were assigned to..

It was divine! apparently the restaurant doesn't offer this dinner entree daily, so this was a real treat..the service was great..there wasn't enough thousand island to make these tasty.the rest of us dealt with it, but don't plan to come back here for lunch until whoever runs the kitchen gets a microwave or learns how to cook to order.i have been dining at tavern in the park for several years and most recently celebrated a baptism at tavern's tree house this summer."where?" i asked.bar staff was nice, except they have a weirdly watchful host staff.the restaurant was full of hockey fans.

Period.so herein lies the problem i've been struggling with since i left philly: you can't get good hoagie rolls outside of the northeast and as a result, i just don't crave sandwiches anymore (much to the dismay of my wife).after reaching out and talking to multiple vendors, we knew real kitchen was the right choice for us.for my 300th review, i will go all wedding crazy and recommend you to try real kitchen for catering or for a stop-in meal.fresh ingredients, and changing menu.i'm so excited to come back again!.we really enjoyed our visit here.there is a nice balance of classic dishes, ethnic food and gourmet dishes...

Very nice family owned shop..great cheap place with good food great family business and get in get out and get on with your day.try the soups, i know that the owner makes them from scratch!don't think twice about visiting this sandwich shop.place can get a bit busy and be difficult to find a seat.yet i've had better hot dogs than this place to be honest with anyone who reads this..fast service, but you can tell the food is not fresh, especially if it is not busy.pretty classic sandwich offerings from delightful subs to gyros and melts.the italian sub is loaded with meat - be careful their hot giardinera is really hot!!the italian beef sandwich is very good.

Also when we went, there were no dishes that were japanese which is also deceiving.all you need, all you'll ever want will be printed on their menu chalkboard.this was an absolutely outstanding dining experience..the food was plentiful and we ended up bringing a portion of the noodles home with us.it is around the corner and went twice this week.it really depends on the availability of ingredients.we're talking 12-seat dining room tiny.there were 3 of us and we tried 3 dishes, we were so stuffed but wished we could have tried more!  everything we had was so delicious!  service was also really great, really nice waitress who chatted with us and told us about the restaurant.it came as a huge portion, but it was all noodles and barely any chicken.

I had a mother's day lunch here, and my mom loved it.everything genuinely tasted homemade and reminded me of my time living in rome.best part is the pasta - home made, so yummy.it wasn't the best i've had but it was pretty tasty.can't believe i've never heard of this place! we walked in during do-division and really enjoyed the food.we also had limoncello with our dessert that topped the meal off nicely.for dessert, i had the mixed berry granita which was also very good.nice date place for sure in a fun area west on division from damen.nando milano embodies one of the things that make chicago such a wonderful city: mom&pop style restaurants.

The high/low is badass because it has a tall ice "spear" flavored to match the drinki'm happy to say the cool ambiance on the patio, the warm feeling you get sitting inside of scofflaw and their tasty drinks all have stayed up to par.prices are great and people aren't douchy.free midnight cookies?! believe it.we ordered a couple other cocktails that were reasonably priced at around $8-$10 each.dimly lit, cozy ambiance with mismatched old furniture.i loved all the flavors and different components to the salad - it made eating greens remotely fun..this spot is a cute and intimate place that puts me in mind of a speak easy.we enjoyed great service, the food looked yummy (esp the mac/cheese, which i only ate with my eyes--next time with my tummy).my favorite thing? free chocolate chip cookies at midnight! and they're still warm!!!.

The restaurant has an extensive collection of crudo and raw fish dishes.the warm beef carpaccio with pomegranate, black trumpet mushroom, and parmigiano was a favorite, but i've also tried pork loin al'tonnato with truffled peach olive, apple, gulf shrimp and that was very good as well.we then decided to try the carbanera pasta with bacon and it was overly al dente and super chewy.we were a large group of people sharing numerous dishes, so i had the opportunity to try many different things.frankly, not worth $45, neat presentation though.a berry smash like elixir and he got something that tasted very herbal.both were good but the bruschetta topped with crispy brussel sprouts was amazing! we also had the carbonara pasta and wild salmon.they also have great cocktails.my husband said that they continuously asked him if we were celebrating anything special, when he made the reservation and again when we got seated.we can for a foursies couples brunch (plus a baby in tow).

I was especially pleased with the crusts.passion fruit is bomb guys, gotta get it! definitely wanna go back and try their biscuits.maybe a little more ventilation would do them good, cause i walked out smelling like bacon biscuits?great staff, to boot.just wow, the food here and the casual communal environment here is great.the biscuit with gravy was wholy black pepper.love this place! a little out the way for us but so glad we made the trip.whatever the reason it was a much appreciated and promptly devoured slice of key lime pie.i was hoping to go to their original location first since i prefer trying the first spot to open for an establishment before checking out additional locations, but i was running out of time in chi and was within walking distance from here so this location had to do.we had the brisket biscuit, ham biscuit, and the chicken pot pie as our meals.i'm also declaring the best hash browns ever.

It was a meal worthy of the tuscan countryside, or the roman city center.this is without a doubt one of my favorite restaurants in chicago!.the wine was great and everything that we ordered from the menu was incredible.instead, i liked the oyster mushroom that came as part of the dish.dessert was amazing, forget the name now but it was the vanilla one...we had cocktails - only premium vodka brand was ketel one, which was fine.that was hubby's favorite dish.(the portobellos, as often noted, are also delicious.

Do i wish the bottom of the pizza was just a touch crispier?  yes.but if coalfire is going to rep thin crust pizza, they have some improving to do, especially in their customer service department ("people over pizza").i'm sure i'll be back, but you know what?  i'll probably go give spacca napoli a second chance first.that being said, come for the pizza.honey/salami is ridiculous..pistachio pesto, $18 prior to tax- this pizza is made with pesto (made with pistachios), sausage, burrata cheese and honey.the pepperoni was meant for the guys to eat, but i couldn't get enough of it! seriously, so unbelievably good.as most have mentioned- there is no ambiance- there are kids everywhere but that's ok by me- most restaurants on southport are like this.the real highlight of the meal was the service and the drinks.

The nearest el station is the cta 63rd.their food and service reflects that..i plan to stop there one day for a donut at breakfast time.free wifi, great space to get a little work done.i already work from home, so going to a coffee shop is no big deal in order to break of the monotony.really enjoy coming in here.i plan to frequent it more once my schedule permits.

Ukrainian village revitalization, and it's also one of the strongest..first of all, the location is pretty choice, as there's a good amount of free or metered street parking within a stone's throw of the cafe.they did not look great - the meat looked sub par quality and they had a weird sauce on them as well, would stay away from this.i will be ordering this dish the next time i come here.this particular brunch i had the veggie burger with a sunny side up egg and fries! as usual i was very pleased! i was a mess, my fingers and face were covered with sauce, that's when you know it's good! the portions are pretty big, i always leave stuffed! i was only able to eat half of my veggie burger and fries and best believe i ate the other half an hour or two later!my boyfriend is a meat eater, he usually orders the breakfast dishes but this particular weekend he ordered the burger and fries.anyway back to food.i've always been able to find street parking within a block.also the portions are pretty good for the price and the staff is friendly.there was no wait this morning so i did not get a chance to use either of those rooms, though i will say the wall of baby heads is quite creepy.

P.overall, avec's prices are very fair for the portion size and the quality of the food.on the other hand another reason for the 4 stars is that i did not quite understand the apple dessert.it was still incredible, but i think i was just expecting a little bit more.i ended up ordering the baked egg, and it was more then enough for brunch.all the other food was great as well and i really enjoyed the burger they serve for lunch.i always disliked communal seating, but now i really despise it.i loved the slow roasted pork shoulder as well, the lemon yogurt was amazing with the pork shoulder.avec manages to be intimate and feel vibrant while maintaining a high level of polish.

We sat inside, but they do have patio seating.totally exceeded my expectations.breakfast house does it right.actually everything was killer.$2.that really looked outstanding.breakfast and lunch.the chicken had some good pieces but also some fatty pieces.plus, as others have said, the coffee is good.it was amazing.

)   the location is only a few blocks from the ashland green/pink line cta stop, and a lot of other fun places nearby.we needed some good additions on this end of randolph.i've been to the gyu-kaku in west la and it was just as good.coming in late to an opera is definitely a big no no, so we really needed to rush our dinner along.some highlights included the shrimp dumplings, the toro beef and the pork belly, but really everything was great.everybody is super super friendly but it was slow.my husband & i came to this location because we had checked out the other location.but if you're looking for some real and authentic bbq, this is not the place for you.we were excited to try gyu-kaku after seeing so many positive reviews.they aren't that expensive but they aren't that strong either.

Servings are large, we had left overs to take home.their spinach pesto, asiago and ricotta gnocchi is why you go here..i again had to ask the waiter for more bread and finally 30 minutes later we got more bread, after we were both finished eating.the place was cute and cozy.check it out!..we will definitely be visiting again in the near future.and in true european fashion, the meal is meant to be enjoyed and lingered over.sometimes the italian bread is a little too toasted (*cough* burnt *cough*), which is disappointing.
