The al pastor is wow!  this stuff is spicy and tastes even better with a squeeze of lime.their tortas de milanesa are pretty good too with the toasted bun and avocado.visit this place.they make their own, and it's heated on a vertical rotisseri.they also have a parking lot across the street.atotonilco taco (carne asada with a slice of tomato and sour cream)- the meat was simply seasoned with salt and pepper..the prices are incredibly fair but don't forget it's cash only..waiti'm missing a lot of details-little village is like stepping out of chicago and into a mexican town.

It really is what it says it is: taqueria and bar.my bf really liked the lobster and i enjoyed both the brisket and pork belly.not my usual type of review, but i'm a little disappointed.the pitchers weren't on special that night and were the full $35...

Would stop in again given how close it is but if high five and oiistar were next door, i would probably head there first.my  vegan ramen was tasty, but i found it weird that it was more expensive than my friend's ramen, which had chicken and pork belly.i have been to ramen takeya at least 6/7 times and i will definitely be back there many more.i can't imagine where they plan to keep coats when winter rolls around.i have been wanting to try this place for a while..recommend both the pork belly and the fried chicken.ramen takeya is definitely up there, making it in my top 3 ramen restaurants in chicagoland area.in a matter of minutes, the remaining empty eats at the bar were snatched up.the music and lighting are on point, too.

Highly recommend this place.i even noticed one of the other ladies would pretty much watch and wait to see when our glasses of water diminished.i now regret our choice to come here and should have gone for the cheaper option which is probably the same quality sushi.we decided to order a variety of things to get a better feel for the restaurant so ordered the tempura appetizer, tonkatsu ramen, ikebukuro, multiple different types of nigiri, etc.the service was interesting.so when i saw the name of this sushi place, i was like, "wow, they must have huge balls to name themselves after tsukiji! hopefully the fish is super fresh.the restaurant looks really neat from the outside, and definitely drew my attention.amazing oyster shooters - spicy, fresh, sour, and salty - explosion of flavors with two oysters in each shot! the sushi flavors were also pretty good, although i wasn't a fan of the ika that they used (it wasn't the typical ika somen, more white and maybe cooked seeming rather than the transparent kind).i loved the cleanliness of the location.

These are delicious! i would go again if only for the carrot pancakes...we were seated right away in the colorful dining room.one of the best breakfast places my boyfriend and i have ever been to! the beignets were great; they were warm and came with raspberry and nutella dipping sauces.potatoes were roasted and the skin was nice and crispy topped off with egg and cheese melt with jalepenos and onions.they always seem super stressed and hurried.my dish was also very delicious, it had turkey chorizo, guacamole, and sour cream.happy to see a normal restaurant occupy a good spot on this block with beurrage bakery and across the street from thalia hall and honky tonk bbq.we had all kinds of time and space to chat and eat.

A real tasty and healthy place that tries to give quality ingredients to their clientsthe potato bowl is awesome (no need to put additional cheese or sour cream btw)they even use compostable plastic glasses for smoothie so it is the perfect place :)))..the staff open and easy to talk to.

It's so rare to find a combination of good service and good food these days, and it really appears the entire staff is both passionate about what they do and very happy to have us as customers.the space is bright and full of frivolity, and the service is excellent.dishes were very flavorful.).also, prices are in the high side for what u get - so be prepared to spend around $25 per person.as you drive up, it looks like a dump from the outside.it was delicious.my favorite two were d and phoebe! d is such a sweetheart.very friendly servers..

On the side, i ordered some bacon fat fries because, why not? they were as to be expected and paired with aioli that i mixed with the accompanied local ketchup (yum!).sweet restaurant.it easily seated the 13 of us and service was wonderful..we love the farm-to-table theme and wish they would make small changes to make the dining experience feel more premium and welcoming overall.the service was great, the food fantastic (the menu changes by season, which is awesome, but since it's been awhile, the fantastic benedict i had has since changed).service was good, the hostess was very friendly and accomodating on a busy friday night.i don't really understand why since it is in a great location and the food is delicious.when we got the check, we were pretty surprised to see the coffee was $3.

Our server was nice, but kind of impersonal, i don't remember much about her, because she didn't talk much.lo and behold, the wait was approximately 5 minutes.service is always fantastic.the restaurant is nice inside with a spacious seating area and ample wait staff.this place has great food period.we had a totally delicious, casual lunch.50 for egg whites only) omelets here!!! they were out of mushrooms so we were allowed to request a substitute vegetable.this place is very consistent in their quality of service and food.yep, really glad to have this place within walking distance of our new apartment.they have an ambitious breakfast menu but they seem to do it all well.

This place is super kitschy after all.i appreciate the simplicity of this underground, divey bar.once you enter down the stairs you place your order right at the grill.i'm a big believer in meat to bun to cheese ratio, but this was mostly bun.it has a small, yet comfortable interior and you will feel like you're a part of the place once you settle in.a simple greasy burger and chips.having not seen the sketch, i entertained myself by reading the very interesting memorabilia that covers the walls.tasty, classic burger that won't disappoint.had the game on so it was good while we waited for our other restaurant to call us when they were ready for us.kinda hard to find, but it sure is worth it.

Place is definitely on the smaller side - very charming, warm and cozy.when dessert menus came, they were hurriedly passed out upside down.nothing fluffy about it.the music was very fitting.everyone was right, they were delicious.our salads were nothing special....we eat early at 5:00 on a saturday and not surprisingly there were only a few people dining.

It's very exciting to have a new craft cocktail lounge in river north!.let me tell you about this new place called arbella.but not sure where the stars came from.drinks here are alright.i was in a mood for chicken so the kfc (korean fried chicken) was on point.i tried their grapefruit negroni and some kind of tequila/lime cocktail, both were fantastic.the fraise d'amor was a bit too spirit forward for me but my friend liked it so much we swapped.earthy toned colors, high-back booths, modern lighting allows it to easily fit into the river north scene.the decor is stylish with intriguing things to look at all around, and the tables are set up as large semi-private booths or seating areas.international beats in the background and bites around the world to pair with unique and exotic cocktails make for a night that you won't forget.
Be sure to bring cash too.* why would she try to manipulate me this way? she speaks and understands english more than sufficiently..not a whole lot of space inside, cash only, but full of charm.

Service was decent.but over all experience is positive in this restaurant:)..the real highlight was course #3 (dessert) -- bread pudding.felt like it needed different seasonings.would suggest a starter or a larger dish to order..the ambiance was intimate and nice, and the service was kind.we would go long periods of time without seeing our server and it always seemed to be when we needed something.the fries were great, as well.

5 stars!!!!.i'm sure my review will go up.everyone was super friendly and the quality of costumer service amazed me.it has a lot of flavor, especially the pieces still on the bone.what made me very upset this time is that they lied to me.after seeing this place basically rated as the #1 tacos in chicago, and #10 in america, i had to see what all the fuss was about.food was delicious, the quiet setting was nice, and i loved the people, extremely sweet.it is authentic mexican here..the goat is good, served with  plenty of juice to soak up with the home made tortillas.

There was only one waiter since the place was empty and he was rude to us.one of the best seafood places in chinatownespecially the steamed razor clam which is one of their signature dish, very fresh and tasty.of course we had our usuals of walnut shrimp as well as beef and king mushroom as well! absolutely delicious and i can't wait for us to all get together again!..we made a note to ourselves to come back sometime to try their renowned chili fusion dungeness crab (goes for $32.menu is simple but has enough selection that you're bond to find something you love.if only it wasn't buried in layers of salt...i've eaten there three times, and each time i've been greatly impressed.

It was my 1st time at the restaurant and the ambience was nice and the restaurant was warm, which is always a plus.i got the lost in translation drink- a little strong but def worth trying.ordered the minimum must-haves of soup dumplings, dim sum, and lamian and can't wait to taste the rest of the menu.this is not your typical chinese place.blue xiao long boa for $10 and some of the money from ordering the specials goes towards charity- a win, win! poke two holes in the boa to get that soup out and that black pepper beef had the freshest black peppers i have tasted in awhile with a kick of heat, i fell in love.presentation of the food is wonderful and i would say is the only redeeming quality to this place.lamians are their saving grace.it's a nice, more casual and relaxed alternative to say stk or rpm, but with very competitive food.i expected a very high level of service for this type of establishment and found that it was hard to flag down my waiter at times.75/5 if i could.

Try the bacon egg and cheese on toast sandwich and the french toast.it was pure cafeteria food.definitely a chicago institution, and in particular a favorite for south siders, u of c students, faculty, and staff.the steak and eggs are pretty good,  skip the biscuit (it's more of a dry piece of cake than it is a "biscuit.they didn't ask me so i got potatoes by default although i wanted rice but it's okay because the potatoes were pretty delicious.it sounded delicious so we gave it a try..great cafeteria style eatery.the pancakes are good and i really like the biscuits/butter/jam.cash only.

An institution in the community...again, the bread is too thick/chewy for me, but the upside there is when you take a sub to go, and ten minutes later get it home and the bread still holds up.my favorite sandwich place since uic.it's phenomenal.this place never disappoints.the corned beef is delicious, and so is the wise guy.can't wait until my next trip..

It's been awhile since i have gone to this restaurant, we had a groupon and the sandwich we got was very tasty!  i'm actually surprised i haven't gone back!the food and the service was really great!..

I'm not the biggest fan of mediterranean cuisine but i was pleased with my lunch at zaytune.it tasted different from the first bite, but it is honestly not bad.some of the chicken tasted a little bitter like it was burnt or something, but other than that i have no complaints.i ate like a king for like ten bucks!!!! lmao!!! no,seriously.no matter what you order it is good.it is warm and delicious.so we decided to come to this one instead.

Just not a good experience for a group of 6 early in the morning when you have an empty restaurant.just don't.good casual ambiance for an after-work catch-up dinner.it was 10:30am on a sunday and we were the only table dining in.my husband ordered sliders from the happy hour menu.i saw other diners' meals and their dishes looked pretty amazing.the fries were good with the large salt pieces and fresh herbs, and the burger was cooked just right..but last night we gave in and stopped by for a late snack/dinner and boy were we glad!it was nothing like what we had imagined it would be.he seemed inattentive, distracted, and uninterested in us as guests and ultimately customers.

I ordered a chai and had to remind the server of my order after waiting about 15 mins.seriously.enjoy!.they have great apple cider and caramel macchiatos.less than $2 for a scoop on a cone is pretty cheap in my books! i had the chai gelato which was deeeelicious, i loved how thick and creamy it was..sat in one of the soft chairs and sank two inches, and judging from the reviews i should have tried a sandwich, but the vibes here were really great and i give it two very enthusiastic thumbs up - fine holiday fun.next time i will try their vegan options.on the positive side, i ordered an "everything" cookie (some kind of nut, oats, chocolate chunks, raisins, some other things).the food was great and the desserts are even better.

Yum!.the gnocchi comes drowning in a creamy tomato vodka sauce that you'll be sure to dip the delicious complementary italian bread into after you eat all the pasta.desserts range from $3.the alfredo wasn't that great.and you may have to do a little bit of dancing, just to avoid bumping into people..i tried some of my friend's gnocchi and it was good, and the sauce was smooth and creamy! i didn't like the black spaghetti as much.tasty dishes that door portion controlled so u can make room for dessert..our server is great, despite the heavy traffic, she still came by often to make sure we were doing okthe food is great, i got the spaghetti neri with seafood, the sauce is very tasty with chunky crab meat in there and the spaghetti itself is very good too, i also like how they have a lot of scallops and shrimps on top.

If i could give 3.the food is always fresh and the portion size is decent.i had the falafel gyro and baklava which were totally delicious.just ate here today and again confirmed how excellent and authentico this place is.i especially like the kufta, meal or sandwich, doesnt matter to me, its delicious.this place is byob, which is great! we brought a bottle of red wine to share.the grilled veggie and egg sammich is the way to go! baba is out of this world.the food is simple but delicious, and dawali works in multiple timeframes.their wraps are stellar, amongst the best i've had in chicago..

Overall, it's okay.."so now me and my guests are being inconvenienced because they are not honoring their accepted reservation.the ginger lime parfait was more of an ice cream and it was a great ending to the meal.the restaurant is romantically lit and the decor is very lush but understated.the presentation is absolutely beautiful.cocktails were pretty good.it was just whatever.service was incredible.i had this giant braised lamb shank that fell right off the bone!can't wait to come back!.

The umami burger with its trio of sauces was good.perhaps this will change my mind.i had to go in and given my reaction, my friend, got dragged in.to my surprise, the kimchi was almost a bit bland, but thankfully the fries themselves were perfectly crispy.it's got all the goodies of the rogers park location, but much closer to home..even better than that, though, are the kimchi fries, which consist of golden, seriously crispy french fries bathed in kimchi, sesame, and some sort of deliciously umami sauce -- perfect dipped in sriracha.i was here a few months back and now have to walk on the opposite side of the street to avoid the temptation.i'll forgive them for that cause the other stuff was darn good.poor guy had to wait outside some random restaurant for 45 minutes while i dashed in and did my business).

Actual food was awesome - i had the rigatoni bolognese, and a couple of my friends ordered the farfalle pollo.my nieces love this spot, i'll probably pass on this place under any other circumstance..this is your basic go to place if you crave a nice plate of pasta just covered in sauce and cheese.i wish i remembered his name, but our service experience with him went well.customer service here is exemplary.the farfalle did benefit from a healthy dusting of red pepper, but it was all so good.wow..lastly, the service was excellent.

Guacamole is made fresh at the table in a cart.this is a mexican cantina but with a latin american twist.the ambiance is great--a classy, fun, slightly bougie mexican spot is everything we needed in the sloop! my first drink experience wasn't the best.so i am trying to say that please dress casual :)absolutely enjoyed the 3 salsas and free chips..it was unfortunate and frankly, not something you look for in a chain restaurant.this place is a must visit!.we ordered chicken fajitas that come in the lava rock (not the traditional ones) and a side of the hispanic corn.it was delicious and a plentiful serving.both were pretty good.

I arrived an hour before our reservation and sat at the bar.i ordered the sea bass but had to modify it because i am allergic to garlic.we went for lunch for restaurant week.:)and the plate ware is pretty dated.shared the sea bass, scallops main courses and a chocolate lava cake with 2 friends as we weren't too hungry.loved!the table shared an order of calamari to start.for second courses, you can't go wrong with the sea bass with hawaiian ginger scallion sauce.the second dish was warm butternut squash salad, which seems to be a very popular dish nowadays - while a nice dish, this was lacking both in presentation and seasoning.the only non-steak meal in our group was pad thai and my fellow diner really seemed to like it..

G.i'm from california originally so when i go to a new place i always look for 2 things: boba and boiling crab..the staff was very welcoming as we were seated right away since we came early (5pm).we also tried the calamari and chicken wings - both were great.we were very surprised how big the mussels were.if i was rating just the taste of the food, it would be a five.the restaurant was also a bit warm inside, but it might have been because they had just opened for the night so the ac hadn't been running for long when we arrived.lolthe dessert ice cream pop stand blew my mind!you can choose your own flavors and toppings.the crawfish fell on the little side though.

Roti has tons of outdoor seating, and on the bustling riverside plaza, its fun to do some people watching, mainly office drones and confused tourists getting off the metra.indecisiveness would make you feel like you're holding up an otherwise well-oiled engine.but the food?  wow.quick lunch place, better than mcd's, but equal in quality to the chipotle's of canada (which is not good in my books).worst falafel i have ever tasted!they are oily balls of who knows what.i didn't find any bathrooms here so i went through their back door to the adjacent starbucks.i have had a wide variety of items and been pretty happy with them.a refreshing combination for any given weekday loop lunch.it gets huge and it is amazing.definitely agree with katie b that this is the medditerreanian chipotle, but it's actually good unlike its mexican counterpart.

Our tour leader -- i was with a group of women in town for a conference -- organized a buffet lunch.3 1/2 stars isn't enough for this place, it was great!! we were seated quickly, i asked for a special beer flight and was accommodated without question..the side salad comes with a thin buttermilk ranch, so it brings flavor but keeps the salad healthy.great spot located right on michigan ave! the outdoor patio is amazing in the summer, with fire places and tvs.however, i am not a huge fan of this place.what keeps me coming back? convenience and those $10 & $15 spring rewards.service was great too! the interior is sleek and modern.the beer selection spans almost their entire back wall and there's all kinds of beers.i was a little disappointed with my visit here.

First thing that greets you when you get here is that wonderful truffle fries smell.-foie dog (didn't have any) but my husband said it was just alright.shrimp taco was covered in a red sauce that tasted like wasabi.they are byob! and yes i did bring my morning beers in with me when i came on sunday lol.i had the fried pork belly sandwich/banh mi.omar is so nice and works harder than anyone i know to give the best service around..the batter is not heavy so the flavor of the crab remains the star.i would've voiced out my issue but the place was packed that night so i just let it be.the ahi tuna taco is a lot of tuna so it's not for the casual seafoodie, the gyro taco is bomb, and the al pastor is nothing special.

My shrimp and cheesy grits with bacons and green onions was soul-fulfilling!  i've been craving for shrimp and grits (one of my favorite southern-food specialities) for quite some time.they're tech savvy, too, texting you when you're table is ready.when i arrived, the host was very friendly.i was disappointed.the host had a very nasty condescending tone, will never visit again.the music.the only thing i think they need help with is that buffet line! also the menu items are a little pricey too..we of course went to the buffet,they were still having breakfast and lunch was being offered also.return.

The bar was slow on a saturday night but the draft selection was nicei ordered the salmon brunch item when i came for brunch and it was excellent and perfect for a september morningi have not yet dined for lunch/dinner but i will make my way over soon!i noticed they have good happy hour specials too..for entrees we tried the steak frites & double cheeseburger.

It's located at a nice spot easy to find.they certainly deserve more attention than this.totally not spicy enough.i figured this was only going to solidify it's "hidden gem" status.a couple of things that i loved.not too spicy and good for a nice meal in the winter.the pork in garlic sauce was good but not great.she was very sweet.our server told us the chef has 6 restaurants in michigan and this is his first venture in chicago (so he definitely has his shit down).the interior seems new and very clean which i appreciated even though i was just patiently waiting at the entrance for my food to be made while secretly spying on what other people ordered.

And i'm the kind of guy who will try a drop of every sauce before the food comes out just because i love trying new sauces.like much else in the pilsen, it's a no-frills, great-grills hole in the wall place that serves mexican delights on the cheap.i like giving business to small establishments like this.my friend got the pastor, carne asada and fish tacos, and approved of all three.

I was pleasantly surprised by altiro.the mussels! they were good! i wasn't a big fan of the heavier sauce it came with but still good.the total with tip was $71.we've sat outside on the patio both times - the tables are high and we can fit the stroller in the available space.i will say our server was very good and accommodating and got that reason i almost went 4-star but the food was really just a 3 stars.

We tried both the veggie and the meat.we finally got in on friday and it was worth the wait.i feel bad for the chef, really.just way too many other places to eat at in the city!.service was solid - attentive and they brought my wife a small dessert.$60 dinner with essentially 4 appetizers and no drinks - minus.it is quite a small space but cute inside.this place has evolved and matured really nicely and i love coming here.we all enjoyed them and that's saying a lot with this group.i loved the cozy atmosphere.

Disappointed in this place after having great food at frontera.the city has way too much to offer!.we were there for brunch and really enjoyed the brunch menu, the guacamole  was especially good.the torta was gross!!! the cuban torta had way too much going on inside.walking down milwaukee trying to decide where i saw xoco, "hmm" i said, the reviews say good things about their aztec hot chocolate, so in i go.the food looked alright but i frankly don't even want to risk tasting it.chilaquiles and torreja (with bacon crumble) are so good they are the latino french toastthe margaritas were delicious..antique taco down the block has food just as good, at more reasonable prices, with friendly workers.the server promptly brought my dog a bowl of cold water which he enjoyed.

Would recommend if you're alone as their portions can be huge!*.i ended up ordering the eggs benedict and it was soooo good.the pancakes are huge, and covered in beautiful frosting, and so thick and juicy.the service and food is amazing and it's why i'm giving this place 5/5!.now that i live here, i still keep this place in rotation..lived them!.majority of their breakfast menu items are sweet options, which isn't exactly what i am always in the mood for.wait is long but take advantage of the area.cost:$12.

Solid spot for lunch in the loop with excellent service and lots of options.value: the staff is friendly, the food is delicious, and the portions are rather hearty, all add up to good bang for your buck.since it's opening, spotted monkey has worked out its kinks and is now in one of my favorite go-too's.overall, i was impressed with the flavors and the service, but the pricing is just too high for me to really go out and eat what i want.got it to go and called ahead.they explained their menus and were patient with my boo and i as we needed a bit of time to decide what we wanted.and last but not least is the puerto rican rice bowl with pork.it was good though the duck ensemble tasted a bit too subtle.a subtly spicy mayo completes the bahn mi.i'm afraid to write this review --- i don't want the lunch lines to get long.

Don't have 3 ceres.nothing could ever beat ceres.our appetizers were great and not overly priced.the waiters were great - really entertaining and nice, and if you chat with them you'll get a little something extra.basically it comes with alot of alcohol for its price.it was $9.most will run or hide - bad memories or they can't face the challenge.we got there around 4 and managed to get a spot on their outdoor patio.

The food was amazing, i always get nervous ordering food at sports bar kind-of-places but this was delicious.the chicago burger fared a bit better as there was a decent layer of marinara which melted the cheese, and while it didn't seem like much giardiniera it was actually a good amount to compliment the meat.thank you, theory for being reasonable!!service was prompt, and i like the atmosphere.solid bar food.5 stars for the food, 1 star for service.we ordered our son cheeseburger sliders and tater tots.for a river north spot, i though it was fairly cheap, the waitress was friendly, and t.no gimmicks, just free beers..very much an iowa bar and a basketball bar with other college football games taking a back seat.

The rice table via pitchfork, is by far the best thing to eat there!  i have yet to go to the byob pop up dinners at sip coffee house, but i'm dying to go after devouring deliciousness at pitchfork this year!!!..$15 for the meal was ok, but i felt that it really should have been a few dollars since the quality is on par with a neighborhood ethnic restaurant--good, but nothing remarkable.

Executive chef mario takes the time to personally walk the floor and welcome you during your meal.the desserts are awesome, and they usually are nothing that we have tried, well the twist part anyway.having one person take all of the orders was not efficient.i don't have a complex palette or array of descriptive words that foodies use to describe their culinary experiences, but let me just tell you: the food at this place is damn tasty.the servers were very nice and very attentive.it was a pretty ordinary cake served with ice cream on a nicely tarted-up plate.my bf said he'll just take it and we still had to pay for it.they were also out of a few things.between the chips, appetizers and entrees we were too stuffed for dessert, but mario was nice enough to send out a complimentary dessert.for entrees we ordered the pork chop which came with mango salsa (requested on the side), rice, beans, and veggies.

We booked a table at the cotton duck for dinner..3.i was really impressed by the flavor profile of all the dishes i tried and even more impressed that nothing was too oily or too salty.we finished with the red velvet cake and one of the other two desserts- i don't recall which one but by then we had all had a bit of wine.i can't wait to try out their spring menu.the mac and cheese was gooey and rich.lots of young good-looking people, but also a good number of well-aged foodies as well.the mushrooms and chard were also on point..

Their freshly baked bread is everything!!! everything we ordered was amazing!! can't wait to go back! our server was really sweet and recommended some dishes as well! such a pleasant experience! highly recommend!..my dinner was the patlicanli islim sarmasi, with chunks of lamb meat elegantly wrapped in eggplant, and a side of white rice.rarely, do i love deserts that much.we come here all the time because it's within walking distance.the chef/owner even came out to greet us.everyone was pretty happy with their main dishes.don't waste your money here!..for the main dish, i ordered lamb chops over a medley of vegetables consisting of potatoes, brussel sprouts, broccoli, mushrooms, and asparagus tips.

Didn't want salad for brunch.always delicious..our waiter was very knowledgeable.now for the meal- oh my goodness! multiple times throughout the meal we commented on how happy we were to stumble upon this place.just come out on their own (recco of the waiter) and it was perfect.others had the hangover breakfast and ham benedict.the strong aromatics of the bev did translate to its strength!service was punctual and fine for the most part, minus feeling like the waiter was trying to pressure us into ordering more drinks and dessert.i'm not sure what it's called.overall, i would love to try this spot for dinner, or again for brunch, but hopefully they can get their reservation issues fixed!.

They were just featured in the redeye and on one of the local news stations, and people came out in droves to try it out.it's a little gem of a shop.you have to put away your own dishes, which is fine, but i wish the garbage can had a better lid because it was almost impossible to throw away things without getting the schmear on the lid! i'd stop by again if i was in the area, but i'd definitely get something smaller.i also got a lemon, cayenne and agave fresh pressed juice, and my boyfriend tried the avocado tartine and a special coffee.after multiple rounds, we came to the conclusion that the kimchi schmear and chive schmear were the best.snaggletooth gets 5 stars with ease.small but absolutely fantastic seafood-centric menu (though not exclusively seafood) featuring house cured fish..while you can get it in chicago, it's not as common or popular.this place is the real deal!  come early because they sell out.
Would not be good for a romantic dinner or upscale service.it's true.

The menu was very easy to read and the prices were great.a friend suggested this place to me, knowing that i love crepes.second, if you request i call you to discuss my questions, (which you didn't read to begin with, obviously) don't give me a bad attitude.(it was ok, but nothing special).come here for great food and coffee and talk to some really cool people.stopped in here while running errands for a quick to-go latte.i loved that is was so warm and cozy even though it was freezing outside.the food even came out one by one.but my favorite part is that they have a really good expresso! will definitely be back.both were served wit ha side of sriracha.

Bummer.definitely get this.to focus on picking out the crab meat.the langostinos al ajo were amazing and they have a thousand salsas you can pick plus complimentary tostada! i also got a fish taco, oh god that tortilla and the fish was so flavorful.we ended up taking a small catering tray full of food home.as i return i will like to try smaller portions but the mega tray was awesome.in fact, writing this review makes me wanna come back and get that seafood combo platter!.the dishes that we ordered were good too.once you break off a big piece of crab, dip that sucker in the sauce, and sprinkle a little of the aforementioned salsa atop.i walk by this place a lot and it's always poppin'.

(bear in mind , you're here because the food is delicious not because you like the dropped ceilings  and banquet table decor )as soon as you sit ,each person at the table gets a ceviche tostada ( on the house).

Even though i arrived at the last minute at 9:30, they were very nice about seating me.the ricotta cheese made for one messy experience, but well worth it.the open oven leaves the crust done but very floppy so you hae to hold the whole pizza or every thing falls of.one thing that makes this pizza so great for me is the chewy crust that can hold out for the ride home to the burbs.the desert cupcakes are amazing! they are brought in from a local cupcake shop and are so good.and the service is great.pro tip: order one pizza at a time..cozy, out of the way pizza joints closer to the south sydeeee are always welcome and this place is a definitely a gem.the cheese topping looked a little different than the sausage pizza.

Had the sandwich combo with the truffled egg salad sandwich which was very good- rich yet light, well  seasoned.mild and inoffensive flavors, my anchovy salad was a sea of whitish romaine ribs with 3 small anchovies and two dead cold premade toast pieces encrusted with congealed cheese, also cold.i ended up with a lighter meal by selecting the gigot d'agneau (sliced leg of lamb, grilled onion, watercress, rosemary aioli) as other's commented the onion was way too much and had to be removed from the sandwich, but otw the lamb was cooked well and the seasoning went well with the protein.i do like the decor, very french-y..my wife and i have been here a number of times considering its close proximity to our old apartment.walking into an open front restaurant with paintings of flowers and humans hung on mustard yellow walls, we felt quite welcomed by both the homely decor and friendly staff.pretty good! nothing too special, but it was a relaxed place for sunday brunch...

This was my first visit.awesome coffee and an awesome avocado toast brightened my morning when i stopped by ancien cycles.these aren't things i really care about, but feedback that someone probably will complain about in the future -- the milk foam has been sort of weak and not super thick- the hot espresso drinks get cold too fast, for whatever reason.
Went back 12/26/14 and even more fabulous than before!..sake and sushi were delish..

Just loved this place!.so i got corn!!!! yet the food was pretty good.the food wa delicious and the jalapenos were hot.i highly recommend this place if you want something super authentic, and as a finicky latino who loves his latin foods, this is as good as it gets.

Impressive mixture of cafe items and meat items, i had the chicken n green mole sandwich and rice, and also a chocolate banana muffin, all were really good, i really wanna go back and try more bakery items..i ordered the matcha latte which was okay, i would try something different next time i go there for the waffle.first time here today- i have to say it was pretty decent.i felt like i got short shrift because of it.i believe the wifi here is free, for first two (2) hours with a passcode..

We also had the yassa chicken and the curry lamb.i had the snapper, it was pretty pricey considering, but was very delicious and they do have other kinds of fish for cheaper options.i was so greatful to have tried this food and i will take a trip to the resturant when i return to chicago.so i was glad i stumbled upon this place during one of my yelp searches.im so glad they relocated.djolof rice are a must have- tasty, but i think flavored with red palm oil (and pretty oily).i also got a side of carrots and cabbage.just good home cooking.put it, "this tastes like sweetened creme fraiche soaked grape nuts..

Jim's, i need to seriously stop going to see you.classic chicago polish and pork chop sandwich! i've had way too many polishes and pork chop sandwiches in my life, and this place is on point.a place open 24/7, cheap meats, awesome fries, what else can you ask for?you pay 5-10 bucks for pretty much a full meal, i got to try the fish, polish sausage, and the pork chop, with their fries.would love to come back and try the pork chop sandwich.done.the polish sausage was tough and onions were greasy.i was so thoroughly disappointed to end my chicago trip with this mediocre food.80 tax included plus fries.

Five stars hands down.instead of running right out to buy some lunch, i've decided to internet stalk zeus.i got the mixed plate: gyro, grilled chicken, salad, pita, all on a bed of fries!   all in it was under 10 bucks..let me say that i was quite hangry (hungry + angry) as it was taking a really long time for the food to be done the first time i came here..well seasoned meat.food was ok nothing special.so i'm on a hunt for the best gyro in chicago since i have had a hard time finding one that measures up to my hometown standard.incredibly, $7 for the combo at zeus (gyro loaded to the hilt, what amounts to a small order of mcdonald's salty fries and nearly uncarbonated rc cola) is hefty compared to the prices at niko's/falafel, where i can get out for $6 depending on when i go and the combo i order.

Despite the prices, i was going to give forno a 4 star review just based on the food until my friend and i went to pay our bill.it's only been open for 6 weeks so it seems to be pretty under the radar.we settled on the carbonara pizza and it was so delicious.went in for a late weekday lunch.the carbonara was great, although the egg was disappointingly overcooked and not sunnyside up, but we were too hungry to send it back.it tasted like i was in italy having authentic food.the staff is friendly and accommodationi will bring friends and recommend !.simple but satisfying.talk about some true italians that know how to make some goooood pizza!!.loved the sauce and sausages on the locale pizza.

I've tried a few things.would i be back? maybe.i'm glad this place is so close to my home base, as i will be a frequent visitor..if you're in the area and don't mind being momentarily stuck to the floor, pop on in!.we asked our waitress for water for three people and only got one glass.they just know how to put a burger together.plenty of chicken and not all lettuce like other places.the location is conveniently located between state and michigan, easily accessible by the l..

But again, the food both times was stupendous.the chicken was spiced tastily in the wraps, and the chicken salad was okay.the yogurt sauce was great, very fresh and not overly seasoned.accommodates everyone, and byob.we just finished our meals and i think it was the quietest meal of our lives..i like being able to see the kitchen where they're cooking, but it looks a bit like a take-out counter.salmon though wasn't to my liking; weird extra fishy/deep see spoiled fish taste..

Great spot for after work tapas or a full meal!came here with a friend and got a mix of both..restaurant week menu was delicious, filling, and a great value for $44!tapasjamon and manchego croquettes--very good as an appetizer/snack! they're delicious but no heavy.i recently had a lovely lunch at salero, just on the western edge of the loop.as the host warned me, they "go down like water...fried deliciousness.but the service at salero was not commensurate with the prices.

My only gripe with the place is that it is cash only, other than that it's perfect.when the second batch of chips came out i couldn't stop eating that.i wasn't really expecting much from them.owner is suuuuper cool! his name is also gabriel too so i'll never forget his name.safe pick, but there are many options that are similar.the beans were decent and was the only thing that tasted authentic on my plate, but were still not what i'm used to.it was very thick and loaded with garlic (i love garlic)..but the staff are super-friendly and welcoming, and the food is terrific -- good solid mexican, with no pretense of ultra-authenticity but with just enough realness to let you know they care in the kitchen..

This is a good spot for me to get some mega-work done while i'm waiting for my oil to be changed down the road.also, the sides of potato salad and pasta salad are really small.girls go to mars to get candy barsboys go to jupiter to get more stupiderah wait - no.once someone brought 2 dogs and they weren't on a leash and they ran around the place.dig the vibe.free wi fi, friendly staff, great coffee drinks and food, comfortable place..it was the perfect day to sit inside but right next to the outside area and feel the breeze.also, it took forever for then to make! eventually, my colleague had to go back there and ask them what was going on - then they brought it right out.this is an interesting cafe located in a trendy warehouse-y part of town.

Other than the food, there seemed to only be a few employees present while we were there, but our server was kind and efficient.and their grape leaves stuffed with race and beef with that homemade yogurt sauce was an amazing choice! a very large order and it is made to order and baked to order, so you have to wait a little bit for it, but so so good! i paired that with their lentil soup which i honestly wished the bowl had been bigger because it was that addicting.3-4 tapas selections for two people was plenty for us.i adored the 2nd floor seating (all reserved, unfortunately) and patterned upholstered chairs.super delicious platter, especially with the garlic sauce (not sure if it was garlic butter, lard, but addictive good).the hummus was flavorful but was impossible to finish with the amount of pita they gave us (so we asked for another basket).the restaurant itself is beautifully designed and the vibe is a causal yet elegant space.i thought that was odd and sure enough, my wife claimed that her proportion was off.i had the mediterranean mojito and i didn't care for it much.we ordered falalfal( kinda mushy on the inside although looked well done), chicken kebabs  were good, lamb shank( had way too much sauce ruining the flavor) and their onion flat bread.

We sat at a rounded large booth right in front of the all star game (how did they know?!)..and by trees i don't mean the ones at rainforest cafe, i mean well made ones that dont look tacky.a must try!!! i can't wait to come back.i also tried the prosciutto omelet, which was delicious and flavorful.at first we were told it would be a 45 min wait, but then a table for four opened up serendipitously.it's basically a wood fired pizza place with river north prices.i think we'll give this place another try because the food was really good but the service needs a lot of work.we also felt a little rushed out of there the minute we were done eating but not drinking.it's straight up a meal.

All very tasty! also love the fufu - a side dish of mashed plantains.i also loved the chivo (goat stew), beef enchilada, and coconut mojito.we were appreciative that he told us which dishes were going to be dry (no one wants dry chicken!).stopped by randomly for lunch one weekend day.and parking they have an agreement with the lot across from them later in the day, otherwise, street parking wasn't too bad at all.the regular and coconut flans topped off our meal.very nice atmosphere inside and the menu has a lot of choices - all of which look delectable! we didn't try the rum bar and hope to do that next time when we have more leisure time to enjoy all that paladar has to offer.like the terminator "i'll be back! ".it took about 10 minutes just for our waiter to come to the table and then another 10 for our drinks to come.

Ordered here again as neighborhood recommendations were still pouring in and still quite underwhelmed.we'll certainly have to return as soon as the weather starts warming up, thank you again!best,charlie.warning:  very hot in this place is not the white washed american version of really spicy.it was ready 15 mins after i called in, which is exactly what i'm looking for in a carryout situation- i don't like to have to wait very long.i had the best pad se iew ever at opart.great place for take out or dine in..i also noticed a glass roof and was hoping that meant it could be opened in the summer.spring rolls were fresh.cooked to perfection.

By the time we were finishing dinner, we were the only ones in there, which i didn't mind because we were celebrating the holidays and had a white elephant exchange going.tender skirt steak cooked to order, nice peppery seasoning, on a bed of sauteed corn+onion+potato+bacon mixture....2.the flavor of the steak and the potatoes were to die for.the service was great both times we went.it's kinda pricey.while i tend to always want to try new places, i definitely want to come back here soon for dinner again or brunch.

They were fairly cold and weren't as flavorful as they should've been.step 2 - sit down and wait for our food.when it's ready, the girl brought the freshly brew to him table and greeted him just like everyone else despite the unfavorable odor.you can order any salad as a sandwich and vice versa.-----------------------(total= $21.food is delicious and freshly made and put together in front of you.i can't say enough good things about this place.btw, i had to take a later lunch because this thing was so filling!will i come back? absolutely! my mouth is watering just thinking about that biscuit sandwich.i also got a big oatmeal raisin cookie, which was a bit hard.there is a full coffee station and a small cup of the drip is available for $1.

Love the fire-grilled steak burrito!!..i ordered 4 steak burrito bowls through grubhub for myself and friends.i came here tonight with family..we ordered the tortilla crusted tilapia and fire grilled steak tacos with a side of elote, which is a corn hash.we came to the area to go elsewhere to satisfy our mexican craving but for some reason, at 8 on a saturday night they were closed.i've only been here 3 times and i'm addicted! the place is just off of chicago and there are a lot of cars coming going for pick up/delivery.the horchata was a little too sweet for my taste, but my friend (who is half mexican) said it was legit, so i guess his vote wins.

The fried chicken taco that i've seen so many people rave about on yelp is just bland as can be, but otherwise, the portions are generous and would definitely come back solely for the $8 boot, shot and taco deal.s.we came for a late brunch or early lunch on sunday and our waitress lauren i think was honestly one of the best waitresses i have had in a long time.i love the option to have a couple tacos but then have some southern comfort food! besides the tacos, i recommend the mac n' cheese and the cornbread! they also have a pretty sweet deal for 1 taco, a boot beer and shot for $8!i have yet to join in for brunch but last weekend they had a bluegrass band play inside the restaurant! hopefully i can check it out next time! all in all if you're around the neighborhood pop in the general!.the vibe here is cool too.but if you're looking for a quiet place to hide after a long friday/saturday night, just know and prepare for the live music.great tacos, tasty sides and try the pie! if you aren't sure about a cocktail, ask for a recommendation.in most restaurants, that'd be a $45-$60 bottle..a great, neighborhood joint.

Nice looking bar located by pequods at the webster clyborn intersection, i thought they'd have a bit more wide beer selection, but the beer i got was still good, very dark mood lighting, kinda hard to see..- not too crowded--at least later on a thursday nightlowlights:- don't be fooled by the pool in back signs: it's a pool tablewasn't expecting much and we loved it here.

2 in the kitchen and 2 out.somehow i think my piece was not as good as the other people's..but the best part was how she told us to eat the dishes, i.gps brings you right too it and so will a taxi.it was exceptional.and of course, the food was awesome and inventive.from the first bite to the last chef jake's creativity was on display.however, literally every seat is the best seat because you are sitting at the kitchen counter..

Not only did we have some amazing eats, but we were also the recipients of five star service from a lovely gentleman server (wish i remembered his name but it's been a while!).they have great bakery items as well..there are some nice selections on the wine list, and the service was friendly yet professional.finish off your meal with a delicious stan's donut..- sausage & pepper pizza: was hands down the best thing i ate here.the ingredients were so fresh! the breads were freshly baked! the flavors were true to each ingredient chosen.i loved the restaurant decor and general feel of the place.

This place was fairly busy even after dinner rush hour, i didn't feel like waiting 20 minutes so we sat at the sushi bar.i ordered the chicago roll and it was beautifully presented and very yummy.i got the spicy roasted garlic pork ramen.i come here every time i visit chicago, and when i do, its for the winter ramen.i came here with a friend on a friday night at around 8 and it was so busy! being out of towners, we put our names down regardless to get seated.it was a frigid (to me) 35 degrees and i wanted something that would soothe my soul a bit.it wasn't terrible but it certainly wasn't worth the $13+ price tag..the garlic flavor was not overbearing.very good sushi spot downtown.

Also they were really hard to eat because the tables were kind of awkward and limited so eating in can get weird since you kind of are expected to share a table with strangers.not much to be said.in addition to wings, crisp also offers rice bowls; however, i would not recommend getting them here.crispiest chicken ever..i do slightly prefer the southern style of extremely crisp skin, and soft and juicy insides.two thumbs way up!.but i wasn't wowed.or just take-out! must also compliment the exquisite kim-chi..

This place has a place in my heart.the chicken taco was pretty delicious as was the elote.we ate once..i'm glad i tried them at the taste, but when i went to the actual restaurant it was a different story.like double the price of a regular mexican joint.one of them was the fish tacos and that became my favorite fish taco place.if i'm not ordering some tilapia tacos, the chicken burrito is just as good.at the end of the day, i thought it was just okay.m.
Love their pig ears! it's the best!!!..

I got the brisket platter - half lean and half fatty (i appreciated that they asked what cut i'd like) - slathered in chicago-style sauce with mac & cheese and cornbread.i didn't care for the chicago style with the old style beer in it.and don't let "bbq" deter you, as you can get very tasty options that aren't bbq-heavy and send you to an afternoon slumber as you try to do some work.all the flavor comes from the sauce that they put on (i had memphis style because duh) and the sauce wasn't even that flavorful.it had real sweet corn in it!this was the 2nd time my office ordered lunch from here and i have never been at the store so i can't speak for service or ambiance.he warned us that it wasn't a huge space so we decided to try to make it there by 11:45 to beat the lunch rush.if the owner happens to be reading this post).so i thought maybe we were onto something.we both chose the chicago style sauce.the mac and cheese was pretty good and definitely fresh out of the oven - good crust and rich cheesiness, although i would have liked a little more spice.
Don't forget to try the spicy and sticky chicken wings!..we tried out the new location over the summer - the space was nicely decorated and clean.

First, our waiter was outstanding.i don't eat seafood at all or meat for the that matter.on-point from start to finish, a really great meal.it's a very traditional old style chicago place-not haute cuisine or trendy new stuff.i had to take some home! unfortunately, i do not live close to this place so i can't say i'd return as often as i would like to.the food is excellent as is the wine list..the dining room is relatively small -- about 16 tables -- with lovely wood paneling, soft lighting, and stucco upper walls and ceiling.i'm a hard core northsider, but the next time i'm in the mood to get my italian grub on, i'm making a road trip to the south side.real, authentic, traditional italian is becoming harder to find as contemporary italian and contemporized traditional italian are currently on trend.

I tried the german chocolate cake and it was decent.even my toaster at home has a bagel setting so that only the inside gets toasted.eat here!!.kugel is really great, and a tasty knish as well.(smh) this has really made me sad.everything inside of me really wanted to enjoy this historic chicago deli.its not to sweet which is good.first, stop on your way in to read the sign showing the day's specials, then pick up tray and utensils and join the line..this place is an institution so eat here!.

+good portion size.went here for brunch with the parents and everyone enjoyed their meal.you totally get the family vibes from this restaurant from the second you walk in.but this place had some interesting items.this place is great for breakfast all day.played hooky from the office one day and before snatching up a case or so of wine at nearby binny's in lakeview, decided to go live inside of one of the many wonderful early 80's style music videos while having a completely unhealthy but utterly delicious breakfast here.we ordered it and it definitely lived up to the hype.we came here with a group on a sunday morning.stella's is quickly becoming one of my favorite places to eat.

We started out with 3 orders of bruschetta, which was very good! i love the taste of the tomato and the bread.i don't know.candle lit dinner, and live music.very quaint little place on the way from ogilvie to the united center.thomas aquinas red wine and has even ordered 3 bottles online..it's not a big place, so i wouldn't suggest a huge party, but it's great for a date or an intimate dinner with friends.for the apps we went with the bacon wrapped dates and they were the perfect combination of sweet and salty.there are regular dining tables, couch seating, hi-tops and a fireplace along with the bar.very good food and nice size portions.

I must say, this neighborhood has really come a long way baby!  anyway, i finally stopped into this new dig and i really enjoyed it!  great build out, well executed menu and great staff!  i don't think there's more that you can ask for from a corner bar!  drop in and grab a seat at the bar you won't be disappointed.we ordered moscow mules which were delicious and shared the mac and cheese..i ordered the southwest breakfast wrap and a bloody mary while my friends had the biscuits and gravy, bit skillet, and some other things that i can't remember (lol).the service was also friendly and fast.very disappointing that all they did was add a telephone booth and changed the face of this place.were cooked well and had great flavor."so we place an order..the staff is awesome.

A bit understaffed for the middle of the work day, but possibly busier at night? flavors were vibrant and the hot coconut cakes were a novel dessert experience of crispy burnt edges, gooey sweet centers, and contrast from corn kernels and savory diced scallions.not supper spicy but full of salvor.

But in a good way.i haven't tasted anything i didn't like.even have a usual already, veggie omelet and pancakes.very small but it has that home like feel to it.it's probably a place for all the cops to eat at as there were nearly 7 or 8 while we were there.and i'm so glad we did!we arrived around 10am and the wait was about 25 minutes!**they close at 12 on saturday so get in before 11.this is a good spot to hit if youre in the area!!!! portions are huge and food is good.this place rocks! back to the truly old school diner mentality.however, as long as you were courageous enough to walk in, you would walk out satisfied and feeling "fly.i always thought it was just our family, but it seems eating breakfast anytime of day is a long standing tradition throughout the city.

If i hadn't been on a sunday walk to additional yelper favorites, i would have definitely bellied up to the bar to try a few more types of vittles.that being said, this is still a great place to grab a bite to eat.you don't see that type of service anymore.what a cute and awesome spot!! puesto is a little sandwich cafe hidden near wrigley that i am so happy i found! they have delicious food - we got a cuban sandwich and a veggie torta and both were really good.it's no wonder puesto has a perfect rating on yelp at the time i'm writing this.they were delicious! felt authentic and flavorful, mmmmm mmm yes please.at 7pm with no one else waiting, the wait was close to 30 minutes for 3 arepas and a sandwich.the people who work here, the decor, the food - everything is just top notch.i really wanted to like this place more because i love arepas and i miss them from florida.

I would come back just to have drinks and dessert.it was melt-in-your mouth with mushroom stroganoff and hazelnuts.given the fact that it's quite new, getting reservation on saturday night was actually not too excruciating.i will be back but i'll try a different meat entree next time..none of the selections listed under segundo or asado include starch or vegetable.

Their multigrain baguette(which they source from a european baker in river north/gold coast) is awesome to go with the cheeses.it was very hard and everyone that ordered a sandwich agreed that the bread gave their mouth a work out.i cannot say enough good things about this place.the wait can be long so be prepared (that is what knocked off a star).i was torn between the southpaw (pimento cheese) and tuna salad so, at staff recommendation i got tuna salad topped with pimento cheese.it was pretty tasty - though nothing outstanding.the san daniele has san daniele prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, oven-roasted tomatoes and housemade pesto.if you can afford the nice cheeses then this is more the place for you!.delicious cheese, sandwiches, and salads! perfect for loop lunch to go (only a 4 top inside) or for noshing at millennium park.our party opted for the sinfully healthy and grant park grinder sandwiches.

Very friendly staff, the food was just missing something.thereafter, my husband ordered the meatloaf, daughter ordered the braised short ribs with a side of crispy kale, and i ordered the prosciuto wrapped pork loin with a side of sweet potato mashed and grilled seasonal veggies (zuchhini both green and yellow).so, it is getting a five based upon the area.then i got the braised short rib and it was enormous! the meat was tender and fell off the bone, it was fantastic.i had the pork loon carrots and potato strings which was good and the server left is alone for the most part.must try here.we came on a friday night and it was empty..i found it to be a bit salty.

I am glad i found this place, it will definitely be added to my list of go to places for delicious italian beef sandwiches.really nice guys who work there, and it's almost like a hole-in-the-wall type of place..

Let's face it.respect restored!.again, don't judge! love love love the super fresh chili..the burger was a pile of turkey patty, philly cream cheese and cranberry reduction sitting atop a 100% whole wheat roll.my burger was a little pricey it was almost $20 for a combo, but probably because it was bigger, my mom's was 6oz and $13 for a combo.there are many components to a good buger, but one of the most important is the beef itself.i'm so disappointed and because it was bought for me and my only lunch in a meeting i'm forced to eat this dry, tasteless, sorry for an excuse burger.hot damn man, your burger rocks!i ordered the 12oz burger point burger which comes with roasted chile peppers, cage-free fried egg, double smoked bacon, pepperjack on a pretzel roll.

They do have lots of pizza and few pasta options as well..our friend barely had a chance to sit down and a get settled when she was already asking if we were ready to order.plenty of vegetarian options.the spinach fondue is sinfully decadent, and comes with a buttery flatbread for dipping.i asked our waitress about it, and she didn't say anything because they were about to leave by that point.the $17 pizza was extremely small (the size of a personal pizza) and the beet salad was just ok.seasoned so well.i was in heaven.my friend who had been previously said they were a little off the evening we were there.

Great overall service and experience.plenty to like, but some stingy practices prevent it from being 5 stars..the food was delicious, i thought the brisket was very tender and they give you a very large portion that will fill you up.the meat was awesome.the elotes was the equivalent of cold corn salad..no explanation necessary.i had the brisket platter with some mac and cheese.everything is either a sandwich a platter or whatever.

Very clean and organized as well.do not order..very helpful when it came to ordering.cochinita is great!the old portage is now cochinita and it brings a community style dining vibe to the northwest part of the city..we sat outside..cochinita = a hidden gem in chicagoi went to have dinner to cochinita this past weekend and i was truly impressed by their drinks and tacos..

They were talented and the music was at a reasonable level.were 15 minutes to early but were seated right away.for the entree we had a whole fire roasted fish.it was a little bit pricey but good meat tends to be and i also enjoyed the restaurant decor.came here for weekend blues brunch and it was so much fun! the band was great and created a fun and relaxing atmosphere.i'd checked out the menu ahead of time and at the restaurant.i wanted beef, she wanted chicken.i got an ipa.this definitely makes for a very great experience in chicago for locals and tourists alike.river roast has an awesome location right on the river.

The price and food you get for it was worth it.anyway, costa rican food is a favorite of mine; it's a really underrated cuisine that deserves more attention, and irazu does it better than just about anyone..i'm just going to stick to my costa rican favorites here in the burbs.i do wish that the yucca fries had come with ketchup (that's how they served them when i was in costa rica, usually with mayo too), but they were tasty with the garlic dip.they also offered pitchers of fruit-flavored mixers if you bring in your alcohol of choice, which i think we'll take advantage of next time.delicious!!! f*** what u heard the pepito is well worth the price.the oatmeal shake was as expected--delicious! i loved it and it was so refreshing.i went back to irazu recently for dinner and was very pleased with everything.

Chef welch's menu & cocktails are fresh, perfectly prepared & served by a flawless staff.the lamb tartar was not my favorite dish.the space is very cool and the service was good, but the food missed the mark for us.we started with the hamachi - cucumber, grape, finger lime,verjus, pickled onion.

Every course - outstanding.for dessert, i'd definitely recommend the butterscotch!  the butterscotch sorbet is smooth and refreshing on a warm summer day and complemented by the stout cake and nuts.we had the small bread course, two charcuteries, and the fabulous mussels (a must have!).hm, this was a miss unfortunately.looking forward to returning and trying the raved about chicken skins and perhaps a nice steak.we also ordered the bread basket (which was delicious) along with the accompanying condiments.my favorite items, the chicken skins and oxtail croquettes, both have since been replaced with other items.the service delays weren't entirely the fault of the staff (who were very friendly and knowledgeable) as they were dealing with a couple of parties of 5-8 gentlemen who reeked of pretense and in addition to being verbally and visibly demanding, were borderline rude to the staff.likewise a dessert titled honey, while decent, also featured other flavors far more prominent than honey.the grand opening is in mid july.

They have a massive menu with about any thai related dish you could imagine..so yeah i won't be going back here.of the infinite thai joints in the city, this place is my favorite.i suppose that means the experiences were not traumatic.to mix up your noodle game, try the sweet and savory golden (egg) noodles or the wide clear noodles in the pad khee mao.they deliver fast and the food has been very fresh each time we've ordered.it was so weird.service has been friendly each time too.within an hour of eating the prik pao noodles, i had crazy stomach cramps, followed by a diarrhea avalanche.

Frying and putting cheese inside a deviled egg just seemed gimmicky to me.but after i finally had an eye contact with the bartender, i got help right away.sadly, i don't think it's on the current menu anymore)overall, the food is amazing so try everything but be prepared for the wait, the tight seating, and the loud atmosphere :).the atmosphere is pretty chill and laid back and the service was great.the meatballs were tender and flavorful.of course we also had their famous bone marrow smear with crusty bread which was every bit as good as everyone says.:).but it actually took 30 minutes.loukoumades- who knew fried dough could taste so elegant? perfect way to end the meal.flavor was there but marrying flavors was a fail.

And the price is righ.it's nothing to really write home about.both were pretty tasty, but for the price of almost 10 bucks (including a small drink) i feel like i was a bit shorted for what i got.it has a large selection (subs, pasta, pizza, italian beef, salads) which helps out especially when you're bringing a work group there for lunch.they have some daily specials (part of the menu-reading i was doing in line).second visit we tried meatball sandwich and chili..decent lunch spot.i am obsessed with the napoli (it might be my favorite sandwich of all time, which is really quite a statement! lol) they have pizzas, pastas, salads, sammies, pasta salads, soup, etc etc.i've also had their caprese sandwhich which is also very good and very filling.

The mac and cheese was great, the coleslaw was so so, and the corn muffins were alright.rib tips and brisket with tangy carolina barbeque sauce.the corn muffin is great too, not too greasy and lots of corns in it, which i really like.prices are right and service was great too.great music, cozy room for dancing.that's a lot of meat!- a rack of ribs!- two brisket sliders! (don't let the word "sliders" throw you....

Upon entering you'll be greeted with a small complimentary "shot" of their lentil soup to warm you up..yes, i'll be back!.i'm a customer for life after that added bonus!.my bf had the falafel which he liked and i had the shwama..first of all, for $5.really liked the home made dough.i'm not mediterranean person so i might ignorant of how i eat this food but i go where i have had it the best an how i like to eat it, why i love this country.i always find myself wanting that at home.

And not one pasta dish is over $13 except.they only had 1 waiter when i came on a tuesday for lunch but maybe they'll get more staff once it gets busier.it was perfect.great place for lunch or dinner in a pinch!.i'd be open to come back and try something new..the bread was lightly toasted with melted cheese on top and served with generic marinara sauce.this one was particularly good though..we were naughty and had the tiramisu for dessert.

I got the black betty burger, my husband got the special burger "van the man", and we split a belly fry.a cookie!!! heck yes!.truly..i purchased the groupon which overall saved me like 5.brgr belly is one of those kind of places.the burger is the best i've ever had! the bun and fries makes all the difference in the world.but i do not love this place.homemade buns topped with white and black sesame seeds was a nice touch and definitely held up to all the sauce slop!amazing grace burger with carolina bbq sauce, fried onions and pork belly was our favorite, the sauce was sweet and delicious.they do have a small patio, and i did like that i saw people of all ages and all races enjoying this place.

Yes, it is a little more expensive than other churro places & it is a little hidden but the place has some of the freshest; least greasy churros i've had in a while!  their fillings rock & they even make cafe con leche like grandma used to make & funnel cakes too!  my mom brought me here a while ago & i have only gotten to go a handful of times but each time i do go, i go prepared to spend & get fat!  my fav churro so far is their apple filled one  ; )..the vanilla cream tasted like cream cheese, a bit tart.and i would find that there is a xocoatl in logan square.i got a churro sundae with mint chocolate chip ice cream and chocolate syrup.first time, good experience.they have different fillings such as vanilla, chocolate (my personal fav), strawberry, cream cheese, nutella, etcthe girl that works there needs to smile a little more and be more chatty since she is the restaurant industry but other than that the place is awesome.hot, lightly rolled in sugar with yummy filings like custard and jelly.i'm glad i came across this place...

I've seen their food trucks at various events around chicago but have yet to give them a try.i substituted the chips for hush puppies and paid two dollars more.they were good, not too memorable one way or another.i am intrigued by the genghis khan, but also feel that it would be disrespectful to lobster..great spot and they are executing it well!.i ordered the traditional lobster roll, hot, with extra meat (when i asked him how much was extra meat he said it was double the amount!).i'll be back when there's another groupon deal.the guy working the front was very attentive and kept checking in on us even though he was kept pretty busy with other tables, take out orders, and cleaning, he was so efficient and while he was busy, we never felt like the service suffered..

If i had to rank them the pate would probably come last, but that didn't stop me from eating it all and scraping the last bit off the board.as soon as you walk in you will see why everyone loves this place.i've been here multiple times for a variety of reasons.even when there is a wait i love looking around their little store at all the awesome cooking specialities they have! it is great on a  cold rainy day to grab a seat inside, get the caramel creme tea and soup!.the ribs were so tender and also very delicious.this breakfast blew me away.i love meat of all types and grades.i've taken sandwiches to go and have had such unpleasant experiences at the register its made me not wanna return for them tasty grubs.i ordered the spinach and potato soup because it was raining the day we came here.it was big and good, came with a side pony of beer (rickenbocker i think).

But i eventually choose the french toast and it was superb! as i write this review i am trying to think back on the food.the menu had lots of exciting brunch selections and it was really hard to choose.my friend created her own skillet and topped it with sunny side up eggs.the pancakes were some of the best i've ever had---so light and fluffy with great flavor.we had breakfast here on a saturday morning in february.the pancakes were fluffy and the fresh were ultra fresh and sweet.this dish was just about exactly how you'd expect a bowl of quinoa, fruit & nuts to taste! not the most amazing dish i've ever had but it was exactly as expected and helped me feel a little more healthy than alternative options i could have ordered.both were fresh and delicious, and our waiter was extremely attentive with quick service.overall is was okay but not sure i would return quickly.the portion size was big so i only ate half, but i could have easily finished it if i was hungrier.

I was full of tasty fresh food for only $5.i have been coming to the refectory regularly since february and i still maintain that the folks here serve the best breakfast/ lunch in hyde park.you get an amazing meal for the price, you won't find a better deal in chicago.so get there early for the best results!like all the other reviews have mentioned, everything is homemade and all the produce is fresh.

O)not a fan of the sweet potato dumplings which were unnecessarily oily.i got the phat noodle, which was decent enough, as were the maple-glazed mini donuts.in my group of three girls, 2/3 finished their whole portion, plus we shared 2 orders of dumplings.we also ordered a passionfruit lemonade.i'm an urbanbelly fan.those were good.i absolutely loved this dish, as well!not often do you find a grand opening running as smooth as urbanbelly's did yesterday, only a testament to chef bill kim's well-oiled restaurant group machine in this city.the food isn't bad..

If you buy something and don't like it, you're sol.i had the spiritual grapefruit and it was quite yummy although i was disappointed by the size for the price.it's a never-ending cycle -- breakfast, lunch, dinner repeat and by the end of day one i'm feeling gross.yes,  a little pricey..not a restaurant but a few stools to eat in and peoplewatch.there was a small refrigerated section that had juices, salads, parfaits, cakes, ketchup and sauerkraut.delicious!i also grabbed a green juice and the raw "egg" salad.it wasn't as good as i expected and i was super hungry.

The lunch combo was great option so i can try multiple menu items.i gotta say, they have definitely stepped up their game in my book! really looking forward to seeing how this place develops with time.it's fluffy and lends itself to the wonderful ingredients of this homemade  tasting concoction.i'd definitely come back here whenever i'm in the neighborhood as i can finally say that i have a place i like for lamb biryani.looking forward to another encounter pretty soon.the paneer was soft and melted in your mouth.last time i stopped in, it looked like they were expanding their dining room and providing more seating options, which is nice, but i will likely primarily utilize their take-out.which is why i felt bad.despite the near perfect rating, i have to say that i don't think this place is revolutionary or that it is the epitome of perfected indian cuisine..

We normally wait a little bit before we would get our water refilled, but it's definitely not that bad.finally, the dry chili chicken is very good but very very spicy.it's a nice complement to mapo tofu, in that you can sauce your white rice with both a sweet and a spicy element.everything was tasty, and it made my first trip to chinatown memorable and delicious..she offered to get us another order and make it less spicy.must have if you are in groups of 3 or more.i would give 3.this led to about ten minutes of awkward standing around, trying to get the attention of an employee and essentially being ignored, until the host appeared.i was hot to begin with when i sat down, so when i started sampling this dish, the steam literally rose from my scalp fogging up my reading glasses.

Everything was fresh and tasty.i didn't mind the sweet part, though i found it slightly strange.why?.i didn't expect much given the restaurant's decor (it's nothing bad, but just very basic), but my dish turned out to be so good that i kept on wanting to come back! the chicken was super tender, and the salad was great, too.the sidewalk seating was open, but i wasn't in the mood to hear the rush-hour traffic honking on wabash and the green and orange lines rattling overhead.very impressive!! if you want something that's super delicious and healthy, beezzee is the spot for you.so it was a brunch buffet and the food was alright.i kept eyeballing the list of dessert crepes and something tells me i will probably be back before the year is over to have one of those!my friends all ordered wraps - i got to try some of the chicken in them, and a side of mashed potatoes - all were very tasty!  i was looking at the food others around me had ordered and the salads were of decent size, so i will probably be back to try one of those as well.as a final insult she forgot to make my fresh juice..

I really like this concept and would recommend it to any business-type suit looking for a trendy and delicious lunch on the go.i liked the additions at the end like the veggies and garlic mayo sauce.the portions are generous.we had a great fast dinner here! falafel was  great.overall i highly recommend this place!!.a pity can certainly serve you for lunch, but if you want to get the most bang for your buck i'd go for the hummus bowl(get rice in it too!).the pita was also soft and fluffy, almost but not quite able to contain the heaping piles of veggie and falafel goodness contained therein.my mother wouldve loved it! ! soooo good,  i wish they would expand this to virginia beach,  my fiance amd mother would frequent this place! !! the employees at this particular location were awesome too.they had a few sauces..

Maybe it's not as metal as kuma or as hardcore as lockdown, but i think burger bar has the best lean-to-fat ratio in its burgers, gluten-free buns for my friends, and appropriate sizing and excellent toppings for burgers that are just right.the ambience is great, the decor is inviting, the food is delicious, the server emily was patient with me while reviewing the tasty menu and on point.from what i hear, their burgers are pretty good.this burger joint is great aside from the prices.also- the tempura battered green beans are a must have! if you leave hungry you did something wrong..worth a try, but not a repeat.i'm actually planning on picking some up from binny's next weekend, so thanks for introducing me to that, burger bar.it has been a little over a year since my last visit and you have gone downhill.they did run out of their specialty shake so one of my friends couldn't order one which was unfortunate.

With that said, i have no complaints, as the low overhead keeps the prices really low.i watched the guy in the back hand toss each batch of wings in order to get each batch perfectly coated.75th street and i need to take a break.everyone get over there! seriously!!!!.10 were american lemon pepper, and 10 were jamaican mango jerk..i tried the buffalo, cheesy buffalo and teriyaki.the fries are fresh and not like the soggy greasy fries that mcdonald's uses on late night orders.
