It was served on a wooden board.of the 3 desserts, hands down the toffee pudding was the best.referring to my unsatiated hunger).the best dish we ordered was the duck hash.i probably could've had another order of each to myself.i have lived right around the corner from the duck inn since i moved to bridgeport.i had the striped bass which was also amazing.and hopefully you really are better than that.this was confusing to us at first, since the same menu is served in both locations--the restaurant seems to have a warmer decor though, for those of you interested in that type of thing.food and drinks make this a solid 4 star restaurant but service and wait time was pretty poor.

So if that's not your thing, you might not enjoy it as much as i do.s.we said it was our first time there and we were surprised with a plate of the house pickled veg plate.when you go into their alcohol section, they have a nice selection of wines and liquors.my wife had the breakfast tamales which was decent, a little dry but not bad.come here and hang out for a hot latte with bourbon caramel sauce with a side of beignet's.this place is good! i ordered the ruben sandwich--amazing! it was a tough choice though, everything in their menu looked delightful.i've only been here for brunch so far, but there has been nothing that i didn't like.unfortunately, i don't think i will be returning..

This is a really cute place! their covered patio at the back creates an amazing ambience even in fall! the drinks were alright! the food-strictly ok! the fried okra was soggy and lacked flavor! you can see it in the picture posted below! the corn was delicious but messy to eat! service was ok- nothing great!..you must try the pickled fried buffalo okra!  yummy.thanks a lot cool guy.

Once again they really came thru with the small burger!  excellent tasting - lasts all day.we absolutely will go back since it's so close to us and a welcome respite from the sea of tacos on the street, the other half wants to try their jalapeno burger next!.will be back for the small burger tho.

I loved it.the portion sizes are enough for average eaters, but share! don't eat an entire ceviche or any dish by your own.it felt like we were dining alfresco, especially with the smell of the grill.tiny portions.i think i booked this reservation a couple of months ago, so know before you go that if you don't have a reservation, you will likely be steered to the taqueira next door (also owned by rick bayless) and you will be out of luck to eat at this little gem.it was a weeknight and my poor visiting parents were getting tired, not to mention those of us who had work the next morning.everyone at our table agreed it was possibly the best meal any of us has ever had, there was so much flavor and care in each dish.drinks were good as well.the dishes which were the most memorable and noteworthy were not so much the entrees, which were very good, but the sides and the desserts which were amazing.

Overall, i'd recommend weber if you're in the area and looking for a meaty meal.otherwise, so great! the decor was fantastic, as well, and the bathrooms were very clean.we usually grab lunch or celebrate birthdays.the service was really attentive as well...if you like meat, then this is definitely the place for you.the link to their site:webergrillrestaurant.to be honest, i was not expecting the server/host to be nice with us (we brought 3 annoying cranky toddlers with us! and trust me, my kids are not the best behave kids around.my husband's meatloaf was a hit.

Everything was so good! it was my boyfriends first time eating colombian food and he very much enjoyed everything.a unique take on street food from colombia, which is a rare find among all other latin establishments.the restaurant is quite small, but it didn't seem to be a problem because there wasn't much customers dining in.pretty good place for a non-traditional hot dog.the musical variety is up beat adding the right amount of energy to the atmosphere..we were definitely full after inhaling all that good food..

But definitely a heavy start to a meal.well i don't even have words to describe how bad it was and the after taste was worse than the first bite.:).like why bother going to farmhouse if you are not going to order the curds? stay at home for your damn burger.i didn't feel too well that day so i couldn't stomach much.the stand out item from this establishment are the fried cheese curds.00  (cost plus tax and tip) for a  bun just isn't worth it.the food is delicious, the ambiance cool but not too cool..the cheese curds were incredible, and i say that after living in wisconsin for the past four years.

The owner, anna, was behind the counter herself, taking orders and running back to the kitchen.i usually get the chap chae and it is epic and their sticky rice, oh their sticky rice.the idea of using mashed potatoes as an option with massannamon curry is brilliant, i love it.the pad thai was ****/****anna takes card if you're worried about it being cash only!.more for take-out though.

The cheese was gooey, the mushrooms were full button mushrooms and were good if you like mushrooms.great service usually.it was chaotic and cramped inside the small space.also beware that there is a ton of cheese on these things.call ahead of time to check the wait, for sure!.i've never had a pizza pot pie before i tried chicago pizza company, but i think this my favorite way to eat it aside from thin crust..also, they're cash only!!!.the pot pie is not as filling as you think unless you love bread but the sauce is basically marinara tossed with some ground meat.

But it wasn't a shocker to me- the ambiance of this restaurant is really cute and the food was bomb!.come with a hungry stomach!.5 hours later and i'm still full.check them out!.i got the bibim-bap bowl with korean bbq beef and white rice.wish i could give it more stars.anyway, this place is super adorable and i am going to keep coming back for the tacos..i don't give 5 stars often but i was really surprised how much i enjoyed the flavors at en hakkore.i know there is a great one right down the road, but this place takes the cake.

The food was nice and affordable..neighborhood gem.call ahead! tue & thu you will be waiting for a long time if you dont.on tuesdays and thursdays you can get a 1/2 order of chicken for free with a whole order.you can definitely feed two people even with the half order, it was a pretty hefty bag of food i got.not to mention it comes with rice, beans, tortillas and salsa.delicious salsa, retried beans and mexican rice was on point!!!!! can't wait to get more next week! there was a single grilled jalapeño on top of the chicken.who doesn't love some deliciously grilled chicken? on tuesdays and thursdays they have a half chicken for free thrown in with your whole chicken order.nevertheless, the place is very tasty and cheap.

When you walk upstairs and onto the roof, you're in another world.would have liked a bit more attentive ness- we only ordered two entrees and the boys were about done before ours even came out.this is one of those places were you have to pay for bread which i'm ok with but my dad didn't understand the concept.my husband and i shared four dishes and a dessert and each dish was fantastic in its own way.the food is literally farm to table and it's so fresh, unique and fantastic.pumpkin panna cotta.we also ordered two desserts- the citrus and the adult hot chocolate.as for dessert we shared the s'mores and beignets.for a place that just opened in june of 2012, h hits the mark on so many levels.we left there super stuffed because everything was so good.

This is still a gem in the heart of chicago :).the pork was underseasoned and dry.a little dry for my tastes but still very good.everything here is fresh.just wish the service had been more pleasant to match the overall ambiance and delicious food.i have been there 3 times now, all since may!  yummy!!i have never had to wait for a table (although it has always been  a party of 2 or 3)..i walk by this restaurant all the time and finally tried it today..we can't wait to go back.

Today, i decided to go with my daughter.our friends had half a jibarito and the chuletas.anyhow, that article made me think of all the wonderful dishes i would have missed out on if i didn't always suggest sharing..(hopefully, with more veg friendly options!).we started off with some empanadas (beef and chicken), they were good, the chicken was one of the best empanadas i've ever had.we get complimentary cups of chicken noodle soup and bread.very filling, if you're coming for lunch consider getting the half a sandwich meal instead.you should definitely try it!.i tried different plates and all of them were delicious.

They use sustainable great ingredients and you can definitely tell! i only tried the "spring chicken" sandwich but it was really good.i imagine this is quite a feat to rotate between.we've been there for breakfast, lunch, and dinner and all were superb.my only wish is that the bread served with it had been a bit different..it was absolutely outstanding with different favors and textures.we were thoughtfully topped off on one occasion where we loved the wine so much we finished the pour before the course arrived.it has to be experienced to be understood.it's right there.their website states "our midwestern omakase is unlike any dining experience you have had.
It's a better date location than a work stop.

Walked over 20 minutes there, arriving at 10:05pm to find out they had closed at 10pm.intimacy.the staff were pretty attentive.yelp totally got this one right! this place does not disappoint.hands down, this is my favorite place to go on a date night in chicago.i was not disappointed.i had a late night meal on my own (at the bar) after a long day of work events.i tell anyone i know who is looking for a good place for wine sipping or some sort of wine adventure to check this place out.once we found it, we were greeted by a server but were told to just sit wherever, rather than being seated.i always appreciate suggestions, especially when they work out well.

Kinda had a sports bar vibe, while trying to be a contemporary bar & grill type.the staff was very friendly, upbeat and helpful which made the experience very positive.work on that kitchen issue, wise owl!.it's cornhole in new england!we grabbed a table in the back room instead.i was very annoyed at this place the first time i came..the service was great and we were there when it was kind of slow..maybe it has more of a night scene? anyway, we had some gilt group deals to use which we did without any issue.aside from that, we really enjoyed this place.

The chicken was incredibly over-cooked..another nando's! this establishment in newcity is no different than the other ones i have been to, and it did not disappoint!we got the whole chicken dinner with nando's chips and garlic bread.chicken is on point and the sangria is great!i'm not even a chicken person but i can eat this everyday lol.although i was still hungry afterwards, place was good.the sauce isn't too think but not too funny, and the lemon one that i got to go with my food had a slight kick to it, but was still a perfect balance of lemon (but not too sour) and herb (but not overwhelming).menu is fairly large so i'm looking forward to going back and trying more items.last week, i went with a half-chicken order with two sides, the macho peas and the mash with a slice of the chocolate cake.hostess was texting the entire time she was at the front.i got to taste the butternut squash and also really good.

They have speciality cocktails under $10 and entrees come with soup or salad for under $20.ordered the "diablo beef" (italian beef, mozzarella, giardiniera and au jus on grilled baguette).interior and decor remind me of an old speakeasy.in that case, if they are truly unhealthy for you, it is worth losing a few days off the end of my life for them.yeah, he was the only server and he had a couple other tables to take care of, but i still don't think that's an excuse for rude behavior.there was the slightest inkling of a chill in the air so i went with a cup of their spicy garbanzo barley soup, the baja burger and the raspberry scone.i really like that the bar is this prominent, dark wooden structure, bam in the middle of the restaurant instead of tucked in a corner...95 i thought it was well worth it.

Honest review its not good the food is so overrated to the max like youll eat here n be like wtf thats what the hypes about n btw it is expensive n portions are small its jus like a normal taco place nothing special i would go to tio luis instead that place is great..i can't wait to go back - the food is amazing!!!.the avocado rolls were crunchy (very creative use of the wonton wrappers), and the avocado paste was rich and creamy.i was not expecting the portions to be so huge!  the pad thai was two meals worth for me and it was filled with huge chicken chunks and tasty cilantro..it's one of those gems that have great quality food for low prices.i wasn't sure quite what to expect from dos riccos, but the reviews were decent and they were in walking distance of the midway hampton inn, so i went for it.

The atmosphere is modern, crisp, and relaxed.- choripan anticucho (chorizo skewer)- carne empanada (my second favorite dish!)- camarones con quinoa (quinoa-crusted shrimp)- arroz chaufa (fried rice - my favorite dish!)- cherimoya & white chocolate (dessert)- chilcanos (drinks)definitely give this place a shot soon! i would come back again.within the first week and a half of opening, i came to boleo 4 times!! steadfast was delicious, the gray is stunning, and now boleo is quite literally the cherry on top.you can get large format punches served in cute cookie jars as well.i can't wait to head back and try all the other additions to the gray hotel.
Even if i wanted to tip less based on service, i couldn't because they added it to the bill!!!  i left there with a friggin' headache.this is a place worth checking out.

They also have a great full brunch menu, and they serve tea on the weekend! i'm a sucker for a good tea service, so i'm looking forward to trying that out with a group of girlfriends.the sandwiches, sweets, tea and prosecco were all very tasty..it feels comfortable and not pretentious.i kind of want to come back every weekend now.the pricing was not bad at around $30 a person and i was absolutely stuffed! parking is not terrible either, you just have to look.i wasn't sure what to expect given that tea isn't their specialty, but i was pleasantly surprised..had the olive and almond app, it was great..

Falafel was very good as well.the margharita pizza was covered with basil, and the herb overwhelmed the flavors.what a great, cheap place for a quick bite..boy did we get that and more! chris has some of the best customer service i've ever had..the owner is super friendly, professional and really has the customer's satisfaction at heart...the dough is delicious, the meat is fresh and succulent, the sauce is slightly sweet, and the basil adds another level of freshness.

Heck of a wonton soup, and the signature "light and sweet" beef broth that's closer to pho than my preferred taiwanese niu rou mien.the won tons are generously packed with shrimp and pork and well seasoned.if you happen to be visiting the chinatown area this place is located on the far end of the newer area complex on the other side of citibank and its downstairs.he packed it so carefully, the containers stayed in tact even though i dropped the package.when the father isn't taking good care of his customers, he is playing with his adorable daughter, which is touching to see.good food2.the fried wontons were really the best part of the meal, as they were light and crisp -- but the filling was a bland and completely indistinct.calling ahead really makes it quick.this was my first meal in chicago! it's a cold, rainy day so i was definitely in the mood for something soupy.it's a little greasy, but that's just because of the spicy oil that they use.

Sit down lunch spots are a dime a dozen..my favorite part of the experience was the windy city martini, which is just titos vodka, olive juice, vermouth and bleu cheese olives.both were really good and not too sweet.we were seated immediately, outdoors per request.it was truly unique, huge and really tasty.our reservation was at 5pm...the dish had plenty of crab meat and the eggs were made perfectly, yolk oozing onto the lumb crabs.
I agree that the service is great!  good mozz sticks, good fries.it makes for a great treat.

The staff was attentive and friendly.i stopped in and tried their combination plate..chicken doner.nearing the end of my salad, i discovered a little treat hiding in the lettuce and unraveled a sticker normally meant to be peeled off vegetables before they were cut up.sometimes you gotta give your wallet a break and a palette a taste of heaven with just 10 dollars or less- and lavash is the place to do it!came in here with a girlfriend around 5:30 pm on a weekday and we got the number 1 and number 2 with cokes for dinner..

You will love it if you like trying new things!highly recommend the egg ball and sweet flatbread.the inside is nothing fancy, but the food.there isn't really a menu so we just asked the owner to bring out some large plates of authentic food for the group to share.not the expert on somalian food, but from what i can tell you definitely get a ton of food for what you're paying, and it doesn't taste none too shabby.

Great date night spot away from the hubbard crowd scene! great atmosphere, awesome food and service! love the ambiance! really a classic place and miss it! hopefully going back soon :)..if you decide to visit bandera you have to try one of the desserts.the atmosphere is charming, dimmed lights, live jazz (they do even modern songs in jazz).bandera surprised me.it's scrumptious.

Such a good neighborhood joint for a quick fix of a grilled burger, chicken, or beef.i love their gyros and milkshakes.i tried some of the other things my friends got and again, not spectacular.the only local open for lunch in the pulaski/milwaukee intersection.outdoor grill is a step up from the neighborhood fast food joint (hot dogs, burgers, gyros and fries) with healthier options like salads, deli sandwiches, wraps and grilled chicken.as my friend and i were leaving one of the guys gave us an ice cream cone.friendly, and genuine.i just prefer more taste for my buck/calories!.there's really not much to say besides, good food for a good price.
We ran out of bread, and we got a bread refill.

95 a bowl, you're better off heading somewhere else for your noodle fix.i'm on a ramen hunt which brought me to strings ramen shop.in terms of service, the first male server seemed a little agitated, possibly due to us walking in at almost 11:30pm.boyfriend got the hell ramen level 2, and he claims he blacked out in the middle of his meal he enjoyed it that much(lol!) it was so spicy, i can't even image the level 5! he really enjoys spicy and said he wouldn't be able to go up to 3 which has ghost peppers included.they have been getting more love of late and even ranked first place on thrillist's best ramen in chicago so i was swayed!  however, reviews that say that the broth is too salty are spot on.my sweet cousin was craving her favorite ramen and dragged me out here.overall, an okay experience.note to self:1.this place has great ramen! i tried the tonkatsu ramen and it was amazing (but a bit overpriced)..

Best walnut baklava also the chocolate raspberry cake is the best thing to have on the menu it simply melts in your mouth, it's ridiculously delicious you gotta try it!!!...i'm a huge fan of the mango mousse cake.affordable, delicious, and opened until the dead of night? yes please!i've been here twice: once for birthday drinks, and the other for an actual dinner meal.awesome bakery! really like the mango yogurt mouse cake and the raspberry one.i used yelp and found artopolis.i know every item on the menu, the owner has become a dear friend after the numerous cakes i have picked/ ordered the last 15 years.

They're going to need them.worth the search though for a nice selection of sandwiches that run the range -- reubens, short rib, steak, fried clams, etc -- w/ a casual gastropub vibe at night.you don't have to eat badly either, they have several items that are leaning toward the healthy side.they were so easy to drink, and after only two it was lyft time.it's a nice spot with a good-sized open kitchen, but it was very crowded and noisy the night we showed up.my husband had the fried chicken and biscuits concoction and it was also very good (kind of like a fried chicken version of biscuits and gravy).which in many ways means it was a bust for our group, given that we saw the phrase "..tequila-lime milkshake was a pleasing end to this meal.the side salad was pretty good, but c'mon, who wants to hear me rave about the side salad?!? the service was great and parking was easy.

I was little surprised that they didn't have any tabletop grill options, but when i asked our server, she said that certain booths do have this option, and that they it gets really popular in the winter.avocado and edamame hummus: wonderful little appetizerlamb buns: i actually thought these would be bao buns, but even though they weren't, the dish was still very good and fillingroasted pork butt: omg, i would order this again and again if i couldbelly mac: it's like mac and cheese and a curry noodle dish had a delicious babyservice was friendly..we started off in the bar with cocktailsi had the stove pipebuffalo trace bourbon, vermouth, cinnamon and jim had a brandy old fashion i also then had the gumball headfor dinnerwe had the grill table which came with:for appetizerscrispy spring rollpork belly, kimchi nuoc chamthai style fried chickensweet chili, limeavocado basil hummusyogurt, curry, spiced rice puff (v) (gf) 8rib tipsmaple bbq glaze, sesame, steamed bunscrab rangoonthe tips and thai fried chick being my favoritesso the grill table comes with seasoned scallops, marinated purple asparagus, wagu beef from japan and marinated short ribsyou get a ton of accompaniments from pickled veggies onions and such to kimchi house giardinare  and you.yum -  edamame, thai fried chicken ( fellow diner almost got stabbed for trying to take the last piece, get two orders to prevent bloodshed), fried rice, lamb buns, short ribs ( super tender and flavorful - see previous note on chicken), grilled shrimp and scallion, cinnamon donuts with vanilla soft serve ( used to come together but now have to be ordered separately- must do, they're addictive)pass - kale & papaya salad ( personal preference, not a kale fan), kimchi potato salad ( bit of a shocker as i'm usually pro-spud) , tea smoked duck breast ( this one was debatable, good flavor but the fat wasn't rendered off enough for my liking which also led to a less crispy skin)while i had a few pass items, there were definitely fellow diners that loved those dishes.must visit spot.we sat at the long table in the bar/lounge area at the front of the restaurant..so good and creamy (can't go wrong with either).

The service was nice and quick--as this is their concept setting up wooden booths (so we don't get too comfy) and smaller venue for in-out service.i came here on a weekday for a late lunch and there was barely anyone inside.sadly, the ramen here wasn't even as good as my "just ok" place at home.the friendly woman working there seated us right away.i'll give the ramen-nod to oiistar and takeya though.will come back to try the gold for a taste of a fuller body soup base.so glad this finally opened up, now we don't have to drive 50 mins out of the city for an actual bowl of ramen....

I had the fried chicken sandwich and he had the cuban sandwich and neither was something i'd go back for..this place is quickly becoming a favorite of ours for lunch or dinner every time we're at the dive shop (underwater safaris) down the block.great place.i'd give the food four stars.don't take your frustrations out on any customer who literally did nothing.there will be a variety of them on all around you!." no.they have daily specials.i just left this place and have to write a review about how wonderful it is.

I haven't been able to find fried oysters anywhere else that tastes this good! the food tastes even better after a night out clubbin! i don't know if it's the grease mixed with the alcohol that makes everything so delicious but whatever it is, i'll take it! i've been daring before and tried the frog legs and smelts, but it's just not as good as the shrimps and oysters.exactly what you think it is: a hole in the wall, cash only, and deep friend goodness.$4.but everyone (staff & patrons) was so nice!got the catfish and fries.the counter people were very friendly, but way too much breading for my taste.because their shrimp is great and they give you a lot for your money..parking is limited in front of the place, though there's other places to park nearby, but just watch out for the towing areas.very plain interior so no place to dine in.oh and they have frog legs for you meat lovers.

Friendly service, yummy food -- what's not to like? we had the loco moco, and it was reasonably priced and had a generous serving size.i love aloha.went with the double chicken combo for $9.healthy options and a quick option is to grab it to go! one meal can be split between two, but it also made great left overs.not worth eating in and service can be very slow so definitely order ahead for pickup (parking in the neighborhood can also be challenging).normally the teriyaki/bbq and katsu sauces are free flowing!that all being said, their spam masubi and bbq chicken were quite good.this past weekend we stopped in since we were in the neighborhood and ordered the pork katsu and the spam katsu.one of the best hawaiian food i had in a very long time.it is so simple, but impossible for me to replicate (i've tried, trust me).i think it may even be better than l&l drive inn! they also sell spam musubi, saimin, and other goodies.

Approximately 4 blocks west) and cta lawrence red line station (pass lawrence and broadway.my fiancé ordered a coffee and when he brought it to the table we asked for cream and sugar, and were brought one of each.i was super impressed and we will definitely be back.

Very good! the last thing i expected to find in chicago was good mexican food.we ordered the steak dinner that came with beans, rice and salad and corn tortillas.this is my go to place when i'm hangry.the steak and raja gorditas i had were generously filled and very tasty.$10 with tax and tip!alot of people also order food to - go, so i will probably do that next time if i don't feel like dining in.the meat was tender, flavorful, and delightful.feels like a family owned joint.we've been here over 5x now for dine-in and take out.these tacos.i did a yelp search for burritos last week and this place popped up.

The polish sausage was very good too.as per previous yelp reviews, the owner will order your food (considering any dietary restrictions you may have) which for us worked out to ~$23 per person (2 ppl.yes the place could look more 2015 but then the prices would go up and it would lose its charm.that's when i realized, "#@#%, he will probably add this to the bill.as soon as the bf and i walked in, we were greeted by a sweet woman who is basically the empitome of what i'd imagine a polish grandmother to be.the portion size of the entree plate was quite generous.the restaurant is a bit like walking into your grandma's house so don't expect a+ decor.it is run by four old polish ladies and one old polish man.if you come, eat at the bar.the potato pancakes are crispy thick and i have to admit much better than babcia's.

The star was the ramen which was chewy, delicious and worthy of second rounds which we all did.this is a lettuce entertain you restaurant, if you're a member, remember to collect your points!.just average.the music playing sounds like it's from someone's ipod shuffle :-) wu tang, salt-n_pepa, just a great mix of old school hip hop..the wings were hot and very flavorful.not a bad option! the flavors were a little too unique for me to try though, black sesame and green tea.the food portion is modest.5 stars actually.moral of the story - savor your broth.

Carb heaven.it's a seemingly small restaurant till you walk in.i don't recommend sitting in the covered (out door area) in the winter.my mom and i came in and i was just as impressed as the first time.smiling post-dinner photographs of these and multiple other celebrities adorn a wall attesting to their satisfaction with the restaurant.grilled octopus was cooked to perfection.this place gets packed on weekends, so make sure you go early if you can! the staff here sometimes gets hard to understand (thick accents), the drinks are nothing to brag about, but there's a feeling of going to grandma's house for good hearty food that you just can't quite get anywhere else!the seafood salad, the calamari, and every pasta i've ever had here are my favorites! the prices are by no means cheap, but food wise, you truly get a bang for your buck!...

The french fries are on point - freshly made, crisp, and salty...it's like a soul food diner..it also came with an unexpected side of fire roasted salsa which went really well with the tortilla and the chicken.the fries were really very fresh and tasted great!whats worth writing about are their desserts- the banana one in particular! i forgot the exact name of it, but its a banana pudding type thing and its delish!! its better than banana pudding ive had anywhere! they also have a white sponge cake marinated in evaporated milk, its very sweet and also good.reasonable prices, but cash only.i really enjoyed this place.the place is cute and looks as you would expect.

Kelly had the gin/farmhouse ale cocktail, and i had the bourbon sour - which was massive - america, what a country!  both were fantastic, but i would say, even as a bourbon boozer, go with the gin/farmhouse ale cocktail - it is a deep, philosophical drink.i loved chef beverly kim on tc, so being personally seated by her at the restaurant and getting to chat with her for a little bit tickled me greatly.the atmosphere is lively with a touch (ok, maybe quite a bit) of hipster.parachute is a good korean-fusion restaurant.the crispy stuffed sesame leaves were a bit underwhelming.maybe if the atmosphere was a little warmer i'd feel differently.food was amazing and very flavorful.it was a creative combination that just didn't work out in this instance.the service, while friendly, was long-waited at times.upon ordering, our waiter strongly advised we cut one, if not two, dishes from our order.

Jackée.the combination tasted like a watermelon bite.we were craving burgers and the wait for au cheval was unfortunately too long.especially when topped with their rotating ice creams.we opted to forego appetizers and just jump into the entrees and sides.the onion rings were amazing! it definitely was great we called early in the week for a table.fried pickles and beer bettered onion rings were pretty good, but a little too much batter for my absolute appreciation.my "bbq picnic" burger had jalapeno slaw, bbq sauce, two fried avocado slices, and was cooked perfectly to order..they close at 4 on sundays.

What we all agreed upon were the nachos.brutha man haven't a slice in a year   i've been waiting for this day.we had a cinnamon roll as dessert.we got nachos and 2 burgers.the mozzarella is on point! the seitan is to die for! the crust is flaky and scrumptious! what more can a vegan need? oh, the veggies and sauce were something to write home about.kitchen 17 is also located in a nice neighborhood with lots of fun shops all around to explore after you have had your pizza.as we were eating we all agreed to come back til we've tried the whole menu.the instant effect was to feel like you were in a fun person's living room waiting for them to whip something good up in the kitchen.we were so hungry i completely forgot to take a picture! while the tacos were delicious, the cheesesteak definitely takes the cake.i was hoping they had wheat bread/ wheat buns, but that was not an option.

Not sloppy italian but clean execution with the right size portions.everyone's mouths were watering by the site and the tastes were even better.now the food is another story.went here friday night with some friends and sat on the lovely patio.we followed with the polenta and portobello appetizer which was delightful.had a big group and was seated quickly, our server was nice.our waiter was very patient and pleasant.for desert, the cannoli was superb.our party of four loved everything we had- i did the orecchiette pasta which i highly recommend.unless you already have a bar and you offer byob, it is a bit of a farfetched policy.
Had the nachos, grilled cheese and fries for my daughter, the potato balls, and for desert my daughter and i tore up the fires twinkie.

This hits you after a few seconds.the service was excellent.regardless, it was tasty.serve me another!.the patio looked darling with it's brightly colored umbrellas but it was too cold to sit there on the night we went..the place is nothing to write home about in terms of ambiance, but you don't exactly go here to get your club on.the food here was really good and the ambiance is cute.service impeccable..

Not sure if the problem is because this roost location is so new, or if this is as good as it gets, but we don't plan on finding out.i was hungry so i opted for the 1/2 bird w/mac n' cheese and a biscuit, nashville hot(that's sort of a given).they also offer coleslaw, i think, or a biscuit (if you don't opt to get your sandwich on a biscuit, or you really like biscuits..usually, it takes about 20 minutes to do that at lunch time in irving park.i finally got in and place my order with a very nice and friendly girl at the front, and she really helped me out with deciding on the peach cobbler.very disappointing because i was really looking forward to a tasty hangover cure and instead it just gave me a fried chicken hangover to add to my pain.we ordered the nashville hot, it is pretty hot but not burning which i really like.great fried chicken- and cheerwine- what more do you need to know- well, 1 thing- call ahead and place your order- tight quarters- maybe best to take it to go- or maybe in the nicer weather, they will have a set up to eat outdoors- although kind of  some dusty roads on that little corner for eating outdoors at this location.i've been to nashville and i dare say this chicken is better than the hot chicken i've had there.

Honest review: umm its good not the best not the worst out of all ur cheezy taco places i would put this as the top all the tacos are great the carne en su jugo is amaizn the aqua achata is amaizing best i ever had its no 5 star restaurant but it is good the salsas are good i come back to it alot when i jus want a normal soup n taco meal if u want the best mexican restaurant go to libertad in skokie check out my review to get more info on it..the tilapia salad is a great light lunch and surprisingly filling.they need to make the carne en su jugo in bathtub size so that i can bathe in it.

I think this place is worth checking out once, but i probably won't be a regular without my lettuce entertain you coupon since it didn't blow me away.the bar seemed to have a lot of tickets.the server was friendly and attentive.my mom insisted that we go here for dinner to entertain some out of towner guests prior to a wedding we were having..the atmosphere was nice and quiet, was seated and served promptly.our sever was very kind and friendly.all in all, a great spot to get a bite mid shopping! and away from the crowd at the food court - which i loved!.no complaints here.it has great food and service.

If you work as a waiter at a restaurant learn the menu.coffee is good but you can taste the magic in the freshly squeezed on (a must have).she obviously wasn't doing it out of malice but she couldn't take the obvious hit that we wanted her to leave us alone.this place was hiding in plain sight.i was so excited to be eating at sam & george's as the food was tasty, the service was great, and the atmosphere was cozy and warm, perfect for a cold chicago sunday.we were seated and immediately poured a couple glasses of water, while we looked over the menu.my husband and i came here to try their famous skillets.i took only a few bites and took it to go so i could nuke it in the microwave.food: for their, brunch, skillets are king.we ordered a godfather skillet (which s&g is known for) and the bagel/lox and had leftovers for the next 2 days.

My guy and i stopped by for brunch and were really impressed.after running a race we were all starving.for brunch, i suggested the fried egg sandwich and a bloody mary.who doesn't like to have a good beer, sandwich and people watch on a nice afternoon?if you're looking for a good sandwich, good people watching and a good location, look no further!.it was the essence of a "meat and potatoes" dish, with chunks of hearty corned beef..my staple there is the egg sandwich, it's really delicious.the interior of this place is cool with dark wood, a nice bar area, and it looks a lot better than many of the local brunch places in lakeview.everyone else i went with ordered different things and had to send things back or live with a less than mediocre breakfast.this spot is truly a neighborhood gem and should not be overlooked!.

Done.it's a family run joint and you can tell.super happy about this place.then we also got their kefta sausage sandwich which i think also was one of the best dishes we got.they cut no corners and the shawerma came in a fully enclosed pita pocket that was fresh so none of the mess encountered when some ppl give you just a wrap.this place isn't fancy, but the food is fantastic!highly recommend the vegetarian combo with hummus, baba ganouj, tebouleh, jerusalem salad, and falafel.it wasn't crowded at all when we went and the food is tasty.there's just nothing fancy about the place and the workers seem unhappy.i've also been quite the fan of their lentil soup as of late.i addition you can seat inside or outside.

I've been here before on my first trip to chi town and i had to come back! the hot dog doesn't compare to other chicago style dogs! i also came back a second time this trip to try the pasta and salad! the pasta was decent, very rich and creamy! the salad was ok, was glad they offered fresh tossed salads! price was decent as well! definitely a place to try and experience! the hot dog doesn't compare to some street vendors but it's a must when visiting here!..i didn't even know i was paying an extra 60 cents each for two tiny things of peppers (so $1.delicious food is good but satisfying food leaves you with a big smile and a happy belly.i think this was our only meal in chicago under $50.that famous chocolate cake.i mean you cannot really go wrong with any options from here.super packed on a wednesday night! i decided to get the dry, sweet and hot italian beef.how about both! :)great food.the only saving grace was the cheese sauce that came with the fries.

The sweet potato fries are very thin and greasier than i though they should be.i'm a huge fan of the brazilian bowl! anytime i've been my friends and i have enjoyed everything we've ordered.the sauce was flavorful and almost compensated a little bit.the service is relatively quick, though the space is quite cramped and there are times where there's nowhere to sit, compounded by much of their menu not being easy to eat on the go.for someone who is gradually getting interested into the restaurant and food industry, i thought that was pretty cool..this place actually has a really big menu with great prices.i have had them in san diego, north county in many many places, in maui, hawaii, in miami, florida etc.i also like their dessert! the mascarpone cheese in their tiramisu is silky and melting in my mouth with the coffee aroma! loved it! will definitely come again!.i've had a lot of food in chicago, and the beef stroganoff is one of the best things i've tasted.

They have a pretty decent selection of food, and they all seem to be pretty healthy.my husband loves spicy food and really likes this chicken! he often reminds me to get one if i haven't picked one up in a while!i also love the veggie breakfast burrito, which can also be ordered with added chicken (if you want that added protein boost.this neighborhood isn't typically known for having nice, cozy cafes, but the green tomato cafe definitely serves the community well..i haven't actually stayed to eat there since i'm on the job, but it looks like a great place to hang out and chill.the people are wonderful..it's located inside the lawndale christian health center so if you get some bad news about your blood work at least you can get a tasty lunch, some coffee, and free wifi on your way out..felt like i was blasting away the cholesterol from my taco bell meal earlier that day.

The prices are fair given the location and quality..whether it's a blistering summer day or the middle of a dreary, freezing february, i'll always get a fresh fruit smoothie - best i've had in chicago.still probably the best fast sushi place around..unagi pieces were so disgusting.usually when you order basic rolls they can be small but these were great!the spicy miso soup with seafood was surprisingly great.i was expecting another type of tokyo lunchbox, but i was wrong!this little sushi joint is pretty kick ass!their customer service can use some work, but the sushi is quite fresh and the prices are very reasonable.terrific, bright corner location three blocks south of the art institute.

It had a clean feel to it and the food was very tasty.i love that we live so close to this place! i'm not vegan or vegetarian but i eat meat pretty rarely if i can help it.maybe they need express locations throughout the city?...i decided to change things up on day 3 and took my family to a different place.how awesome is that??as a meat lover, i really liked native foods and would come here again.this many meat substitutes cannot actually be healthy for you.we were lost and had to walk around the restaurant to find a staff member who could direct us.everything about native foods was positive, starting with the cashier, who cheerfully answered questions and joked with my friend and me while we were dithering about.

I really enjoyed the spicy tuna hand roll and the panang curry.placed a pick up order here over the weekend and loved everything! from spicy tuna rolls, where tuna rolls, pad thai and the fried rice, we tried it all! the lad thai and fried rice were incredible.his curry was so fragrant and flavorful that i was impressed with the thai side of the place.great place to eat or order delivery if your party wants both sushi and thai.we went there for my 8 year old grandson's birthday.everything is tasty, but i personally think it's a bit overpriced for the quality.they use the wide noodle which is far better than the thin ones so many places use now.i think the minimum might only be $10..i asked the waitress whether they can do rolls without rice and add cucumber and she looked at me like i was speaking another language.

The desserts (we tried two- the chocolate cake and the marcona almond caramel bar) were the perfect size to end our meal on a sweet note.great sangria as well!.yum, love this place.deviled egg: it was good and had a little bit of a kick to it.i prefer m a la p's patatas bravas over the spicy potatoes at cbbr, but for the price point, cbbr hits the spot.haven't been back in two years and it was way below par.it's a great place to work (there's free wifi) when they're less busy but when it's packed, it gets very loud and the wait can be very long! as per usual at a tapas bar, the portions are pretty small here and it can be very easy to rack up a big bill, so don't come in too hungry if you're not prepared to pay with your wallet!rioja-braised short rib - fell right off when i cut it, very tender and flavorfulshrimp with garlic, olive oil - this was a little too much for me, the shrimp were practically drowned in olive oil, taking away from my appreciation of the shrimp itself!chocolate cake - delicious!i would like to come back and try their paella! next time i'm ordering the sangria as well!.never been a better combination!i've been here a few times, both with small parties and large groups.there are about 6-7 to an order.we tried quite a few items from the menu and sadly nothing really stood out.

They offer refined friendly service and high quality food at really reasonable prices....i'm not local, so i don't have much to compare it with, yet i can say that the food was on point and service was top shelf.especially after i asked for some balsamic vinegar to dip it in with the olive oil..this is actually a difficult dish to execute, as the scallops cook much faster than the bacon.i'd rather it be this than to be ignored.not sure how this place has an average 4.

Just be patient, they're working diligently to provide quality food...the freshly made corn tortillas here are incredible! i'm typically more into flour tortillas, but they changed my mind forever on how great a corn tortilla can be.

00 i spent on the watermelon fruit cup (bought 2) because watermelon is in season.i am so bummed out to see that review with the plastic glove (ew) and i'm really hoping it isn't real because i love this place!.

Smothered burrito was amazing!red chilaquiles was amazing!  it didnt sound that great, but honestly terrific flavorgreat coffeepretty good servicebusylots of kids.amazing brunch! arrived at 10:45ish on saturday and landed a table for 2 with no wait.although they are very attentive, i wouldn't say they are the most friendly.the reason why this is a 4 and not 3 is because flo has one of the best buttermilk pancakes i've had in this city.the brunch drinks - flavored mimosas and spicy bloodies - were pretty on point, too.the bartender helps to make my rojo bloody not so spicy by diluting it with a little more tomato juice and get it with the bacon and bourbon and i'm the happiest chick on chicago ave for awhile.the breakfast drinks are great as well...and, i also had a classic mimosa which was delicious.

Get it, get it!.for a friend's birthday we ordered 3 pizzas from here after polishing off a couple bottles of vodka.we swept both the lightning and regular round..so i was craving something sweet and ordered the nutella pizza for delivery..but really the pizza was worse than freezer pizza..they have drink and food specials every day!i just moved in the neighborhood and am excited to have a great pizza place so close by!.

We also decided to split the tuna sandwich which was good- a little too much mayo but overall good.grouper entree: could have been good, but the crust overwhelmed the fish.i've been here once for lunch and once for dinner and both times have enjoyed my meal and good service.it does end up getting a little loud when it gets busy, so if you desire a quiet dinner don't come here on friday or saturday night at 8:00 pm.about the only thing i don't love about the new decor is the menu situation.i ordered a vodka martini, and my fiance ordered a seasonal beer.eager to try the fish.chicago cut has a "lobster-cargot" and this is similar in concept but i almost liked this better.overall, this was a great pick for dinner and i can't wait to do michigan girls night out here.they have a nice little patio.

The roasted pork here is incredibly tender and seasoned to perfection.i came here right before the work day lunch rush.man, i really am glad that i moved to chicago.food: ropa vieja was infused with shredded skirt steak, plaintains and beans.i'm pretty sure it was an issue specific to this sandwich because my coworkers didn't have the same issue with the other sandwiches.on my visit to chicago, i stopped by here twice because i couldn't get enough.prices are reasonable and the food is authentic and unpretentious.steak chimichurri pressed sammie was spot on with great taste and a fresh parsley/citrus theme.these are condiments you will want more of.

Awesome food with one of the best patios i've been to! the fire pit is amazing and the bartenders make a great hot toddy.overall, i thought parson's was a fun restaurant to be outdoors, but the food didn't impress me.further, the bartender was friendly and knowledgeable, recommending more fall-driven drinks (although the negronis got me) that i'm sure were also delicious.i actually enjoyed the fish more.the chicken was perfect, this is easily the best fried chicken i have ever eaten.but the dark and stormy.the food is good not amazing, but for the environment, and frozen drinks this is a must visit for summer.but i would never complain about a drink being too strong, lets be honest.nonetheless, between we decided to order half of a chicken, hush puppies, fried fish, and the spicy chicken.hooray! i love parson's.

Skip.great service and great food, what more could you ask for?..making a reservation is best for parties of 4 or more, especially on the busy weekends.there's a lot of hype surrounding this place and to me it was honestly just ok.the atmosphere is incredible and the food really stands out compared to other brunch places.the prices were very reasonable and the portions were great! i don't eat like a bird, either.it took us forever to get seated.only issue would be parking, there's a lot next door for around $7 or the ffc lot is there too..

There are booth and bar seating inside and an outdoor patio out front.this is a very average mak.they also have alcohol at this restaurant.fast-casual chinese up in herrre.for $12, the stir fry with quinoa (with quinoa is extra $$) was disappointing.but there wasn't much to bring us back.clearly, there were some operational issues that need to be worked out, but the effort and willingness to accommodate our long wait made up for the experience (extra goodies thrown in the order)." my immediate reaction is "where is the chork on the menu???" it wasn't until i received my order that i realized chork is a utensil that combines a fork and chopsticks into one.i don't want to eat individual pellets of rice, i want a bundle at a time.location is prime, the idea is great, the staff was incredibly friendly.

The set up of the restaurant is really nice...i need water.what i like most about this place is their quality consistency..we tried the phat rice, ramen, and a pineapple-guava macaroon.very quick service, pretty good local beer (can) selection.the service was outstanding..

Oh, and they deliver /fast/,i wanted dinner that i didn't have to go anywhere for after my flight into midway, and i ended up getting the best thai food i've had in a long time.i've had better pad thai from trader joe's freezer case!btw, two entrees and two appetizers, delivered, cost $28 and change.we didn't eat anything and we felt bad not taking it to go.still great little place, and other people dig it.when 4 p.the curry noodle with peanut sauce was a tasty balance of sweet and savory.:-d.

I loved hanging out in the lounge area although for a full meal it is tricky to eat on that couch..san fran style joint with great cocktails & food.i do recommend making reservations..i've never been on a weekend, only week days but have had no problems getting in.i think most decade-long residents of the wicker park area were sad to see bluebird go; it was one of the few (the only?) wine bar/chic lounges that didn't require a trip under the kennedy, so anybody brave enough to take over the space undoubtedly had big shoes to fill.it was my favorite spot in the 'hood.it wasn't super crowded, which i was surprised about.

My friends and i visited joy district last night for dinner, and wow - the space is stunning.i went to joy for the first time as part of sunday funday with friends - the rooftop is officially one of my favorites!  the artwork, stringed lights and comfortable booths make for a great place to go and enjoy (get it? haha) all that chicago has to offer.not impressed.don't even get me started on the two dj's that night, who literally played the same song four times - without request.really liked the octopus tacos and the hawaiian tuna poke cones which are the ones i remember.chicago's finest if you're into that sort of thing (i am!).this was a fun place to meet a girlfriend for drinks.i just wish there was more salmon but that's just me..with the crispiness of the cone - you do feel like you are in hawaii.

Pricey for what you get and not all that mind blowing.this place has potential but i think they need to work on the details more.take advantage of the byo ($5 corkage) until they get a liquor license!.the pizzas they serve are super thin crust pizza.the bruschetta is also delicious! fresh and piled high.

Order the scallop and coconut ceviche - it is so good and like nothing i've ever had - super creative.the atmosphere is relaxed and industrial yet really small so reservations are recommended.deliciously fresh oysters, some of the best.overall, the seafood was fresh, but the bread was over-toasted (difficult to break off and dip into the mussels broth); the octopus was chewy, and complemented the andouille sausage well; and the coleslaw that accompanied the sandwiches was perfectly dressed and the cabbage still crunchy.i thought the smoked mussels were also quite interesting, though not sure if i'd eat too much of them in one sitting.definitely worth a try.i know cold storage is known more as a seafood restaurant, but we came here for an industry special -- order any alcoholic beverage and get a free cheeseburger.definite fan of cold storage, actually liked it better than swift & sons - but so very different.the grilled octopus was a bit too charred for my liking.cold storage has it.

Had some super cheap old fashioneds to ring in the new year, not a bad startive been here before and cold weather makes for a cold bar but the patrons and staff are friendly, and hell im always chilled anywaysserves food and lets you carry in once the kitchen closesseveral rooms to hang out in and pool and plenty of tvs to keep you entertained..after a few pints  i continued my one man pub crawl, but i do plan to stop in the next i'm in back in chicago, pretty cool place to grab a few beers and talk chicago sports and chicago in general!.great place to throw back a few beers and burn a few hours over a long lunch.love:1.what we didn't know was the green door tavern has been around since 1872 and was actually a speakeasy during the prohibition after we went on a prohibition tour.wouldn't mind coming back for another beer but not where i would go for a memorable night.people are friendly and just looking to have a good time! the inside has a unique and interesting decor.the prices were average.

Delish.love this place! really vibrant ambiance and the food was good.i love the location of fulton market because there's so many restaurants and bars in the area.came here with a bunch of coworkers today for lunch.it's a fun time in or outside!the drinks are well made, unique and not too over priced.the shrimp ceviche was too spicy and the octopus was hard to chew.a booze place (1.menu was sparse, but food was amazing.4: i got the papi greengo, looks like a kale smoothie but packs a wallop.came here a few times it is alright.

Zenwich does what they do best--including serving up delicious, hearty bread, homemade pickled veg and loads of cilantro..the chips were different and had a great flavor..inside, the restaurant was super dark with little natural lighting.i was impressed by how healthy it was, but not much else.where else was i going to get indian-greek-jamaican-mexican fusion? well, zenwich rolled in with a pretty strong reputation so i was interested to check it out.i used to frequent the elmhurst location when i worked over there, and loved everything - especially the spicy shrimp sandwich, katsu sandwich, and the toffee bars!  i got the groupon for zenwich, and headed on over to meet a friend for lunch.the korean cheese steak is filled with chunks of grilled soy marinated steak, grilled onion, green onion, mushroom, and smoked gouda cheese.

I think i just wasn't a fan of what i ordered.the khao soy is a creamy coconut curry dish with thin egg noodles and topped with crispy fried egg noodles.5location: 4cleanliness: 4ambience: 4value: 4service: 4overall = 3.walking into this restaurant, i fell in love instantly with the decors and smell.thai is my fave so that says a lot..the beef was nice and tender and the sauce was silky and velvety.i would probably order again as take out!yummilicious factor = b+.they aren't personable but, at the same time, they are not annoying.highly recommend and look forward to coming any time i'm at asco!.

It tasted like a jar of peanut butter with chicken.however, any doubts i had quickly vanished when the food came out.with the two curries we got one small box of rice..super affordable, i think our whole meal for 2 people was like $22..5 stars to the only thai restaurant that has ever been able to deliver take-out beef to me served at the proper temperature.the shrimp in my pad khee mao were bigger than average and cooked perfectly.will not order again.i love noodles in the pot.

The place is usually busy.actually they have tables set out in the foyer of the hotel, which we opted to sit at..i'm visiting chicago from california and decided first on wayberry, but the wait was too long so, we decided on this breakfast spot and i am so glad we did! easily 5 stars for location, service!!, food, everything, really!! perfect place to beat the heat in the midwest.nice sauce, hash browns could have been better.we did neither of those things at pittsfield cafe :)the chocolate chip belgian waffle was delicious, and the bacon was super crispy (a little too crispy for my taste, but my boyfriend was loving it).i had the greek skillet which had onions, mushrooms, feta and hash browns with three eggs on top, cooked however you'd like.and yummy! it is a hidden cafe in the pittsfield building.they have a rather large menu.ended up here after finding out another place had over an hour wait and am so thankful we stumbled upon this little joint!  it is a diner and was warm and cozy on a chilly, dreary, rainy morning.

I will definitely be back for dinner soon, you've stolen my heart la storia!!.our server also told us that there was going to be a patio opening in a couple of weeks so be still my heart as that seems like a great choice for wine and friends during the warmer months.which i plan to.it's close enough to the pulse of rush street without being consumed by it.i got the rigatoni, i tasted the ravioli which i think tasted better.they were rather forthright about items on the menu and their specials.welcome to the neighborhood!.if i see that on future visits that the the quality of food and service we experienced this time is in fact sustainable and repeatable (versus just a lucky night) then in my opinion, la storia can well become a 5 star chicago dining experience.

I heard about this place from a friend decided to check it out.only ate about 1/2 of it and had to take the other half home..especially if the owner comes by and chats you up (or any of the regulars, which there are dozens) or if you make the mistake of showing up in a packers jersey for a bears/packers sunday!  definitely a very chicago-ish place to take friends from out-of-town or if you are a sports fan.i hate bad experiences.this mainstay for all things united center is as solid as it gets for pre- 'hawks game eats and drinks..+late night diner.very good food and awesome decor.he spoke to us about his experience with the cup and invited us all to the party the restaurant was hosting for their 75th anniversary (which neatly coincided with the convention that weekend!).

The margaritas were fresh and delicious.we didn't complain at all because we were enjoying each others company as well as our drinks.service was great!  the hostess and our server were friendly and accommodating toward our toddler.i did not enjoy this place and actually got sick afterwards..the restrooms were clean.very filling~overall, the servers and manager at takito kitchen were very accommodating, and it was much appreciated when the waitress allowed us to pick two types of tacos rather than ordering four of the same thing.everything about takito kitchen is amazing.solid twist on traditional latin.

Keep in mind the portions are enormous.the creme brûlée duo and the molten lava cake are out of this world - and i don't have a sweet tooth..i would recommend the restaurant because of it's accessibility and price point in a crowed downtown chicago market.the pasta i ordered was amazing.we finished our meal with the strawberry shortcake! off the meter!!! (drops the mic)i believe who owns the cheesecake factory has a hand in the grand lux café.it's basically a tad bit more upscale than cheesecake factory but only because it's right on michigan avenue- so the views by the window are great for people watching from above!.we had a very late lunch and thankfully, they serve lunch until 5pm (and brunch until 2pm).i've also eaten at this particular location, several years ago.i ordered the indochine shrimp and chicken - combination of chicken and shrimp, onions, ginger, sun-dried cherries and dried apricots sauteed in a sauce of mild curry, plum wine and cream.

Good food, good service, and good deals!  i am not a bar person and was actually kind of scared to go into this place at first, but it's a really nice and friendly place to go.in a day when everyting has pretense - this is a place that doesn't..medium, please.we had never been to polk street before but the waitress made us feel like we were regulars.i wish i had gone out of my way many, many times to attend this hidden pub.placed a delivery order for supreme nachos and a caesar salad.had a groupon so i brought my cousin here with me cause we both like to eat like there is no tomorrow hahawe came on a monday and there was a wing special! awesome!!ordered 20 wings, build our own fries, and i had a south western burger with tator tots.for soda refills, use a gun, not a pitcher since the ice is then melting into the soda! the service was solid, i was pretty pleased..

Nothing all that mind blowing.the portions are generous without being ridiculous.says the hot and sweetness is balanced to perfection.i met up with a friend for dinner at whisk awhile back and overall i was rather disappointed.we went super early after my friend got off her night shift and whoever served us (looked like a manager) was great.there's one communal table that seats 8-10, and 4 deuces on a banquette.hell, everything sounded amazing! we started with an order of the loaded pepper jack fries.doesn't take reservations, its quite small, so be ready to wait even late afternoon.the amount of chunk crab meat on the crab benedict did look decent.we will be back again.

What's not to like about big & littles? and i feel like everything good has already been said about this place: great food, service and space! you don't really need my review! i will say that i'm happy that i chose this location over their other locations because there was no wait and lots of parking!...for $4.

We arrived shortly after 11:30 to avoid the long lines as it can take a bit to order food.i will definitely be back! cash only!.the cold pasta salad served on the side (although i wish it was room temperature and not "refrigerator" cold) is as magical as everyone states..around 11:30 or so, the line would start to form in front of the sandwich counter and by noon you would have a tough time finding a table.yes, i've been to johnnies.the eggplant wasn't soft and soggy, had just the right amount of cheese, and had multiple layers of eggplant that stuck together nicely almost making it like a stack of eggplants.they were even less impressed than me.great pasta.

Allejandro (sp?) is our favorite waiter, and whenever we go he always remembers us..high quality, hand made pastas, tasty risotto with fresh seafood, fresh bread, good service and nice ambiance.fresh, authentic,top of the line ingredients.the food here was delicious.it did come with some greens.hugely disapointing, food and service!came in on a monday night around 6:30 and waited for a girl friend.good, but not special..the lamb rack was good but ordered medium rare and it was definitely cooked medium if not medium well.

There's a novelty soda fountain which is kind of neat - ice cream floats blah blah blah..it's kind of tucked away a bit in the south loop, but right when you walk in they have candy for sale, so who can complain about that?!  getting seated was a little interesting, as we had a large-ish group and a child in a stroller (they took us upstairs), and then at first took us to a table with not enough place settings/seats, but eventually we got seated.best matzo ball soup i have ever had in my life.another fun visit to eleven city diner.i have however sent other deli lovers here and they have reported their newfound love.definitely has that old school family diner feel which i like.my favoritest pancakes.they give you alot.i wish they had a location in texas because i can't think of a better thing to order for comfort when you're feeling under the weather.

The mashed potatoes were good.i know lots of people who are lactose intolerant and can't enjoy a cone of ice cream like an average dude and dudette.what can go wrong? nothing.even though the line was long, the wait was short.maybe a bit tricky to find, upton's breakroom can be hard to spot if coming from the east, as there is no outside signage and only from the west can you see the mustachioed man painted on the interior wall.i've been doing a pretty good job of losing weight lately and the fried bacon mac and cheese just seems to want to foil my plans! alas the heart wants what the heart wants and though i don't live close by i still find my way there more than i should.so basically a restaurant only 8 people can eat in at a time.the mac and cheese is just awesome---it's savory, hearty and crave-worthy..the only bummer was that we didn't have room for desert, but we did try samples of the cinnamon soy-based soft serve and it was fantastic.

The service was good.great thai spot in our new neighborhood..( ok it's imitation crab but it's still yummi).their pineapple sweet sauce pretty good too.so delicious.i thought, "hmmmmm, thai, why not?" the decor inside wasn't bad.talya's noodle dishes and sushi rolls are consistently good and this is my "go to" for thai food in the west loop.we've always enjoyed it so we figured it was about time to actually go there and dine in..

The ingredients supplied the amazing flavor, so much so that i'm looking forward to return visits to try everything.i kicked off 2016 on the right foot, with dos urban cantina being my first restaurant of the year.the beet and avocado salad (one of the only "greens" available) was a creamy mess and was more like eating chunky guac.i loved the creaminess that the poached egg added to the dish..and for dessert, coconut tres leches, sugar pie, and date sticky pudding.maybe the flavor profiles of the dishes just don't match up with mine.i wasn't crazy about any of the dessert options but my friends ordered dessert and loved it.5/5.you can actually taste cocoa.
02 after tax..i will be eating here often!.my favorite was the steak..

Very busy for weekend brunch, but quick and easy to get seated at the bar.i can never get sick of beatrix.the salad is perfectly dressed (don't need to get it on the side!) and the burger is so freakin' delicious.last, but not least, is their amazing pastry selection.first, about the food.came with a friend who has celiac disease, she was very happy to find out they have a specific gluten free menu and that they were very accommodating to her allergy..so unique and the chocolate topping was on point.i ordered a regular iced coffee and my boyfriend got a "mexican iced coffee".the kale salad had a nice presentation with shaved parmesan cheese on top.

Again fantastico! pork tacos, rice, beans and mexican water! what more can you ask for.it was empty so quick ordering.a hidden gem in lakeview on halsted and waveland.there is a small ledge lining the wall and window with bar stools if you choose to eat there.i would stay that based off the prices and the quantity of food they give you i can see why everything loves this place.the food is the same and still good quality but not worth what they're charging now..the owner explained that they make it homemade!  another thing to try here is the amazing pineapple/jalapeno salsa.no frills just authentic food.chicken and steak are my go tos for protein when it comes to this burrito alternative.

Everyone was telling me this location is so much better than the 26th & cermak location.and it is soooo.while the ordering was a little hectic, the food though was definitely worth it." little did i know ny, nj and pa mexican food is very rarely legit, it's usually more towards puerto rican style food, which is totally fine and also yummy, but it isn't mexican which is what i've believed i've been having all these years..

We started with the mititei (sausage) appetizer followed by chicken schnitzel and short rib goulash entrees.the owner was walking around and greeting people.he showed us to our seats in the dining area, which had nice decor and ambiance.better than that..this first experience is definitely all the more reason i shall have to return again very, very soon to see what other menu items they have to convert me into a regular customer.then we had  braised short rib goulash, it was an pretty okay dish, the short rib was a little dry but the goulash was absolutely delicious.holds up pretty well for delivery.this place goes on my list.

Just can't count on the food or service, as i'm not sure what i'm going to get from visit to visit?  visit at your own risk!..can't wait to come back and try something else!.i had an au cheval burger followed by an owen & engine burger in the same afternoon to make sure i could actually compare these two.it's easy to get to from the western bus, but not great area for street parking.it is easy to park around here and conveniently located near a movie theater.they serve high-quality traditional british inspired comfort food with their amazing crafted beverages.also, i expected the burger to be good but was not prepared for the house made fries.my friend got the cheddar biscuits and gravy while i  went with their famous burger.my friend made a reservation, so no long brunch wait (a big plus) and the local pub decor inside made it all feel very quaint and comfortable.

It is really nice inside but very small, like maybe 12-14 seats so i expect it fills up quick on a weekend.some key notes:**if you're going on a weekend, definitely make reservations.went here for dinner tonight, and it was an excellent choice!  my friend and i tried the bibimbap because the sign listed it as a top 25 must-try from huffington post, and it was superb.can't wait to go back and try the noodle bowls.the chips were light and airy, but still really crispy.the ramen was slightly above average, but nothing jaw droppingly special..there are probably only ten seats so plan accordingly.many types of toro on menu, which i love.i would definitely call ahead since there are only about 6-7 tables.

The food is cheap, very well flavored, the meat was super tender.came here with my coworker today for lunch..99, which i think is a regular portion of steak, chicken & falafel with whatever sides you'd like.my food was delicious and filling without that overly overly feel.the spices and herbs they added to them make them less beany/starchy, but more herby!the only thing i have to complain is that they are so far away from where i work! :)hope they will expand into the "north" loop :).so an israeli and a mexican walk into a restaurant.when i say big portions, i really mean big portions! holy cow.the food was good and the customer service was great..

We finally got a seat and menu and the selections looked pretty impressive.customer service here (from the staff) is actually awesome.the food was ok.come here if you are in the area, starving, and it's on an off day because it is definitely not worth waiting over 10 minutes to be seated.i just have to.but i  can't over look the tiny details that just affected the experience..i wanted the coffee but the waitress told me that regular coffee is sometimes made in the same carafe as the peach flavored (which my bf had and he reported it was delicious).the place is bright, the prices are fair, there is plenty of  seating and the staff is very very friendly.the wait was pleasant enough (five minutes longer than expected but short considering they were busy).

My mother orders from them all the time for our birthday parties or house-warming parties the potstickers are a hit!i also recommend their almond jello, and shrimp dumplings ( ha- gow).the potstickers are good..the xiao long bao are awesome as well.

They were undrinkable! way too strong and not tasty.what a difference a great server makes!third times the charm as on this visit, the entire experience was spot on from the food to the service.we ordered a side of brussel sprouts (their sides were only $5!) and a spread plate to munch on (just okay)..i had the warm mushroom salad with walnuts.i think this place has great potential but they need to revise their menu and get rid of the losers or rethink the plating and ingredients to match the price with the value.i would highly recommend getting the spread with dips to share with the table.everyone was really satisfied with their food (ribs were the best they had ever had!).interior is pretty large and has a cool ambience.i am adding an additional star for the vig due to the owner's immediate response expressing concern regarding my most recent experience at the restaurant.

Reviewing their smoothiesdelicious and fresh, under $5i swear there were 100 choiceskiwi mango was literally the entire fruit pieces..the main attraction always for me is the mango fruit freeze with tapioca balls.my favorite is pineapple, mango, coconut with strawberry and mango boba!  there are lots of options for vegetarians! the portions are also pretty big! my favorite things are spicy orange tofu, wide noodles with vegetables + pineapple, and vegetable fried rice.

It's a half pound black angus patty with 2 year old wisconsin cheddar, caramelized onions, bacon jam mustard and served with lettuce, tomato, a pickle and side of fresh cut fries.this is also a great place to watch the game even if you are not going to the game.not that there's anything wrong with pedestrians.excellent hawks bar! we always manage to find street parking when coming here.i can't recall our server's name but he did a good job.the only reason i'm giving this place a 3 star instead of a 4-5 star is because of the service.ate margarita pizza and some wings.the place can easily be described as cavernous, with the aforementioned lounging seats, bar stools, and assorted tables throughout.this was a cool place! my friend and fellow yelper, sarah jayne, and i met here before madonna's recent concert to grab dinner.great crowds it gets that come for events at the united center.

Would definitely come back for drinks, maybe not dinner.all time favorite drink - the mama d's cream sodafave dessert - the s'mores, which come with home made graham cracker ice cream, marshmallow and a smoked chocolate soufflé.rapidly becoming the dominant "place to grab nice drinks and maybe some food after work" in hyde park.we had the clams, beef short ribs, chicken, pork char and kentucky burgoo.the party was great with three djs and three different channels in the headphones and great fast bartenders.definitely a little high end to frequent often, but great vibes, great options, super interesting beverage selections.there was a surprise at the show, r kelly came out and sang a little this made the show pretty good.i also tried a couple of my friend's chickpea fries.after our pre-dinner bubbly, the sommelier brought out our first course.

Great drinks & beer list!  the menu is actually kinda small.the restaurant is a $$$ price range but is getting close to a $$$$ price range.the huarache de tinga was the highlight for us - amazing.other yummy looking dishes on the yelp page are gone.they were both so good.we naturally started off with cocktails.while the food is among the better mexican venues i have dined at in chicago, what elevates masa azul even further is the people and the cocktail program.everything was delicious.awesome tapas style mexican food! dishes are small so just keep that in mind when ordering.if anything i have to go back for the ghost pepper salsa.

We ate half of them and were already adequately satisfied for dinner, but they were so good that we couldn't help but finish the rest..i also ordered waffle fries and that may be the only thing that's not korean.overall i think they did a good job! i do wish mine were wrapped a little tighter, they seemed to be completely falling apart about halfway through, but other than that, the flavors were solid.this trend doesn't seem to be going anywhere and it's safe to say that en hakkore 2.i tried both popular burritos and man the spicy tuna will literally light your mouth on fire.i've told about a million people about this place since i went last week.it was hard to chew and had no taste.0 is definitely worth checking out! of note to us were the kimchi and chorizo fried rice and the crunch sushi burrito.i finally got the chance to go for lunch with some friends and i ordered the fire sushi burrito.

I will definitely come back.it is amazing that they have the knowledge to think of such great and original drinks off the cuff.we love it so much that we are buying a to go.the cocktail list is small because what you should really experience here is the "dealers choice.for realz.the vibe of the room is great, a relaxed lounge feel..i enjoyed a couple bubbly gin cocktails, the second with a lavender essence.a special, unique venue where you can forget the stressors of your daily life, relax and feel pampered.i can't get enough antique leather furniture to enjoy fine, dark spirits.
Everything tastes great.

I can't say it enough that this place is always always always always being crowded and packed !came here for a date a long time ago.i love eating out.both were seasoned just right, not taking away from the flavor of the cut..except we'd been lugging around a bunch of booze..from start to finish, the experience was wonderful.the atmosphere is great.00/person for the other two people as a sharing charge.the other amazing thing about this is that it's byob.
