~ crispy pork belly taco ~ fried pork belly, pickles, fresnos, mustard, tomato, red onion, celery, poppy seeds on a flour tortilla~ bollywood taco (wtf - their "weekly taco feature") ~ rotisserie chicken, baby spinach, saag sauce, potato, crumbled paneer cheese on flour tortilla~ falafel taco ~ falafel, tahini crema, arugula, tomatos, fresnos, avocado, red onion, pea tendril on a lettuce wrapi really enjoyed the individual flavors of each of them.quick and casual our lunch was great.the tots were the star of the meal, very creamy, perhaps a bit too much cheese, the egg on top was a nice touch, just all around great..while they are more expensive ($4-6 per taco), it's worth it..my rotisserie chicken taco was soppy and wet, and split in two when i picked it up.the tater tots make me want to cry..discovered this place one friday night when exploring the area with a friend, craving margaritas.

All in all, i'd say that the ambiance, service, and food were all great!i'll definitely be back if i am in the area! you should too :)..while in town we ate here and although it was a sports bar (not a fan) and way to loud to even have a conversation at my table, they had the best chicken wings i've probably ever had.i won't recommend the bacon lollipops however.truffle fries were bathing in oil, burger buns dripping with butter, meat patties over-seasoned and fried in a pan?it'd be one thing if the food made up for the service or vise-versa, but this michigan ave.the staff was super friendly and i enjoyed my experience and plan to go back to try more burgers and sides...it was barely okay.they also have a keg cemetery for dead kegs.

For food, we split the pierogis as an appetizer.lots of cream sauces, so the calorie count is high; and not much in the way of vegetables, so don't come here for health food.i was expecting more after reading all of the rave reviews..will definitely return for the good food, drinks, and gorgeous decor!.the hearty firm dumpling was scarce at 3 pcs with a skinny half chicken that i hoped is organic.i ordered the butcher's goulash as my entree and the potato pancake as a side..in all, it was good company and the service was professional.note this place is not german but it's a relative cousin of the cuisine.

I have not tried the burgers but i hear good things about it but i figured one burger taste like any other burger but i will try it next time.cool neighborhood bar with lots of tvs but loud, rly dark, and maybe a bit on the pricey side.the food here though is really good.my dad and i had a mixed experience here last evening.we will be back soon!!.this is not a huge place but there are tvs literally everywhere you could possibly move your eyes.however, when i tried to order them, i was told they were out..the mac n' cheese side was not bad but not a reason to go back.what a fun neighborhood bar.

However, last night's dining experience was not one i would consider a good one.i really liked my dinner here.you can order the mac regular (just cheese), 2 meats, or 3 meats.first time visit on a tuesday night and found the place to be fairly busy but still lots of room upstairs..i came here with a group of lady friends on a weeknight.everything seems brand-new and it's very modern.it ends up being about $50 a person which isn't a bad deal.i tried to write this review immediately after dinner.good start.

Their cocktail menu also looks good, but i don't think i've strayed from the beer.my coworkers and i have frequented moxee many times, and it's all for one thing: happy hourwhile  my first experience left me thinking this was just another bbq shop, their happy hour has certainly made up for any and all doubts in my head.it's a place i would keep coming back to just to bounce around the menu.we shared the pulled pork nachos (amazing) and then i behaved myself by ordering a salad with a side of salmon.we had a flight for $10 plus an additional une anee pour.friends had the pulled pork.meat is always cooked to perfection and the sides that come with the orders are also very delicious.tucked out of the way, i can tend to forget about it as an option, but it's definitely worth a visit.the beer list has many more beers from other breweries, but a few that are mad mouse.

Tandoori/chargha or whatever.there is nothing made to order, you get what has been made fresh that day.the two of us ate until we were stuffed and still had a ton of leftovers, which were still good the next day! also, customer service was great.fpgbtc: you are a doctor, right?np: no, i am not a doctor.i was a first timer, but this cuisine is really cheap, served in huge portions, and incredibly flavorful.overall, i'd rather drive out here to get chicken biryani or haleem.there were no other women in the place and although nobody gave me attitude, it just felt a little weird, so that's where they lost the other half a star.seating and restroom like what you'd expect from a cabbie place but very clean (seating not the restroom).food is fast, cheap, and sizeable..
It's a great 2 story coffee shop with creative coffee and smoothie creations.latte or mocha, it costs under $3.happy me!the people that work there are so nice!.

I most certainly must return for an espresso! & another of those very welcoming smiles of domenico's.recommended.it was amazing.the panini was perfectly grilled and the chicken wasn't dry, so we were very happy with our decision to stop by here.you get three wonderful types of panini- the caprese, calabria, and franchino.some of the items go fast since they are pretty popular and they only make limited quantities for the day.we came for a quick stop for desert and received a well made bowl perfected with the best flavors ever.for me a good panini has an impressive crunch with great grill marks.it came with a little tub of melted butter in which to dip it.i called in for a prosciutto pizza and picked it up exactly 15 minutes after my call.
Heard of this place and decided to go while in town.food preparation - service was slow in regards to when our food was ready.plus the air conditioning want on and it was really hot in there.

Our group was pretty disgruntled after the west end sports bar next door treated us like crap..i accepted and was mind blown! it brought me right back to the sunday dinner table, so much so that i actually felt bad not saying mass before taking the bite.the massive meatballs are probably the best i have ever had.this place was delicious.highly  recommended!.the meatballs were huge and perfect - nicely juicy and perfectly cooked with a great flavor.its a nice little place, usually fairly crowded.do you self a favor and stop in for for good italian food and see how a resturant operation should be ran- and say hi to dave and tell him "sherm" sent you!.this spot's reputation preceded my visit and i was not disappointed.

I'll definitely be back for the music and to check out brunch..the upstairs is nice and open though could use an update on some of the types of decor...lots of variety/choices for food for everyone.the tangy goat cheese and sweet pears worked amazingly with the caramelized onion and peppercorn.i was scared brunch would be the same and it's really not.having a drink named after a beyonce lyric earned one of these stars on its own..

Each dish was so flavorful and tasty that the hubs and i started to consider ourselves foodies.my wife ordered the funny guy and subbed out the mushrooms for chicken, it was epicly good!! amazing flavor.food was surprisingly terrible.the artichoke dip had a little spice to it and tasted better on the pita bread.all were great.the grits are super awesome.what a great idea.i was looking for a simple but good-quality meal for a solo dinner tonight while in chicago on business.the chipotle mayo sauce they gave didn't really help the taste.

I'm pretty sure if the snl super fans existed in real life, they'd be getting together at ricobene's on a regular basis.i'm just sorry to see that all of the other locations have closed as the darien/woodridge location was around the corner from where i live.not good.i have been going to ricobene's forever now and it still is one of my go to places if i'm looking for a bite.ricobene's on 26th is ancient and a no nonsense authentic italian eatery.looking forward to a future visit!..so if you are considering making the drive out, i say that its worth it.inexpensive and they also have a parking lot across the street.also, you'll want to try their deep dish spinach/mushroom pizza.

My panamanian friend love jibaritos so i had to take him to eat one.ha, probably not nutritious, but damn are they good! if you've never had one and you want a different chicago culinary experience, try this place out!here's the low down.i'm kind of picky about this, but it's the only reason i didn't give a five start review.she pointed to the guy eating dinner behind me.service amazing - it's byob but there is a liquor store across street.the plantains were excellent.people that were behind me in line were allowed to cut in front of me, who all seemed like they were acquainted with the owners/workers there.other than that, another puerto rican gem on division!.i know this is ubiquituous in chicago, but it isn't in dc.i had leftovers for breakfast this morning and i already want some more.

We ordered the following: clasica causitas, all three empanadas, plancha marina, and arroz criollo.i might be biased because i love pork belly and tamarind, and this dish married the two so brilliantly.i did try the pork belly and it was really delicious.but, it was just way too salty.our waiter was so patient and explained the ingredients i didn't know.most of it is open air and has an awesome chill vibe.there's an interesting list of cocktails, topped by a fragrant take on the classic pisco sour.the food did not disappoint either.i have had ceviches with much more flavor and less acidity than what they served here.ask the waitress for advice because the menu can be confusing if you're not used to the food.
Red hot mandarin! enough said!..

The cats out the bag.the biscuit was average, but the cornbread with maple butter is a must.for brunch, we ordered the monkey bread, which is sweet, soft and oh so delicious! get it for brunch, no regrets! i also split the bacon strada benedict, which is easily large enough to split.there are a few good ones, just not much to choose from.service was fine, other than the issues mentioned above.we had the skillet cornbread, mimosas (strawberry), bloody mary (amazing with hearty bacon), the fried egg sandwich and the lakeview omelette.they also have a small bar, so if you're lucky you can grab dinner there, which is what we usually try to do.the service was great, especially considering the crowds of people who trailed in behind us..over easy eggs? double yes.

The coffee kept coming, just as we like it and our waitress was smiling.good breakfast, chill atmosphere, not too expensive..the breakfast here is always fresh and good, but it's the seating set up that i can not appreciate.i came the sunday after halloween at 9am and there was still a 40 minute wait for a table for 3.if i were to return, i'd recommend just going with a biscuit, sans gravy.cute little cafe and a rewarding brunch after a long week!..went here for breakfast and thought my overall experience was just alright.
Waitress was super nice as well...the fries were so limp they had the consistency of wet pasta.

Nothing to remember.if you want cheap, hearty breakfast in hyde park/woodlawn, this is the place to go..i would frequent this place more often if it was closer to me, but i always think of this place when i'm in the area.will come back soon if i'm ever around in the area again!.stumbled in here after a college visit to the university of chicago.finally when we got to order our drinks.some parties in the large group got their order before me.will be back to try the daily specials next.i'm a bit of a chicken and waffle connoisseur.

I opted to switch things up a bit and sub the chips for the grits, which i enjoyed.the service was awesome and the manager was so kind and accommodating.they were delish! they have two sauces that  did taste pretty damn good.we sat upstairs for our table for 4, and upon being seated we were able to cruise by the tank where the lobsters come to die.our server took awhile to greet us and filled our water glasses..bomb, bomb, bomb service.the small red potatoes that came as a side were slightly smashed and crispy and very delicious.however, for an expensive joint (aka not red lobster), i had some expectation on the service component of the restaurants.there was plenty of booze and plenty of that sucker in a tall glass; be prepared.

I told her yes she'd already ordered an appetizer..overall, i don't think the experience was what my fiance was expecting 100 percent.if you have a large party, this may not be the place for you.clam and pork appetizer: really enjoyed the lightness of the dish as well the perfect amount of spiciness that elevated but didn't overpower the flavors of the clam..together with the house-made bread, it is the best! you have to try!-hk style milk tea: another must-try!-the other fat rice: it was ok..asparagus with sausage (seasonal item) -- sadly this was the best part of the meal, only because it was the only flavorful dish; it reminded me of the sausages i would have as a kid in taiwan so the nostalgia only enhanced the flavorpotstickers -- interesting presentation because there's a lacy crepe attaching them together; besides that nothing good here, i've had frozen potstickers better than these!pok kok gai aka portugese chicken -- this dish was pretty underwhelming, tasted like your standard chicken curry you'd get at a thai restaurant, nothing specialcoconut rice -- not coconut-y enough for me! you could barely get the fragrance of coconut when you eat the rice by itself! when you douse it with another dish, the fragrance is completely gone, i was very disappointed..

Everything about this place is near flaweless.so, our waitress listened to what i was looking for and suggested what turned out to be the perfect wine for the mood i was in.there are about 20 of these scattered throughout chicagoland, and this one is one of the better ones.just as great as the original on clark!  top reasons i love francesca's:1.to say the pasta was al dente is an understatement, i think it may not have been cooked all the way.it was tasty, not anything outstanding, but good.delicious classic italian food, it's amazing how wholesome and satisfying a quality bowl of spaghetti with seafood in a cherry tomato sauce can be!artichoke appetizer is a beautiful and delicious (and fun to eat) choice..i didn't realize it until we were looking at a menu and it looked so familiar, especially the girl on the menu.boyf and i got the calamari, the pesto sausage penne special, and the grouper special.

It was a really unique dish with layers of kimchi, rice, and tender shredded meat covered in some sort of rich, tangy orange sauce.our server was really great.definitely worth going back to in the future.we also ordered the steamed dumplings which we're really delicious and savory with the pork.we have even attempted to replicate this dish at home that just don't stand up to mott streets'.we didn't finish the first three dishes and didn't even touch the last one.my friend brought us here and ordered all his favorite things.the mussels were good, but not $22 good.the portions aren't necessarily large but they are sufficient.overall, super creative concept, delicious food, awesome ambiance.

It also wasn't an overwhelming amount of food that we had any to take home either, so that was nice! i went with the catfish tacos.i'll be back soon!.this place is good, no doubt.as for the chicken and dumplings they were nice and peppery (like really peppery) but were good rather than great.i don't think i'll be disappointed.the only thing i didn't like was that it's byob but that may be a good thing and can be overlooked with food of this quality! must try joint.if i am not mistaken, i think they used dang chips, which if you haven't tried it yet, definitely do yourself a favor and get some!- bbq brisket mac n cheese - second favorite..it doesn't seem like the kitchen is equipped to handle a large volume of orders.if they operated like a traditional sit-down, i'd probably try them out for other meals or more often.

I also thought it's a tad pricey for what you get.they where very good, a bit spicy and re-fried beans with crumbs of fresh mexican cheese on top.i was very pleased with the platter.tried mexican coffee for the first time and i loved it!..overall it's a neat little space.my good friend and neighbor truly loves to grab me by the hand and fly me away to adventures i'd never seek out alone.the coffee was amazing, as was the food.

Everything we tried was spectacular and so fresh.i wonder how long it took him to memorize every ingredient in the dishes he would bring out? mad props.this is the "tried and true" omakase that highlights the best and greatest of kai zan.best japanese restaurant i've been to to date.definitely worth it though..superb staff who knows their dishes well and are very courteous.carlos and melvin well done, you have a great restaurant and a place we always take visitors to town.we also ordered an additional dish, diy toro uni hand rolls ($28) which was amazing.so delicious.

Visited to grab some drinks.the wait was 45 minutes from the beginning and ended up to be an hour and a half.every detail is accounted for here, and i can't wait to come back!!.i ended up taking out one of the three patties on the wolf burger, because it was a little too much for me.the moscow mule was awesome on a very hot day - all their other cocktails looked pretty good as well.will have to come back for a drink and explore the rest of the menu!.my first visit was 5 stars, my second visit was 4, mainly due to the service (service was excellent on my first visit).probably on a weekday when it's not so crowded.my biggest recommendation is to definitely get the mussels, fish taco and elotes!.the selection is pretty solid, and i stuck with a couple of local ipas that hit the spot just right.

In over 5 years of yelping they're probably my most reviewed category of business on this ole here site so i think i know my shit when it comes to cheap, delicious mexican food.they have some authentic, unique varieties (cactus taco, corn mushroom enchilada) and it is delicious.menu is fairly extensive, fitting for the most diverse palate; a hard task in the taqueria world.it's easy to get a good dinner for under $10..this place has one of the best tacos in the city.

Some of the pricier items on their menu are actually extremely small portions wise.amazing beer list and fun food menu.its a burger.the bolognese fries and calabrese pizzetta were both delicious.they have some good drinks there and some nice beers on draft.i have never left three aces dissatisfied.too bad i can't just shoot the bolognese sauce straight into my veins lol..the prices are a little high for what is (or should be) a neighborhood pub, but they're worth it, for brunch, lunch, or dinner.

They were all really good and tasty.we had to wait about 5 to 10 minutes for our table to get ready, but that's not bad compared to the 1.both were flavorful and tasty, except you're not given much and it's gone within minutes.the service here is the best and wonderful people.or soccer at all.our waiter was very attentive and friendly.tortellini in alfredo with peas and prosciutto - good amount of prosciutto to provide the right amount of saltiness for the dish.they tasted like slices of breaded polenta which were dipped in an amazing sauce..i came with a big party of girls and we were seated right away on a friday night with our reservation.

The guacamole was the biggest disappointment - lacking salt or lime.one night at work my coworker and i wanted to try something different.thanks to yelp, we received a complimentary chocolate chip tamale, flanked with some of the best custard ice cream i've had.mmmm mmmm mmmmfyi no longer byob so leave your bottle at home.lol.get the sweet potato fries.i gotta say, i still love this place!  i had the goat cheese chilaquiles (minus the eggs) and i was floored.we ordered the ceviche and two entrees, which both came with posole.maybe i have antiquated views on the issue but i don't think that's the case.all entrees come with a side.

Really great neighborhood bar, and also a place worth traveling to.servers are really knowledgeable and helpful, and can recommend a good beer based on your flavor preferences, if necessary..the portions are hearty, and toward the end of our meal i could barely finish! the meat was also a beautiful medium rare as i had requested.i had the chupacabra burger which was white cheddar, braised goat chili, roasted garlic and guacamole.maybe cut them if you want to share :-).while i enjoyed the burgers, i could not really distinguish much between all the toppings, which i guess isn't uncommon for a burger with that much going on.a friend and i ordered the cheese curds, quinoa salad, and bayou chicken sandwich to share.on the other hand, service was phenomenol and most of food was amazing! we tried the poutine special(if your crazy about fries is the way to go!), large southwestern cobb salad(healthy tasty option!), cowboy killer medium rare with side of minced garlic fries(burger good but well done fries!), el chupacabra medium rare with side of spicy chipotle fries(again burger good but fries well done!), and tenderoni well done with side of regular fries(burger ok even without marina sauce but fries well done!).the burger list has such a wonderful varity of moth-watering burger designs that you could come back a second night and have a completely different experience.

The general tsos chicken was great, freshly made and flavored excellently.i was in the neighborhood and stopped in for a quick lunch after seeing other positive yelp reviews.the batter was light and crunchy and served on a small bed of crispy chow mein noodles.(and only a 20 minute wait).now, where they shine is obviously their chinese food.the food was great and the sushi was really fresh.
Giant portions!..i loved the sauce! sadly i tasted very little mushroom flavor, so that was disappointing.

Nice service, and they always do good business.there would be a line around the building to get in.overall, the majority of the food is great my only thing is that they can sometimes overfill the burritos with the lettuce & end up putting less meat in them as a result.i discovered huentitan when i was about 13 or 14 years old and in the early years of my rebellious stage.

Yes, $20..came here only once.in fact, when the momentous occasion of parents meeting loomed before us, together we thought that han 202 would be the best spot.the lemon cheesecake was delicious, but the chocolate souffle had no chocolate flavor and was very bland.way to lure me back.a $20 prix fixe five course dinner and byob? how do they do it?it must be on volume, for on the sunday night that we were there- the place was comfortably busy from the time we got there to the time we left.will definitely go back.the food is also very delicious.i enjoyed the atmosphere clean and fresh!  our host was very nice.

I can hear them.i don't know how to explain it, but i just felt welcome here.in the summer it spills out onto the street, but the cozy inside part is better.we ordered guacamole,  calamari,  and bruschett a,all amazing.who cares.classic chicago joint.best bar in chicago.only one bartender that doesn't seem too chipper.

The chicken, mac, and fries were all very tasty but i think the best part of the food was the sauce they had to go with the food.i was super excited when i saw this place under construction.pricey but that isn't the star drop off i don't punish reviews for price but understand it is pricey for lunch.yes, it's a bit pricey, especially for the portions you get.give it a shot, you won't regret it.décor: this is a pretty small place that is a bit of a "no frills" place: tables, chairs, menu = done.however i didn't think the food was as great as i imagined it to be.the slaw was ok.make sure you try the rude girl sauce, your taste buds will be happy you did.but never fear, the bread and accompanied fritter is perfect to combat the heat and is yummy on its own.

All are great.i'll be back!..service is prompt and they are so attentive! overall, i believe you can't go wrong with any of their dishes and that is making me a religious fan of their food!.i would definitely try to go later or around 11.she said all the vegetables were cooked together so if i didn't want bean sprouts, it would be a longer wait..i also got the short rib bao taco--this was good but you'll need to get 3ish to feel like you had a full lunch.i loved every bite! the rice was nice and crunchy and the pork sausage made it taste so much better! they also have sriracha sauce if you want to add some kick to your food.i had a chorizo eggroll, which was good, but i wanted it to be better.

I ordered the large (4 scoops) bowl with 2 scoops of salmon and 2 scoops of spicy tuna.it's a bit out of the way but definitely worth trying at least once.really happy to have this addition to the neighborhood, and i will definitely be back again and again.but it's cool that you can pick 3 different types of protein while some places only allow you 1 or 2 selections to choose from.my poke bowl included:brown riceahi tuna, salmon, yellowtail mixed with soy saucetoppings: crabmeat, green onions, masago, radish, seaweed salad, furikakethree-way affair sauceoverall, i thought the poke was good.the $10 version will you get 3 scoops of the fish of your choice..

We ordered drinks with a server and literally waited 45 minutes until we went to find him and he said "they're out of the drink".tall guy with dark hair and super friendly?), the chef, and manager felix--fantastic service the entire way through..as for the ping pong (and more importantly beer pong) it's was great...it's cool once the black lights come on, gives it a dance party vibe.the ambiance is super cool--lots of ping-pong tables with buckets of balls and paddles galore, black lights, and even a beer pong table!  as i walked in, i was greeted by a server passing out cocktails.overall a great hangout spot, right by the river walk.it's a ping pong bar so there are table everywhere and balls bouncing.

The menu is printed out nice and big on the wall near the entrance.it was a super fun time..2.luckily there was no line when i arrived.seating here is impossible and to top it all off,  i started feeling sick a few hours after eating here.they had special roped off areas for the line so i'm assuming it's busy a lot.good burgers if you're in the area - no need to go out of your way.there she was, right at the cash.standard menu with their city's signature concretes, and local beers on tap.

That was it.in these colder months, i especially enjoy the tomato spinach bisque.love this place.the only bad thing is that the food does not come out instantly.i absolutely love, 'da steve'..according to most reviews, the caribbean jerk is the meal to get so that is what i did.this establishment offers smoothies, wraps, salads, subs, and so on.i have had a couple of the wraps such as the chipotle chicken and the caribbean jerk which were moist.i got a jerk chicken wrap and a tropical breeze smoothie, they were delicious! and all for $11 i will definitely be coming back here again!.

Order no green peppers on greek salad.the falafel was as expected, which means it was equally amazing.pretty decent find in the loop.menu looked good, so in we went.the plate is about $9 but the portion size is quite generous.i got the meat combo plate and it was pretty good - chicken was well-seasoned and super juicy but thoroughly cooked whereas the schwarma was almost dry.bad customer service,  felt like i was inconveniencing them by speaking.it was good.but the two guys behind the counter must have noticed my hesitation and decided to let the food speak for itself by handing me a fresh out of the fryer falafel.the pita was a bit stale.

There was a community atmosphere, with at least three different birthday parties, all of whom had staff sing to them.during my last visit i ordered the tortilla soup and it had plenty of ingredients but yet lacked flavor, i took it home, added salt and chicken broth and it was delish.ended up there on accident.i would just try finding else that i like.even though the restaurant was mostly empty, we were seated right in front of the band so we had to shout to be heard.i want to thank this establishment for doing a groupon.

Love.only thing listed so we thought we'd try it out.another gem in bridgeport! so simple yet so delicious.definitely enough that you don't even need a side.i was very surprised that i liked everything..it's pretty small inside; i'd say that there are about 12 tables so don't bring a huge group.i'm not sure if there was a change in cooks, but zaytunes is heading south.i ordered the chicken schwarma wrap and it was pretty darn good! i loved the sauce, but as i stated above- i felt like i needed more! the meal was filling and pita itself was awesome! i will definitely be back to zaytune, and plan post again once i have herb fries and ample sauce.when the wraps arrived, i quickly realized we had over-ordered.

There is also a kids menu in case you're bringing them along!food: their menu is huge even for just the breakfast /brunch options.go!.we got the fat burner 'cause i love grapefruit juice, but i also hate pulp, and i keep forgetting that custom juice blends in restaurants are usually loaded with pulp, and this one was no exception.they always forget something.in all i have to say this is not a five star place.in any event, try the caprese wrap!.food was okay.yummy yummy yummy chicken and waffles! this is the first place i've been that actually seasons and puts bacon into the waffles.the artichoke was tender and the potatoes were tasty but you can't really go wrong with roasted potatoes.service was meh.

Built in 1883, from the original tin ceilings, wood floors, imported german stained glass windows and other fun stuff, the place has the authentic cham of yesteryear chicago while being a comfortable, contemporary community treasure.the beer selection is phenomenal and the staff is friendly.the steamed mussels and chorizo is a star dish here, but the 20 small and delicate mussels won't do too much to quell the hunger.i really liked this restaurant and the food.the menu is unique and the food is incredible! there is a spacious outdoor patio and the inside is cozy, yet has a fun vibe.but the food underwhelms.just saying - this place has character.overall, not bad and the waitress was attentive.came here after work because i was having a hankering for wiener schnitzel.in look and feel, glunz tavern is a genuine early 20th-century throwback.

After all, we ate our main meal at lunchtime.we went on a saturday night, and it was busy but we got our food pretty fast.don't get me wrong, it was very flavorful and enjoyed every bite but the portion size is tiny even for tapas (~15 each).i had the sangria flight which was very interesting and the sangria flavors were very different than what you normally find, but the flavors could have been a bit stronger." like the bacon-wrapped dates, the serrano-fig salad, and the peppers which used to be one of my faves too!service was friendly but slow at times given how slow it was when we were there at 9pm on a friday.oh yeah, the paella was amazeballs.i am truly astonished at their handling of the event.will definitely be back for another meal - the joint was a bit loud so made the networking a bit tough, but otherwise it's a very neat space & ambiance!.she brought dessert menus and when asked for her recommendations, she happily and honestly guided us.each couple they recommend to get four dishes.

Unfortunately, i was pretty disappointed with my order and probably won't be ordering from here again.he'll help explain anything if necessary and he would also explain the correct way to enjoy the dish to the fullest potential.4 stars for food but overall 3 stars for service and attitude.all that being said, it was quick turnaround for takeout and some of the better indian food in the area, so it definitely gets 3 stars and probably 3.i'll agree that sometimes the customer service isn't the best, but on our last visit, we had an amazing waiter.

This place is my favorite place to get ramen! i had the spicy garlic miso (or garlic spicy miso) and it was hands down the best i've ever had! their vegan ramen was pretty amazing too! i can't wait for the next time to get the spicy garlic miso again!..the mini chocolate dipped raspberry cheescake was really good, but when they mini they mean bitesized.i have eaten multiple times at ippudo and at totto ramen in nyc and i can say that i still rank wasabi's ramen above theirs - maybe it's because i'm a sucker for wasabi's ramen-like egg noodles, which are just tender and amazing.ultimately though, the broth is vital to good ramen and it was disappointing here.this place was quiet small when i came here with my girlfriend there was already a line out the door and a 30 min wait which as you know by now we waited.even though i'm still working through my list of ramen places in chicago, wasabi is now ranked number 1, because wow.best overall japanese restaurant experience i've ever had.

This was a new dish for both of us and i was impressed by how evenly cooked the rice was while dotted with bits of tender lamb and vegetables.they gave us pita bread and salad.the portions are generous and the price is right.i wish they actually packed for falaffel balls into their large orders since i find our groups always end up with that awkward stare down over who will be the person to take the few falaffel or who would be the nice one to offer to split one with someone else..really good mediterranean food!! i got falafel and the kifta with tomato sauce! average, tasty falafel.crappy takeout experience.there's a huge seating area inside and when chicago weather decides to cooperate, the seating outside is even cuter.the menu offers lots of choices.

My husband really enjoyed his fried chicken benedict which was boneless and fried to crispy perfection.except 2 things:1.and, the hummingbird cake! for what this place is trying to be in the chicago restaurant scene, they are doing a great job.- roasted beets & carrots are tried and true ingredients for a beautiful and colorful dish..shrimp and grits also were a nice sharing dish with good texture and flavor.we tried this place because it was "hot and new" and not too far from second city.i wish the burrata would have come first and then the two entrees together.the juice was pre-bottled so i am honestly not sure what took so long.

Walk in and it's a small mom and pop joint.i go there whenever i have no food at home and i feel like some quick bite.it's a bit on the "expensive" end of fast food, the gyro cheeseburger alone is almost $6 (without fries or a drink) when you can get gyros+fries+drink for $7 in greektown or burger+fries+drink on maxwell street for $5.very tasty..i came in here to grab a quick bite...other items are great here too but please try the gyro sandwich.i've also had their gyro hamburger, which was also okay.

And best of all it is byob.i phoned ahead and ordered naan, two samosas and chicken tikka masala.this is a great place to eat and if the seating had been comfortable, easily 4 stars for food, but the seating was just too cramped.we came to rangoli for my boyfriend's birthday because we love indian food.they must have sensed my stomach is usually sensitive to the spices, and it was very comforting to see they cared bout what the aftermath of the meal might be for me.it's warm, it's cozy.great conversation, great food and since it's byob the bill comes and you are just shocked and thrilled at how inexpensive it is! we got about 12-16 diff dishes for 8 people and shared it all and it was a perfect amount! we will for sure be back!.biryani was also really flavorful and it is recommended to pair it with raita(curd with mix veggies).i was stuffed and we still had plenty of leftovers to bring home.for the party, the staff let me bring a cake beforehand, decorate the table with corny bday crap and when his fam rolled up with coolers to byob (which is why i love them), they didn't even bat an eye.

It's very much an urban log cabin.fresh ingredients in both the pizza and salads and the service is fast and friendly.the pizza was good, wouldn't say it was extraordinary, but there certainly is a ton to choose from! we also ordered lavender mules (moscow mules with lavender bitters) which were fantastic and split a rice krisipie ice cream sandwich for dessert! super fun, cute place, and our waitress was the best part of it (her name might have been tara?)..my favorite ones are the kern-holio (chicken) and the zephy (meet-free), but all are (or seem to be) very good.i was the lone wolf in the group and agreed to go here, as i am lactose intolerant.we arrived earlier, so we didn't have too much trouble getting a table for a group our size.the ambiance is unique and much different than your traditional pizza joint, in a good way of course.stinks that patio closes at midnight..

Beef tar-tar wasn't really my cup of tea, but my friend really enjoyed it.when it's boiled down, this is a typical hotel restaurant experience no matter how much vintage "design" you put into the space and menu.excellent.for this girl who doesn't really like mornings, i loved that the menu is playful and kind of fun with it's "tongue in cheek" french (yes, even this girl knows what a "omelette pours moi" is) and the creator of this menu who obviously is in step with me that "sides, glorious sides" are almost as important as the main course!  (bacon, anyone?)we ordered enough food for a small family but it allowed us to taste a little of this and that and that was definitely the way to go.it was just kind of there.it had huge chunks of peppercorn in it that made it unpalatable.....

P.don't skip it! i didn't care for the beer foam on top but the rest was sooooo good.it is not the standard frozen hard dessert with cream cheese and a graham crust.delicious, but only satisfying because we had a heavy lunch and snacks before.let me just stop for a moment and clap my hands at the legendary drink menu here.everything after this point will be positive.main coursethe cider braised pork belly served on a sweet potato purée, melted in my mouth.nice cocktail list.despite a packed house on a friday night at 9pm, seating at the bartop was plentiful so we grabbed a couple chairs at the end and began perusing the lengthy menu.service was wonderful though!!!.

Like, so gross..oh yeah i forgot to mentioned that i order that desert and i almost broke my tooth.the pepper jelly/cream cheese sandwich was the bomb, it was a good combo of savory and sweet....we liked having all of the sides to sample and share.

The eggs were the perfect amount of runny-but rich, and the hollandaise was perfectly seasoned.the fact that they didn't require any syrup was all the better.i'll go back.stax was the first restaurant i ever ordered an eggs benedict, and i've been looking for a benedict to match since.the place looks nice, it's like a rustic feel like your at home.honestly these dishes are nothing short of delicious..bonus points.but instead i'm going to tell you a tale of woe and tears.m.

I ordered the steak sandwich and a latte..the staff were super friendly and helpful.having worked in the area for almost a decade, i've had my share of cuban sandwiches, this is really middle of the road.for my first lengthy visit to the windy city, i perused yelp for solid places to eat.my favorite cuban sandwich in the city and i've been eating them my whole life.for the female clientele, not as much.i only had a coffee after my morning run, but i will be going back to try out the menu.it's not crazy over priced.definitely coming back soon!.

They have so many different italian cookies to choose from, i ended up getting two, a lemon knot and an amaretto meringue type cookie (i don't remember the exact names).if i come back, i'll resist getting it again, simply to try some of the other delicious cakes and other desserts on display.ferrara for some reason is hell-bent on finding the rudest and most incompetent late-adolescent girls to work at their establishment.apparently they sell pasta and sandwiches now.i love the selection and always leave wishing i ordered more!!! they have a full menu equipped to fill your hearts italian desire!oh and i have to mention that my very first cannoli was from this bakery and i'm totally hooked for life!  this is a local neighborhood business that my boyfriend and i will continue to support..overall, its ok , a lot better than fast food sandwiches.i have never been disappointed in anything i ordered (although i do stick to the italian staples).very impressive.customer service is great, too.

Thank you!i look forward to fried chicken and wings (asian, i am!).it was pappin! absolutely poppington.what a hidden gem in the loop.if you deep-fried my kate spade wallet, i might have a nibble.the staff are very friendly too! highly recommend!.i felt afterwards exactly how one would feel after eating half a pound of fried lobster--sluggish and gross! i did enjoy the steak cut fries through, seasoned and crunchy on the outside, soft and tasty center..coco's is the cleanest soul food place i've ever stepped foot in.i would've given them 4 stars easily had they had anything to say to a 1st time customer that spent $60.

Biscuit - best biscuit ever6.who doesn't love a good chicken sandwich?  the nashville hot wasn't as hot as i thought it would be and it delivered on flavor.there's a new food nazi in town.after a fun day watching the air and water show on belmont harbor, my girlfriend and i finally made the trek to the roost! i have been wanting to come here for a very long time, and i was very happy to finally make it.the mac was super thick and creamy...finally did try the nashville hot chicken out, and it didn't disappoint.fortunately you don't have to run a 10k to earn these sandwiches.the restaurant is quite small and they cook your chicken fresh to order so be prepared for it to take a little while for your food to come out.

The stromboli was a bit of a disappointment - the bread was so hard it bordered on stale and was completely flavorless.excellent food! went here a few months ago (in march).the family that owns the place are very nice and the son is the chef.the beet salad was made with very fresh vegetables, and the chicken was nicely grilled and warm.so delicious.i got the meatball sandwich since that is my go to and it was not bad.i was a little worried since i don't eat pork, but i had no problem choosing menu items..everything was excellent, anna the owner is very personable and has excellent customer service..

I went with the shrimp alfredo.-portions could be larger for the price u pay.the jerk chicken, grilled tilapia, and salmon caesar are my personal favorites.finally stopped in to try the food and i was impressed.i wanted to try the jerk chicken...who would pass up moist cake.i've gotten take-out from here multiple times in the past as it's only 3 blocks from our place and i think every time i've ordered the jerk chicken.i usually get the salmon lunch special which is always on point.

Everything was fantastic!  the salad was perfectly dressed and the chicken was moist and tasty.lastly, i could see that the waiter was ticked off because of "another groupon" but i told him we would tip him on the original amount..unfortunately, all 10 plates were done for the night.the salmon was nicely flavored and a bit different.i immediately liked it from the outside, it looked très français to me and the inside was beautifully decorated in calm grays and blacks.having had a birthday dinner party here, the duck confit mac and cheese and the pan seared foie gras were the favorite dishes among the group.i love a french restaurant where everything is slathered in butter, and so when i saw a groupon for a prix fixe meal for two, i jumped at the chance.i can overlook the service issues because its not the kind of place that you would go to if you were in a hurry.donte was our server, and as other reviews have suggested, he was on-point.

Just got an update a couple days later- i have a stomach virus from eating here.i ended up getting a huarache.it was a mess.my experience there wasn't amazing or anything.strangely, though, sometimes it's hit or miss.being only a block away, i left right after placing a phone order and it was ready by the time i arrived.the chips and salsa you get at the table are top-notch.it's always interesting to see the nuances of a place or neighborhood from individuals who know it from earlier years..came here on our way to the south loop costcoi normally judge a mexican place by the quality of their horchata.

The mushroom/pepper combo, flash friend, gives a heavier feel to the burger and the combination of tastes on the buttered bun was awesome!  pair with a side salad and you'll feel great about your meal, even if you have a brew (or two)..dan had the old fashioned type of burger and he enjoyed it very much.they were really busy most of the time we were there, but the people behind the bar did a great job! we are interested in their food menu, so we will return for dinner.we came here this past friday and had such a great experience.walking by last night, this newly-opened spot looked so warm, festive and inviting, we couldn't resist stopping in to have a drink or two.we thought they were a little different than your standard cheese curds but i was starved by that point and couldn't care less.great beer selection in cocktail selections matches a menu mostly of burgers and homestyle dishes like meatloaf and pulled pork.oh so cozy, unless you sit in the front half of the narrow restaurant, brrr, and the chilly december winds come a blowing in to chill your nose every 5 minutes or so when a patron chooses to come or go.i first off, love the concept of all the food being farm to table, locally-sourced from midwest farms in il, wi, mi, in.

The interior of the place is nice - it's trendy and a little intimate also with a little bar area.it looks old and kind of dirty compared to the interior.silli kori takes thai food from chinese take out to dining elegance! wow!  we'll be back!note! silli kori is in the location of the former thai village but thai village still does online orders.

Bienmesabe was a really enjoyable experience.i recommend it.omg, one of my all time favorite restaurants which was an arepa place in oak park (aripo's) closed not too long after this placed opened.take it from a venezuelan: try this place, it won't disappoint..the server came 45 minutes later to apologize about the delay and said the food was coming, but it took another 25 minutes.the food took forever to come out.we then took advantage of the $6 arepas special (on wednesdays only) - she got the reina pepiada, a rich mishmash of avocado, chicken, gouda cheese, and sauce, and i got the roast pork arepas with added sweet plantains.

A friend and i came to celebrate my birthday, and we had the three-course dinner.dinner for burger club.food is marvelous..for example, many restaurants offer free bread.there is a bar and lounge in the front, while the main dining room is towards the back.com).that paired with the awesome 90s mix they were playing in the background, made this restaurant off the main path of dining options in chicago, well worth the trip.double espresso also helped clear the northern passage.i liked it but it was not a crowd pleaser at the tablelamb-this was much better than the canape.

Quality bread, plenty of filling.apparently if you don't order the "super" version, it is literally meat wrapped in tortilla.i am usually picky with my rice and beans and i like that it's flavorful here and that they melt a bit of chihuahua cheese on top of the beans.lots of chicken, decent price, and fast.i give three stars for friendly fast service with a smile and like i said the meat was tasty the rest of the topping was bland so i hope they improve the flavors because i would like to try their food again.great on the go or a place to take the kids for a bite..a solid b+.however this place will not disappoint.
I instantly felt a southern charm coming off of her every time she spoke.

No mayo.and i'm not a cucumber fan, but the way it all comes together with the mayo sauce is ridic.took a bite out of it and boyyyyyyy it was good! it was full of flavor and was juicy! the fries was awesome too! the meal was delicious and its a must try if u haven't yet.when its your lunch time then this is the place to go or call for a delivery.

The restaurant is unassuming on the outside in the middle of nowhere by the home depot on north ave.the main meat/fish dishes we got weren't good and the roasted potatoes that came with two of the main dishes were too salty.i'm not as brave as most, but still took the opportunity to try plenty of things, and even like some of them.overall a great place for drinks, food and atmosphere.favorites include the fried oyster and pork belly sliders, lamb scrumpets, and chicken liver.i loved the elegant touch of brown butter and oregano to what is normally paired with heavier flavors.the crunch on the outside of the steak, and i usually don't eat steak, was seriously to die for.the environment is very relaxed!! service is great! fast, careful and nice!we were three and got 6 plates althought he server said 2-3 per person but 5 was more than enough! we tried the ribs, the octopus, mexican meatballs, whitefish and the gem salad.the amazing-crispy black eyed peas (for the southern girl in me)polenta friesfried manchego cheesefried brussels sproutsstrip loin.

On the side were some delicious pan-fried mashed potatoes.huge portions! a great brunch spot but often there is a wait.i also liked all the memorabilia at the entrance of all the celebs that have visited the restaurants..omg that was the feature of my meal!!!.he just swore and ran back to the kitchen.m...we came across hash house a go go.

I have been here once when i was in downtown and flying back to minneapolis.one of my favorite lunchtime spots in the loop.it's the perfect place to not be adventurous.the whole rosemary frond in the london mule is a nice touch, and the sinners and saints is appropriately strong..convenient location- service was good.i do like the place for after work as it's conveniently located.the patio here is money; food is average, but there's no incentive to be great when you are in the loop and serving $12-$14 cheeseburgers anyway!  i will say, a bit of a surprise--my colleagues enjoyed their ahi tuna salad and the veggie version of the santa fe wrap, so i'm sure we'll be back since our new office opened just a 10-minute walk from here.pretty solid lunch spot in the west loop (have also heard good things about their happy hour, but i cannot attest personally).with the addition of the appetizers, i was able to take half of the sandwich home and enjoy it as a second meal later.

I was in chicago visiting friends and i was so excited to find this place! i've had pierogi's at a local farmers market but i never went to a place that just sold them and only them! these are delicious and there are so many to choose from! i'm also from california and i came when it was below ten degrees so it helped that they had to deliver on the nights that i was way to cold to go outside!..the menu is minimal, but they have a wide selection of pierogis.you go here for the food!!!.we also had lettuce wrap sausage something.as yelpers have commented, you must order pierogi in sets of three, so if you buy six pieces you can order two different flavors (but not six)..it was heavenly.good, no frills lunch spot that wasn't too crazy busy.

It was quite a big order than i expected.i love that i can get gourmet fries and they're still piping hot by the time i get back to my office.that was really cool.just be sure to come with someone else, because it's almost too much cookie for one sensible adult..the aoli was tasty, but i think i've decided i just need to stay away from fries.huge sandwich with bacon, avocado, argula, tomato, truffle aioli on texas toast.their regular sandwich rotation is the blt, the grilled cheese, the buffalo chicken, and the turkey.rambling setup aside, i'm pretty sure they mix molly into the sauce on their spicy sesame fries.super fast, friendly service.

- salt and pepper tofu - overwhelming with way too much pepper.any type of drink!  i usually come here to grab a smoothie and i'm never disappointed.chinatown joy yee) pulverize the red beans.the soft shell crab was meh, the crab was too briny for my taste, the noodles were alright though.i would be here every day of the summer trying all their creations.i'd avoid the lunch hour rush.i always looks forward to coming to chicago to stop and eat here.there are way too many options so it was difficult picking just one thing, but i chose a papaya green tapioca drink..this place is the real reason why i go to chicago.
Hands down the best vegan food ever! everything was made fresh and tasted incredible! i couldn't have asked for a better meal!..the chai was a little bit too strong.

Although sometimes it is too loud.amazing cafe! so glad i found this place and that it happens to be a block away from where i keep busy..that says a lot given that the selection of goods down there is not as great.fortunately it was warm and we could go to an outside table.if you are into fun, hipstery, slightly overpriced food options in a cut atmosphere right here on campus, this place is pretty all of that and more.plein air is a great café.i also really like the ginger plum iced tea.

The fried ball of liquid didnt have much flavor to me.just sitting around, thinking about the food.so, how did i end up here? on a date, where i spent my 10 minute walk there thinking i'd rather go eat tacos.the food:-sweet corn - beyond awesome, unexpected goodness-marinated zuchinni - simply yum-bavette steak - perfectly cook, rice had some crunch like bimbibap-swordfish - perfectly cook, giardiniera was awesometldr: must go.the standout for me was dessert - blueberries in a vanilla sauce with ginger! so surprising, so fresh - i had one bite and was like "this tastes like summer!" service was great.nothing was too big, so you were able to sample several dishes without feeling too full.you are literally 3 feet from the kitchen and can watch all the chef & cooks at work.com.the only negative comfort wise is two of my three dinners have occurred during 90+ degree evenings and the air conditioner struggled to maintained a pleasant temperature.description of the appetizers/main course was succinct and didn't do solid justice of what you'd eat.

It was about 30 minutes in between our appetizers and our entrees.the best part is, during lunch time, they offer dollar glasses of wine (red or white) and a huge list of great beers for only a dollar! i'm in love.but the space is still beautiful and it still owns my heart enough to be crowned (by me) the best whiskey bar in chicago.the noodles were homemade and very luscious, but not as meaty-silky-tasty as the duck broth, with accompanying legs.just wonderful.finished with the lost 'n paradise for dessert.the food menu covers a wide range (keen on trying mushroom soup and shrimp bisque next time!) and you surely won't be disappointed by the fine and vast selection of imbibables.we went last night (sat) after dinner around 10:30p.they were served in a spicy miso broth that was great for dipping the accompanying toast.i would say it was a little on the slow side, but since we were out with friends, it wasn't very noticeable.

Always fresh and good....ordered the chickpea of the sea after browsing for their salad options online and ordered it with kale in lieu of the romaine.i will have to preference this review with i'm not a salad person to begin with.beware, this place can get pricey.never wasting my money here again.

Other places will throw in a falafel, or hummus, this was just double serving of lettuce.the order itself was assembled correctly and my food even arrived 20 minutes earlier than estimated.falafel, chicken kabob, & tabouleh is amazing.you can tell that the ingredients are super fresh by the taste.have only had the chicken kabob but i def recommend it.the delivery all the way down to where i live took a long time (more than 40 minutes after i was notified by gh that my food was out for delivery); i think that may have been a part of the issue in terms of food quality.we did the old switch-a-roo and swapped halves so we both got to try chicken and beef.we hardly come to the area, but me and my husband spotted this cute place amongst diner food, and we thought this would be the healthiest option.

Between the 2 of us we shared 4 dishes which was the perfect amount for us.with one dish that was really stellar and another that was good as well, it goes without saying that i can't wait to try out the rest of serai's unique offerings.the roti paratha (canai) was great.best malaysian restaurant i've tried so far in chicago, where there is a dire lack of southeast asian establishments.the lamb meat was a dry and would be more complimented if the skewers came with a dipping sauce.the restaurant is small, but it is comfortable as the tables are spaced apart nicely.5 for me, but i've bumped it up given it's our go-to choice now in chicago.but honestly, this dish tasted just like how i described here.the spices were well balanced for great taste.the only complaint i have about this dish was that after a little bit it got a bit salty.

I find them to be heavy and oily.the samosas are little pieces of doughy heaven!.oh, and they've got mango lassi.we got a bunch of samosas which were only so so for someone who has had quite a few samosas in her day, but their chickpea chana masala curry with spinach was probably my favorite thing we got.the dishes had a lot of spices, and i thought the saag paneer was pretty good.everyone was stuffed and happy!we had:chana masalagobi mutter currydal curryrajma curryalu bengan curryalu currysaag paneeralso go dessert of ras mallaimy favorites were the saag paneer, gobi mutter curry, alu curry, and alu bengan curry, but i would eat all of them again!.i will be returning.it isn't really a restaurant, but more of a place to grab a quick bite..and neither does the combination of southern soul food (fried chicken, corn muffins, sweet potatoes) with curries and mango lassis and tandoori chicken.

A really cool small bar/restaurant to enjoy seafood late in the evening/night..00 and received a $10.both were delicious! i love garlic on almost everything so it was fantastic! they cut up the lobster for u so u dont have to do it yourself which was helpful..the bartender/server/manager/everything else was very polite and attentive.it's an odd place..

Only instead of grabbing a number and picking our own seat, we were told where to sit by the hostess (not even escorted, just told)...happy that there's one here in roosevelt collection right by the crib.in the two nights my boyfriend and i have been there we've tried almost all of the sides and still can't decide our favorite.the chicken was packed with major flavor the rice and the mushed peas were flavorful spicy and amazing.snuggled in the corner of the roosevelt collection, this restaurant has a lovely view of the city with both outdoor seating and indoor seating with large windows.however, the amazing chicken makes the seating system a side note.they don't give you little cups to pour your peri peri sauce in (like the location on wabash).

Like tbe settings inside and out.the bolognese was rich and flavorful.anyone who lives in chicago knows that there are precious few days when eating outside is optimal (not too hot/humid, no bugs), and last night was perfectwe didn't have a reservation and fully expected to have to wait for a table outside, but we got lucky and were seated immediately.5 years after moving to bucktown, we thought it might be nice to try out the restaurant that is literally 2 blocks from our house.he admitted his mistake and was very apologetic, which was appreciated, but it did slightly damper what had been a perfect experience so far.5 out of 5, rounded up to 4 for the service.the waiters are fun and focused, and the food is always consistent..he made the experience that much more enjoyable.pleasant environment.

Honest review do not go here i went because it was in diners drive in an dives the food was not good i was so disappointed like its nothing special i would not go there ever again it is honestly not good..everything was fresh and delicious.

I really can't for the life of me figure out why or how any establishment would name this salad after them.the layout is pretty much the same as the old bar, but the food is different.parking: decently easy street parking right outsideoverall i recommend everyone to come for the great happy hour deals and bar bite specials!.)the appetizers: we tried the fries, tostones, plantain chips, and nachos.overall a good meal in a comfy setting.this place is a block away from me but it is worth going out of your way for.wednesday it's $0.

Awesome spot for breakfast.they also have fresh juices which were quite good.having a new employee up front attempting to figure out the ipad and another debate the merits of the coffee carrier with two fellas, that don't look like they are in the packaging industry, without a hello to the next person in line got me to leave.i opted not to add the egg (what was i thinking??) or bacon (huh??) to the burger but i am glad that i did not as the flavor of the meat definitely had a very "beefy" quality to it that my tastebuds could really appreciate.that said, i know a thing or two about breakfast sandwiches, so when i say that "eastman does it right", they do it right!i got the fairfax, and it was lovely..service was fast.this is a wholesome option for breakfast/brunch/lunch around the loop..sometimes they are overflowing with toppings and sometimes they really skimp on the toppings.

Plates run for about $8 and sandwiches for $5.ordered the falafel sandwich and hubby ordered a chicken kebab.the food is super fast, their entrees are enormous, and again, i can't say it enough, their falafel sandwich is killer.the food is always good and they maintain the standards..if you're in a hurry and want something filling but don't have a lot of cash i would definitely recommend this place!.key thing is the place does not overcharge.i have yet to be disappointed by the falafel here, though the rice reminds me a bit of uncle ben's.i am going to end this review now before i start making bad jewel/gem puns.patty's day weekend and sadly, they were out of rice and lamb, which are the two main ingredients for mediterranean food.

We had been here before and really enjoyed the smoked margarita, so we ordered them again.i loved the vibe and liveliness of this place, i'll visit the rogers park location more, i'm sure.my only recommendation is to make this place not so short staffed for sunday brunch (only one server/bartender and one cook in the kitchen) which caused long wait times and little blunders here and there (brought me the wrong tacos) but other than that i will return!.all 3 were awesome but the brisket and kale were amazing and the avocado was just okay.a few more people rolled in while we were there, but it remained pretty empty; i hope that's not normal because i'd like them to be around for a long while.sure that this was only during this weekend and would love to give them a second chance if we ever end up in chicago again.cash only drives me (and probably most people) crazy! go plastic, baby! otherwise a great place to have dinner and drinks!.the music is always on point  and do yourself a favor a eat a grits and kale taco.possibly lots of food and several drinks..

This meal could not have been more different--exotic, spicy, and varied.chocolate cherry pudding was awesome as well.try rickshaw republic down the street.overall, neighborhood gem for date night or dining alone (there's a nice bar to sit at as well).definitely will come back though !.love this place!street parking on friday at 730 was easy!.the cocktail menu is creative and the wine list provides varied selections.if there were a reason for me to up and leave the wonderful east bay area, which is not at all lacking in great restaurants, de quay would be one of them..all in all, a delicious meal with some pleasant and subtle surprises; i'll be back!.
Owner taking orders at register and is helpful with ordering, etc.right away i put it on my to visit list.
The taco was small but very tasty.the homemade green salsa is really good.

Not that i want to send all the "particular" folks like me here, but the food is excellent and the staff is knowledgeable and will work with you to identify options that work for your dietary restrictions - all with a smile!..

I am not an expert.i will definitely be back - as will everyone i know because i'm bringing everyone who visits me from out of town here for this deliciousness.the veggie ramen was still delicious though- and i'd order it again!the drinks are extremely cheap ($3-$4), so you get great bang for your buck across the board.their fried chicken ramen, although not authentic is amazing.just make sure to say "put the sauces on the side" so that way you can dip your chicken in whichever sauce you want.spicy ramen - ah so yummy!!! so big! so filling! it is legit pretty spicy tho so if you're not into spice get the regular..three years later, i still consider this my 'check please' restaurant.i was looking forward to trying the ramen here since it's been a while since i went out for ramen.my friend and i both ordered the pork belly bun as an appetizer, which was extremely delicious.

This was very sweet of her (i yelp a lot and no one has ever taken the time to do this).it was odd.i like a good time so i stopped in.new fave bar in old town, a nice change from all the other bro-tastic bars in the hood.i would love to come back and try a burger or since that looks like more their forte, but for a first time try it was good!..i ordered a side of sweet potato fries which were just ok.we had no leftovers to take home! burgers are all in the $9-12 range, but none of them come with fries, so you have to order them separately as a side if you want them.seemed like a cool place from what i remember.my boyfriend and i split some shrimp tacos and we got their $6 pbr tallboy/jameson shot (love that deal!).

Extra points if you grab a groupon, which turns their very affordable sandwiches($5-7) each, into incredibly affordable sandwiches(basically 40%) off.this place gets super busy during lunch so you may have to get here slightly before lunch if possible.the soup was quite good, but the star was by far the sandwich..i ordered a chivito for myself and an exotica salad with chicken for the girlfriend.thank you for being close to my work and apartment.the sandwich looked small but was super tasty and filling..while i wasn't as impressed with their platters (the meat was a little bland for me, but i like things really bold), their fried plantains are amazing.we were in chi-chi for 5 days and i ate here twice.

Good event..i wanted to dip all that bread in the mussels broth.i can't believe that it's taken me this long to write a review of the dawson.i wish instead of pork they used crispier pancetta.i'd been refraining from going, thinking it was just an over priced drinks and share plate joint with a cool patio but was pleasantly surprised to find innovative cocktails,  interesting and delicious share plates from a small but refreshing menu and an intelligent,  friendly, personable mixologist (sorry justin or jason) who busy as he was had the knowledge and graciously made the time to explain some of the more esoteric components of their drinks..this is a very cool restaurant in the river west area, and i hope they continue to do well.i went to the dawson for dinner on a friday night with some friends.next time its the hummus and 1 cocktail to avoid that bathroom.

But it is just a sandwich in the end.just not what i'm looking for..it wasn't at the nola level, but it was good!i've always had great service here and i would recommend it to anyone looking for a slightly fancier brunch in the area!.great location to visit for breakfast date.it's a true appetizer.the much-hyped avocado fries were cold in the middle, which really contrasted with the burning hot fried exterior, creating a really weird taste that i didn't care too much for..came in friday night about 530.it was supposed to have coconut cheesecake filling, but none was visible when i opened up the two pieces of bread, which were put together like a sandwich.

It's the oldest standing bar in chicago so definitely worth checking out just for that, aside from that there's not that much special about it, not to say it's bad, they sometimes have live music, the beer is cheap, though just standard domestic selection, i know their food is supposed to be good, i haven't had it yet, but it's a full dinner menu, one of these days i'll come back and try it..friendly service & great turkey club.i know it's cold outside, but seriously? it's just tacky.

I ordered a standard dish off the menu and the chicken was served far under cooked (see picture)! the response was an "i'm sorry" from the young girl who took my plate and a 10% discount.i went and it was the best thai food i've had in years - and by far the best in chicago.i had requested mine mild but it was still very spicy." however, the best part is the food.once inside, you'll see plenty of seating options available, including those for large groups.the place has a cute patio with hanging light bulbs and pretty flowers by the windows.they have a spice rating system from 1-5, and they ask you to pick a number...it was topped with a generous scattering of peanuts and two huge, plump shrimp.

Papa rellena: good.i headed here after the conservatory.i am glad they welcomed me in their restaurant to eat some delicious puerto rican fare.no fun with a messy sandwich and containers of beans and rice.steak jibarito por fa vor!the steak was delicously tender n infused with garlic..they are know for their sofrito and delicious condiments but this food was just bland.the only good thing here is the sorrullos.i tried there vegetarian jibarito in stead if had vegetables and yuca did not need meat at all.don and his staff are just really good people.

The ribs were st.i would say it is ok.highly highly recommended!!!.we don't hestitate to order some succulent meats!! ribs?  brisket  sausage  pork belly  salmon  oh yeah & some sides (corn, macaroni salad)all the meats were great.ambiance is very cool--picnic tables that have ample supplies of much-needed paper towels.watermelon saladgorgeous space, bar, and coffee shop.hipster bbq indeed.if you're looking for bbq in chicago, this might just be the place you're looking for.they're everything you want out of baked beans: smokey, meaty, sweet, salty, tangy, dialed all the way up to eleven.

Roscoe village has had a few surprises pop up on the landscape recently.the yuca fries were addicting.open almost one year (?), cuba 312 has really proved themselves as a roscoe hot spot.i have been in a coconut mood so i decided to give it a go.after that, service was good.the staff was young but friendly and opened up our bottle of wine since it's a byob restaurant.my friend had the surf and turf and it was good.my friend and i shared the ceviche and the pollo de roscoe.of course i ate half of both.perfectly citrusy with mango and pineapple chunks.

I have been wanting to check out miss ricky's for awhile since i am a big fan of the virgin hotel.which is good because the omelet (and in fact, all of the food) is more spendy than you find in a regular diner.what a delightful experience!  i just visited miss ricky's for the first time and was so pleased worth everything from the service, the cocktails, and the amazing dessert.if you take away the waffle and the sauce the chicken can stand alone..not a bad place to grab food if you are in the area, but probably not worth going out of your way for.chilaquiles absolutely amazing.pretty meh all around.breakfast all day, and open until 2 am, too.my co-worker and i planned ahead to grab lunch at miss ricky's that day.

We are like cool, find a table and sit down.really good place to eat, no frills but park around the corner and make your way in.i was glad that they didn't make it way too spicy as many other restaurants would sometimes.chill place.

And if you're thinking - it's nice weather, why wouldn't i sit outside? well, there are tire swings to sit on, nintendo to be played, and sweet neon signs inside so..while i haven't been back since just after they opened i'm hoping this place continues to stay busy..my personal favorite appetizer- meatball, pizza- the pat, drink- bourbon mule.i'm not sure when i'll go back to chicago, but when i do, i definitely want to make the trip to happy camper.5 stars* meat 'za: tony (prosciutto, spinach, balsamic, goat cheese.solid lunch spot.i think we were the first customers she had ever waited on at the restaurant.it was giant, and stuffed to the brim with all things breakfast.
For my entree, i got the ribeye rubbed with cracked black peppercorn..the portion was large- i think 8 shrimp for $12.service was great too.

If you love bacon wrapped dates, the twist here is that it's simply better and more of a semi similar combination.they were giving out samples of popcorn (amazing flavor, just enough heat), granola (didn't try), almond bar (lightly flavored delicious cake).

The likelihood that my theory is right is about.the cheese flying out the middle when squishing it was a sight to be seen.the buns were good, the fries not oversalted, ingredients were quality.for us we were somewhat in the area and it attracted us to go check it out.my bad.they've also got a solid beer list.at first we accidentally walked in the take-out side, and the girl behind the counter seemed like she'd been sleeping..the quote of the night came from a latino barback/server: "man, i'm hispanic and *i* can't even eat that sh!t".i'd been anticipating this meal for weeks (went here as a celebration reward beefaganza after a competition) so maybe i was just hyping it too much in my head, but i don't think so.

One spicy broth side and one savory broth side gave us options to dip the high quality ingredients..on top of the amazing hot pot, the staff here is super friendly.instead they have a menu list of all the items.after they brought out some chili oil and soy sauce all returned to greatness.this place blows all the other hot pot place in chinatown out of the water.and because you're given the menu and a pen at the beginning, as soon as you do sit down you can hand them your hot pot menu.they were very helpful in getting our kids settled in, and they even have kiddie trays.food quality: good and freshfood selection: very good for all you can eatoverall cleanness: goodservice: prompt and goodwe got seated around 9:10 and were able to eat till 10:15.we loved this place! the staff is so friendly and helpful and the food was amazing.

The price isn't outrageous like river north, which is a plus.there are no descriptions of the cocktails on the menu, just names.i would of ordered one if i wasn't allergic to cocoa.the gentleman at the door checked our ids and we entered the small, dimly lit bar with about half a dozen booths and tables surrounding the main bar area, all full.0/5, most direct line to type-2 diabetes, a hangover, and a fun time;negroni - 4.every single item was so perfectly executed that i gave compliment to the chefs..sidenote, i'm not sure how true this is, but according to my friend apparently there's a two sided mirror in the men's bathroom looking into the bar, interesting? not sure about its validity but that's what he claimed.the bar was packed, as it should be, and they only had two bartenders making craft cocktails for a crowd of 30 to 40 people.overall, i'd likely go back if i was in the area.

All the burgers are amazing.a little weird, but whatever.and he was really into it.not sure how i feel about their fries..it looked like someone shoved onion rings through a paper shredder.i didn't get a chance to taste his bison burger but he says that was phenomenal too.meat didn't have flavor, the only flavor that came through were the peppers on the bottom bun.unreal and nothing overpowered anything else.nom nom nom.

Excellent!.but we weren't too fond with our waiter.taco joint is located on halsted and armitage, it's pretty busy in the area, not too much parking on the street.it's a smaller restaurant, little darker with a small back room.they have a wide array of choices and you can get 1 oz pours for as little as 2 dollars each.some of my other favorites were the al pastor (chicken) and barbacoa.it's a small space and fills up super quick.the tacos were pretty standard and i was hoping they would be more flavorful.taco joint is the perfect place to grab drinks with friends, especially now that they extended the space.either way, it was a good deal and delicious!! the bottle was the "on the rocks" version - definitely recommend this over frozen if you like the flavor.

Naf naf is a great lunch or quick take out dinner type place.naf naf is the new winner!  $7 for this was a bit of a crime; five small pieces of falafel mixed with the other items left me fairly hungry, and nothing about this was special.the steak swarma was served with rice and i had it topped with assorted vegetables and a spicy cilantro (?) sauce.i don't know what naf naf is doing to their falafel and pita, but they're doing it right.it's not fast food but good food fast! i like how everything is fresh and quick.if you're in a hurry, beware of the lunch rush, because the line can get pretty long.it was as good as other local favorite fast-food chains such as pita inn and roti, but i think the pita bread put it over them.i really like the falafel's and it's nice you can order one on the side for an additional 50 cents.very tasty!my only complaint is that it's more expensive to get a non-pita dish.today however, i was able to try their chicken and steak shawarma rice bowl and i must say that it was quite delish.

It is kept simple and i really like that.nice to know of a good italian spot that is kid friendly and closer to home.my group and i actually rang in the new year here, and it was great! besides the food (the prosciutto pizza - which was more of a flatbread - was delicious with salty, crispy prosciutto and a spicy bite to the dough), the waitstaff was very friendly and fun..i loved my kale caesar because the kale was tender and the salad was well mixed.the prosciutto had a white sauce of sorts and some amazing peppers to add a bit of kick to it.to be fair, some of the dishes are smaller portions so it sounds like a lot but was a pretty reasonable size meal for two.it had cacio e pepe levels of fresh cracked pepper which i loved, but if you're shy when it comes to pepper, you may want to have the kitchen hold off.
