The food is simply good..we ordered half portions of each pasta and we're glad we did!  these were plentiful so i'm sure the regular sizes are huge.fried calamari was excellent.had a very filling italian dinner with friends here.and given this was a bit of a pricey dish, i would not have expected the skimping or priceyness.next time i am in chicago this is a must return.they really make an effort to personalize your experience..and as you walk in, you would immediately think that it's a small joint, but there's more room in the back and a second floor full of diners as well.

The chilaquiles are bomb, as are the tacos.makes me really happy and i like to take the leftover soup home, throw in some noodles and bokchoy as a second meal.i'm of the belief that any restaurant should let you have a glass of water for free, but these guys want to push bottled drinks on you.personally the tacos de lomo are some of the best i have ever had.i just had sesos tacos - as in beef brain.maybe a late night taco crawl is in the works.i pretty much wanted to order one of everything on the menu there and you could tell that this place has it set of regulars too, since people would walk in and all of the staff would say hi to them, give them food hook ups, it was like being at cheers but instead being at a late mexican taco spot that felt as happy and homey as cheers.i will come back because this place is a five-minute walk from the house.they have bottled drinks, bar style seating and affordable prices.best mexican in the city.

It seems several other chicagoans love lyfe, as the place was poppin with business peeps in the area.the tables have salt and pepper shaker but the salt part is very small (maybe 1x1x1 in) so it's a way to encourage a lower sodium meal, which is pretty cool..it has a very calming atmosphere, you feel healthier just by walking in, and the people were so nice.it's also a smaller location but very popular.there are better places around streeterville to spend upwards of 10 bucks on a healthy and fulfilling meal.i had the wrap along with the ginger mint chia tea which was just okay.my sister and i went here for lunch since we were in the area and needed something relatively quick.they have a full fledged gluten free menu!my favorite is gluten free lyfe veggie burger with sweet potato fries :).

Their prices aren't cheap, and the portions aren't large, but you get what you pay for, and i will go back.all of the dishes i tried were quite tasty.not overly sweet, so moist.this place is so beautiful and eating here made me feel majorly posh.i like simple flavors, but the flavors in some of the dishes are almost too simple.boo! my very first kourig amann was from dominique ansel bakery in ny and was known as the dka.it's really hard for me to separate the pretentiousness and clientele of this place with the actual restaurant and food.the bread and butter was very good.but the value prop is way off here, so i'm not sure i would come back.the display case had a lot of turnover with various items offered with each switch of the trays.

'it's slightly below 'big daddy' which i think most would agree is about sandler's 3rd best flick.it was gamey to the point of tasting like lamb.whether you're a meat head or vegetarian, you'll be satisfied.saw the reviews and decided to stop in for something quick.henry ford never intended his process to be used for falafeling! (yes, i verbed falafel.in a rush?  craving some medi food?  want a cheap lunch?this is the place for you.while hummus, by definition is impossible to screw up, it's not hard to make hummus fantastic or incredible.this place is genius! fast casual restaurant offering flavorful, delicious mediterranean food.a young asian girl behind the counter wouldn't listen to us, was rude, and we stood there for at least 10 minutes waiting for someone to slice the chicken shawarma.*credit cards accepted.

It can get a bit loud and crowded but the food makes it worth it.i found another great restaurant on yelp.we also got the cuban sandwich which was so fresh ,hot,and ready to consume..everyone we've encountered has been super friendly and we've never had any issues with the length of time it takes to make the food.it's casual, but not a hole-in-the-wall.when we saw that half the restaurant had the chairs on the table we realized it was time to go.this place is pretty good.the bread was good.

The egg inside the raviollo was running as well, so well-prepared pasta.it felt rushed, and they kept checking on our plates before we even finished our meal.the maple gelato on top was really the icing on the cake..vasi (bread with ricotta and honeycomb) delicious, and you can ask for more fresh-toasted bread.i also got a glass of wine that i guess did not pair well with my dish because it was super bitter and they were kind enough to replace it with another that was much better....you can't go wrong with the ricotta and honey comb to start.

I also ordered the veggie rolls which were hot and crunchy on the outside yet sort of cold and had a weird texture/taste inside.this was my favorite place we dined at during our most recent trip here.if you are into japanese bbq, then def check this place out!.we started off with some drinks we got a lychee mojito, lychee martini and a lychee-tini all super sweet and just okay.with two people, we got a variety of meats! overall, a very good experience for my first bbq experience.i can't eat edamame though.we ordered about six cuts of meat and a veggie.when i knew that i would be visiting chicago, this was the first place that i put in the reservation.great food and excellent experience!.that's kind of the one thing you need to watch out for.

It's incredible how this street has transformed over the years.went here on a saturday around 2pm with no reservations and was able to be seated right away.it was quite hot outside, and all the patio tables were filled up, so the hostess took my number and name, and said about a 20 minute wait.i need to go the gym just thinking about it.oh well.more soft than crispy.this was a little too sweet for me taste, but still good.the hostess should get an instant bonus.me and willy, we bonded.my husband's manhattans were also good as was the "early house", a rye based drink with a hint of apricot.

She is clean, and her tamales are just superb!.awesome tamales! every once in a while they end up being my breakfast too ! i've been getting them for about a year and they are always consistently good.note to self "come back here fore sure, if in the hood and this time of day".very nice lady, but does not speak any english, so prep yourself before ordering.

I've been here a few times and cannot say more great things about it!first, the drink selection.place gets loud and crowded, but if you go early (before 6) you can snag a booth or spots at communal tables..the portions were kind of small for most things.i came on opening night and was very impressed with how the concept turned out.it looked like a lot of other tables also ordered it.try the fried cauliflower and the garlic naan! really everything we tried was fantastic, can't wait to visit again soon.they all did their jobs just fine.rotates just enough to keep it interesting.maybe i'm picky, but you should have a good time here and should check it out.

We started with some seasonal cocktails, which were creative and amazing..there wasn't many items on the brunch menu that i felt i had to try so i just got the cheeseburger.nothing memorable.phenomenal and so.food is really good here, and the patio is a nice place to enjoy it.outstanding experience!.our 3 starters were all incredibly flavorful.just noting to people that may be on a tight time schedule may need to think twice just because how busy this place gets.definitely check wood out, but get a reservation especially on the weekend as the restaurant is small and gets busy.

It wasn't until my coworker informed me that i knew about the change in the restaurant week menu.for an appetizer i started with the rabbit sausage with gnocchi which was very tasty.however, the combination of food, service, and price still makes blackbird 5/5 in my book.the first couple of courses were very good and would have warranted a 4 star review from me.it's also fun to watch people try to get up from a table with all of their gear after moving the tables out of the way, but ultimately this means that blackbird can really pack 'em in.i'm a pretty open minded guy regarding food and will usually eat anything with minimal complaints but after hearing a the good things about his place it made me really disappointed with my choice.everything else about this dish was spot on!.i started off with the gnocchi and rabbit sausage..came here for their prix fixe lunch for $25.

Overall: great place for some interesting spicy twists on a variety of foods, along with some great bar options.they just unveiled some new menu items and all i can say is damn.tried it last night with our significant others and i think 3 stars describes it perfectly.but this is one of the best burgers evurr.kick is the new spice-oriented restaurant located in the old sola space.get dat did.we dined on a weeknight and we had the place to ourselves.we stopped by this past weekend and at 7 pm on a saturday, they certainly were not crowded.enough to share among 4, easily.if you are a spice lover and looking for good quality dishes, then kick would be a good start.

Those sweet plantains are delicious! next time i'm in the city i'm definitely stopping by again.the flavors in this one blended quite well.juan was super nice, explaining everything to me, and even giving me a free avocado upgrade on my sandwich (yas!).i stopped by for lunch on a cold rainy day and scored free parking right in front of the shop.this place is great! it's a family owned business..until next time, the minute i return to chicago i am going straight to nini's deli!.i did enjoy everything that i ate and tried! if you're not too hungry, the empanadas are huge and a great choice! i personally found the hibiscus lemonade more refreshing than my iced cafe con leche - will def get myself one of those next time!bring the beef back please, nini's!.you'll understand), but being the suburban food girl, it's hard for me to make it out to the city during the work week.the last two times they were closed due to holiday hours, ect i finally got to eat there today and boy was it worth a trip back.

Now dessert - amazing!!i love a good fusion dessert and when i saw the pumpkin mochi cake, i knew it was meant to be.the pistachio cream brittle was actually better than i expected and actually helped tone down the flavors of the yuzu pie.typically i avoid doing takeout sushi as lets face it, its never as good after its transported...i probably should have taken advantage of that.i would definitely not order rolls without rice here again, but would try other rolls and give this place another try.everything buthe parking situation lol next time i'm uber ing here.(e.the price of half a roll is the price you could pay for a special full roll anywhere else.

Love their sandwiches! very flavorful and very tasty! menu offers a wide-variety of selections depending on what you are hungry for!..it was spicy and tasty.as soon as i got to the front of the line, they knew exactly what i wanted and it was already prepped.props!.this appeared to be working quickly and efficiently.i've been flying out of midway for years and cannot remember the countless times potbelly has provided a satisfying sandwich that's quick and consistently great quality.i was kicking myself for flying out of midway at 6:30a.

The staff was very friendly and happy to provide knowledgable information about available beers..they have a lot of options for food, even if you don't eat meat.but hey, look at the neighborhood ;).2% abv)..the bartenders were friendly and efficient.this is a great song!"overall aberdeen gets an a+ as far as i'm concerned.it had parmesan crisps and truffle giardiniera on it.solid neighborhood bar.

I bought a groupon for uprising, and stopped by on a weekend afternoon, so the place was almost empty.just do it.i can't recall the name of the other pizza but we enjoyed both.having a $30 dining credit via gilt city, let's just say that is more than enough food for two people.

Haven't tried the ramen yet, but holy crap the loaded ahi tuna poke bowl is fantastic.it is very nice to have outdoor patios to enjoy the chicago summer, but its close vicinity to the l line makes it extremely loud and hard to carry out a conversation without distraction.i didn't particularly enjoy the vibe of the place, and although i can appreciate 90's hip-hop, it wasn't the good kind that they were playing in here.watch out, warning, you sure you can handle it? that's the shit you'll hear if you dare order the furious ramen bowl because it's sooo next level spicy.if you sit at the bar the bar tender will take care of your food and drinks.after eating, i could have passed on the corn but still enjoyed the bowl.and the l is right outside so you get that too.i've been to this location 2 times, and i really like the food, casual atmosphere, and early 2000's hip hop music they play.as to the sake, i need to find out what local markets sell it.day drinking and delicious rice bowls, and furious ramen options are very much available.

It is seasoned very well and served hot.the server was accommodating she comped the check and also gave one of us (as if we were a couple) a certificate to comp our next meal.all i can speak for regarding this visit is the chicken and i am still in a fried chicken with hot sauce coma..let me just say that for some reason my taste buds changed awhile ago and catfish is something i stopped eating frequently..

Another sweet and savory combo with the maple mustard and mornay sauces, this dish is the most unique brunch dish i've ever had, and super delicious.i was excited to sample that delicious waffle again, but was a little disappointed to see that the brunch menu only had one waffle option: a $9 waffle with blueberries and cream.everything just went well and tasted delicious.we had to ask another server to bring us our check after waiting a while.food and service were exceptional yesterday for brunch.to me it had an off putting smell to it.there are too many other solid brunch spots in west town and that being said, we wont be back.i ordered the smoked salmon caesar which i thought was great (a bit strong with the horseradish flavor) and the perfect size.we also ordered the root vegetable hash, which includes smoked trout, potatoes, golden beets, fennel, pea shoots, and an egg ($14).i love how the tables are spread out at a decent distance so you don't feel so crowded.

You heard me right.i had a strawberry cider based off faith's suggestion...and eat lots of food, and laugh a bit too loudly and too much.all in all, it's a great place to go post show occasionally, but it put a huge dent in my wallet going two or three times a week.atmosphere was a 6 on a 10.the third time i went, it was fairly busy again, and this time, i didn't feel resented or unwelcomed in the least (and it helped that lindsay was our server again).we came here a few weeks back one lovely saturday afternoon and met up with a couple of friends on their amazing deck.plenty of belgians, local brews and various and sundry other beer.

Maybe order off the specials menu.i have ordered panang beef curry and crispy fried tofu.great for take out as well though we sat outside on one of their two tables.i think it was a little bland, which is funny because lemongrass is a very aromatic flavor.we got the chive dumplings, pork shoulder as appetizers.yummy hot thai food, i got the pad thai with peanut butter sauce and he warmed it up for me! if the weather wasn't so cold i would've got a thai iced tea! also weekly specials looked great!super nice owner, he is happy to be there! i even got the cute mini tote/wine bag.fresh and flavorful.small thai place primarily for takeout.this review is for a delivery order so can't comment on service or dining in house.

Some were incredibly bland and below-average (pigeon, fish), while others were quite outstanding (vegetables, fried rice)..other than that the food came out quick the rice was alright but not as good as some other resturants.i believe it is one of the best hidden family restaurant in chinatown among all the other more popular restaurants.good place for family style dinner..make sure to ask for their free chicken soup at the beginning of the meal (although my caucasian boyfriend got a chicken foot in his, which scared the crap out of him haha).i guess we just expected better for chinatown.this was deep fried goodness.i would probably return with less people.

I have tried several other dishes and they were all very fresh and tasty except for the the seafood hot pot, which the shrimp and squid were a bit overcooked.this little restaurant is located inside the chinatown food court along with other small shops and restaurants.the price point is reasonable for all the dishes.so far, the few items i've tried at this place has been pretty good and will have me returning back to try the other items on their menu.the prices are great and the chef is very nice.my mom loves this place.

Tips:pancakes are must try: berry bliss pancake tastes amazing.i like how i can make my own omelet.i wouldn't order it again if i came back here.the bf got the venetian skillet and it was also good, but nothing amazing.it will be long.there are so many options to choose from on the menu from the sizzlin' skillets to french toast creations, they all sounded delicious.(they are on the nowait app, though, so download that to save yourself some time.ok.if you are not in a rush however, i would recommend putting your name down and wandering around millennium park until they call you back.at the end it was really awkward waiting and waiting with our table cleared, people waiting for tables looking at us and no check in sight.

Highly recommended for good grub in the loop..a group of 2 should be fine because there's bar top seating along the wall.knocked them down a star bc althoug the fries were crispy, they were extremely salty.he said it was very good as well but too much.inside, they were green and vibrant.get an additional side of either (or both) with your meal.salads were blander than i had hoped, could all use some extra spices or a touch of salt but that's where tahini and hot sauces come in.easy on that hot sauce, it can over power the salads, hummus and what not.the first choice is picking salad, pita bread, rice or a wrap.

Loved that we could order an appetizer portion and even with only 3 dishes between the 2 of us, we had enough leftover to feed another person.the decor is beautiful, open, warm, rustic, and inviting..balena's service was impeccable.and we had to get the tiramisu!  this was seriously tasty, the flavors melded together so nicely and was well-orchestrated.when we were seated, our waiter was very pleasant and informative.there is a huge flower arrangement and large open dining area in front.everyone at our table tried it and nobody said anything beyond "meh.this was a pretty decent dish but nothing that really blew me out of the water.

Atmosphere was really good though.cheers!.eh, i'm totally over hub 51.for $20 dollars, i could get three chipotle burritos assembled to my liking.going back to the variety on the menu, i've had the sushi here, which is definitely super average.the restaurant was extremely clean which really impressed me.deliveries have been fast every time and also have been pack well so there are no spills or mix up between sauces or condiments.nice ambiance for sunday brunch.they give you all the ingredients separately and you make your own tacos.my company hosted a holiday party here last february where we blocked off the back section of the venue with open bar.

I am obsessed with this little hidden gem.i passed this place a million times in my ashland travels, but one day hunger pains brought me in.i frequented this cute little establishment on a wednesday night and it was pretty empty which made for good service and fast food.my first place for al pastor.our waitress was helpful with the taco recommendations and pretty hands-off allowing us girl time to talk and catch-up with no interruptions.volcan taco: get this.i asked her which was the most popular and she told us that the comadre (steak, chorizo, bacon, poblanos, onion and chihuahua cheese) was the most popular item..we both enjoyed it.really great.

The mango was very fresh, and the sticky rice was fantastic.i came here on a tuesday evening, so there was space to sit.overall: i'm glad this place opened up as there are a multitude of thai places in lakeview, but none are very good in my opinion.slightly overpriced in my opinion for thai food and for the quantity as well.gf ordered the tom yum w/ chicken soup and green curry / chicken.and ps bancock is some of the worst shlock i've wasted time chewing in years.entrees are reasonably priced and a good size, so i will stick w/ that next time.i dined in with a friend on a saturday night, and there were just three other people eating instead.i haven't yet figured out where the tom yum cafe fits in to the ecosystem of thai restaurants in lakeview:it's not quite as fantastically flavorful and innovative as andy's thai kitchen, let alone tac quik.i find this to be so impressive because for a small place she would probably save money buying it pre-made.

We ended up sitting at the bar and having some wine and snacks.the mocha bombe for dessert was also tasty, with a light interior and not overly sweet.she was so talented but unfortunately it was her last performance at travelle.my friend and i stopped in here for lunch today because i've been hearing amazing things about their burger and, since my tag line is "burger inspector", i figured i had to verify the claims about this creation.my husband and i celebrated our one year wedding anniversary and very quickly approaching arrival of our first baby at travelle, and we were treated better than family from the time we checked-in to the time we left the restaurant.i like that this place is always riff-raff free as well.i would definitely come back here to try the dinner menu.it was a little sweet and everyone at my table really liked it but i wonder if all of the fanfare scattered the possibility of analysis.i loved travelle.

I thought it would be a wisconsin style supper club but with high quality chicago food.we had a pleasant time at millie's, and we will definitely be back in the weeks to come!we would like to thank the staff and management from the bottom of our hearts for taking the time out of your evening to make a birthday so special! looking forward to seeing you soon!!.great service and awesome food.i couldn't finish mine.i've had beer flavored soup before.

What was most memorable was the square-shaped latkes that were served on the side with applesauce and horseradish!  man, those were delicious, perfectly fried, and addictive!   solid establishment.table, donkey and stick is on the 2015 michelin bib gourmand! what exactly does that mean? these restaurants are honored for offering quality food at reasonable prices, but most importantly, they are also frequented by michelin food inspectors.came in a group of three on a snowy sunday evening without a reservation & the only spots available were at the bar! highly recommend making a reservation, especially since they have a pre-fixe menu on sundays for $29 that features their menu highlights.i normally hate venturing out to logan square.my brother recommended the place for my mom's birthday dinner because she wants to try girl & the goat.our entire table was pleasantly surprised with the crispy tripe, which came with house giardiniera and mustard greens.still, consider turning up the ac on hot days.did i mention it was expensive? $180 for our portion (2 people).the staff was also quick at cleaning our table and getting it ready for what is coming next.when you walk in the host stand is absolutely gorgeous and all i could think about is if the stand was hallow and how hard it would be to lift it.

When you come in you are escorted to the elevator which takes you to the 2nd floor dining room.that said, despite it not being terribly busy, it took a quite a bit longer than unusual for our food to arrive.you can probably snag a spot in the bar/lounge if you have a small enough party so worth coming in for a drink even without a reservation.we ordered the lamb ribs, aged ribeye, surf and turf, oscar crab, wild mushrooms, and onion rings.we made it difficult and they really delivered.but the bartenders take it all in stride, pouring some amazing drinks and watching the crowd maneuver.you walk to the far back of the bar to an elevator which takes you to the 3rd floor restaurant.steak was perfection and mashed potatoes that were out of this world.it was a refreshing grapefruit martini.

Spicy pizza is definitely spicy!there are cute comfy couches for romantic dates or casual group gatherings.the busboys were also friendly - refilling our water glasses whenever they looked low and offering us boxes and bags for our leftovers.anyway, we went to the joint tonight and the place is sooo beautiful inside.food is awesome!!! siena chopped salad tastes amazing and the portion is huge! #4 cocktail is awesome and i love the lavender tone in it.the hearts of palm salad was a bright beautiful salad.on the other hand, there are several great cocktail and wine options on the menu that you could grab at the bar if you do have to wait ; ).10 bourbon concoctions to start our outing.siena tavern's pizza is about the best it's going to get! we sat at the bar and we can see the meat slicer and they were slicing fresh prosciutto right in front of our eyes!they made the dough right in front of us, slapped some sauce and ingredients and tossed the pizza in their oven.the plate served to my toddler was searing hot." the rest of my group enjoyed their dishes and we agreed that this may be our new go-to spot whenever we need nice, relaxing dinner downtown.
Love love the blackened chicken!! be ready to get drink refills! perfect amount of heat! definitely going back!..

I'd definitely give them a try again as the food was good.chillango has tacos, taco salad, burritos, and quesadillas as well - all in line with their mexican street food fare.chicken and mushroom empanada - nice and cheesy, went well with their jalapeño cilantro saucechicken tacos - were good but the tortilla just fell apart on me after one bitethe sauces they provide table side were awesome.omg!! the fat boy and his mrs.in this case it is a matter of the former.they have amazing burritos about the size of chipotle, pack em with protein, and have several interesting sauce options to top em off.chilango!!!! fun name to say..fish tacos were excellent; fresh, lightly breaded, sweet, mildly salty, and perfectly paired with julienned slaw toppings.a little more taste, but the pork was dry & chewy.

The bar is very large and the rooms were spacious.this place is a great location if you are looking to throw a unique event..the mosaic tile and dark woods define the dining space.perhaps this is just my personal preference, but i think this at least bears mentioning.

First off the live country music was fantastic and the people watching was top notch.i would have loved them if they actually had a decent amount of crab on them!our waiter was very uninformed of the alcohol selection and couldn't answer anything we asked him.overall, i always have a super fun time at bub city and enjoy all the food, beverages, and music!.there are decorations everywhere and tvs as well..i visited their rosemont, il counterpart a few months back, and this place is just as good!  their appetizers (all of them) are amazing.i don't think of bub city as like a concert venue, where i would go see a country band play, so i wasnt feeling that.also, can we take a minute to talk about these waffle fries? probably my favorite fries ever- we got an order for the table to share but i may have gotten a little territorial.also a great place for groups, bachelor/bachelorette parties/live music.looking forward to my next visit!.

It was no excuse for the horrible service we received.you can get the old school foods of way back when, there is a door to the left that used to hold a slot machine way back when.i love the cheeseburgers! yum!this is truly a hole in the wall place that i'm sure you have driven by a thousand times.it's a nice neighborhood diner and the staff is always nice.i ended up ordering my usual, the veggie omelette - side of hash browns & wheat toast..solid diner food.the patty is quite juicy and the bacon is fried perfectly.

Great place to meet up for some wine and apps! amazing service! love the staff here! they make the experience all amazing! i have learned a lot about what wines i like through the different flights i have tried :)..i ended up loving the one from oregon and macedonia.a solid 4.the selections were extremely young and most weren't very interesting...

I wish the lady who took my order told me ahead of time because it took us a good 10 minutes to find!now that we know how to find this place.it's certainly a hidden gem..tucked away near trump tower, this pizzeria is a hidden gem with bargain lunch specials and fresh, hand-crafted eats.the stuzzicoso is perfect for the summer, fresh mozzarella, and lots of salty but tasty prosciutto on good crusty bread.prices are reasonable too.delicious!!!  there's a great wine selection, too, and my bros were excited about the italian beer that is offered.amazing, great service, great patio, and i still love that my beer cost $5 while my lunch cost just a dollar more.75 10 inch pizza special for lunch and its pretty good pizza which comes in about 4 slices.thankfully the food was as good as it looked.

The workers have attitudes.i've heard about the long wait times.it'd be insane to think i'd eat anything else today!!!! the service was prompt, and professional.other than that the food was yums!!!! i'll be back but later than the 8 o'clock hour.it was definitely worth the wait.and the jerk flavor is soo good.it's a unique food offering.the fact that they are in a single spot and can give me both in a simple hand carried meal..portions are out of control at this place!  like straight up no joke.

Casual atmosphere.another must try is the eggplant with brown sauce.there's one really good waitress that is a little more proficient in english and can give good recommendations.probably the best i've had since tl's four seasons.i've had different appetizers and they don't disappoint.the chive pie and sauteed string beans were also great.we had to uber to get there quickly..if you enjoy string beans then i would recommend giving these a try.awesome!.

Great service and great prices.right off the dan ryan east on 51st street.we saw baba's closed at 11:30 so we headed here.drove by this place a few times and decided to give it a try.when i arrived the friendly guy behind the glass recommended the deep fried philly cheesesteak.

Service was cheerful and the prices are right.well worth it.my in-laws have been going here for years and the owner and some of the waitresses still remember them even if it's been 2+ years since the last time they where in!the food is great, i partially love the mussels and lasagna but i've yet to go wrong with a dish.for $5 you can't get a better salad.yummy calamari!tufano's is always busy with great cause.we left full but not stuffed, very satisfied with a wonderful meal.i never knew this place was so close to uic! being a student there we decided to go as a group to see what's it about.if you aren't looking for frills, bring a few singles for the valet and drive over here.cash only.one thing i wish they would do is brine their chicken, or get some pastured chicken.

But wound up having zero regrets!the chorizo tacos were so good that i had dreams about them during my booze-soaked slumber that night.but it goes further than that.with all of the good mexican food/taco joints in chicago, why go to this one..first time here, the food was good..

It is a beautiful room and a great atmosphere.i felt like i a movie star.we started with the goat cheese and it was amazing.overall this was a good experience, but not good enough when compared to the high price..has an old school steakhouse vibe but not in a stale/outdated way; the restaurant feels decidedly hip (part of this might be because it's the darkest restaurant i've ever dined in).it was a sunday evening and were told on the phone that the wait could be an hour or more.another thing to consider is actually the burger.i could've stayed forever.because it is gilt room's sister biz, the menu for drinks and cocktails is almost the same as in the library.

Oh yes, it was delicious.good, healthy pizza.i'm a huge bread pudding fan and mista's was ok but had far too many pecans on it for my liking.this place seems to be popular with folks who have gluten allergies, but without such diet restrictions, one can find a better pizza elsewhere, even at renaldi's down the street.a little bit nerve racking when you just want a confirmed order.:) i'd definitely go back again.it's pretty close to where i live, so i wouldn't rule out coming back - i'm just not scrambling to plan my next trip..we had a really hard time deciding on what to order and i can't wait to try some other items.recently revisited mista, for the first time since their andersonville location on clark street closed a few years ago.

Don't come on the weekend unless you actually want to wait an hour and a half to be seated..i keep saying sure, one day.he was friendly and all smiles, swiftly input our order into the ipad, tasked us with a couple of fun riddles and then boom our food started coming out - fast, like fast food fast.i basically maul over the people in the coffee shop to head back to batter & berries.would i run back here first chance i got? not really.my niece had chocolate chip pancakes which they loved.the food is prepared and plated to perfection; colorful, flavorful, strategic and downright mouth-watering.batter & berries is a spot i strongly recommend trying if you come to chicago!.you know there must be something special going on.

My favorite south loop spot, we always get the sausage and beef pizza, and it's amazing, plus the pork wings as an app are so good and big, plus they always have so many good craft beers on tap, i don't think i've ever had the same one twice, we're usually able to get seated pretty quickly too, lotsa tvs to watch the games, and outdoor seating when it's warm, i'll always come back here..huge selection of toppings to create the perfect combination.unfortunately i didn't get to try their food here but the menu did look good as well as their polish drinks.

We also had another member join us a few minutes before we were sat and she ordered a small deep dish personal pizza, which came wayyyyyy later.the pizza is good.we seated and ordered fresh spinach, and the wait was for our pizza was about 45 minutes.we ordered half "the special" and half "the chicago classic"the pizza itself was one of the pizza i've ever had.as for the pizza, we got the deep dish (duh) with pepperoni which was great! super cheesy and had plenty of stuffing.excellent spot for getting your chicago style pizza box checked off your vacation in cicagoland list!.a very good stuffed deep dish.and it was! lunch special of sausage pizza, house salad & coke all for $9.eating at the main location right now! the pizza is stuffed, similar to edwardos.i came here with my parents on our trip to chicago and we were slightly overwhelmed by the menus we were given while waiting for our table.

I got the tonkatsu black.) wish it came with more broth!.as the queue grew and their space lessened, our table was occasionally and briefly trifled by various intrusive body parts and cross-body bags.compared to other ramen places in the city, i was also pleased at the prices.i'd recommend thick noodles over thin, as they have a more chewy texture.they have condiments at every table so i added in two dollops of the spicy sauce to give it a little kick.it took awhile for us to decide what we wanted since there were quite a few ramen options but we both ended up ordering the tonkotsu black and added spice.i had the traditional noodles, they were incredible! even the leftovers tasted great next day.i found it a lot better than at other places like furious spoon, oiistar and slurping turtle, but not as good as at wasabi or ramen takeay.we were seated right away; the restaurant was less than half full.

Scratch that.service was friendly and efficient.after a wonderful bowl of gougere hope was high, but a disappointing dry pork chop and a table full of lukewarm entrees i found myself disappointed with the kitchen..our server frequently visited out table asking "are you ready to order? are you ready to order?" leave us alone dude.we had the oysters, liver pate and the ribeye.i hope this place gets more exposure.hell, lunches with friends too.prices are fair for a downtown location, but the comfortable seating, chill atmosphere and river views push it over the top in a side by side comparison.i passed by this place multiple times and kept saying i was going to try it and never did, but decided to try it today.

Don't forget a side order of the thick cut bacon (it's a must!)...in my opinion, their special double patty with fried egg and large bacon is.2800+ reviews and counting and today is the first time i ate at au cheval! fortunately, it's a monday afternoon at 2:30p and although the restaurant has been consistently packed, we didn't have to wait at all to get seated.featured unassumingly in the middle of the menu, and lacking any description, the "single cheeseburger" is nevertheless the star here.dip them into those two sauces and its a done deal! my favorite was the garlic aoili, not overpowering but made those fries even more flavorful..speaking of which, as far as diners go, au cheval sits in an entirely superior realm.finally, the burger.

They are modified to appeal to less venturous taste buds and do not have the traditional minty leaves that you'll find in argyle shrimp spring rolls (which are generally fresher from my experience).we were definitely looking forward to some oozing egg yolk!..thanks for a great 1st experience!.i have ordered delivery from here several times.will go back in the winter to try the pho.however, you do get what you pay for.i would say the taste is better too.just a short walk from home i've had this restaurant bookmarked forever but never made my way over.we also got one of the rib-eye pineapple vermicelli, and i thought it was just okay.

50, that amount is equivalent to what you pay for.i've said this in a previous review but don't take this for granted!!  other places with a less populous hispanic population will charge twice as much for the same fare.i only tried the chicken tacos but they were tasty and flavorful.im mexican.my husband had the breakfast burrito, and i had the quesadilla with carne asada.

The staff is always very friendly and patient even when i'm being indecisive.pipping hot when it got to us.we ordered the gyro wrap which was a good portion, but had way too much meat and it was rather dry.there was no feta on the side salad...the falafel wrap was a good value, but the hummus portion seemed a bit small to me for $5.i had their falafel appetizer platter and my husband and kids had their combos..added a side of hummus  as well at it was thick, creamy, and loaded with flavor.

Beer/wine but a quick call to troy got me to know that they will let me bring my booze with only a $10 corkage fee (note: wine is $6).the fresh bread that i got with it was also amazing, and i typically don't eat bread.then again, middle eastern food is known for its meats, not so much mushrooms! all in all, we were pleased with both the food and service.i went here a few weeks back with my byob club and was very impressed.it comes with this tasty tomato salad and hot  (temperature-wise) rice that hits the spot.you get plenty of food, and the meat was tasty and well-seasoned..i mean come on, it's not like it's even that expensive, it's just some beans, you give free bread, why won't you give us more beans.baba ganoush was soo silky, smoky, and smooth.slow service at first but once the waiter got our orders in the food came quick.

Mmm talking about it is making me crave it- flourless chocolate cake: pretty big portion! we destroyed it.all were as desired, fresh, refreshing, delicious.music was slightly annoying, loud and techno.there're many brunch options along with some items from dinner menu.my tip of advice: create a couple pitchers for your most popular drinks.they didn't have any flavor to them.the menu is full of many small plate options that are meant to share with the table.the lollipops were super juicy and had a welcoming kick from the piri piri.i also had a couple of the house-made cocktails.we were not completely forgotten, but the service made a good food experience, just okay.

Our group arrived at 6:30pm and the place was particularly empty even though it was a friday night.add to this reasonably priced beers and i'm sold!.went there on taco tuesday night.drinks are your standard, hipstery fare (if its a standard is it really hipster any more?) service was good.i will be back to visit this place next time i'm in chicago.i would steer clear of the shrimp ones though, not the best.we shared a couple serving of chicken fries (chicken fingers) and a bowl of tater tots..they make infused liquor, i tried the blackberry, apple, blueberry, pineapple vodka and it was to die for.

I do notice that the prices are creeping up but hopefully the quality will also.but i haven't been there yet, and i have been to mary's, and, now that i have seen the light of mary's taqueria, you can bet  your chorizo it's my go-to next time i am anywhere near pilsen.still think mary's is good, but down a step from my first visit.lengua taco all the way!..on a positive note, they have changed their credit card minimum from $10 to $5.will be back!!.i pulled up to a corner house which is a small grocery store and a restaurant in the back.first time in chicago, coming from miami, this was the best food i had on the trip! tacos were amazing!! the area looked a bit sketchy but the inside of the restaurant was very clean and the girls working were very sweet and attentive.go somewhere else for the burrito.

This was the ultimate experience.then a friend and i split the grilled cheese which was once again absolutely amazing, and the rh burger which was just as good if not better.we shared the arugula salad, grilled cheese, simple prep of fish, and the fries.if you don't have the app already, download "no wait" and it will tell you the current wait time.a must visit chicago restaurant experience..we went on a saturday morning around 11:00 and the wait was 1:15 minutes.so, to sum it up: be prepared to wait.want to get a taste of the high life? desiring that spot of fancy? looking to transport yourself to one of chicago's finest options for lunch/dinner and inspiration for your home? 3 arts club cafe (i'm calling it 3acc) and restoration hardware (rh) has got to be at the top of your list..

I ordered a gyro plate.finally i had the opportunity to try them at jacky's.i love jackys./garfield) bus and got off at pulaski.gyro platter - can feed like 2-3 people.the list goes on.those things are good but i can't give them credit because they just reheat them.jacky's is not health food.well this particular night i decided to stop by, since my sis was in from out of town and wanted a chicago style hot dog.i yelp'ed the area and this popped up.

Their slightly spicy bbq and their salsa which i think leans more toward gazpacho, which is great since i love that stuff.so cheap.i even pour the salsa on the bread or mix it in with the rice.really good lunch option.corn on the cob, mashed potatoes just blah but good cole slaw..holy smokes! this is my new favorite lunch spot (as if i ever had one).thank goodness for chicken planet.huge bang for your buck!.the meal is big enough to fill any person's appetite.

It didn't particularly stand out from any other kimchi fried rice i've had in my life (still not sure how polish food came in to it) and was pretty pricey especially considering it wasn't that much food.sorry, honey.recos be damned!!!----we ordered the whole menu sans a couple of items they were out of.the potskis and kimchi fried rice were just okay...nonetheless, we will come back for the patio in the summer and the awesome drink selection at maria's!.g!.- scallion potato pancakes: pork shoulder, kimchi, and smoked soy sauce.maybe it was just what i ordered that i wasn't a huge fan of.

I also tried one of their summer flavored mimosas, and it was delicious and sweet (just how i like it)! i had a wonderful time, and enjoyed the decor of the restaurant and the table.it's a tasty benedict and a good portion size (without being ridiculously large).i got the avocado toast with cumin for an appetizer and it was incredible.the wait is also long if you go on a weekend for brunch since it's a pretty small place.came here for breakfast and was extremely satisfied!! got the chicken sausage and king crab benedict.menu has plenty of other things for those who are hungrier.service was great and the vibes were excellent but boy that crab benedict sure knows how to make my tummy happy.thanks yelp and if you are around you can't miss it!.we sat outside, which was nice because it was such great weather, but not so nice because legit there were so many bugs, bees, flies, moths, around that it felt like we were in the woods.i can't really justify spending over $20 on a sandwich and iced tea.

That being the said, the actual taproom and food are just as impressive.you can come here to have a drink or to have a meal..i feel like the "craft" beer scene is not alive and well at revolution.i like revolution beer but this place isn't somewhere i feel wad worth going to..on saturday and sunday starting at 10am, rev offers a menu full of beer-centric spins on brunch classics...we had a 40 minute wait (by the way, there's no where to wait).

Sat at the bar and had an appetizer and entree.our server emily was attentive & friendly & made the visit very memorable..and the cocktails were nothing to write home about.the coffee is dark and hot, just like i adore.he was just the kind of server you would like to have sit down and have a drink with you (it was slow so he probably could have!, ha!) as we talked about not only the food but shared some personal stories.skillet.i met a few friends here for random drinks on a weeknight and even though the place was pretty empty, service was slower than ideal.my only complaint is that we didn't have time to stay for dinner.

Loved it -food and service top notch! my faves were the papas alioli and the bacon wrapped dates!!..the dish was prepared nicely but the serrano itself was just meh.their sangria was not nearly as sweet but i still wouldn't order it again.i think the dessert was my fav part!.

For sandwiches and tacos i had a chicken, brie & fig sandwich which came w/ sweet fig, roasted apples, spinach, garlic aioli, on rustic ciabatta.the service wasn't bad just not genuine..i waited a while for someone to take my order, finally the manager took my order.this happy hour which runs from 3-6 each weekday afternoon had not one, but multiple hosts opening the doors for the three of us, welcoming as we entered the modern, open, airy space.there were two sushi chefs creating the dynamite shrimp roll with mango and avocado, sriracha mayo,and mango- and the presentation is the same as you see on their website- that were giving me an itch to look into sushi making classes.the sauce makes the dish taste chinese not korean.the restaurant is very spacious and chic looking with a lot of windows and natural lights.they have a very eclectic menu, but everything i tried was well executed.so - since it was warm out and beautiful, we got the "big spoon".

It's one of those places that has every kind of cuisine on the menu, which is usually a red flag in my book.i'm sad i missed out on the tom & jerry cocktail this past holiday season, but i'll be back for it next year!.i haven't sampled the food here, but the beer menu is extensive, as is the cocktail menu.now, they set the bar pretty damn high by self-proclaiming them to be world-famous.most of the menu is meat oriented.i would rack them in the top third of ribs i've had in my life.typical fare is really good.really, really good!!!!the service is crazy,  it's so fast.once all of my friends had arrived, we were seated.good old bar feel here with a new food and ambiance.

Why not?overall: i'm a fan!oh billy goat.this lake location has the same menu and the same atmosphere (albeit higher up in elevation).the burgers are fast, juicy and so satisfying.i guess i should have just gone to shake shack like i originally wanted to.it is clean good service and you can just relax and enjoy the time.the guys running the food counter were rude and acted like we were inconveniencing them..and  i so appreciate that they stay open late, until 1am on a weekday!i've never been a fan of their burgers - the bread is too hard & chewy..the burgers are fine but nothing amazing.

It was so good, we ended up ordering a second one.baby girl enjoyed the large meatballs.ordered the squash blossoms.i really enjoyed the flavor - it was exciting and different compared to a lot of other specialty pizza places in the area.made for a nicely timed dinner.you wanna dress it up kids, more of a collared shirt kind of place.people missing out on the pistachios gelato here! ordered a scoop of mint, pistachios and coconut.it was great and the rest of the pizzas are likely also just as good given the wood-fired oven.

The crab meat was definitely fresh, not from a can thank ya little baby jesus! if you get it straight up you get 3 crab cakes, but if you happen to have an empty pit where your stomach should be you'll definitely need a side of tots.i don't think you have a choice.this place deserves zero stars.the lobster roll was on what was a beautiful and toasted roll, but the roll had so much of whatever the light orange sauce was on it the bread had become mush by the time i took two bites out of it.and, like, omg, the tater tots..i had the crispy fish and shrimp tacos, and they were delightful - plenty of seafood, really fresh ingredients and the perfect portion size.we sat inside, but there was seating outside with people coming and going constantly & the food came super fast, which was great!overall i have no complaints.service subpar, food subpar, and the prices really high..

I will not go back because there are much better bbq options throughout the city.i ended up ditching the bread and just eating shrimp.the restaurant space itself is beautiful.no sauce necessary.what a hidden gem.the service was also very kind and prompt...i enjoyed the food, but it wasn't mind-blowing spectacular.

The basil was very aromatic, and the yogurt portion of the dressing was smooth and didn't taste acidic at all.both were absolutely delicious and chock full of fresh ingredients.they also have some other items like yogurt, fruit, and nut mix..if you see the shrimp succotash on the menu, get it! the avocado blt is also amazing.they also provide sides of grilled chicken and tofu which you can add to make your salad heartier.the concept of salads in a vending machine might raise eyebrows; i'd stopped by the location in north bridge a couple of times and always thought it looked intriguing.the dressing is unbalanced, maybe too sweet, and it kind of made me a little nauseated.i can only see this being my go to option if this were the kiosk next to the train station and i was starving.

The barista was fantastically friendly and generous, the cafe was nice and quiet, the prices were low, and they had a bakery case that i would have gone bananas on if i hadn't been there killing time before meeting friends for brunch.lovely location with a very homey feel, especially for a strip mall.

However, the heavy rain the evening we visited prevented it from being used.tried this last night.also docking the point because i felt that the pricepoint was a little high for what we got.now onto the other dishes.that last one was me.we ordered the fried avocado, the speck fritters and the scallops with grits.the scallops were so delicious and the polenta they were served with were so creamy.they didnt say on the cachaza :-)overall, a very nice place although i think it is a little overpriced and the portions are very small.it felt like stepping into a cafe in a small sunshine drenched coastal beach town.don't go in without a reservation though - the space is tiny!the menu is always changing but be sure to order the ceviche.
Ahh in tue, wed, and thur they have a special buy 1 full chicken get 1/2 free (only to go)why the 4 stars then???  just because they were there when i needed them the most.crazy good..

Came by to try an old school greek spot.i got the rice (because #carbs).the whole meal was about $25/person including tip, which was reasonable.my favorite greek restaurant in all of chicagoland.by the time the check came, he couldn't get us out of there quickly enough.it was unnreal.it is so juicy, flavorful and tastes amazing!  the spanakopita was good too..this place is huge and if you spend a few minutes watching the kitchen at work, it's quite remarkable to see how fast they are able to deliver such great food.this is my favorite greek restaurant not only for the delicious food, but because of the charm as well.

If they make a branch out on the west coast, i have a feeling i'll be quite the regular there.service is exceptional as well as their mission.there were a few other tables occupied by either couples or groups of friends.i had a smokes fish sandwich (i forgot what type of fish), that was actually in the form of a slaw put between two scrumptious brioche buns that were amazing! their sweet potato fries were pretty tasty as well.the inspiration model of teaching students to run the kitchen is really great.the service is great.they've changed their menu since my last visit - to a fixed menu.i'll be back, particularly because i didn't feel like i should order both the chicken and waffles and the short rib sandwich.i then ordered the chicken and waffles.i have eaten here numerous times (i work right down the street from them) and i am newly flabbergasted every single time with how creative, delicious, and inexpensive (for what you get) their cuisine is!being a raw vegan i have not eaten their meat but everyone i've taken with me has raved over it.

I do wish there had been more avocado...we had a short 20 min wait before our private table was ready.take public transit or divvy over - parking is kind of a pain.the service was great and the food was really tasty..smoked beef and hashed brown: wonderfully flavored hash, goes well with the beef.this is definitely a place i would visit again.i stumbled across little goat diner, and i just knew i had to come based on the photos and reviews.

In addition to the excellent food at oriole, service was very polished, precise, polite, and personable.i feel like caviar has really kind of been done, but oriole managed to give it a new spin with sea grape.we were given complimentary sparkling elderflower bitter cider because my friend and i don't like to drink.portion sizes were just right, so that we never felt over-stuffed (although we would have happily consumed another six orders of just about anything we were served!)rather than attempt to describe individual courses, which change anyway, let me just list those items that topped those i've had at the best michelin-starred restaurants in the world: sea urchin, foie gras, alaskan king crab and japanese a5 wagyu.just when you think you have eaten everything devine the pastry chef sends you home with pecan lemon pie!  this pie had the most amazing airy flaky crust and decadant filling.this will forever be one of the best eating experiences of my life and definitely one of my favorites.absolutely flawless from start to finish.yelp note: you can split a drink pairing! it still ends up being a nice amount of drink per diner.the pasta was cooked perfectly, sauce was not overdone, and then you shave some truffles over it and you have perfection!  then the a5 wagyu course with charred lettuce and hollandaise sauce was a close 2nd best dish of the night.the ground rye berry added a nuttiness to the capellini and provided a nice crunchy contrast to the overall creaminess of the dish.

If the cubs win the world series, then we may have to consider low country as the place that got the goat off of the cubs back.i had the clams & crawfish.beerpong in any restaurant is a great idea!the staff was super friendly and explained everything to us in detail..they also have beignets and deep fried oreos here for dessert.better than angry crab.my favorite was the blend.after getting a taste of almost all the combinations between our party of 4, lemon pepper level 1 became my favorite.angry crab is byob though, but lowcountry has a really great beer selection/cocktails.yes, beignets that are usually only covered in sweet powder are instead drenched in butter and fresh garlic will leave you wanting to more to drench in the seafood boil juices.

First bite and i was in love! the pancake was soft and fluffy.the white chocolate and caramel pretzel pancakes are crazy good.even the coffee we had was brewed just right.i was a little disappointed when i saw that the online menu was different from the in house menu, as far as the pancakes go, so at the last minute i had to switch things up..honestly it tasted a bit bland.by the end of this visit the waitress hadn't checked on us but once and that was due to us searching for her to ask for something.this location is very close to public transportation, and very close to things i might go do - tourist spots, work, etc.our table wobbled so that got under my skin when i was eating my shrimp benedict, which i shall comment was delicious.i've heard from several people that the bongo room is a must-try for brunch, so my boyfriend and i opted to try it out while we were in the city.

It definitely needed some spice to it..this is more like a 3.the pork soup dumplings were bigger than the soup spoon and very juicy.we ordered four things:shrimp and pork boiled dumplingshouse dumplingspork bunsand chive and pork friend pancake (not really a pancake but i don't know how else to describe it)the house dumplings weren't really dumplings, they looked more like egg rolls and were nothing special.outstanding chili oil wontons, pork bao buns, onion pancakes and house potstickers.the pork cutlets were similar to what you might get as sweet and sour chicken elsewhere - deep fried, very crunchy..i will definitely be back next time i'm craving soup dumplings!.

That was dashed today--quick-like, too--when my wife and i stopped by for lunch this afternoon.came here a few weeks ago, unfortunately they were out of the pork belly tacos but he carnitas tacos were delicious.the tortilla was wonderful...you've only cooperated once..tempers steered me wrong here! i don't get the hype here!!!  ordered the pastor burrito today not only did it take about 15-20 mins for it to be made but the flavor profile was not impressive.i really love this place! the big state is my top choice for tacos in my neighborhood, and there are lots of other options so that is saying something..

I scoured yelp to find the perfect place somewhat near the airport and which had some chicago flair for my friends.this crust was definitely fulfilling, buttery, and salty goodness..dough is good.good stuff!.their's did not disappoint.love you guys and gals at lou's! your service is incredible and food is amazing!..00 (for 4 people).the service was friendly and nice, the space was clean and the walls decorated with some cool sport memorabilia.

Once we ordered our food using the easy-to-use dimsum menu, our food came out quickly and hot! the dim sum items are a little more oily than other restaurants but they tasted great.the shrimp har gow and pork shumai were my favorites.the dim sum dinner menu is missing some of the classic traditional dim sum dishes because the waiter says all the dishes are available during brunch hours.if you go to the chinatown location then you can take a nice stroll in the area.dim sum is good here.they still had a lot of customers, but no wait.the dish that came out was pale, steamed looking shrimp with walnuts that looked like they dug out of from the back corner of their kitchen that sat there for years! they had the "sauce" squeezed on top for us to mix into the dish.quick and easy.the shrimp were plentiful and a nice size, but this was supposed to be combination fried rice!we noticed that the dining rooms were all packed and people were waiting to be seated, so business must be good..

After waiting, waiting and waiting some more i expected this to be one of the tastiest sandwiches ever.that said, the sandwich craft aside from ratios was fantastic.even though my dining compadre and i snagged a seat, i think that's pretty rare to do during normal lunch hours.the worst part is the fact i dove in so quickly and ate it before realized i forgot to snap a picture.the cafe is a most welcome addition to merch mart which has been hijacked with the standard box box brands for food and drink..small so not much seating at lunch time.while you wait for your delicious panini, peruse the selection of amazing cheeses and think about how fun it would be to have a wine and cheese party and impress your friends with the different kinds of cheese.paninis for lunch are my favorite! i have been here so many times that i should get a loyal customer card by now.

The first stop in our chicago food hunt was pierogi heaven.now this is a pierogi!.i've also eaten their polish sausage, which is served with mashed potatoes, sauerkraut, and fried onions.i don't really care for sour cream or bacon with my pierogi, so i opted for it plain.we had the potato cheddar, spinach, meat, mushroom,  mushroom and kraut, and spinach and meat flavors.we were excited to have chicago pierogis and ordered both their cheddar and farmers cheese filled version..thanks pierogi heaven!.this place was our 3rd stop on our food quest on a monday evening.pierogi heaven?!  more like pierogi.

The pool table in the main area adds for a non-typical river north atmosphere.their menu is so fun, as is trying all the different sliders...streets raised you.been to this great bar several times.for food i went with the kentucky hot brown and merkts cheddar sliders.i also ordered 3 of the sliders: kentucky hot brown, fried chicken and elvis!they were all really good but my favorite was the fried chicken.very nice place with great drinks..

The waiters here were very nice and gave good descriptions of the menu items.the fried rice and the crab meat fish stomach soup were basic.great spot we stumbled upon via the great yelp reviews and photos! they offer parking which is awesome to start! and then the wait staff is so friendly! they made great recommendations and were so inviting.holy cow! this boat load of goodness came out fairly quick with a variety of seafood.the standouts included the shumai (pork dumplings), har gow (shrimp dumplings), and taro puff.the decor is very nice..dolo is on the low low.everything else was delicious.no hostess so people wrote their own names on a piece of paper at the bar.

Plus everything ended on time, and those who wanted to linger were allowed to linger.it's not a new flashy happenin" spot.trattoria no.i've been to trattoria a couple of times now, and it's a great restaurant for dinner, a business meeting, or lunch.i saw the crispy onions and what looked like to be a pile of white, textured goo.the soups are always delicious and their handmade spicy sausage ravioli is perfection..place is spacious--it was full of tourists --overall good job..finish with tiramasu and a double espresso.

We went to rice' n bread for burger binge week.it's super cheap, byo, and has super friendly service so overall it's pretty tough to find a reason not to love it.as a meetup organizer, i truly appreciate such good customer service! i've been to rice'n bread a number of times, and my favorite item so far has been the dolsot bibimbap.food is consistent and at a good price point.overall, a great option in wrigleyville if you're looking for a unique twist on diner food.my favorites are the jap chae, bulgogi or the spicy ramen..the dukbokki was decent and will do to satisfy my cravings but it wasn't the taste and texture i was hoping for.great bang for your buck, as portions are very satisfying and prices are definitely affordable.unique add-ins -- nutty or garlicky.

Highlights included the biscuits, the kale salad, the prosciutto/cheese board, and the truffle spaghetti.thought this was gimmicky though somewhat cool..are all worth eating, enthusiastically even..i liked the decor throughout the restaurant - rustic, shabby chic of sorts.we would definitely come back again to try more stuff.the food: 5/5.he insisted on a jazzy mock-tail so i said.this shouldn't just be a special.

I ordered the food and they prepared it immediately, which was perfect since i really needed it asap before hanger would creep in.it's very much fast mediterranean food.the jerusalem salad is tasty and i am a sucker for the gyro plate which is odd because when i am out i typically opt for the steak schwarma.$1.- chicken was a little on the dry side, but the baba ganoush was so amazingly garlicky with such awesome flavor that i would go back just for that!  great deal for tasty food!.my husbands loves this place and i think its just m'eh.i got it to go as i ate it as i walked to my car.-we ordered the lentil soup and it was sour/spoiled.my reasonably priced six dollar gyro was ready and i ran home and devoured it.the staff is friendly and efficient.

My husband likes their cajun louisiana the most, and my favorite is the coco sauce...decent sides, albeit smallish portionwise, but tasty nonetheless.the seafood isn't swimming in butter like other places and it's way closer than going north to angry crab.we love this place and enjoyed the dishes we ordered.i've never had shrimp in a bag before, nor have i worn a bib for years.potatoes were bland and lacked seasoning and didn't really pick up much of the sauces.my only "complaints" if they can be called that are that the music is too loud.the coconut curry tasted good but with my shrimp, it was very runny and watery.

All i have to say is once you have one of their homemade pop tarts(especially the apple) you will never want to eat another by the big k!...if it wasnt for the quietness and strangeness i felt from the lack of music i would have given this place 5 stars.will be coming back for the vanilla and fig latte.

I looove thin crust pizza which they have here as well..the stuffed pizza is an absolute must.if deep dish isn't your thing, don't worry, they have thin and regular crust options as well..now i know people from new york city have a hard time accepting a pizza you have to eat with a fork but i have a hard time accepting a slice of pizza that is folded in half to eat.no fancy cornmeal crust or gluten free something-or-rathers here - just pizzas with tons of toppings, sauce, and cheese.the ambiance was perfect for a saturday pizza hunt..also, the willis tower was right across the street too! very convenient for tourists.

Basically this is limited menu appetizer, pizza, pasta concept with better than average food.the restaurant is slightly above street level on ohio so it's pretttty nice people lurking from a slightly different angle.lastly, i highly recommend that they restaurant takes down those tacky holidays lights that are hanging outside the restaurant.the environment is good and the servers are very attentive.their wine selection was nice with glass, quartino and bottle alternatives.great seasoning.)  they only offer four bottles under $30.might be the best octopus i've ever had!we also ordered various pizzas, pastas, and salads.the salads where delicious!  drinks were incredibly strong!!!.overall, everything was really tasty and reasonably priced.

After an extremely long day at work, i had decided to stop into this lincoln park gem.i would recommend based on the sandwiches being delivered around me.it was a great option.they're known for the "all you can eat" salad bar, but i was not that hungry..my buddy got an ice cream sundae which he said was very good.overall the menu is  overpriced considering the quality and taste.but there were no cucumbers, artichokes, roasted peppers, or celery, and very limited cheese options.i was also terrible at pouring water from their carafes.i really did not like the feel of the restaurant.

We salvaged it by dipping it into our lattes..i guess i'll just have to go by another one.i ordered the rainbow cake and iced horchata coffee for around $10.loved the overall combo, although at points i felt it may have been a little too lemony.definitely a fun place to check out..there wasn't a huge selection of places to sit and sharing a large table with many groups of people isn't as relaxing.i had ordered a nitro coffee but i did not like it that much.can you fall in love with a coffee shop? if so, consider me love struck.

Delicious food at this amazing little restaurant.huge tacos, and not ones with just lettuce and cheese on them and real pieces of steak!  they do come in at $3.they were out of bread.this kind of thing really annoys me.come here if you want excellent tacos!.(hmmm..i will be back here as it is great value and solid quality food.my favorite has to be the beef stew dish they serve.i like tacos like i like my oil changes--quick and cheap.
I had to sit my two year old in that..the double cheeseburger was fresh, on a sesame bun, and they use red onion, which i always think is a nice touch.clean and well put together.

Food came out slower than expected.the only reason i gave it 2 stars is because though they do use some fruit in the smoothie, they also use sugary syrups.still, good options.very friendly people and the crepes came out as they were ready, so timing was tough with such a large group...the creeps are made with some herbs in the batter! they are a decent size.m came with me and had the rotisserie chicken, which was very flavorful and quite succulent.i die.i'm still hoping that i misunderstood.

The food and margs were great.all while dolly parton's silky vinyl voice filled the chicago sunny morning air..the tacos were also delicious.the queso was delicious, but the pork belly taco was disappointing.i've been wanting to try big star since it opened.what's there to say that hasn't been said? good tacos.this saved my girl and i from most likely a hour wait when all we wanted was some quick food before a art event."i don't have "special needs"; i just didn't have any reason to think that taco would be the spiciest on the menu.every time i have ordered one they throw cinnamon on top and it taste amazing! this was an epic fail!i will however return to taste the tacos! :) and definitely recommend stopping in for some cheese!.

The carne asada tastes like it comes off the grill at a backyard cookout.don't be fooled and walk into the first door, that's where they fulfill their wholesale orders.chicken was tender and juicy, beans were flavorful and not overpowering, and the whole thing just made my day.very flavourful at the same time it was great price!went there on a saturday morning, and it has its own store selling tortilla/bread and stuff, it was filled with people speaking spanish, making it very authentic.on sundays they also now offer tamales de mole which are very unique and savory.definitely give this place a try, you'll thank me later.really like the kick from the green sauce (tomatillo) in the chicken tamales.the tortillas were a little more puffy than i usually like in my flour tortillas (i love the ones that are basically just fat and flour, rolled super thin) but were tasty all the same.plenty of seating inside, and if you're lucky some sweet serenading a la guitarra.only bad thing, there was at least 3 solicitors that came into the restaurant asking for money.

The green goddess is my go-to in all seasons (hot or iced) and the pancakes are great.once our orders were in, the service picked back up.it's actually a lot of chips sitting in a jalapeño-tomato sauce, covered in chicken, sour cream, cheese and eggs, which i ordered scrambled.the food is good and has lots of vegan options.portions for those dishes were also significantly smaller.the girls were nice but not attentive.the server was very friendly and quick to ask us if we were only getting coffee or also food.built as part of theaster gates's community developments, the currency exchange café is across the street from the garfield green line and only about a mile from the uchicago campus.we had to wait awhile, but i didn't mind because everyone else waiting was so chill and the music kind of make me want to stand.it was busy so i wound up seating myself while waiting to figure out where my subject was, but there was no acknowledgement of my presence for at least 5 minutes.

The ambience of this place is pretty cool.this is my go-to place to take any vegan/vegetarian buds, and it's really great.i'm not a big fake meat girl so would skip this in future, but otherwise this thing was where it's at.it was simple yet delicious.this is one of the havens i bring my vegetarian friends to, almost every dish can be made so.it was a smaller appetizer with only 5 spears but was well worth it! the sauce that came with the app was superb!i has the ahi tuna steak sandwich with the house cut french fries! it was great!they are know for there appetizers and nachos!i loved this place! the food, the atmosphere, the style, creativity and diversity in the menu, the staff! this place is a must and i can see why the locals love it!the only downside is i tried to buy a shirt on the way out but the didn't have my size, probably because everyone loves this place just as much as i did!i will be back handlebar! cheer!.dinner faves: black bean muduro, everything green salad, fried pickles, chilli cheese fries.my friend ordered the vegan "sloppy joe" and even as a meat eater, he loved it and finished the whole dish!4/5 because it was a bit dark/loud/crammed..i honestly probably would've been happier if i had ordered it as my entree.

Vendors include:antique tacoaloha pokefurious ramensmoquethe budlongfarmer's fridgeblack dog gelatoand a few more.the great thing about revival is that all of the vendors are chicago based-- no chain restaurants here..there are only a handful of the shops opened around 7:30ish that sell breakfast sandwiches but it's a great way to try a different item menus without waiting in line.i thought about getting the slightly healthier turkey option but i saw the guy at the counter slicing the brisket.i love how they are so flexible and can customize everything to your taste.the meal came in a brown box and the side in a mini coffee cup (eep! cute).i had the strawberry basil, maple ginger snap and chocolate.each vendor is unique and the decision on where to dine was a tough one.if you want to eat lunch here, you'll end up spending about $15, which blows my mind and something i never do.

I had the whitefish with pine nuts and it was buttery and just the right amount of flavor.the price was comparably reasonable so i ordered it.and then tried to make it seem like it was our fault for not mentioning it though it was clearly advertised when you walk in.upon arrival, out table was ready for the group.all were delicious and cooked perfectly.yummy! but the salad i ordered? ehhh i had the house salad and added chicken.brunch without mimosas and coffee? not a brunch i want to go to.solid spot for drinks after work..of the little bit i know of chicago, i would say this is one of the best happy hours there.

Good to go in a group to pick a sushi platter and avoid confusion.so simple looking but a perfect marriage of french and japanese with the panko and foie gras living happily ever after...i ordered the unagi don and i was so happy that unlike most places, they sliced the eel and didn't give you too much rice..for the price point, i would expect to fish to be more fresh.it's in a very convenient location right next to the w on adams.good windy city roll.do eat here.

How steak should be.i also had the autumn chopped salad which was fantastic and full of delicious veggies including sunchokes and fennel.the bar tender was very enthusiastic and helpful in giving us some guidance with the drink menu.very odd, but edible.if you're going to try this place out, i only recommend going right when they open..the dining experience was good, 'twas well lit, music- i don't remember (which is a good thing), noise level- insignificant - easy to have intimate conversations at usual speaking volume.the entire meal showed finesse and high quality.

Overall, things about twisted spoke that stand the test of time:1) great outdoor rooftop bar and seating...my fiancé had arrived soon after they'd opened on a saturday morning and it was perfectly quiet, though it became more crowded as our time there progressed.they had an awesome po' boy, amazing bloody mary's and great rooftop seating.we ordered jalapeno poppers and cheese curds.whether or not you should actually be consuming that disgusting spirit is one thing, but if you want a unique taste of chicago, you know where to find it.i enjoyed every single bite of it.tons and tons of good beer on tap to choose from, so you're sure to find something you'll like!the atmosphere is cool, laid-back with a biker vibe.not sure of the crowd after the sun goes down but would be willing to try it out!.

That was after some kind of blue margarita with jalapeños.i'll see you soon rojo guisanos!.they were all delicious.i was impressed.went for $2 taco tuesday.the two pieces of fried chicken (leg and wing) are my favorite pieces of the bird.this time i tried the green shrimp curry, pork and steak tacos all excellent but the green shrimp curry was the star of the show.the raspberry sauce was perfect!will definitely come back and take advantage of the patio!.why four stars? service was really lacking, but i'm sure it's just a growing pain.
