Usually the non-booth person has to suffer.absent the art institute, millennium park, a concert here or there and congress parkway, i have spent very little time exploring this vicinity.i wish i could recall our waiters name to give him a shoutout because he just might have been the best server i have ever encountered.venue -- seating can be tight if completely filled.sure, there were quite a few there for dinner but overall, for it being 6:30 in the evening, it wasn't filled to the brim.there were so many other items on the menu that i was exponentially more interested in, but i was anxious about not ruining my suit :/ i was also trying to be healthy after a long weekend of fried foods.the general manager even cane over to recommend a wine and he was spot on!  the prices are high but for a reason so just go in and expect it.there's no debating that this location is great.this restaurant i pass by many times and went here with a very good friend of mine.one can only wish for to dine here on the daily.

It seemed like they were grinding the coffee beans to make my coffee.we started with the guanabana juice (say that three times fast!), which our server described as a cross between pear and apple.we visited because it's not far away from home.the blue demons in this neighborhood are definitely dating up.this part was kinda disappointed but the waiter noticed so when he brought it he apologized for the delay.:)the staff if very friendly and the inside is cute with colorful walls.let's just say i felt like my arteries were being clogged.left my husband wishing he was venezuelan! the meat was cooked to a perfect medium rare, the fish was tasty and fresh, the chicken and pork were perfectly seasoned and went great with the sauces provided.if you want a taste of venezuelan/south american food, you need to come here..

My bud and i had the tuna tartare, lobster roll, maine style, and asparagus salad, all of which was delicious, though oddly presented, with the lobster roll arriving way before either the salad or the tuna (we ordered all together.we ordered our drinks and food and everything came out quick! no complaints on anything! the drink i had, sunset (something), was delicious! strong too! but i liked it.wait staff was very friendly, and for a few hours i felt as if i was really in an uppity beach town.it's a must to visit the place at least once just to see the setting.delicious pizza.we had some mimosas, ciders, and oysters and for food i did the lobster blt and husband did the prime rib sandwich.service was quick for us and they had no problems splitting up the checks which is always a plus..this place is pretty close to the office so i've been here for lunch a couple of times.

This trip included: dressed oysters ( happy hour special) which were good but a little on the salty side; very fresh seared tuna with a kicky miso mustard sauce (tuna tataki); agedashi tofu which was one of my favorites -perfect meld of salty/crunchy/umami; crispy maguro maki (delish); northern california maki (yay soft shell crab!).choice of rolls seemed pretty basic, but very fresh.i love sour!here are the bites in order of favs:pork belly -- this comes with a poached egg on top, so when you break that yolk.was satisifed.okay, so i've been to the old sushi wabi and always thought it was just okay so when this place opened we've wanted to go for quite a while just to see if it would entice us in the randolph foodie zone and well, it didn't really entice us too much.they weren't on par with gt fish & oyster, but that's a tough measure.there cocktails were all delicious! loved the atmosphere.what is important is that all the rolls we ordered we really good, not blow your mind.the salmon was so fresh and we were back in heaven with each chew.not amazing.

Overall: good pick for a quick an tasty panini that are a good size.so good !my boss got the tuna and loved it! said it was the perfect tuna meltthe smoothie was great.i'll definitely be back in the future!.it is very small restaurant that is very clean.may come back at some point for more soup and to try a salad, but will stray way from the over-priced veggie sandwich.the soup was ok, decent flavor but nothing to write home about.the owner asked if we liked spicy things and we said duhh, so he gave us this ridiculous sauce that was part aoili, chutney, and siracha mayo (maybe?).this panini is delicious.if you're looking for an upgrade from your typical potbelly's sandwich, panini republic is a great option.very excited to have this place near my house.

Great food!byob.the tiramisu was very good as was the carrot cake.do yourself a favor and give this place a try, you will not regret it!.lots of mayor daley lookalikes and your stereotypical broad -shouldered chicagoans.i think for what you get, they need to lower the prices by a few bucks.mom and pop style, good food, byob, you are sitting inside a store, good prices.i got the mona lisa salad today with spinach, peas, and chicken.terrific neighborhood gem for authentic italian food from a friendly wait staff/family.i will look forward to trying something else on their menu next time like perhaps their pasta dishes.it was all sooo good.

A-ok..i think i am obsessed! i always get the same three things to share with a friend.i live next-door and i get that frequently, as well as the falafel and baba ghanouj.if i had to die death by hummus, i would die happy..the rice and pita were standard but this is a good place with fresh meat so i'll be back!.it was alright.with pretty quality portions of tasty marinated meats it's definitely a steal for something that you can potentially eat for two meals.last time we ordered here we went with the combination feast.

We arrived on time and were seated promptly.the only minor criticism i have is the bread it was served with could have been a bit crispier.next time!we throughly enjoyed our dinner.the wait staff was good.we tried bershire porkchop, octopus, cassoulet (must get!), bone marrow arancini (omg amazing), salmon flat bread, scallops and feta burrata cheese.we went last night for the first time..the decor is really nice, you feel like you are eating out on an adventure, the dimly lit restaurant space, the bar space or table areas, all of it pairs together so well and they have outdoor seating with the weather is nice too.we ordered the burger medium rare, and we were in a bit of a rush - the burger took awhile and was well over the mark of medium rare, to the point of being pretty much well done, but regardless we ate the entire thing and thought it was delicious, my boyfriend commented that he wished we just got our own meals instead of splitting.attentive service.

I have only been here once, but the steak quesadilla was delicious!  this is the perfect place to hit up after being out on a late night in pilsen..and know what? i thought this place was totally and completely average.anyways, service was cool and they are open late.that is exactly what i ordered when i came here and it was delicious.

I had a iced latte.this place makes a perfect macchiato, which is a rare treat in this city.the menu, while limited, is creative and unique-- i had the shakshuka and a prosciutto + gruyere croissant.current menu sits on a table counter for you to browse.the food is diverse and you have a lot of options that are delicious and diverse.i think there was kale in it? it must be healthy right?anywho we sat outside on a nice sunday afternoon.met a friend here for a late lunch midweek and we both left happy and fed.so much so that when i needed a relaxed and lovely place to get married, i chose bk..the interior atmosphere is white-washed brick and american-amish dining chairs, but i think the back deck has a lot more potential for warmer days.

My only gripe is that they're cash only.best tacos in chicago.nothing outstanding or terrible either way.00...the al pastor taco is pretty good too.the alpastor was not alpastor and it was drenched in sauce but the sauce was good.that's alright though, they make some pretty solid tacos.it was pretty cool that the waiter took our orders with an ipad, but this place only takes cash.

This is exactly what i had been missing in austin! i loved the atmosphere; it was different from the typical chinatown push-cart craziness that you find at most places.likely any dimsum dish you can imagine, they have it.we tried the mango pudding, and all kind of laughed because it tasted like a big bowl of nothing - no flavor at all.the only problem was the timing.it's great.no, you gotta order off the menu here, but no big deal because the food is very good.everything is so fresh and delicious and not greasy like some dim sum places can be.when it compares to hk, this is definitely a strong contender.the food is without a doubt authentic and high quality.waiter gave us a window table with gorgeous view of the park and the city.
We finally placed our order after having stuffed ourselves on fresh tortilla chips and spicy homemade salsa.

This was exactly what i was looking for in my first experience with chicago deep dish.this place will give you layers upon layers of deep dish delight!! i came here while visiting a friend and she recommended here for satisfying the tourist's craving and her own native craving for deep dish.great food and average service.i came for the deep dish due to all the hype.get the chicago classic with mushrooms, onions, peppers, and pepperoni--stuffed...we did run into an extremely rude bartended.this is probably the most random irrelevant, and poorly drafted review i've ever written, but i just can't even put into words how f'ing amazing their pizza is.nom nom nom me wants more in my tum tum!  thanks giordano's!!!.

It is not what i would call authentic.it had a weird smell and taste to me, and i'm usually a fan of wheat beer.the menu is amazing!when you sit down a basket of fresh rye, pumpernickle, and wheat bread is served..that seems to be pretty factual, since the table next to us was a large group of people on a chicago food tour.got the wiener schnitzel and it had zero flavor.but it was both good and filling, and, given many hours of drinking, completely essential at the time.i got the berghoff flight just to try all their beers in one go and the bratwurst plate lunch.i hadn't been to this place since i was a kid and i was just as finicky an eater than as i am now, likely even more so..

Devil dawgs is located in the south loop, which isn't particularly close to me, but i made the trip after reading some reviews..and the fries were chock full of fresh, greasy goodness as seems to be the norm in chicago.alas that i will not be in the neighborhood in the foreseeable future, because based on this first visit, devil dogs must have a hundred other winners that i will not get to try any time soon, and at a great price for someone looking to get adventurous with the menu.came here immediately after landing at the midway airport because i needed to try my first real chicago dog and portillo's was farther from our hotel.i was too drunk to remember what was on it but it was fantastic.i just came here for a quick dessert after dinner at nearby lou malnati's.the dog had a pretty good "snap," and the relish was really neon..although, i'm not sure if i would go out of my way to visit there if i was in another part of chi-city.

Staff was very friendly and always around when we needed a drink refill.they were delicious, such incredibly fresh avocado too!  it was a really unique taste, like nothing i'd had before, and it certainly helped calm our starving stomachs.we only found it because we were in search of something we could walk to on the 606 trail.sadly, we were the only table in the entire restaurant on a saturday night!  tell your friends and check this place out.it's a nice place for a date or for couples to relax with a few drinks and outstanding mexican fare...in decor that is, odd art on the walls.i hate eating in silence..

We weren't a big fan of the flavors and the dish overall; however, the grits were awesome!  we were also served these complimentary pimento cheese topped crackers which were also very tasty!.there's also a huge patio that is thankfully not on irving park, so it's nice & chill.it is a little loud, but what do you expect for a boozy saturday brunch? really great.everything i tried was great!!.the cocktails were pretty good so no complaints there.they have a "chic" appearance that blends with a gastropub.i will have to return to leave a more detailed review.many food items to pick from..went here for my friend's birthday brunch a few months ago.

I think our server sensed the tension and made it a point to give our gauntlet, er, i mean table some space, though i'm sure it was hard since there were 8 different dishes that needed to be brought to the table now..+ wonderful mimosas.it certainly has a bit of a hipster vibe (not a bad thing), which i tend to like a lot.we also tried their breakfast burrito but it wasn't as flavorful as we like it to be.it was definitely one of the better brunches i've had in recent memory.i tried the food all through our table, that makes it a total of 4 dishes, and honestly not a single one was great! it's different, yes, but i wasn't blown away..there'll be lines unless you hit 'brunch' around 'breakfast time'.what a delicious melody of different flavors.

Coffee was average.discovered this place through yelp and its definitly a hidden gem in new city.we park in front and from the outside the building looks normal, but once inside it is a pretty cool place, simple but very well decorated.i like the bread and how they press it so it's crispy, but the meat inside was a bit dry.the food and service were top notch.i liked it here.

We grabbed a dogfishhead pumpkin ale and the bartender first stopped us and asked if we wanted a sample.but please add a some soulful music selections (e.served in a mason jar!their drink menu was very appealing to me, many great options for different types of people.the food is decent, and the service is good.bellwether.i had the lamb burger here, and it was perfectly cooked with a perfectly toasted bun.after the movie, we nevertheless returned with even more friends due to the convenience of the location.something about that place had charm and character that this new place is lacking.the cocktail list is definitely on the terse side, but i knew that i wanted a bloody mary..

The ramen is very authentic, the shaved noodle is great too.i had the vegetarian fried knife cut noodles and it was good..there are some appetizers available, but the pork and chive dumplings are a must try.there was one thing that drew me to the doorstop of slurp slurp.the beef stomach, brisket and a slice of pork belly from a generous neighbor's bowl couldn't have been better.i used to be someone who would only frequent new chinatown.this place really took me back to the 5 rmb bowls of ramen that i had in china back in the day.one of my friends got beef shank hand pulled noodles and i thought it was looked a little bare compared to mine.when it comes to noodle places, the only protein i look for is oxtail noodle soup (my favorite).

I love a mexican restaurant that has pickled carrots and cauliflower in a big container right beside you.i think their fair.the service is very slow though.random stop the other night while walking bars in the area.i usually just get the carne asada burrito.asada and pastor had great flavor but the heaping pile i was left to eat them from left little to be desired visually..open late.basically i am saying all of the menu items do not have details.it's a small place, but bright and inviting.

For entrees i split two things with my boss because i couldn't decide on one and she was looking at the same two items.here's why, portions are large and perfect, interior is gorgeous and the food is absolutely delicious.for my main course, i ordered the vitello caluzza, which included veal, sun-dried tomatoes, peas, goat cheese, white wine and garlic angel hair.i didn't feel rushed to leave either - big plus! though that did mean it took a little while to flag down our waiter for the check in the end..i got the flatbread pizza which was very good my friend got the burger and the stuffed french toast.i highly suggest the breakfast pizza but nobody in my groups were unhappy with any items.great food and great decor.we got a couple bottles of the wine special (great wine for $20 a bottle), and shared the quail app as well as the pizza with the figs and i think pancetta? both very good.i don't know this is how is supposed to taste, but it was just ok for me.

Definitely a higher end establishment, though their lunch menu isnt too expensive, the cheapest item is $12, i got the grilled chicken sandwich which was pretty good, they had a decent beer list, the interior is very nice, especially if you can get a window seat, most people i went with got the cheeseburger which they all said was very good, gets kinda packed at 12 so try and be there at 1130..

The salsas were all really fresh and tasty!! the chips were also pretty fresh and super thin just the way i like them!special of the day was barbacoa plate with beans and rice.let's seei am not a history teacher so will not ramble about the connection to nuevo leon restaurant and all that.the waiters speak spanish to you and, i guess that if you don't understand, they will switch to english..similar feel to el nuevo leon but a little nicer decor, smaller, and the dinner/lunch menu is mainly grilled meats..nuevo leon was my favorite mexican restaurant in the city so i was really excited to try the new restaurant opened by the owners.the establishment is clean and i feel like i can't mention enough how delicious it is.we started with the queso fundido (which i would highly recommend for some all around cheesy goodness) and had a few skewers each of chicken, steak and shrimp (which were blackened perfectly and full of flavor).

The bread and olive oil were nice, as were our appetizers, which were plentiful for the group.risotto mushrooms for $ 8.the pasta was divine!!! ii'd love to go back for a more personal experience so that i can really look over the menu but i'd be back for sure!.they change their menu often and seems to do a good job with most dishes, so definitely deserves repeat visits!.the service was great and our waitress gave great wine pairing recommendations.photographs turned out wonderful as we sat next to the window.the calamari was tasty but the sauce wasn't very flavorful.the bread that they brought to the table coupled with their flavored olive oil was phenomenal - the best i've ever had at any restaurant (and i eat out a lot)!  it's safe to say that we couldn't stop eating the bread, but do yourself a favor and save some room for the amazing meal you have ahead of you.i had peppers and sausage as my appetizer.the husband and i greatly enjoyed our experience at francesca's on taylor this past thursday evening aka jazz night and $5 martini night.

After a couple months of my boyfriend talking about how he dreams of umami burger at night, we finally got around to going together.my first time here today with my cousin and i was impressed by a number of things- the service was fast even when they seemed to be busy on a saturday afternoon! most of the food tasted delicious: the umami burger which i added egg- very flavorful and patty was big and not dry, and truffle fries were yummy! unfortunately the ahi tuna-i don't see why many people are crazy about it and the umami caesar salad added grilled chicken-chicken was dry and i didn't agree with waiter that i was really good.ordered the umami burger and sunny side burger.it should really be served as a combo, yknow? but regardless, the experience was nice and would love to come back again to try their other bites.good food, ok service, good drinks.these were the standout of my meal.the place was definitely busy, but there were tables for 2 and 4 open all around and so we were shocked when the hostess said there'd be a 30-minute wait.i had the umami burger and it lives up to the hype..i knew burgers here were good, but i wasn't expecting such an amazing burger.

So after few comments of friends i decided to try this asian bistro restaurant..they try, i mean they really do.the food was fresh and delicious and our server was friendly and helpful.the sweet and spicy bbq sauce is delicious.very confused since we already ate our plate with no complaints, she said she told the kitchen to make another plate for us.it came with 3 cute little mini corn muffins and honey dipping sauce..

Acapudia was less greased then other spots which is a plus.the pernil box is absolutely delicious, especially with some of the garlicky sauce.it said "breadless" so i was interested to see what the sandwich was going to be like.) and make great food.i couldn't order from any other food truck once i saw that they had lechon-- i love me some crispy pork skin with tender, falling apart pork! tried the beef and cheese empanadilla and the shrimp and potato empanadilla.you can choose your own cheese too!i tried the coco rico soda! it tates sooooo good and refreshing!!!! they also offer other authentic mexican drinks, which are worth checking out!!!.the steak jibarito sandwich with queso chihuahua is the best, the shrimp empanadas and the platano maduro.get you some.i use to crave jibarito every time and would drive up north just to fulfill my cravings.first experience was seeing the food truck by chance over by the merchandise mart.

There were about 10 dishes ordered.totally random).we will definitely be back again.we were seated immediately and a white sox game had just finished.the young man expressed his curiosity on the goose island beer (yay 312 babe).bridgeport has lots of these little gems hidden away..gio's in bridgeport has better ones in my opinion.i've never been to the restaurant to try the italian ice, but it was not very good at the taste of chicago.

Two of the areas are more casual area then the third area has a bar and an eating area for the "market".good service.it's true.95$ which is pretty decent i think.our waiter was friendly although seemed a bit overworked on tables and didn't really check in on us until we were almost done.it turned out to be no big deal, but he felt so bad that he sent over free cookies- really nice and really unexpected (and totally unnecessary because the snafu was not the slightest bit of a problem).i had a salad with salmon and the salmon was cooked just right.another leye hit!.first off, where else can you walk in at noon and be seated right away? here.had both breakfast and brunch during my one week business trip and was very very pleased with the service and food! the staff is pleasant and attentive to our needs.
The portions were large and daily priced.cant have any better bbq wings.were they always this good? lol.recommendation...

Beers are reasonably priced.this place is great!!.my favorite has always been the veggie pizza - the basil flavor is great!they have a nice back patio for good weather! happy this place is so close, but definitely would go out of my way to come here.i like this place.the food was fine.i think the side was customer's choice, if i recall correctly..beer is very affordable ($4 drafts) and they have a long list..they have a variety of food; sandwiches, bbq, and pizzas.

Very good foodvery good servicethe environment is uncomfortable because the tables are far too close together, the noise verges on unbearablei used to enjoy tuscany, now i avoid it because you always feel crowded and rushed because of the proximity of other parties and the horrible noise that results..can you really go wrong with chicken with prosciutto, fontinella cheese, a chardonnay reduction, and spinach?be prepared for a loud environment.both were really tasty, but i thought the grilled calamari (which was a special) had too many chick peas in it.everything was well seasoned and presented well.i'm assuming they would know where to go to get good italian food! :).i had to unfornuately give it only three stars, because the food was not that great.anyhow, the parpadelle and chicken with gnocchi special were delicious! can't wait to come back in the summer and enjoy their outdoor space.

Bone marrow - this came with 4 bone marrow pieces.what makes this place is so great is how beautiful it is.we both did not finish this item.overall, a great place for brunch with friends.hence, 3 stars overall...despite being father's day, we walked in without a reservation and were seated immediately.we'd go back constantly if we lived in chicago! i loved the ambiance -- the restaurant was clean and modern, classy but unpretentious.dinner plates were cleared, and only then did we inquire about the pickles.

It's just a hometown restaurant that consistently serves amazing food.huge chunk of feta came on it as well.the good: tasty food with large portions.everyone ordered the kalamata chicken, which is half a chicken, accompanied by bread, french fries and salad.do you need a hug, girl?i will continue to go to athenian room because the prices and food are always on point.even though tina fey says the chicken is delicious i don't think i'll be back.the menu had many different options to pick from.i just can't stand watching people belittle others.pretty great place for classic mediterranean fare in chicago.solid place in the depaul/ lincoln park neighborhood.

We went for restaurant week lunch 2016 which ended up being a pretty excellent deal.so we waited at the door 4:45pm so we can get an early table if possible.i travel to chicago a lot and am glad i finally tried frontera grill.the guac and chips starter was terrific and was offset by room temp entrees.seriously one of the best meals i've had in my life! the decor is adorable and stays true to the mexican style rick bayless is known for..for our main courses we shared the mushroom tacos and the shrimp/fish tacos.but what really soured the whole experience was our busboy, if you could call a balding grown man that.they had marinated pears on top with hibiscus flower petals and chocolate sauce covering the plate.

Would you like some cheese to go w that wine?don't mind if i ~do~! so simple, yet classy which make this charming neighborhood bistro a slam dunk.i want to come back and eat more!!!  there are like 20 sandwich options with delicious and creative ingredients, how can you go wrong?  it's a little pricey to go to on a regular basis, but i will definitely keep it for my treat days..i love, love, love, pastoral! my boyfriend loves cheese and is extremely picky.great, cute shop and very helpful staff..the least they could have done is a small la fournette item - it's right down the freakin' street.you can add all the extras you want or build your own, and they have a few salads/sides to choose from.but not in march.

I've been here 3 times now and i can safely say this is my favorite breakfast/brunch spot ever..the torta which i ordered was perfect!  of course, i was being rewarded by the heavens for being a father, lucking out with a wonderful daughter..still, the people are nice and food is tasty.the result is that it's cheerful and lively, but without the kid-dominated chaos of ann sather, the eternal florescence of melrose diner, or the hipness of kanela breakfast club.it was cold outside so the site was not necessary.it's on the corner and the seating is on roscoe, not broadway so you can enjoy sitting outside without crowds, busses etc rolling but you can still people watch if that's your thing.the tacos are good but not outstanding.i'm going on record to say that i'm going to become a regular there and will eventually set the record for most machaca burritos eaten there.

Ugh never again used to be my go to place for ribs.great pulled pork sandwich.but seriously.parking was also relatively easy if you don't mind the slight walk.this place gets packed quick but there's an outdoor patio and ordering take out is swift.hit this place on a tuesday so that you can finish dinner and roll across the street to see a movie on the cheap at the regal ($7 on tuesdays).i definitely think it's worth trying, but it wasn't my personal favorite (compared to all other po boys in life).i also hear that their pulled pork sandwich is top notch!it's a casual place and the location is across from the movie theater! you can grab lunch or dinner before a show!!lastly.the cole slaw was great.beef brisket is cooked perfectly with a great smokey bark.

(that and something else, but i'm trying to keep this review pg.the -..overall, the meal was excellent.normally, i would've mentioned this to the waiter to get another glass and replace it, but seeing as how as i was about to drive out after paying for the meal, i decided it would be better not to.however, it was still a good steak, but i would likely try a different meat dish next time.i also enjoyed some of the a la carte items like the beef cheek ravioli..we had a fantastic evening, and i would love to go back!.drive past here regularly- keep hearing good things, too.

Hang out at the bar and you'll get to talkin' craft beers with passionate drinkers, and you might meet a local craft brewing celebrity! the fundraiser event lions, tigers & beers was fun, and very popular.front is tart with raisin, dark chocolate, and soy sauce notes.our server was wendy and she was honestly amazing, even split our checks without us asking and when a server does this i automatically leave a better tip.there were three of us, we ordered the small(er) size fries, they were delicious and incredibly plentiful."any time of the day is a good time for pie..will be back to work my way through the menu: vegan chili, mac and cheese, quinoa vegetable plate.and no one wants that..i came here last night for dinner and it was delicious!  i had been here once before a few years back on a date but don't remember it being this tasty.

Awesome chill and laid back place to get some brunch!.too bad i don't live in the neighborhood so i won't get to try it all!this place is close to perfect, keep it up!.one of the best places i have tried mexican food,  i would highly recommend this one.it's byob and i ordered the pecado al pastor salad which i was surprised to find it was spicy.as soon as we entered the guy (i'm assuming maybe he was the owner) was sooo sweet.it was a good experience and i know it exists in case i need a bite while in the neighborhood..the dish came with two eggs, breakfast potatoes, tender pieces of pork, and tortilla shells.

Cute little corner restaurant.although they were absorbed in their conversation, they were very quick to welcome us and offer us some of their unused seats.mangu was excellent, and the oxtail, just a tad bit overcooked, was still delicious.food was delicious! i ordered the jabarito steak and it took about 10 minutes to make..fast forward maybe 7 minutes and we had two huge steaming plates of food in front of us.very tasty and reasonably priced fare.other than that this is a good restaurant with good food for a great price.i've never been a fan of my eggs sunny side up, but i didn't complain when they came that way with my mango and fried cheese.it's a sandwich with fried smashed plantains as the bun, greek tzacki sauce, gyro meat, onions, lettuce, and tomato.
Exactly what i wanted.not bad of a price for such a great experience.

The place itself isn't much to look at more fast-casual than anything but that's all you need for a wing joint they offer a few asian appetizers as well as a couple of side dishes including a few different rice options..i've been here twice now; both times the wings were great.this is not the first time i've been there, but it will probably by my last, unless i'm in the hood.their wings remind me of lollipop chicken wings.a bit pricey, but nothing too bad.will likely only return to get the sauce, which they bottle and sale.the meal gets a bit boring with just wings and rice so i plan on ordering a side of veges next time ( i heard the broccoli is good!)..just go.

Glad we ran across another one because last time i didn't get a chance to try their burgers.we ordered a couple of the double shack burgers, cheese fries, a strawberry milkshake and the shackmeister beer.not too much cheese and perfectly crisp..she said it was good, but it was 6pm and she hadn't eaten all day so i won't take her at her full word.cons- seating: in the fast paced life that is chicago, it can be awfully hard to find a seat.their crinkle cut fries are fairly average but a notch better than in-n-out's fries, in my opinion.their take on the veggie burger is the "shroom burger" a portobello mushroom cap, stuffed with cheese, and deep fried.i also had the s'mores concrete, which was good but again, a little bit too pricey.one of the best burger joints i've been to.

Plus i could see that the tortillas were being made by hand! love that..yes, we both had 4 tacos each.it hadn't opened yet and once it did, the line was out the door.i've been to their north side location and preferred the atmosphere and set up there.the service was friendly, but our food came super slow, it took about 35 minutes..could also be because i ate this after the amazing fish taco, so nothing could really compare.came by right before 6pm tuesday evening #tacotuesdays.we hope this place works out brings a lot of people into the bridgeport area and see what bridgeport has to offer!.

Not sure i'll be back on my own accord..one thing that stuck out about the nacho's were cotija cheese that was finely grated on top and there house made qeuso sauce.tacos here aren't bad-- i had the fish tacos.let's pretend you were having a contest with your friends to see who could create the perfect yelp list of summer spots.yes, now this is what you want in a mexican bar and restaurant.they don't have a record player &  bartenders playing vinyl.i didn't get to try the octopus ceviche this time round..inauthentic, pure trendiness.

The menu is a little confusing.as with everything else, perfectly cooked.our table agreed that the fennel apricot dessert was one of the best desserts we've had in a really long time.they are incredibly creative and innovative in their kitchen-and at their bar.actually, as soon as we finished the flight i ordered a cocktail to go with our final dish of the banana curry.the space is gorgeous and free coffee on opening morning - how fun is that?!dark wood, cozy chairs and a really open and inviting atmosphere will make for a great spot for breakfast, lunch and dinner.i needed my old fashioned (i always do everywhere i dine at!) and asked our server which of their specialty cocktail he recommended and that was similar to an old fashioned.) they were outstanding.i very much enjoyed my experience here, though, and will return soon for sure.the steak with barbecue raisins was definitely the hit of the evening, though the fried chicken ancho-chile mole was i felt a close second, and the pork collar a very close third.

Probably shouldn't have done that.always love publican brunch!  the bloody mary, which i usually love wasn't up to par, hence we knocked off a star.sat right near the bar.they also tasted a bit stale, so they wound up mostly being crunchy flavorless calories.i was a bit disappointed in my meal at the publican, but perhaps my expectations were too high...publican dinner will always be a favorite but i'd probably stay away from the saturday brunch.the others ordered chicken liver pâté, mushroom toast, sausage, and a combination of the following:pecan sticky bun-- deliciouscinnamon streusel coffee cake was ok, big slice.service was attentive even with how busy it was.

We checked in yelp, so got a coupon for half off a specialty roll.this is my favorite sushi place in the city.best sushi i have ever had in south loop or even perhaps in chicago in general.i'm going to cut to the chase and tell you to order the ocean roll lol! if i could have one roll for the rest of my life, this would be it..i also tried two different rolls - the first visit was the hamachi roll - which was just ok - i expected more flavor..i think that's my least favorite.fish was of very high quality across the board, and their sushi rice is superb: sticky, vinegary, and just slightly sweet.

Wow! this place is the true definition of a hidden geml my boyfriend and i came in here after wanting to try this place for a long time.i'd like to check out the mac and cheese the next time i stop in! great corner spot for a good burger especially if you're on a budget!.it's sexy yet approachable and an all around good choice for drinks, dinner, or doing it a little classier compared to almost everything else within a couple block radius.but that is just between you and me, got it?the burger isn't the only reason to visit, for hours, even days, on end..the bacon was lackluster and i think i had a 1/4 of a chicken thigh on my sandwich..got two rounds of gin cocktails, which were very good, and their smoked mac&cheese, which was also good.there was also an underlying spice to it making it have a full, bold tomato flavor..

Nom nom nom.that was a long time ago..why haven't i been here before?anyways we got 1.i mixed the hot sauce (orange) and the bbq sauce, the best!!!! i'll definitely be back.second time we asked them to cook it well done and it came out just perfect.the driver was kinda rude like a few others said.this place is delicious and totally worth the wait for it to open.99 for a whole chicken.i especially enjoyed the green chili sauce.

The service was really slow.i'll say that the texture of the noodles was good-the noodles were firm and you could tell that they were hand-pulled; however, the broth was pretty bland and flavorless.for $20 i got a ton of food.the waiter explained that their food is made authentically and therefore may tak a while to come be served.if you are in the area and need a snack, the flatbreads at xi'an are pretty tasty.wanted at least one meal in chinatown during my visit to chicago, and my friend yelped and decided she wanted to try xi'an cuisine.service was fine - not amazing or anything but not completely absent either.the flatbread is delicious.however, you can expect a 15 minute or so wait that garuantees the quality of said flatbreads.i am sure it will improve with time as well.

They serve tacos de carnitas and chile rellenos as well.for $6..it comes with cilantro and onion.this place is it, i definitely can't wait to come back here.i did enjoy the tacos, but nothing beats atotonilco on 47th.and the green sauce gets your mouth oh fiyah!.the meat is cooked right in front of you by a dude who looks like he could be my uncle and the tortillas come out steaming, heated up on the same greasy grill the meat was cooking on..i will be returning to get my taco on!.

-  mac & cheese -  i've had better but it was the crispy top was a nice touch." this flavorful dish is sliced and made into sandwiches.i came here a week or so ago with a group of work friends.i wish i hadn't been so stuffed from my dinner across the street at bellyq so that i could have ate more of the sausage that i ordered, but alas i only had it halfway through my happy gaucho.beer, bacon, sausage..and a ping-pong table.we stopped here after browsing the antique fair on randolph, and after standing forever to catch someone's attention to be seated, then waiting forever for menus, then waiting forever to give our order, were pleasantly surprised by the both the beer and the food.excellent beer selection as well.i ordered the chicken sammwich which was less than spectacular.

Better than my dish!and worth ordering.2.the food items i ordered for pickup traveled well, and it was definitely tasty.the portion was very generous with lots of pig blood cubes.everything is pretty reasonably priced as well.fire this guy with the tattoo on his left arm.i'm comparing this chinese to my casual chinese food experience that i've had in chicago chinatown and other city chinatowns.clean and artistically modern ambience, well dressed staff wearing cute waist coats with chitown logo.the crab rangoon is what has me coming back :).but they still kept those handy dandy pull-out drawers built into the table stocked with utensils and napkins--quite possibly my favorite thing about this place.

(4..4th bite, uncooked..toppings are amazing!!! so fresh and delicious.if you like mounds of oozing cheese, maybe lou malnati's is for you.[we ordered spaghetti as well - please pass on it, it wasn't that great..
It is best to eat them onsite than to take them home, something about the ambiance and the aroma of oil in the air.you can choose to get the sauce on your chicken or on the side.

Because i frequent this place so often (along with countless others) they have to brew entirely new and completely different beer every couple weeks, which means i have to go more often to sample them, which means they have to brew more often, which means i have to go more often.this place has a nice selection and definitely offer something for every beer drinker.the bottomline:  skip the apps, they are small and pricy.we ended up standing along a wall, which put us in the way of servers busing food back & forth.the place is small so there can be a wait at peek hours.banana grabber".ones that seated and served us were very chill & funny people!..though you could certainly do worse, convenience is the only draw of a place that manages to consistently brew boring beer.we stayed there for a few hours and ended up eating a lot so i'll go through a rundown of what we sampled:poutine: the poutine was good but was not at all what i expected, very different than poutine i've had at other places.

Her gumbo is fresh & delicious.since it was a saturday, we wanted to try the specials.check it out and you will not be disappointed!.this restaurant lives up to its rating for sure! such friendly service and delicious food! we just felt so taken care of and experience fine dining quality service here!we ordered the 1/2 fried chicken with garlic mashed potatoes and collard greens and the 1/2 smoked chicken with string beans and cornbread, and lastly, we ordered the peach cobbler for dessert.there was one employee in there, there was only my wife and i and 1 other couple in there as customers yet it took him nearly 10 minutes to take our order.the service was a little slow but i saw that the cook was multi tasking and taking orders.the gumbo served over rice was very tasty and clearly homemade.

And the pancakes were different (read 'much better') than most places i've been..crab cakes were moist and flavorful..woah, yum.the scallion pancake was cooked perfectly and provided a great base for the eggs and pork belly.long wait for brunch on sunday but worth the wait.i've taken my daughter's and gone twice.maybe i should have ordered one of their french toast or pancake dishes that came with a variety of fresh fruit instead as they looked incredible..

We love lyfe kitchen and are happy there is now a location much closer to us!  it was pretty empty when we came in the first time.absolutely great service!came in on a saturday morning.choked full of chain everything, and almost certain to congest this corner with yard house clientele, it's pretty hard to love anything inside it.

I think that filipino food tends towards the drier side (where the flavor is in the meat marinade instead of a sauce), and i found my dish kind of dry.my qualms involve the service and ambience of the place.

Grabbed some food to go.the lobster roll is really quite good, relatively light on the mayo, and not a skimpy portion, but not enough for me for a meal.not great on the amount of lobster here but otherwise love it!.if you're going for lunch, make sure you have a big breakfast.the lobster was very fresh and yummyonly downside is you are paying an extra $2 for a gf bun, so its almost $20 for a lobster roll.love it..a little pricey for lunch, but worth the splurge when you are in the mood for a treat.ha) offering to discard my plate-thing for me..

They were great in accommodating to slight custom requests.clearly this restaurant has a problem with math and proportions because they serve a pretzel bites with cheese and give you 12 pretzel bites and just enough cheese for maybe three bites.the ginger ice cream, while interesting, was more on the forgettable side.our group opted to share everything so we could try more of fork's offerings.my boyfriend got the blt and was not happy with it.our food came out somewhat staggered, and they seemed to forget about sides or toast.i sat at the bar and mike, simply put, was awesome and made some great recommendations.nice layout.we are a fun bunch, so we definitely had a good time..

As much as i like the service here.amazing service! food is always fresh and made to perfection! best noodles and red curry around.super friendly owner, fast service, more than reasonably priced..he kept consulting me to get the correct heat for each dish.we moved on to pad thai (great example), a basil beef (served with fried eggs.every seat was filled and there was only one person working the whole restaurant.fantastic experience.well i loved it cause when you order a dish hot it comes hot!  i goto other thai restaurants and most of them make it mild when i want it spicy hot.i usually get the steamed wonton which are delicious along with an order of egg roles, which i believe are the best in the city, and think you would agree, along with #62 - the pad woon sen which is a made up of chicken, pea pods, shrimp, egg, mushrooms in a vermicelli stir fry.

Our server didn't even care to ask how we were enjoying our appetizers or our main courses or whether we had any comments..reminds me of the chinese dong po pork:) coconut rice is also tasty:)also, ask for mommy's fave.soybean tofu type stuff was pretty good.went here twice in the last two months and both times the service was really bad.ironically, it tasted like indian food.good sized portions.

We started with the midwest fried chicken and the maple glaze is amazing! not a huge fan of the hot sauce (it's very smoky and a little too blunt for our tastes) but since it comes on the side it wasn't an issue at all.- octopus:  i would skip this.my boyfriend got the burger with bacon.overall, we were really happy with our meal at the dearborn.we dressed up and felt like we stuck out like sore thumbs.dessert:key lime pie- so good! i was not a fan of the massive layer of meringue but the crust and bottom two layers were beyond perfect.definitely more on the pricey side as the rest of the restaurants in the area, but i loved the interior decorating of this particular spot.very nice ambiance with kind of theatrical seating atmosphere..i came for lunch, nonetheless and do not want to spend the price of an entree on one glass of wine, sorry.

Little sandwich shop right on halsted, not a whole lot of seats, but the decor is pretty cool, i got the goat meat sandwich, it was definitely good, it's a little bit pricey ,but the quality of the sandwich meat is definitely above average, they have breakfast items as well that i'd like to try next time..5 star review.instead of cream cheese, i ordered hummus as the spread.this is how i could only give andorkas sandwich shop five stars.i ordered 3 cookies, egg salad and the italian sausage, which i got on their house-baked wheat bread.

Plenty of star wars and ninja turtles gear as well.it's a bit hidden on the block, but once you find it - you won't regret it.this place is pretty cool! they have the back to the future delorean in the back of the cafe.i'm sure you can find 30 places that serve better quality coffee if you really wanted to.it's not hard to find a great cup of coffee in the city, and i can get one with out the side of elitist attitude.m and all the couches and chairs were occupied.the decor is ridic and will summon every lonely memory you had of the 80s(but like, in a good way).we grab a seat at the coffee bar and waited for drinks.what a unique twist already right?then came time to order a drink.bathrooms are gender-neutral single-seaters.

I'm so done with this place! it used to be one of my favorite restaurants..he was also disappointed, and both of these dishes were top recommendations by our server.for dessert i tried the tiramisu and it was very good.very good.we came here based on a suggestion from our front desk lady at the hotel..lots of yummy appetizers to try in the future!we had the eggplant parmesan, the rigatoni alla vodka, and the chicken special, which was some kind of roasted garlic chicken with potatos and peppers..it made for a great night.

This is our go-to place for thai food.i was happy with the spice level and flavor of all three because i like spicy.plus they included additional hot sauce on the side.noodles were a bit on the softer/mushier side.go to golden thai if you are to eat some thai food on taylor.the staff were really nice and the service was pretty fast.i will be coming back here more!.you get a choice of meet but i usually get beef (it was the server's recommendation).so this was once my spot for nice thai, great thai iced coffee and just really great pad thai.bonus points for having variety on the menu, while still nailing the fan favorites.

We found this place and i have to say i'm impressed.had a donut testing at work with 5 of the best donut shops in chicago (glazed, stans, do-rite, firecakes, and doughnut vault).brown sugar peach marmalade was delicious, and believe it or not, not too overwhelmingly sweet!  yum.good donuts and coffee -- but definitely not worth the price you pay..they also have some coffee selections and a few table/chairs, but i didn't indulge in them nor did i stop and eat there..it's also hard to bite the bacon without the whole thing falling off.chocolate 4 (3.with coffee this was the perfect morning snack.

Very good fish cakes and larb began our meal.first time in the windy city and we had friends take us here.maybe it's more popular as a neighborhood place too, not worth the ten-mile drive imho.because:- byob- huge menu with diverse selections- good food- quick service- friendly service- reasonable prices.you can pay with credit card online too.why?  because this place is consistent..food came out very quick.we ordered:shrimp pad thai - just rightcrispy pork with green beans - the greens beans were naturally sweet and the pork was fried perfectly.very authentic northern thai food!.

The gf liked them that way, however.but, for $12, i was just like 'eh'.there were a few gripes i had with our experience, though.verdict: don't bother with higher end seafood, you're smothering it in sauce anyway!also, if your dining partners don't like seafood or getting their hands dirty, the thai food entrees are a great menu alternative.we ordered the calamari appetizer and i was not impressed, it was very salty and seemed like it was made from frozen.everyone will tell you what you need to know about a boil.had a to go order and omg soooo good.& service was remarkable.i ordered a total of 5lbs of seafood.i'm a fan!.

The pita is very good.you may feel acidic the next day, but it's definitely worth it! :denjoy!.chicken shawarma rice bowl was awesome.get their chips and use the garlic sauce to dip them in- oh my gosh this was sooooo good- who cares if you smell like garlic the rest of the day!.got their veggie bowl where they mash the hummus and baba ganoog at the bottom.5 stars..my friend ordered the chicken shawarma bowl, which was basically the same thing, but with chicken instead of falafel for about $9 as well.lentil soup was the yellow kind with some intact but very tender lentils.they don't give you enough chicken, especially if you are just getting chicken and hummus with toppings.

I came in on a saturday night which is packed everywhere in downtown chicago.everything was tasty! the ambiance was very intimate which was nice.the night didn't just end upstairs..i'm sure i'll be back for more, but until then will remember gilt fondly..but this place is really dark inside.and maybe because we were hungry, or maybe because i didn't know what to expect, but boy the food was amazing! every dish was very well prepared and very interesting.i know that every day a new restaurant opens up in chicago but i will definitely be back to gilt.i sent the pasta back and the very attentive, smiley server informed me it was a new, thicker cut of pasta.

It's not the best german-inspired restaurant in the city, but it's good.i appreciated every bit of it...we had a nice server by the name of ashley that was very nice.loved this place for a group dinner.i'd recommend skipping the mustards when ordering a pretzel, the barley butter is the real highlight.the impossible was done however, and food needed to get in my belly before the real night began, so here we go.i sat at the bar during both of my visits, and i found the bartenders to be pretty disinterested on both occasions.the schnitzel, the sausage, they remind me of my family dinners, but it's in a new and elevated presentation.

One standard bloody is served and it hit the spot.smart and decadent idea..fresh fish great wine service exceptional..food: 3value: 2we walked in around 7:30 on a saturday night.clam dish is flavorful and the bread that comes with is to die for crispy, buttery, and seasoned.i'm not sure how he offended them, we sat next to them for almost their entire meal; he seemed so attentive and jovial toward our table and theirs.the crudos are not cheap, and the serving size lives up to its "small plate" billing..

Service was quick, and the atmosphere welcoming.i think crab rangoon can tell a lot about a place and these crab rangoon were good crab mixed with good taste and fried to perfection.best part? they delivered in 30 minutes!  glad this place opened up in the hood.however, the price here is a lot higher than your typical thai place.

But, please, don't go there for the ramen..the green tea was a little cold when it was served, but i drank it anyway.i've past thru south kawa many times and finally decided to dine-in to try their rolls.nothing special about this place.i love scallops but the combination of scallops and crab meat on a roll makes a really fishy and slimy texture that was hard to get past.waitstaff were very friendly.for the price they charge, i think they should maybe offer a little more.with a bit of spicy sauce on top.instead, there are leather seats and attention to detail.

In any case, i was quite disappointed by my experience at mita.the broth was nothing memorable and under seasoned.we will be returning (with friends) asap!.it's a pretty hearty appetizer divided into 4 pieces.we weren't happy only 2 of 13 sake options were available on the menu but we knew mita is new and perhaps don't have any in stock yet.the okonomiyaki, a large savory pork belly pancake, is excellent and well worth trying..the food was good (not great), and for the prices there are better options in the neighborhood.freeze your nose off cold.i think that their prices are a bit high for the quality and amount that you get however.

Food was ok.this is probably one of the nicest diners i have ever been to.between waiting a while for someone to take our order, and then adding on to that the time we actually got it i doubt we'd come back.i'd like to see the prices come down a bit.owners are great and remember all their customers.just a good old fashioned diner.the waitress that took care of us was all smiles, and unlike clark's.friend and i tried to go to little goat but there was an hour wait so we decided to just get a quick bite here and we were far from disappointed.i wish they could have conquered their need for instant gratification so that they could enjoy an even more satisfying meal.going in we thought wow this is can't be that good of a place.

I was overjoyed at discovery the existence of pleasant house pub.i loved their food to begin with, but since they opened this location i would say everything was even better..small pitcher for $22.very excited to hear about pleasant house pub's new location.the gravy was super savory (maybe a little salty?) and the pie was okay, i didn't get a huge curry flavor.how do they do it? magic , i tells ya! just a perfect accompaniment to my salad.pies are still fantastic plus additional food items and a full bar! ambiance is a 5/5! the fish from the fish and chips we ordered was so tender and fresh.bubble and squeak was a large medallion with a golden crust and fluffy interior.we also got the wee jar o' pickles, or something like that.

Very small seating arrangement inside, looked like full bar.that's the place to go..definitely going back soon.joe's comparable! the crab was perfectly cooked.around this time we noticed it was a cash only place.eat at half shell on special occasions, and never had a bad experience.each entrée was accompanied with fries and lollipops.cash only, so stop at the atm or withdraw from under your mattress before you stop by..

I will preface my review by saying that i am not super familiar with ukrainian food, so i will judge the food on flavor.the decor is modern ukrainian, with a lot of culture..music is definitely foreign and not too loud..
I defiantly plan on ordering here again, you should too, i don't think you will be disappointed.i imagine it's hard to mess up chinese food food but this food is just too yummy.

Overall, i really enjoyed the place itself.loved it!  we were out shopping around north and halsted, and got hungry so my friend recommended we try this, and what a great idea that was!we split the grilled cheese with fig and arugula - holy smokes it was amazing.but the cashier was not very friendly.there's even a chalkboard on the wall showing exactly where your food came from.the atmosphere feels rustic chic (if that's even a thing), and they have some houseware/cookbook items to browse in the entryway area.it sounds like this restaurant is fairly new, so i'm sure this will be sorted out soon.my one beef is they were very leaf heavy, and light on the accoutrements.this place is super cute and good but pricey! everything tasted super fresh and the salad i got was pretty large but not that amazing for the price.for those who like their greens, the current menu features kale prepared four ways: baked with parmesan as a chip, combined with artichokes as a dip, as the base of two substantive salads and cold-pressed in green juice.this dish changed that! perfect lunch spot!.

Oh, and the thing is that you can choos how many toppings you want.i realized once i started eating my pizza that she never put any mozzarella cheese on the pizza.it's a beautiful thing.on a diet? don't go to blaze'd.since the pizzas only come in one size, here are some words of wisdom; "every pizza is a personal pizza if you try hard and believe in yourself.with lunch lines being so long, i finally came here for dinner..it was large for one, but thin, so i figured i could down it.i created it with their spicy sauce, which to me is the key ingredient that distinguishes this pizza from anywhere else.i ordered one of the pre-styled pizzas from the list, and it was delicious.

And trust me, they tend to have a heavy hand with the booze..it came smashed by the nachos box placed on top...service was great but never been a fan of places that title their food and try to make it sound all exotic.dinner for 2 with drinks was only $22.although this location is a bit small, the quality of the food and drinks make up for it.i hated that we had to wait 25 min for a counter service restaurant and then to top it off the tacos were just ok..

Hakka bakka made the right move by opening next to depaul and offering indian cuisine in a modern and approachable manner.this place is so delicious! it it is basically bringing indian street food to chicago! how great is that.not much else.looked very sad!lastly, this place is not cheap at all.i would definitely come back again!.we were the only customers upon entering and we weren't even greeted.i especially liked the kati roll - crisp and delicious with an egg on top.if the employees were more professional and quicker, i would give this place a five.they prepared the food patiently and didn't try to rush us out.i got the paneer with hariyali and the lamb with tikka sauce.

I figured the lunch rush would have died down, which it did, but fast food.i usually get the chicken torta.i've been to velvet taco which also sell expensive fusion taco and i like theirs better.i love watching my food be made in front of me..she also liked the guacamole (chunky, not gloppy), though the guy taking the order said casually, "and what toppings would you like?" not mentioning that they're 30¢ each extra (the menu says it, but it just seemed kind of shifty).it was approximately $10 per person which is slightly more expensive than your typical lunch.i never realize how much mexican food is a part of my normal diet until i'm with non-americans explaining a mexican menu, struggling with the concept of items like "tamales" being uncommon.but i didn't find it exceptional.

The torta is fantastic and comes with garlic shrimp, goat cheese, black beans, argula and lime on a chewy bun.macy's white chicken chili is strangely famous.this is just about the best food court in the loop."  lunch at seven on state is so dependable.the portion sizes are reasonable and the service was a bit slow, but fine.salads come with a soft tasty pretzel bread..i'd give my pinky toe to have a food court like this in denver.though a little pricey, you get real silverware and real glasses.how difficult is it to scoop up some fried rice and put it in a bowl? apparently way too complicated.

That is a high bar.if you are a peanut lover, you will love this dish..probably one of the best restaurants i have ever dined at.if you aren't secretly hoping no one is watching you so that you can lick this dish clean then you're crazy, because this dish was so good.the dining room is sophisticated, understated, and calm, a serenity that extends even into the visible kitchen, yet the contemporary soundtrack keeps the experience upbeat and fun..excellent communication between the staff.wine pairings in addition to their substantial wine listing also available.my favorite was the spring onion and leek.

The ribs!! get the ribs - you will not be disappointed.the chicken honestly was average, a little dry for my liking, but the ribs were great.we got a basket of fries to start.the two mixed together were a perfect combo, a match made in heaven some would say.prices were low.amazing menu choices but if you're coming on the weekend, prepare to wait.also, the bar is great--very, very affordable, great beers.my go-to is the half slap of "zesty" ribs, side of fries and coleslaw! the zesty is a little spicy for my sensitive taste buds-but well worth the pain.if i could have one last meal, it would be ribs, so me saying that says a lot..
Can't go wrong.honestly, i forgot it was there.

Service has been consistently good and we were not rushed between courses/throughout dinner, which is always appreciated!.the wait staff was very helpful and honest when making decisions on entrees.the candied ginger, i felt, didn't particularly pair well with the cake and (i think?) there were banana pieces on the plate as well, but couldn't tell.this location is cursed by the ukrainian black market and hasn't managed to maintain a single place in over twenty years.we ordered the burrata as an appetizer, which was very pretty.in the evening, you're allowed to park in the lot across the street for free! there's also free street parking but its kind of a pain to find.for dessert, we all split the salted caramel chocolate torte.every dish seems to have some sort of personality disorder.next time, we'll order entirely new items since there were many items we'd still like to try!..

I ordered chicken madras bowl and two samosas online.but in any case, that place isn't for me, but naansense is.keep up the delicious food guys :).naansense quickly moved in to the old panda express space (i didn't even realize they closed) and opened this, their second location, this week.i think indian food is delicious and making it more mainstream like this introduces it to people who may not have the time for a full sit down meal.choose a rice, choose a protein and sauce, and then add all the toppings you like.personally, the madras sauce with the chicken is my favorite, but they give you free samples throughout the line to make sure you like the ingredients you're picking.i added everything to my bowl and had the coconut sauce.finally, i absolutely love the chicago / indian inspired mural on the wall.

Service: 7/10atmosphere: 8/10food: 8/10.the staff knows us pretty well so many times, our drinks are at our table before we order them.they have a ton of beers on tap and several midwest brews.i was here for a meeting, and did not get to experience the bar and restaurant.the high top tables are a little too close together, and the bathroom is way too small, but the guy behind the bar (mike?) was really attentive..the food was fine.i wish i lived closer to jaks!.straight from the heart of west loop, it's jaks tap, ladies and gentlemen!.ah, jaks.

But they are amazing.he was very informative & knowledgable about the menu items and took time telling us about the different dishes.how dining should be.it's so amazing to see such a variety, there really is something for everyone, whether you are a vegetarian or a meat eater! chicago diner serves up amazing dishes that anyone can enjoy.the winner and star of the meal was of course, desert.just trust.i think if you are a vegan this place is probably paradise.i went on a date to this restaurant.what a cool place!!! this was our first stop (as a group) for dinner when my whole crew got to chicago.

" now let's get this straight..i have also had the strawberry and vanilla shakes, respectively, and i have to say i enjoyed the strawberry much more than the vanilla although, it wasn't bad either.do yourself a favor and check it out!.it was seasoned well, freshly made and had the right amount of jerk.2-3 stars based on the success of the wings and fries only.the burgers are reasonably good, somewhat like a less greasy and less well-assembled burger from five guys.burgers are one of my absolute favorite things to eat, and now mikkeys is one of my absolute favorite burgers to eat.

The menu has everything and anything and everything is good and a decent size.hubster's "plate" was an assortment of awesome veggies prepared in a variety of ways.i had a waiter come over first and take my drink order and then the waitress who ended up being my server came over and was a bit confused as to why the other guy had been there - once we got past that she 'took over' and was my server.um, ok..they were seasoned just right.5 stars!..i will start with the good.i appreciated that we were greeted by a staff member as soon as we were seated, even though they were not our server.

The sushi roll is very creatively presented with the sauces made into different shapes, it makes good picture :) the food is just so so and it does not feel very authenticthe service is great and the environment is good for groups of friends..
We couldn't say no to the crepe with caramelized plantains for dessert.the special coycoyo was delicious and the perfect match for my palette.

Highly recommend it!if i were to ding them on anything is the torta bread they use.muchas gracias!..with all the great taquerias in the chi i would skip this one.but i won't be in a rush.you can't ask for anything more! there have a nice parking area so that you can run in and out of there easily.the chips that were served with my dine-in order also won't set the earth on fire.two bottles on the counter that people had to take to their table then (hopefully) return, is not enough!.also, please note that the price per taco will go up as you ask for things like avocado or sour cream.

Good atmosphere, a little loud, and friendly service.)..i wanted to come here to celebrate my friends upcoming nuptials...no complaints on this one, other than maybe a little heavy on the salt, but that's pretty normal for skirt steak dishes..worth a visit just to check it out.

The cocktail menu seemed ambitious, but i was in the mood for something more straightforward.i think what irritated me was that they recommend you order 4/piece, i get they want you to spend more $ but as it was i felt like we could have done without the 5th plate.we had the hummus, crispy broccoli, and grilled chicken kebab for dinner and the deconstructed baklava for dessert.the spicy hummus, the crudo, the lamb skewers, all stand outs.friendly and professional staff and service.it was sweet and spicy, as it had what appeared to be pickled jalapeño in it.really an impressive debut, and we'll be back soon.was it really from israel? who knows but it was amazing! and i loved the chocolate torte, it was super creamy and chocolaty without being over powering.it was semi-sweet.our waitress was really nice and helpful in guiding us through the ordering process, and suggesting certain dishes to start.

)also, maybe we could use a little more in the way of accoutrements.big problems.alert alert - there are freakin' gummies in their milkshakes.i heard about small fry before it opened (thanks eater) and i was ready for the hype.maybe slightly too wide because we were stretching a bit.
Die.

The main dishes and chips and salsa were all very good.i went here a couple times with my friends and i like the food here and the drinks.though before i got food poisoning my tamales were great, and i liked the spicy salsa they put down on the table.there are always drink specials so i would definitely suggest getting whatever the drink of the day is because the pitchers are pretty expensive!the chips and salsa are delicious - can't go wrong with that!!!.the chips and salsa were great.love this little neighborhood mexican place!  i've been here several times over the last few years and have never been disappointed.but as soon as the waiter left, they moved right back out and repeatedly bumped into our seats.maybe it's all about expectations..impressive!i'm looking forward to trying other items on the menu, but i'm sure i'll always order a couple of steak tacos!.

It's almost like a chicken pot pie, except this is flaky and soft.this isn't my first hot pot and i was really satisfied with our meal-we will be back!the restaurant is hip and comfortable with comfy booths and a great location right by the chinatown redline stop.the service was wonderful, and they even gave us a 10% discount for paying cash.when you don't feel super thirsty after your meal, you know there's no msg or too much additives.the veggies here were fresh.it's not as hot as they say it is.all the ingredients we ordered were fresh, and i especially liked the fish tofu.what a fun place.so unless you are a regular to this type of cuisine, you don't know if you like the sauce or not.this was particularly aggravating because my wife only picked up a small container of green onion and the other bowls were for eating.

Crepes are fantastic!  can't get anything better in chicago.very reasonably priced as well!..i would definitely recommend this place.in my opinion, the portions were generous considering the price.bougatsa -- a reliable dessert that is unique.service is good, and very friendly.i had only been for coffee before, but i stopped by on a saturday with two friends and came in for a late lunch/early dinner and found ourselves waiting.add me for more updated and reviews.you would never guess it was sugar free.
I want to try the fried chicken tacos if we're in the area next time.the tamales were so good that i wanted to order like 20 more.

Great atmosphere i've  by going here since i was very young! food and service  the best in chicago! literally my favorite restaurant-  highly recommend the lemon chicken!..as soon as you walk in you feel the comfort of this restaurant.quaint, and cozy were the two words that came to mind.i cant wait to return and try something new.a quaint italian restaurant situated in a quiet neighborhood.i would like my first experience back..i'd come back in a heartbeat and i'd love to try the fish -- the fried calamari looked - and smelled -- excellent!as far as ambiance goes, it's a small room (beautifully redone), very clean, excellent bar to wait for a table.we ordered veal, chicken parmigiana, spaghetti with mega sauce and the gnocchi.

As for dipping sauce, the carolina was definitely my choice- sweet and tangy!the platters each come with two individual sides, and hands down our favorites were the baked beans and the mac & cheese.they are very soft and tender..i preferred the beef brisket...manager al came out and explained the whole menu.so, yes, i engulfed the meal out of hunger, but it was a disappointment.food was ready about 2 minutes later.coke products to drink (so much better than pepsi in my opinion) but i heard its byob?.

The atmosphere in this restaurant is spot on..we watched a copa america match with argentine while there, and it was a good experience!.editing what they offer and concentrating on a few things would be a start.great place for a steak and drinks.i need to be convinced.we were provided with a basket of warm, soft, fluffy bread to enjoy while we perused the menu.when my friend finally arrived i ordered "la lengua en vinaigrette" which is a cold apetizer..i went with the el filet off of the chef's specials menu and was totally blown away.

It was so delicious and went too fast.we decided to go with the brussels sprout salad, the turducken meatballs, mac and cheese and the fried chicken..i met up first with a buddy and had a drink at the bar..food wise- we split the brussel sprout salad, cheese curds and mac and cheese! fair warning- this food is not for those susceptible to heart burn, it is heavy and fried and perfect.they take reservations, which i love!..to summarize: great comfort food + awesome cocktails = amk kitchen!.waiter was great! very attentive and helpful.

So happy we came here instead though!!! i was a bit early, so i grabbed a margarita de fuego- i love me some spicy drinks.the chips are a very fun medley of house chips.i ordered three tacos (listed in order of deliciousness): halibut, ribeye, and shrimp.the ribeye asada was good and props have to be given to this joint for not up charging for premium tacos.it tasted like we were drinking juice.one of mine was definitely the morita as it had steak and bacon and i think the other was the chorizo, but neither of these even had all of the ingredients listed on the menu and the runner was impossible to understand.love the decor, and the sparse, stylish layout.the food was pretty good but not worth the price.first time was last friday night for the bf birthday.the service was pretty quick and definitely professional, he came in a lot of times to check on us and what we needed.
The el pastor is as good as it gets.they have a tuesday/thursday special with a taco costing $1.

I then had to tell him no, it's wrong because of his math and he actually charged us way less! he took the checks back and no apologies were given.they are smart to make wicker park their fifth stateside spot as i think it will do really well in this location.however, all the eggs were super salty no matter what you got that time -- maybe they were part of a bad batch.so my friend and i walked in here at random cause well, we were starving.i did not like the dumpling itself.they had high chairs for kids and cute plastic kiddie bowls so they can have some ramen too.if you're looking for ramen, come get some here.as for the other toppings, they also had a mix of bamboo shoots, green onion, and nori.also, their cook staff was loudly, randomly yelling, and pretty unpleasantly surly.i hate it when i got to a ramen place and their noodles look like they took it from the instant ramen pack.

No follow-up or apology from the store.oh bari, how i miss you.the bread i found was just okay and was too much for the sandwich and the sandwich was a bit over dressed.they have a deli counter with a great selection of sandwiches and subs, with different specials every day.wonderful, wonderful bari sandwiches.for someone who doesn't care for for giardinara, i loved bari's, and am now converted.i had the italian with spicy giardiniera.if you happen to be looking for italian groceries, they carry an ample selection of oils, canned tomato products,pasta, canned fish, and homemade condiments.on the whole, it was good, but not outstanding: the bread was crusty, but the fillings were limited (really kind of light on the mutz and the prosciutto).for the weekend i was here visiting, this was the best thing i ate - hands down.
The food is shown stoppingly good and we will definitely be back and will try the lincoln square location.

Definitely will be back on our next trip!.the hot chocolate wasn't so hot, but liked great.thanks to yelp, i found yolk! i wasn't sure which location would be best so we chose the one closest to where we wanted to be for the day.make sure to grab one on your way out..would i go back? absolutely.i opted for the california omelette which i will highly recommend right now...inexcusable!this man needs to be fired because he is incompetent at handling the stresses that come with the service industry.

I love veggies and garlic, so this was naturally another favorite.it seems to be family owned by an elderly lady.one star for the irony of an ugly duckling like this place being named the "grand palace.the flavors are spot on from the ones i grew up with in hong kong with adjustments that i think make the plates prettier or easier to serve and eat.she laughed when we placed our order and told us it was a lot of food..the food here is really good..it took like another 15 minutes.cheap cantonese home style! like my mom made it.

Oh golly! only at christkindl market chiraq can one get a puff of doom!oh hell yea - pulled pork smothered in mac and cheese on big chewy puff! that's how you warm up on a chilly wet night!bwahahahaha...i went over to their truck at the food truck social..
It's called the antelope canyon (who knows why) and is $8 for a whole roll with sweet potato tempura, ichimi mayo, oshinko, eel sauce, and scallion.

I highly suggest it.if you're looking for a breakfast spot with no gimmicks, roll on thru but be prepared to wait to grab a table especially during peak hours on the weekends.so delicious and perfect.the food was ok for the cost but it was certainly nothing that should cause such a buzz and commotion and be so overly crowded and noisy.chicken and waffles were good! love the bits of bacon in the waffles.the food was amazing service was good.even though you're almost always going to have a wait a while before getting seated here, yolk is so worth it.if we weren't visiting and wanting to try every breakfast spot within walking distance, i could easily see returning to yolk on a weekly basis for some breakfast time indulgence.you can bring your own alcohol, i saw a table of guys making their own mimosas so that was cool.big plates big waste for no quality!bon appétit!.
