Chicago is killing it with its breadth of healthy fare options.a solid lunch spot offering good bang for your buck..this is the place for high-quality, fast, delicious stir-fry.pretty good chipotle style asian fast food.they cook up the ingredients perfectly,  and serve a good size portion.anyhow, it's worth my visit.my friend got the tofu bowl with creamy cashew and brown rice and loved the sauce and the cashew bits.we carried out our food, but it was pretty warm while we were there.then you choose your sauce! (thai basil, creamy cashew, chili coconut curry, adam st, or light lemon glaze).

) and the coffee is spectacular.the reviews were great, and casa yari did not disappoint!  the menu has a lot of meat dishes which are mostly served with plantains, which is a dream come true for me.in fact i'd say if they had more than a single (but proficient!) server on our recent visit i'd be giving it 5 stars..we splurged and tried the reese's flan for dessert - it was so smooth and creamy it tasted almost like cheesecake.i live in hyde park and it was well worth the trip.the restaurant itself looks like a homey kitchen in a beloved aunt's home.excellent! i moved to chicago a year ago, i have tried many places here since then and i have paid for way overpriced meals in places you are supposed to get fresh and quality food but you don't really.this place was a cute lunch spot.churasco & eggs: a decent sized skirt steak - maybe 4-6 ozes.

I want my food to burn going on the way in and on the way out! this place accomplishes that.my friends come here every week and have tried everything on the menu.kudos to chengdu impression for better use of aromatics and spice in their food although i still want it to be even more spicy! the staff spoke chinese to me right off the bat, which was both nice but also awkward because my friend didn't speak chinese at all and my reading isn't as good as my speaking (#chineseamericanproblems).definitely my go to chinese restaurant north of the downtown.the restaurant is pretty accommodating with what level of spiciness you want.you won't find 95% of these offerings at most us chinese restaurants.very good chinese food.the names are a mouthful and seemingly harmless but most of the dishes are drenched in hot oil and chili peppers just the way sichuan cuisine should be..the dan dan mien came out first and served as a great starter since the spiciness got us ready for and and wanting more.

It's always good), it just wasn't the best that i've had in chicago.and it wasn't busy so i don't know what our server was doing!we wanted to sit upstairs and if you go- shoot to be on the main floor or upper level, as the seating in the lower level seems low energy as well.they were perfectly cripsy, with the perfect tangy sweet and spicy sauce that is just incredible.i love the concept of a steakhouse combined with a bar vibe.my go to 3 star rating means i'd go back but nothing stands out.thrilled that the big man, brendan s opened shop around the corner from home.we also shared the shaved prime beef sandwich and fries, which i must admit i usually don't like beef sandwiches; this one was good.i would definitely go back.

The best thing i've gotten here is actually the cucumber mint lyfe water which was super refreshing and delicious.lyfe kitchen was highly recommended by a friend in chicago.i ordered the chicken and avocado sandwich.but not my first lyfe experience.i have eaten at another location before and it was good so i will attribute the disorder to being a new location.ordered lunch for pickup which you pay over the phone in advance with a credit card.

Good deals are hard to find in the gold coast/river north area so i fully appreciate all the specials and discounts they have to offer here.great spot for a casual date or group dinner with friends.i especially enjoyed the addition of mindoro blue cheese.i personally did not like the taste or the weird velvety texture of the beer cheese and would ask for the pretzels without them if i were to reorder them.also my burger came with pickles, if you asked for them, so my boyfriend asked for some extra.i tell the full story not to criticize them but to thank them for their good customer service and so others will know they are good to do business with.3 stars - i would stop by if i happen to be in the area.as for the food, i ordered the breakfast sandwich which consisted of scrambled egg, cheddar cheese, apple-wood smoked bacon, arugula and a killer herb aioli..

Happy munchingordered1.they have other flavors to try, but we were too hooked on this one for now.it also tasted great split among three people and after spending 4 hours shoved in the bottom of my purse.both were very, very good, but the former was probably the best gelato i've ever eaten!we also got a malted hot chocolate, served with marshmallow fluff and a disk of chocolate floating on the top.meh.both amazing.they have ice cream too i really regret not trying it.be sure to ask for their seasonal specialty (currently the red velvet, and the pistachio cream) as they are as unique as they are delicious.it's a really neat place to go during the summer time for we had their italian ice treats that comes in adult size capris sun like bags.it's pretty cute--you can see the server filling the lil doughy balls while you wait.

Always a solid choice for a quick lunch or dinner, and a nice alternative to the soup/salad/sandwich places that saturate this area.abc 7 news report that quickly mentioned that roti's first location near the sears.the portions felt small for the price but i left with a full stomach.this restaurant may be considered fast food but it certainly does not taste like the average fast food chain.now this is what lunch in the loop looks like!fast, quality tasting and fresh, happy employees and cha-ching!! a meal under $8.this place is great.i had chicken with hummus, eggplant, and couscous.the meal was pretty satisfying and i wasn't hungry 2 hours later, so that's a plus.

They give a huge portion size and the burritos are better than the ones at chipotle although there's a smaller selection of meat.delivered in less than 30 minutes so that was fantastic..this could be my bad for getting togo so i don't want to fault them completely on a less than perfect experience.the interior has been completely overhauled from how it looked before and almost feels like you're sitting in a street art gallery.it was a sunday at 2pm.seoul taco has standard offerings that are good, but not great.the food was really good and i liked the relaxed vibe.maybe giving patrons a table number to place in a stanchion would be better?the queso was good, but i'll head to del seoul next time i want this kind of meal.there aren't many options on their menu but the things offered are all decent.

Don't get mewrong, i'm still giving it 4 stars because the service was friendly & attentive..world.the wait was very long, but at least we got to enjoy the view of the lake while waiting..this was the beginning of a beautiful, delicious weekend in chicago.the hostess offered to sit us at a high top table near the bar..happy snaps to the waitress!  when you ask the waiter/waitress for food recommendations, they usually don't even know what they're recommending, have never tasted it and are actually possibly allergic to it in real life--however, this lady was very enthusiastic about her salad recommendations..

I come here at least once a week for lunch.i've had two bowls from here; the classic poké bowl and the warrior bowl.beside the bowl not having what i wanted it tasted great.umm! about 6 months ago i was in hawaii and i had poke for the first time and i knew i was in love with the dish, so you imagine how happy was to learn that a poke shop was opening up downtown.okay, ever since i had poke for the first time here, i've been looking for it back at home in maryland!you can build your own bowl or choose one of the combinations on the menu..when we finally got our food, i sadly realized i paid over $16 for a half empty bowl..great food, great service, great concept, but the ordering process for a custom bowl is quite slow.the only downside is that the space is small, so not a lot of room to eat in.

Both dishes were pretty good.unlike his delicious mussels (really good) my crab cakes were very tiny and did not resemble a crab or crab cake taste.we waited an hour (yes, i checked my watch) for the oysters to show up..they green split the salad for us which was simple and delicious.no.i made a reservation for my husband and two girls on a saturday afternoon around 3pm thinking it wouldn't be the busiest time which is good since i'm bringing my kids.my boyfriend and i were in lincoln park on a saturday morning and decided to stop here on a whim.my only quibble is that there was too little of actual calamari--the plate was heaping, but it was mostly fried lemons and peppers, and a huge slice of toast under all the fried goodies.then what? the swordfish schnitzel chef must've been overwhelmed.

Atmosphere:relaxed while still maintaining a trendy vibe, this is a perfect combo for anyone that loves a good beach taco shack without the sunburn and screaming children.i was at moody church for their founder's week to hear ravi zachararis, (notice, he's in my list of must hear and/or read), but my friend and i arrived a bit early and yelped this place.boyfriend and i decided to give this place a shot and both ordered the combo which includes your choice of two tacos: i went with a bbq glazed salmon and crispy panko-crusted avocado taco while boyfriend went with a seared mahi mahi and sapporo battered alaskan cod taco.same with the guac and chips, both a must try!.i've been looking for an awesome fish taco place in chicago and finally found it! with how fresh tasting the tacos are, this is as close as i'm going to get to a solid west coast fish taco stand.glazed salmon was just about right.the taco did not come with a lettuce wrap at buzz bait unfortunately.we were looking for someplace to eat quick before a show, and stumbled across buzz bait.cause i literally fly to texas for those tacos..

My only suggestion is to find items to set you more apart from the vast amounts of competition.great family style italian restaurant in my neighborhood that helps avoid the tourist attraction chaos..home style italian, stick to your ribs, food coma kinda goodness.it was sooo delicious, i contemplated stealing his dish.totally full of character, nice guy working there, free shots, fun, big portions, food was tasty, an institution.it was creamy, but flavorless.it was very good.my boyfriend had the chicken florentine and could not stop saying how amazing it was.we loved looking at all the pictures on the wall of famous, and not famous people who came to the restaurant.
I should not have waited this long to go here! their snow crab legs are ah-maazing!!!! garlic noodles and cajun garlic fries must be ordered!!!..

I'm definitely coming back to this spot.cubans kick ass at porkif you want variety, ask them about their sampler platter; it's great and is way more food than you think.which includes the liar plate.so many of items on the menu sounded great! in the end, i lamed out and didn't try anything new, but ordered an empanada and a cubano.also, they raised the prices but not the quality.def recommend the pechuga de pollo and palomilla dinner entrees.i would definitely come back if i wanted something made with heart and soul.you know, i really love this place...

Hubby and i were hunting pokemon in lincoln park this evening.also i did not like the noodles.staff was very friendly, too.overall this is a great alternative to going to chinatown or argyle - i will definitely come back.there was also a suggested menu board, for those who need some inspiration or dont want to bother picking out each ingredient.this pho place is definitely unique and much appreciated! everyone working there was very friendly and welcoming!i ordered the fuh noodle soup for $8..pros-fast casual atmosphere and great concept.pho is probably my favorite kind of soup in the world and i've had more bowls of it than i care to admit.wear and tear shows up with greasy floor in women's bathroom.

The masitas de puerco, or pork was awesome.one thing i didnt like how everything was really over priced n the portions were small..their menu looks really good and they cater too.yum, yum, yum!i love 'dried' meat, so the vaca frita will be my forever go to.all the food here is just so packed with flavor, it's definitely memorable and makes you want to come back for more!atmosphere here is pretty cool as well, seems pretty eclectic and just like mish-mashed together, but it's cool and it works.if you're a first timer, or new to cuban food, i'd definitely recommend.i tried the goat cheese and chorizo and beef empanadas and they were flaky and delicious.i love garlic and so does the fiance so my garlic breath just cancels out his, right?they have a lovely outside patio but unfortunately bees, so we moved inside.i love the look of this location, and i anticipate sitting outside on plenty of warm summer evenings.

The young lady at the front register was super down-to-earth and friendly.it's hidden away bellow the sedgwick brown line stop, so you really have to be looking for it to find it.the noise level is low, the music they play is -- i don't really know what genre it was and i wasn't really listening to it because i had earphones on -- neutral? not bothersome? not distracting?it's a healthy walk (about 10-15 minutes) from the clark/division red line subway station and about a 2 minute walk from the sedgwick brown line subway station.i was not disappointed!  the baristas were entertaining as well, which is always nice.delicious.a narrow passageway to the back room has a couple of deuces or two-tops, and in the back you find a big old bar, and four big tables, like dining room tables, with six chairs.it's a great hidden spot to get work done.this is my favorite coffee shop in the area.the sandwich i had (although it was for breakfast) was pretty good, the pumpkin latte was flavor-fall and the climate was cozy especially on a rather cold day.i came here on a saturday afternoon and it was really crowded actually! luckily i grabbed a open seat at one of the larger tables in the back because someone just happened to be leaving.

Disappointing and the only reason 3 stars because i know they typically has good food and service.i went here last night.but the crust was a little bit more dry and mealy than i remember.originally we planned to dine-in but when we got there, the place was crowded and they said the wait time would be nearly an hour (and this was on a monday night).com.the wings were good but calamari was a bit disappointing.so we ordered one.get there early because the line starts to run out the door as early as 5 pm.delicious !! loved this pizza..

I had the cowboy salad which was nice, chicken slathered in a tomatoey chipotle sauce and served over greens, but not at all special, and felt overpriced at $14.two of us ordered salads and they were filling.we stopped in for lunch around 2pm with no reservation and were seated immediately.conversation is impossible, except via shouting.they have a number of big screen tv's around the restaurant providing an option for watching games or other shows.a great find just a few steps away from millenium park!  you feel instantly comfortable when you first walk in, a very warm space with a lot of roomy booths, a long bar offering a wide variety of beers on tap, and lots of screens to watch some football on a sunday afternoon.as is normal, the turkey was somewhat dry and she felt it was too strongly herbed.the chicken salad with tater tots and pickle are the way to go.did a group lunch the first visit and then a late night burger the other visit.in the area it hits the spot.

Then i found a hair in my food about a third of the way into it.service is def friendly here with a good selection of cocktails and craft brew.i look forward to coming back for dinner at some point! the pierogis on their menu look delicious!..5 if i could, so i'll go for 3 and give them the benefit of the doubt since this was my first visit.there are 4-6 different fonts from less than a 5 point font, to a massive 16 point font! for a minute there, i thought i was going blind.finally.the potatoes have a nice crisp but are too salty, the chicken and maple syrup combination soaked through the undercooked and doughy waffle, and the omelet looked sad and limp.the french fries are some of the best in town and that alone is reason for me to come back! the decor is classy and it is clean.

Thank you, pazzo's for really caring about your customers!..the floor is a wood laminate that had noticeable air bubbles.the pasta dishes looked yummy too..i was taken here to lunch by a vendor today and while i was happy to see so many seafood options on the menu, the reality wasn't as good.pazzo's was great to work with and provided wonderful food, based on the compliments from our guests both on the quality (that food was delicious!) and quantity (i've never left a wedding so full!) and was reasonably priced.after receiving our food, he did not check on us once..i never knew this place was there - i've worked across the street for a few years.

To eat i had the braised beef meat pie dish.melt in your mouth and simple, no frills.good beers, good champagne gin cocktailnice appetizer special and the 1 lb.and the fries were mediocre.seemingly plain but but oh so good.lamb sausage, beef navel, sunchoke salad, tarragon toasted almond chimichurri, serrano cocktail...i wasn't a huge fan of the goat cheese fritters, not that they were bad but just not notable enough for me to order them again.

While the drinks were tasty--chamomile whiskey sour & bourbon basil (y)-- the service was unbelievably slow..this place is amazing!! we accidentally stumbled across it! we were trying to get a table at dokku which is a sushi restaurant/bar.they also have a good sushi option (ask it's not on the menu)..first of all, the bar snack bowl is good in general, and the rest of the food ranged from decent to solid.we ordered the karaage, and instead of receiving it as nuggets, we got it in the form of spicy wings.i started coming here when it first opened and wasn't so trendy and packed.food: we were actually more excited to try the stuff on the bites menu than anything else.the rolls were bigger than your average rolls, so it is a good deal--plus pretty presentation.

With the pretty much non-existent similar offerings in the area, why not give it a shot?.th establishment is nice, small but nice.it's edible and kind of pricy for the portion size.it gives you something to watch while waiting!  plus you can tell they are clean and using all real food that is fresh!the staff is friendly and helpful.i'd received the spanish rice which was very good, but y heart was set on corn.i liked it the most all around.all burritos are $8 with the exception of the veggie which is $7.

I went here with a few of my friends and we loved it! my friend is brazilian and was in the mood for some brazilian food.the food is delicious as well.bb's version also comes with rice, collard greens, pico de gallo, and something called farofa which is some sort of cream-colored powdery grain topping.tasted like home ( i'm brazilian ) i will be back.the food- very good food, loved the brazilian burger..

My food was great and my husband had serious meal envy.mac and cheese  (~$12)- my husband was sooooo amazed by this dish.everything was also super delicious and well priced.sometimes that's all i'm looking for in a restaurant..other than that, i do really like the bar area itself.one of my criteria for a 5-star review is that i could recommend this to someone coming in from out of town.our waiter was quite busy and more attentive to our table towards the end of the meal when it got to be later on in dinner service..

They had different flavors to choose from.we tried:ensalada de vegetales - a selection of seasoned grilled vegetables marinated with sherry vinaigrettecroquetas de pollo - chicken and ham puffs served with ali-oli sauceternera asada - roasted veal served cold with raspberry vinaigrettepaella iberica - a cafe iberico original, served with seafood, chicken and porkseveral meat dishes with french frieswe also have a few other dishes that i can't remember.not a terrible experience--just nice tapas in the city.iberico is great for groups; that's for sure!.it does take a while to cook, so make sure to order enough tapas as apps...i have been to cafe iberico many many times over the past 20 years.it seemed like they just bombarded us plate after plate to the point where there was no space on the table.

5décor/ambiance: 5.large space with gorgeous planet like inspired light installations hanging all over the ceiling..pump room was overall a fabulous meal, with an insanely fabulous decor.next, our table was unnecessarily close to others.i would recommend making a reservation, this place gets busy.each dish was connected by a spice to made all the dishes play off each other in a gastronomic work of art.we took forever, so i kind of felt bad for our server.we had garlic fries that were very salty and our party ordered spinach and mozzarella pizza that was just ok.for dessert, we had creme fraiche cheesecake which was delicious.

Come check this place out already!.service was inattentive and slow.i went back twice during my week in chicago.however, service was spot on and the recommendations made by the waiter were on point.all of their dinner plates are small as well.in my four visits to sable, i've shared many small plates with friends.i've only come here to drink from the fountains of the best bartenders on the planet.crab + truffle = heaven.the sliders, broccoli salad, and desserts were all great, as were the drinks..

To much cheese and when it got cold it didn't seem edible.it takes about 40 minutes to get to the table.chicago-style pizza in the shadow of midway airport.finally had the opportunity to try a real deep dish pizza while visiting from california.and i ordered a 2 person pizza that came with 6 slices and were barely able to finish 2 slices each in one sitting with some beer! we were greeted by the friendly owner who told us his personal favorite toppings are the all-beef meatballs and the chicken sausage.service was good..i tried the stuffed pizza with pepperoni and everything about it was heavenly.located next to the airport i went there with lower expectations but was surprised of the quality of ingredients and pizza served.this one is just too pricey to give it a second shot and it to fail.

There is a grocery section (bodega) inside the restaurant, which made the place seem more authentic, but less upscale.spanish beer, a housemade sangria (tinto de verano), and some pedro ximenez added  up to the perfect kick starter for a night of fender benders, mosh-pit slam dancing, and carpool karaoke.adobo -  swordfish was a tad dry and overcookedcarne al toro - this was my favorite dish, tender and the sauce was delicioushabichuelas - my husband really enjoyed this dish, the beans were cooked perfectlycroquetas de puchero - really small, i would pass on this next timeserranito - small sandwich that was tastyseta - loved this dish and as others have stated the jamon was tastytorrijas - when i read the description i thought it would be like french toast, the bread was really soggy (someone just told me they were supposed to be soggy, when you google are torrijas supposed to be soggy there is an overwhelming response of no it should be firm enough to hold, these were not)as for the space, it is warm and inviting.check it out.i have enjoyed many of the spanish wines on my visits -- i particularly am in love with the sparkling rose and several of the white wines.stopped in today for their open house prior to the grand opening tomorrow.the atmosphere was laid back & had an upscale feel without the attitude (if you know what i mean) & service was great!stop by & give them a shot.there were three girls, we ordered 7 small plate dishes, + 2 desserts and one glass of wine and our bill was around $90 and we left perfectly full.the jamon iberico is an interesting topping on any tapas; i didn't realize that acorns have such a taste.but none of the food had any flavor.

It definitely has a modern feeling lounge to it and dj was dropping mad beats but there's really no where really to dance.came here with a group of friends for nye and really enjoyed our experience..we didn't eat, but the food at the table next to us smelled quite good so maybe change is good.my sister and i agreed to try lunch there next week and we'll definitely be around for the night stars view..prices are very reasonable for food and drinks, and the food and bartender are great! we got the crispy risotto balls and scallops.the drinks are moderately strong, and appropriately priced for the location.but it just gives me a reason to go back when it's a nice day out!..

It's a cute spot with rustic charm (read: an abundance of mounted animal heads and kitschy dark wall paper.not terrible but not something i would come back solely for.it's is needless to say, a must, based on how beautiful it's presentation is in photographs.the donut wasn't even that great--kind of tough on the outside and not that special.their drinks are also fantastic.from the cocktails, to the service, to the atmosphere, to the incredible food, charlatan was a home run this past friday night for dinner.i really appreciated the service.my friends took me here for my birthday in march.i'll definitely be back!.lol i didn't know they were considered a classic drink - so the bartender effortlessly whipped me one up.

My friend ordered the poutine, which was heavy on cheese and not gravy.you can nurse your drink all night and no one will bother you.food:i ordered the traditional creole gumbo.we got here around 2:00 and there was no wait which was great.please do something about that before you make someone else seriously ill.however, it was juicy and well-seasoned with great toppings.a side of some type of spicy aioli made this appetizer just right.pei mussels -- now these were interesting!  mussels are great for a lot of reasons and these were anything but ordinary.my friend from out of town was down in the loop for a bit, so we decided to meet up for a quick drink.the bartenders were very busy with the after-work crowd, that didn't stop them from checking in with us plenty.

My friends were all really happy with theirs also..don't expect any frills with atmosphere or service, but for a quick, inexpensive, large and satisfying torta (with fries!) this place is a great choice.not since cemitas on the northside have i tasted such bliss...the pineapple was not grilled or anything, looked like it came straight out of a can.by 'ask', i mean 'told.you're eating (mid-mouthful, actually) and a restaurant employee asks your group (again, happily noshing away) to re-locate to a different table because another group has just walked in and they want your table.

Sorry mom, i know it's bad etiquette.you walk in, and you already feel like you have escaped the hustle and bustle of the work life.as an aside, this place has free wifi.if you eat pizza, get pizza.this place is great for hipsters, the interior is amazing so authentic.i had the roast beef on rye, which wasn't anything special...the service was great -- the waitress decided that our fries weren't hot enough when they arrived (we didn't really notice.

Five stars! ten stars! forty hundred stars!me + xoco tortas 4evai know it's a chicago thing but maybe you should migrate up to mke and kill it, eh?..dinner with tip for 2 was about $48..it definitely wasn't worth 11 dollars.it tasted like there was a ton of salt in the drink, which i don't like.that being said, i saw them putting out some delicious looking food and sandwiches.ambiance of the restaurant is trendy, loud, and kind of tight.50.

But i figure if you have a portobello mushroom burger, a turkey burger, and a chicken blt sandwich on your menu, then clearly its fair game for reviewers.it is moist, flavorful, and perfectly seasoned; their turkey burger definitely needs some recognition.the burger was overcooked and fairly dry.busy burger fit the bill.i'm pleased to report that the burger was fantastic! delicious, hot, grilled to perfection, with fantastic grilled onions with the right amount of carmelization on them.the burger comes with a spicy mayo and all the veggies..for a local burger place next to a university, they are kind of expensive.i am really impressed with their burgers.nothing spectacular, i will say that the sauce was definitely a game changer! see for yourself! my favorite from this visit was my strawberry shake, it was pretty great but i do wish it was a little bigger! yeah, i'd probably be back ;).

Economic-as-hell hush puppies.their fried shrimp is the best i have ever had and i will be supporting this restaurant for years to come.it's lightly breaded w/a good flavor.unfortunately, i don't have the same nostalgia for troha's that my mother has in spades.still not the best shrimp, but their frog legs are like on steroids.this is a pick up place as there is no seating.the cold slaw is a hit and the cocktail sauce has a nice kick to it.they weren't cheap on the shrimps either, it was pretty jumbo!.i've pretty much tried everything from the menu like wings to cod.they had a specific guideline for what you can order for the groupon deal, posted on the cash register (pick two (2) kinds of fish for the two (2) combos; this came with two (2) fountain drinks as well).

The fries can be cajun'ed or truffle'd (both yum, i like the former).not offered any other burger place i ever been to.i'll throw a little sriracha on it next time to make it heavenly.wonderful and unique.it was very hard to remember which is my top 5, as best as i remember i enjoyed the soft-shell crab tacos, mango chutney, hawaiian pork, banh-mi and the littles' taco's.make sure you have your patience in check as i mentioned before, you may run into a slight wait.there's a few parking spots in the back.it's fast food taken up a notch, but not out of reach for those on a budget.really amazing truffle fries, shrimp tacos and soft shell crab sandwiches.

I'm not much of a pizza fan but it was our last day of our 5 day chicago road trip.it wasn't just the thickness of the pizza, it was so absurdly covered in cheese and the sauce was not very good.there was only a 20 min wait for my table.tried their deep dish pizza.yeah, giordano's pizza is better..we put our name in and our pizza order in so that it would be ready by the time our name was called for a table.when the pizza arrived 35 minutes later, since it does take time to cook..not the best.

I ordered a cup of the chili and the chopped salad.it's chill vibe reminds me of places i went in college.we started to come here because they have good spicy chicken wings.i ordered the nitro shake chocolate porter.they definitely didn't stiff you on the amount of alcohol, but you also didn't feel like you were drinking gasoline.we also had several beers each, including a "mystery beer", which was a fun novelty..also - the service was perfect.ask for a beer book to peruse the selection.not the absolute best wings ive had but still pretty good along with great service and a bustling atmosphere.

A delightful italian restaurant who knows good food & good wine!great atmosphere & knowledgable servers.a+   fresh and beautifully plated.rigatoni and octopus were good.the restaurant seems to be centered around wine, with wine filling the walls all around you.when i heard the bruchetta had pine nuts and goat cheese, i was a bit uneasy because i like neither.plenty of classic italian to please half pints, including the standard cheese pizza.we ordered 3 pasta dishes (the raviolo, rigatoni and cacio e pepe).the restaurant set-up is homey, bustling, and charming.you can never go wrong with a classic prosciutto and arugula pizza, they pair well together.everything i tried was delicious.

The parking is not available exclusively for the area(street), so if you are out of town you may have a problem..if you don't mind a bit of a wait, stop by!.the sides were also good.when we asked to have the server corrected, more annoyed looks.what made the wait even more unbearable is that you are literally standing above the dining area while you wait and you can see and smell all the delicious food at the tables.the lines can be terrible on the weekends.my server this time was frank and he was very good and pleasant.i understand that on sunday's people come with their families from church, and there are also many takeout orders too.the macaroni and cheese, collard greens, and beans with rice were also notable.
The sandwich plantains weren't quite fried enough for me, and i was expecting more crunch to go with that sandwich.yummmm!.

Cheese fries with cheese whiz was so fulling but goodthe cashier was so friendly and entertaining, always smiling and greeting you like a bosssss.this was my first taste of chicago! the chicago style hot dog served as a warm and friendly ambassador of this lovely city.definitely the best in the city in terms of specialty hotdogs..it's like there's a party of flavors going on in my mouth.the menu is your pretty standard chicago hot dog stand selection - dogs, burgers, chicken and fries.i'm not usually a hot dog fan but while in chicago, i had to try a chicago dog so i came here and was blown away at how much i enjoyed the hot dog.this place definitely had the best hot dog.this didn't seem all to special to me and tasted like any old hot dog.we had a chicago dog, a joey and a maxwell street polish dog, all were amazing!!!! the hot dogs were on point! the chicago dog, well, the relish the onions, the tomato, everything just made it delicious.

A group dinner with a reservation for 100 people, we didn't have to wait in line and this seemed to disturb some folks - those who were waiting to be seated.perfect every time.also, their crispy brussel sprouts are the things of dreams.i do like that you can write on the walls and furniture, although they should probably warn people to check their seats for wet paint before sitting down.it wasn't even that deep.it's almost as if though it wasn't straight out of the oven...but if this so happens to be the full gino's east experience then that's just sad.management should make a rule not to write on the photos because there were some i couldn't even make out.

-great food (order the lobster pizza!!!!)-tremendous service-valet-burger bar right next door, same owner-good atmosphere and locationif you want really good brick over pizza that's reasonably priced in a cool atmosphere, come here!  before or after ...when you think about the food the offer it sounds pretty simple - bruschetta, salads, pasta and pizza.we stopped by sono wood fired for dinner before a show at the io theater nearby.the margherita was as i expected - perfect!  i love that burnt crust!  the pancetta was chock full of spicy arugula and oven dried tomatoes!i left full of happiness and boxed up what i didn't engulf.

The only reason i am not giving them 5 stars is i wish there was more food.we were served 12 courses, which included two desserts.the chef warned us that some people love the dish and some people don't.but it goes beyond wardrobe choices -- with the chefs cooking in plain view of the diners..the chefs are still hot.quite a wonderful dinner, we'd compare el ideas favorably with everest, where we ate just two nights previous.i was hesitant when i was invited to eat here as it is pricier than what i like to spend on a meal, however, i was shown a great time and ate great food that made the price worth it..i love that tickets were bought in advance so you didn't have to mess around with a bill at the end.

Even though we were just drinking, the service was friendly and attentive.agnolotti: i chose this for my main meal and while the flavors were nicely put together, the portion was teeny tiny.this caused some serious glares and attitude from the folks at the front who greeted me for my reservation and i think caused them to hide us in the back.this was such a treat! i worked all day, snagged a flight to chicago at 6pm.the bar set up is attractive- very open and airy.we both tried them and loved them.the food was excellent..dark upholstery and low lighting plus the servers all wearing white jackets give a very nice ambiance to this setting.the service at the bar was great.

Full bar with great drinks.though the atmosphere is too modern for my taste, the food keeps me coming back.my coworkers all ordered a variety of delicious looking dishes as well.gave me a hot towel to wipe away burger grease..shrimp was cooked perfectly and the noodles are incredibly tasty.there is a bar at the front and seating in the back..the menu was a easy to read, with tons of good looking options.they didn't split the check for us though even though they said they would but it wasn't too hard to figure out.

Pretty much steak frites lol.loved the many different textures and elements of this dish..really, 4.- yes the bathroom door is rather interesting :)the meh:- the whitefish was nothing to rave about..at a normal small plates place, each of these dishes would have been a small plate on its own for $18-19 (look at avec's menu), but here, they charge you nearly full sized prices with 1/3 size portions..yum..

I have had the mac and cheese, beans and rice, yams, and coleslaw.comcoupon.the food is cooked fresh to order, so you might have to wait a little bit, still you won't be disappointed because the food is well worth the wait.

Today i had the cheese curds.i didn't spend much time inside as he had his party on the outside area.the place was packed with bulls fans ready to head over to the stadium.great beer selection..our bartender was mike and the server chris did a good job of making sure we were well taken care of aware of all the offerings of the tavern.i opted for a burger, which was pretty darn good.overall, nothing to complain (or brag) about.once the weather gets nicer and they open the beer garden, look out chicago!.we had a reservation but there was no one at the hostess stand to tell that to so we just took a seat on the patio.

Love this cozy, metro spot.ran in here late night after catching a show at the palace theatre.what a nice hidden gem off of rush! and what great prices and food too.they were very efficient in making their sushi.very nice server! they were extremely accommodating in the very small upstairs part of the restaurant when we had 6 people instead of 5 like our reservation was marked as.the tables are close together but the dim lighting made it not so bad.loved the eel nigiri and the sweet potato tempura!.the service was kind and prompt, prices were reasonable, and i loved the friends roll and japanese green tea that i ordered.let's start with the good.it also had a weird sweet flavor, almost to the same tune of candy.

The beans tasted like they came out of a can, the greens were meh and the fried okra was the biggest let down.the chicken was tender and juice and the mac & cheese was divine.i wish they did b/c i would bring my parents here.at this point i wished i had ordered hot chicken.we ordered the 3 piece dark and 4 strips dinners.but.my friends and i are sold on gus's! fried chicken (and sides) for the gods! i gotta try their chocolate chess!.i went shortly after the restaurant opened for business, so it was not quite stuffed to capacity.the pie slices aren't ginormous, but my body would be upset with the calorie count had i downed two slices.figuratively.

That's fine though, it ensures your food is hot.here are my ratings!expectations: kind of small place.of course, the most popular item--and the one i tried--is the prime rib sandwich..my hubby first stopped in solo as i lay at nearby northwestern recovering from surgery.i'd come back on my next trip north.would i be back? probably in a year or so when i can't figure out what else to eat.we shared and loved everything.i'd recommend the braised pork belly - its crispy outer edges surrounding melt-in-your-mouth fatty layers and moist meat covered in a sauce that's full of umami goodness!!! i'm drooling just thinking about it even though i just had it like 5 min ago! i had the lawry's wedge and it was good too.got to stop by this place for lunch today.
We started with hummus and the eggplant salad..great lunch spot.service wasn't the fastest and it isn't fancy, but it was damn good food.

The food was good and fresh, but very pricey and huge portions for a lunch.i wanted to throw it out.we were seated promptly and got the bread and avocado dip which i really loved.both were delicious and the picked onions accompanied with the dish made it a wonderful bite.the prices per plate were in the $20 to $30 dollar range, but if you didn't get steak, didn't get an appetizer, and brought your own booze, i bet you could do a meal for two under $50.i changed our reservation time and the host was more than willing to assist..i visited peru with my family a couple years ago, and i've been on a quest to find food just as good.one thing i did notice is that they use the same menu as ay ay picante since apparently they are owned by the same person but i thought that was weird.i know it's somewhat pricy, but purchasing a groupon will certainly help with the cost.

This was by far the best food i had in chicago, and the numerous reviews of this place only proves that this is definitely a place to try when in you're in this city.day 6.i loved everything.i happen to snag a last minute reservation to girl & the goat for early friday dinner.i did like that they gave me a bite to give my pup!.i'd eat this for a meal any day.- wood oven roasted pig faceone of their staple items! i don't even know what part of the pork it was, but it was gloriously amazing.1.somehow, we were stuffed to the face with just those plates.here's my hit list:cauliflowerbeetspig face (trust me)goat shankduck tongue.

(5 stars)drinksthe drinks were strong and delicious.for sides we ordered the whipped potatoes($14) and lobster mac&cheese($12+)..atmosphere is energetic but as expected for the area.next time i'll try something different...i think i want to give this place another try, and revisit my rating.the cauliflower is actually purple and in its original state.upon arrival i asked to use the washroom and the hostess directed me upstairs so the 2 times i needed to use the bathroom i kept going upstairs assuming that's the only bathroom i have when it turns out they had one downstairs.

The interior of the restaurant is very stylish and fresh.the only issue with this place is i always call it "silver fox" by accident and my friends make fun of me like "oh is that who you're going to pick up tonight?!" but that's my fault =p.he had a crispy chicken sandwich with a jalapeño vinaigrette and avocado..i'm in love.worth coming back for sure.since i'm a big review person, my friends and i were like hmmm, should we risk it? and i'm so glad we did.loved the calamari fries, biscuits, corn grits & brussels sprouts!!!other items we got were good but nothing memorable.i think he went by every table.she had such a great disposition and her service was efficient while also expedient.

56 and i get 2 shrimps?   i  called ahead because i was pressed for time.through the social media person on instagram, i found out that this restaurant is around the corner from where i work.friends had the jerk chicken taco and the chicken mole tamale.i got the nachos for lunch with jerk chicken, and it was awesome.i ordered delivery for our team in the loop.i'd stick with the tacos.i like this place! the prices are reasonable and the chicken nacho's were tasty.this was the worst mexican food i have ever tasted and being a vegetarian it isn't really hard to mess up veggie nachos.both were super.

The employees are super cordial and personal.the lamb skewers are really tasty.it was great then, but the service was slow and i thought it was pricey for a mall foodcourt.i asked the front person for her best recommendations, of which she said the lamb + coriander and pork + shrimp.unlike other chinese restaurants, this one was virtually spotless, so i could relax a little bit more while enjoying our meal.i will start out by saying the only downside to this place is the wait times but they are totally worth it.the lamb ones - those were a different story.that means the make plus steam for an order can and ought to run you 20 minutes.the decor is pleasant and not overly cheesy, and more importantly, everything was immaculately clean and tidied.only came in for a little snack, but would like to come back sometime to try out all their other dumpling offerings.

The food.i'm done going here.cannot wait to go back here! i wanted something healthy yet tasty and this place really hit the spot! i was so happy with the jerk chicken salad that i got, it was delicious and spicy and just what i needed to hit the spot..we had a side of chips and guacamole, the guacamole was wonderful.they play a nice light jazz in the back ground.deliciousness.see how specific you can get? it's great! orders come wrapped in foil which makes for easy transport for leftovers.really bad on timing when food is being prepared i literally waited 20 minutes for my order while i seen a long line of people get there food before mines.definitely a great place to stop in for lunch or dinner.

Cornbeef and hash were delicious! potatoes had a really nice zest to them.it's small- so you can't get very comfortable in your seat.my favorite plate, the truffle hash, is a veggie hash with kale, brussel sprouts, some other veggies and this amazing sauce.i ordered the italian beef sandwich with a side of hash.prices were cheap when it comes to chicago brunch.they also had a variety of mexican sodas which were all exciting.it wasn't the best or worst i'm not rushing to come back here.you order up in the front then they give you a number so then they'll bring the food to you.they start with potatoes and eggs and from there it gets interesting with combinations like corned beef, brown carrots and kraut or spicy chick peas, yogurt, and crispy kale..

Flat top is a great choice if you're the loop and looking for a place to eat.^___^ i hope this location remains here for a long time since it's refreshing to find a restaurant like this, which is uncommon especially in the "loop" of chicago.after i was done, i walked out onto monroe street and felt really hungry.i got lucky on this visit as there was street parking available right across the street.interesting concept for a restaurant.but, meh - if you're indecisive, it's not the worst place to be.now you can only get up to three different ones, and if you want to "double up" on one of them, they'll charge you $4.i almost went with the all you can eat option and was told by dwight to slow my roll and that my eyes were bigger than my stomach.i was wise enough to back up two steps before they splattered the sauce across my white blouse.everything, given the style of dining, is kept very clean as well, which is nice when you think about it.

My girlfriend and i ordered steak tacos, pastor tacos, chips, guac, water & horchata.signed,satisfied customer.the lacquered tables were def a nice touch.lines/wait can get long because this place is so popular.chips and guac is also required upon any visit.they use chunky cuts of meat deliciously marianated.but let me tell you, the wait is worth it.since i'm working for l patron i walked 5 minutes to jimenez to get out cash and pay $3.new location, same great tacos.just as good as the old location only better with outdoor space.

I tried the tikka chicken on rice, the korma chicken on salad, and the lamb naanwich on korma..this place may be busy beyond measure, but that's simply a strong acknowledgement of their well-earned success.you know when you just met someone for the first time, but there is an immediate bond?  that happened here!  the people are doing a great job honoring and promoting the brand and mission of the establishment.i expected an indian version of chipotle, but the thing about chipotle is that it is very flavorful.cute decor, great music and unreal food.it will take you right to naansense.food: i had a chicken rice bowl with cashew ginger sauce and all the toppings.the interior was filled with mashed boiled potato.since this is a fast food place, it gets bonus points for offering really tasty meals.

I am a fan.not a coffee fan so my review is strictly reviewing the aesthetic and the desserts..i look at my phone and three hours have passed by.they are filling and delicious (french bread, black beans, pico de gallo, cheese)...the staff was so nice to me.ordering was very hard.
This is for my uber eats delivery of the boneless wings combo.i wasn't hungry, but i could use some appetizer or dessert..
The food is delish!! and they have a big chai selection too!..decided to give this new nepalese cafe a try.the chai and lassi were both fantastic and they have a variety of enticing flavors of each.

To start, the guacamole was huge and very fresh with hot chips and good salsas.but its just like xoco in wicker park, same price and very similar menu items.heads-up - this is a cash-only place, but they do have an atm available.50, the tacos were only 2.the service was attentive and nice.it didn't match the quality of food.for dessert, i had the perfect pair of a piece banana cream pie and cup of steaming hot cafe de olla, made from chef's grandmothers recipe.recommended the vegetarian for my sister and she was very pleased.our friends said the chef should definitely put that sandwich on the menu! tacos were just over $2 each, and tortas around $9.the carnitas were salty in the best way, and the homemade tortillas are a thing apart (plus they give you the perfect amount to go with all the meat, so you aren't left wanting).

One of the best places for thin crust in the city, their crust is thick, very similar to beggar's, you get a healthy amount of toppings as well, and the peppers are sliced and not diced, in addition it's very reasonably priced for the amount you get, definitely the best pizza place in bridgeport..although the latter may be sweeter...now i just get to rate their poor customer service.when i'm drunk, phil's is my new go-to..the sauce was thick but not well-spread.

Just rename the place robert's beet salad! absolutely the freshest app you'll ever enjoy before diving into robert's amazing pizza!but, then again, there is the pizza - and the peking duck pizza was about the most outstanding thing we've had at robert's!how good was it? the wife spent ten minutes trying to design the perfect "last bite" of the evening.delicious, chewy and cheesy pizza with a great tasting crust.i'd certainly order again and perhaps dine in next time since they do have a bar and ample seating upstairs.as soon as she had finished describing the special seafood pizza, my decision was made.it not the type of dough that will full you up after a couple slices, great texture and chewy.we ordered the 3 cheese pizza and also ordered the prosciutto n arugula pizza.so gewddd.solid 4 starts..we also ordered a chicken breast and spinach pizza ($19).

Seemed odd- she didn't even bring 3 small pours for her instead.it was very oily but different than anything i have ever had.it's stylish, comfortable, and the ipas are really delicious.+/-cauliflower cheese curds- interesting concoction.prices are a tad higher than similar spots in the city, but location is key.i will be back to try the elusive cauliflower & curds and their pie and pint special for $14 5-10 on monday nights!.i would have too, if he didn't take it back from me after i tried a bite.just a good solid stop for after-movie dinner and drinks.corridor brewery falls between 3 and 4 stars for me.it was fine.
I shared a chicken and a lamb shawarma sandwich with my cousin, and an order of fries.probably not a sign that i'd become a regular customer.either way, i would for sure come back..

Found the place next to our hotel.ordered in to hotel lincoln just a block away..some mio was by far the best, creole shrimp came in second.a nice place for dinner with friends or family..the service is pretty much meh.all of it is fantastic!it's a little dim inside, but it's a neat layout and the service is great.pizza is still incredible.excellent beer selection too.

Fries are crispy hand cut, and the cheddar cheese is good.aight.nonetheless great burger! happy muching!.i've now been to fatso's more than a dozen times since i first reviewed it three years ago, and as good as the food has been, the addition of milkshakes and the always-fair prices put this solidly in five-star review territory.really wish we saved room for fries!!..watched a documentary on capital punishments..and the fries i love how crispy it was.

Fresh gourmet burgers, fresh cut friends and healthy options make this the perfect place to eat with friends as everyone leaves happy.served without sides, it's a little more expensive than your average meal, but compared to some of the other fancy spots it actually comes in at a lower price point..prices are great for the portion size and quality of food..

Noodles were cooked perfectly.and waited.people lined up to be seated, lined up to sign in.first and foremost i think the address is misleading because 112 n green is really sawada coffee.the wait for your food isn't long, but i had unfortunately ordered spicy soup and was now starving after a long wait..the half spice had the right amount of heat to it; it was not overpowering at all.vegetarian, earthy, savory.but, it comes down to a few tests for me, did i close my eyes when i ate from enjoyment  (no), would i want to come back here again (unfortunately, no), and would i recommend this to other people (no)..

Had a great dinner here tonight.it's quickly become one of my go-to neighborhood restaurants!.well i finally returned after a year plus hiatus.when i saw it on the beer list, i got excited.was a little tough, was expecting something more 'soft' if that makes senseentree: i got the lamb sandwich.yet my burger was fantastic and my gf's mac n cheese truly decadent.the categories are great.just loved the bar! it's got a slightly more upscale feel than some of the bars in the area.i've lived within walking distance for a year and i'm really mad i've never come here before.the beef yakitori was amazing - perfect amount of salty and sweet in the sesame sauce on it.

The sauces are distinctive but i was distracted by several things.the biscuit is crumbly, buttery and you'll only get a few bites in before it's a mish mosh of bread mixed with the ingredients on your plate, forcing you to knife & fork it..my mom had a sausage and egg biscuit and said the homemade sausage was delicious.i must admit, i didn't have high hopes walking into buck's.i don't usually go to wicker park for fried chicken, but i followed some friends here.g.chicken was perfect-juicy, tender, cooked just right.last week, the third time was the charm.we got a bucket for the table and the chicken was cooked perfectly.

This restaurant is a little better than the average run of the mill restaurant hotels that you're use to.i will continue to go to all of the restaurants that they own, especially the local!.i liked the way it was cooked and prepared and i asked for my fries extra crispy and they came just that way.i went for lunch and had a sampling of everything - soup, salad, and sandwich.he was attentive without being overbearing and honestly that is my favorite kind of service.the chicken pot pie was my issue.we were getting a late night snack of lobster mac n cheese and mint ice cream pie and both were fantastic.he was so helpful.the restaurant is in a hotel, so that might be why it's overpriced.the menu doesn't allow you to have pancakes and eggs without paying for their $25 buffet.

This is the perfect place! located right on wells and lake area..it finally happened today.a viable mexican option downtown.mostly because it was too cold to walk back.but again, it didn't taste the best...is a bit pricey - but that's to be expected in the loop..

99/lb and pork/chicken is slightly cheaper.this place also has brown rice, $1 up-charge, cooked to perfection, not too chewy and not too soft.the dumplings were our favorite! located outside the store (you'll see it to the left of the entrance): $2 for giant freshly made pork, kimchi, or black rice w/red bean dumplings.that is typically a great sign for good authentic food.but joong boo is great because at times, it does feel like i'm shopping in a marketplace in asia.i don't know if there exists any other grocery mart located as close to an interstate exit as this one off of the kimball exit on westbound i-90/94 (a few feet off of the exit and entrance and most convenient!).that being said, the selection is very good and you'll definitely find what you need.possibly the best value for korean food in the city.2 words: sashimi platter.it is a great little diamond in the rough oriental grocery store/general merchandise market.

This is not going to be a typical kavita review.note: there will most likely be a wait.the "plague bringer" was like a punch in the face, but felt really good.i also loved the sprecher cherry cola.my better half ordered the slayer, which is essentially an 'un-burger'.i would seriously have issues deciding between a burger and the m&c if i could only order one thing at kuma's..it's amazing.ohh one thing: servers are real catchy, they will serve you exactly what is written on the menu.which is a damn shame because if they're so creative with toppings, they could make a bomb chipotle black bean burger from scratch that people might actually be able to eat.

The cashier and host were always checking in with us - great hospitality.i had smothered chicken and while i admit it is not the healthiest choice one could make, it was one of the tastiest choices.fries, biscuit, hush puppies, and mac & cheese are all fine.the owner is a gregarious guy and fosters a friendly operation as well.at the time of my visit, this place has only been around for 5 weeks.) cool people (the owners)! support your local "fried chicken for breakfast!" down home, country establishment!!.so we took our time and the owner even tried to help with suggestions-super nice and outgoing guy..chicken came out fairly quickly, if there's inventory, otherwise you'd wait about 10mins.it did smell like "deep fry", and numerous yelpers have attested to their frying prowess.

Servers were more than awesome and took great care of us.the chicharonnes showed up in about 2 minutes before we even had our drinks.note: everything was $5 on the hh menu.the waitress was very attentive and helpful, but the cocktails were very mediocre.i was screaming my order at the bar tender to the point where we were joking about how we were basically yelling at each other.i think that had more to do with the flavor combination for me..i am happy to say i have found my new regular happy hour spot.during happy hour, the bar and kitchen can really get backed up, even on a "slow" weekday.the rooftop here is beautiful.

The garlic smashed potatoes were also very complimentary as the side.the food was mediocre at best and they charge your normal vegan prices.a chill place to share beers and reasonably-priced cocktails in a divey bar setting or outside on the sidewalk patio -- the kind of place that chicago has a million of.this place is my favorite place to eat at..what a find! these guys do seitan and tofu right!  we got the asian bbq tofu wings.dear god, it's bourbon, basil, ginger ale, and balsamic vinegar.after much deliberation i decided on the smothered sweet potato tacos.utterly obnoxious and the staff did nothing to calm them down.not to mention the prices are very reasonable.

We went with beer instead: he had the moody tongue chocolate churro porter ($8), which, to me, had more of a bitter "bite.loved the upholstered dinner chairs with arms to them! we were started off with a mason jar of their in-house baked rosemary cracker breadsticks, which definitely had herby flavor but were maybe a tad too dense for my taste, making them a little dry vs.i really wanted more! (but the servings weren't overly small).don't touch the dough that much!  for my second dish i had the duck ragu parpedelle and it was solid.kenny and i both thought we'd like the cacio whey pepe the most because it had such great reviews on yelp and elsewhere.we ended up going an hour early and had a couple seats!.when we arrived, i was impressed by the light, airy decor.we saw many people walking around and checking up on tables, so we thought that service was going to be great.i wish there were more to an order because they were that great! not what we expected though.they knocked it out of the park! the food was top notch and the ambiance and service was stellar.

Almost gave it 5 stars, but wish they have free chips and salsa like other mexican places! i would recommend this place to anyone! large menu too!.the more i thought about it, however, the more i realized they do have some of the best steak tacos i have ever had.if a little nondescript taqueria is slammed on a tuesday night, you know they're doing something right!see you soon, buddy.the first time was based on yelp reviews of their breakfast burritos.still, a great place and we could tell it's probably popular during the late night hours.every time i've ever been the salsa completely takes over.there was nothing like ending a heavy drinking night with some allendes! the salsa was killer back in the day..tacos seemed to be a popular item too.i only ate half and saved the other for lunch!  the burrito was filled with a good amount of ingredients and the carne asada was flavorful and not overcooked.

And of course, american chinese food is not complete without fortune cookies so we also had them.starting  off with the water taxi,  we boarded at michigan avenue..beef was extremely lean, which is always great.i ordered the lunch shanghai rice noodles combo, which came with a hot & sour soup and 2x crab rangoons.the only compliant was that the pinã colada was very watery but that's so minor because again the food was wonderful.the noodle dishes were crispy.the portion sizes for our two entrees were huge.the staff was very attentive making sure they were around when we were ready to order.they had a few traditional offerings, but it was not what i expected it to be.

I went with an epic classic burger with bacon---no onions, no tomatoes.i think it could be a bit more reasonable..fries are also fresh but could be crispier with a bit more flavor..great burger, great fries, great value.*sighs*crazy over priced take out..the fries weren't so good but the burger was.the staff was very friendly, as well.

Parking was a bit of a hassle, but we were still able to find it on milwaukee ave with metered parking ($2/hr, 3 hr max, until 10pm).the taco salad is super flavorful, and the potato & poblano tacos are so good to vegetarians and non-vegetarians alike! the homemade tortillas are the perfect texture.if you're looking for good tacos in wicker park, give this place a try..this from a man who spends hours squeezing fresh fruit and making his own simple syrup.the creamed elotes are insane.i had the pork carnitas with avocado, bacon and cheese and was fabulous, with all ingredients perfectly cooked.i love patronizing this business because the food and service is upper echelon.i'll have to write about drinks ate a later date because i am doing the sober thing this month :(i loved staff interactions.the fish taco's was very tasty and not too doughy with just the right touch of red cabbage lettuce.

I might try to come back tonight to try some biscuits since i missed them earlier (they ran out, sadly)!!.the sides and biscuit are solid.)  quite a bit of seating in the summer, too.my bf and i sure do love fried chicken so we had to make the trek up to this neighborhood to see what all the fuss is about.sides are topnotch at a great price!.you'd be a fool to not eat some of that bread!!!  what to drink?  well, they have a selection of soda pop you're not going to find anywhere around here.about 20 seats inside along two separate shelves for dining in, and a patio on warmer days that adds another 15-20 spots..guess i am on a "best chicken sandwich in chicago" quest these days.i'm pretty sensitive to spice, but the classic chicken was tolerably spicy.

Definitely not a nice scramble that i am accustomed to in chilaquiles.it made me really regret ordering the chilaquiles, but you live and you learn.an hour later and it definitely didn't disappoint.it was okay, but i've had better chilaquiles, and it seems that this dish is prepared completely different everywhere i've gone.my chilaquiles were spicier than anticipated (especially because when i asked if the ranchero sauce was spciy, you would think that when she said no, she would have said but the dish is).both dishes were very well made with a homemade feel to them.if i lived in this neighborhood i would stop by on a regular basis.i wish i had found out about this place ages ago! loved the food, service, and their outdoor patio seating is super cute and perfect for a sunny sunday brunch in chicago..i imagine it gets more crowded on the weekends, but this food would be worth waiting for.

The steak was good but nothing really special.i decided to go with something a little different for dessert - the blueberry goat cheese bread pudding.overall, a good spot for a drink or snack in the bar, but don't waste your experience or time/money on dinner.the best one in my opinion was the carrot cake, idk who this julia is but she sure does know how to make her cake! lol.- the carrot cake was okay..we took the elevator to the main dining room and had a table on the mezzanine level at the railing.went for restaurant week with a group of six.it really depended on what you got as to how you would rate boarding house.walking in, you can't help but be impressed by the ceiling art and fixtures.

The owner said they aren't open.my boyfriend had the diez y ocho burger with regular fries, my mom had the turkey burger, my sister had the classic burger and my brother also had the fifty shades, except he had cheese fries (omg, yum).their hand cut fries are also cooked to perfection and taste extremely good..we went around new years and only a few people were there, so it was nice to be able to chill without feeling hustled out.i liked the burgers, they had some interesting options.i wasn't going to say anything since they were good either way, but the server brought out my fries and apologized..there were 2 servers working and 2 cooks.the owner is also great.

I love bangers and lace.delicious! both the food and the beer.every time i've been here has been a good time.-4 stars for the service and cocktails, mainly service.then we kept sitting, totally ignored, even as we repeatedly reached out at the waitress marching past us.they had a selection of various bells beers that were delicious.i don't really enjoy wicker park all that much anymore while in chicago.i don't have much to say about bangers & lace.it felt like our cheese curds could have lasted days! definitely a group sharing plate, those curds.the place gets cramped at night, so the best time to come is happy hour.

Don't choose.i ordered the snow crab legs and the headless shrimp with the maniac.good place for cajun seafood - i came here with a group of 9 people and they had no problem seating us pretty quickly (all members of your party have to be present to be seated).i do recommend bob chinns in wheeling.the shrimp were not deveined so fucking disguising how can a seafood restaurant not remove shrimp shit cause thats what it is if u dont know the black vein on a shrimp is shit..calamari- this was a miss, only because the batter was so light it was falling off.she's been about three times prior but i was an angry virgin.they were all delicious.the perfect combination.

Nothing special.our favorite dining experience at two was for the groupon dinner.and even though the dining room was full, it was quite enough for a peaceful conversation.duck fat croquettesprawnsscallopssourdough breadasparagusshort ribselktri tiphalibutsaffron spaghettipana cottabingetsservice was spot on and consistent..- gulf prawns- the flavor on these was bold and so delicious, everyone at our table was slurping the prawn heads to get the rest of the flavor out.food was fresh, and such a fun blend of tastes and textures.bacon jam was delicious, had a unique taste to it.this is a bit of a late review so the menu quite possibly may have changed since my visit.it was difficult to eat such a large chunk of salty meat.
Judging by the reviews the food is very good.it was absolutely delicious.

They also have the au cheval burger here as well as a pastrami sandwich.food taste and quality is very high.95 a pound, getting heavy and cheap items like cucumber or tomatoes in your salad might not be the most cost-efficient choice, but omg the smoked salmon.yes they have a beautiful salad bar.the idea is hella dope, however you can't do these fancy pants buffets and expect people to rave about the amazing quality of food.our favorites are the fresh a salad bar, fried chicken, pancakes, and thick cut syrup bacon.glad they opened up a place like this in the neighborhood.staff are quick and friendly and they said the opening week has gone great, with chill mornings but already crowded lunches some days.their salad looked decent as did their soup bar.will definitely make a return.

Yum!  seriously some of the best pizza i've had in a while.the pie was spot on as they make in brooklyn.the second the pie came out though, i knew it was in for a bit of trouble.as good as the one in green point.the bathrooms were unisex and nice.i really wanted to love this place, but couldn't get around a few things.(he is a character - he only would pose for a pic with the ladies i was with and he told us of how he spent a few hours the previous day at the track betting on a horse that had pizza as part of its name.service is fantastic..however, what paulie gee's is trying to do doesn't work for me.

As others have noted, this is a trendy, "hipster" type of place, with relatively loud music.now the bathroom tickled me! (get your mind out of the gutters folks).i asked for a medium rare burger and they brought me one in about 10 minutes.the remainder of the food is really great, the menu is always changing seasonally but everything we tried was really great, especially their steak.food was good albeit very overpriced.i think i set my expectations too high.we tried this beer with curry, coco, and coffee notes.they were able to seat us despite missing our reservation.i thought the food, atmosphere, and service were all tremendous, but didn't quite feel that x factor as with other michelins.i never heard back so i figured i didn't have a set rez, but we went anyways.
